projectDesc.p: The Maurer School of Law, Indiana University, Bloomington received an LSTA Grant to scan, markup, and make available the Brevier Legislative Reports. The Reports are a transcription of the proceedings of the Indiana General Assembly from the Special Session of 1858 to the Regular Session of 1887.

div.head: LIST OF ACTS & JOINT RESOLUTIONS PASSED.
SENATE BILLS
div.p: Introduced by Mr. Cobb:

S. 4. An Act to provide for the making and authentication of transcripts from the records of the recorder's office in certain cases, and for the admissibility in evidence of the same, and certified copies of the deeds and mortgages contained therein.
Introduced by Mr. Brown, of Wells:

S. 16. An Act to amend section three hundred, and forty-nine of an act entitled "an act to revise, simplify and abridge the rules, practice, pleadings and forms in civil cases in the courts of this State; to abolish distinct forms of action at law, and to provide for the administration of justice in a uniform mode of pleading and practice, without distinction between law and equity," approved June 18th, 1852. [So as to except actions for divorce.]
Introduced by Mr. Vawter:

S. 21, An Act to amend sections nine, ten, eighteen, nineteen, twenty-three, twenty-four and thirty-three of an act entitled "an act to incorporate the town of Vernon, Jennings county, Indiana," approved January 22, 1851.
Introduced by Mr. Bonham:
S. 25. An Act defining certain misdemeanors, and prescribing punishment therefor.

SECTION 1. An assault is an unlawful attempt, coupled with a present ability, to commit a violent injury on the person of another, and every person who shall perpetrate an assault shall, on conviction, be fined in any sum not exceeding fifty dollars.

SEC. 2. Every person who shall, by words, signs or gestures, provoke another to commit an assault, assault and battery, or other breach of the peace, shall, on conviction, be fined in any sum not exceeding twenty dollars.
SEC. 3. That section one of the act entitled "an act prescribing certain misdemeanors punishable only by justices of the peace," approved June 7, 1852, be and the same is hereby repealed.
Introduced by Mr. Niles:

S. 82. An Act to authorize cities to prepare, execute, negotiate and sell bonds, to provide means to complete unfinished school buildings, and to pay debts contracted for the erection of school buildings, and to authorise the levy and collection of an additional special tax to provide means for the payment of the interest and principal of such bonds, and declaring an emergency.
Introduced by Mr. Hord:

S. 84. An Act to amend section two of an act entitled "an act prescribing the powers and duties of justices of the peace in State prosecutions," approved May 29,1852, so as to authorise the service of a warrant throughout the State.
Introduced by Mr. Hord:
S. 93. An Act defining the crime of embezzlement, and prescribing the punishment therefor.
Introduced by Mr. Bennett:

S. 103. An Act repealing all general laws now in force for the incorporation of cities, providing for the incorporation of cities, prescribing their powers, rights and duties, and the manner in which they shall exercise the same, and regulating other matters properly connected therewith, and repealing certain acts therein specified.
Introduced by Mr. Cobb:
S. 114. An Act to amend section thirty-eight of an act entitled an act to provide for the incorporation of railroad companies," approved May 11, 1852.

[So that Stockholders shall be individually liable to laborers, their executors, administrators, and assigns for all labor done in the construction of said road, that shall remain unpaid, after the assets of the corporation shall have been exhausted.]
Introduced by Mr. Brown, of Wells:
S. 115. An Act to amend section eleven of an act entitled "an act concerning county prisons," approved May 27th 1852.
[By appropriately inserting this : "or any person convicted of a criminal offense and temporarily ordered to be imprisoned in the county prison."]
Introduced by Mr. Downey:

S. 156. An Act to amend the fourteenth section of an act entitled "an act to limit the number of Grand Jurors, and to point out the manner of their selection, defining their jurisdiction, and repealing all laws inconsistent therewith," approved March 4, 1852, and to change the form of the oath of Grand Jurors.
Introduced by Mr. Niles:
S. 175. An Act to authorize the formation of companies for the protection and apprehension of horse thieves and other felons, and for mutual protection and repealing all laws inconsistent therewith.
Introduced by Mr. Allison:

S. 187. An Act to amend sections three and fifty-three of an act entitled "an act to reduce the law incorporating the city of Madison, and the several acts amendatory thereto, into one act, and to amend the same," approved Feb. 14th, 1848, and declaring an emergency.
Introduced by Mr. Hord:
S. 196. An Act concerning the writ of Habeas Corpus.
Introduced by Mr. Bennett:

S. 198. An Act repealing an act entitled ("an act for the relief of the families of soldiers, seamen and marines, and sick and wounded Indiana soldiers in hospitals in the State and United States service, and of those who have died or been disabled in such service, and prescribing the duties of certain officers therein named," approved March 4, 1865, and providing for the collection and disposition of the taxes levied in pursuance thereof for the year 1865, and providing when the same shall take effect.
Introduced by Mr. Thompson:
S. 199. An Act to amend an act to incorporate the Indianapolis Insurance Company, approved Feb. 8, 1886.
Introduced by Mr. Bradley:
S 201. An Act to provide for the care and treatment of the incurable insane of the State of Indiana, and matters properly connected therewith.
[Appropriating $35,000 for the erection of a suitable building in connection with the present Hospital for the Insane.]
Introduced by Mr. Hord:
S. 202. An Act making a specific appropriation from the State Treasury.
["Ths sum of $50,000 is hereby appropriated to defray the Legislative expenses of the General Assembly."]
Introduced by Mr. Brown, of Hamilton:
S. 205. An Act to fix the time of holding the Circuit Court in the several counties composing the Seventh Judicial Circuit, and repealing all laws in conflict therewith.
Introduced by Mr. Oyler:

S. 206. An Act supplemental to an act entitled "an act to authorize, regulate and confirm the sale of railroads, to enable purchasers of the same to form corporations, and to exercise corporate powers, and to define their rights, powers and privileges, to enable such corporations to purchase and construct connecting and branch roads, and to operate and maintain the same," approved March 3, 1865, and for the purpose of making the same more definite and certain.
Introduced by Mr Hord:

S. 215. An Act to amend section seventy-seven of an act entitled "an act to revise simplify and abridge the rules, practice and proceedings and forms in criminal actions in the courts of this State, approved June 17, 1852."
["When the objection is to the judge of the Circuit Court, any other circuit judge, or judge of the common pleas, may hold the court and try the cause."]
Introduced by Mr. Hanna:

S. 216. An Act to repeal sections forty-three and forty-four of an act entitled "An act prescribing who may make a will, the effect thereof, what may be devised, regulating the revocation, admission to probate, and contest thereof," approved May 31st, 1852.
Introduced by Mr. Ward:
S. 219. An Act defining who shall be competent witnesses in any Court or judicial proceeding in this State, and to repeal all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this act.

["All persons of competent age, without distinction as to color or blood and not otherwise by law rendered incompetent, shall be competent witnesses to testify in any proceeding or suit, civil or criminal, in any court in this State: Provided, That no negro or mulatto who has come, or who shall hereafter come into this State in violation of the Thirteenth Article of the Constitution of the State, shall, while said Article continues in force, be competent to testify as a witness in any case in which a white person shall be a party in interest."]
Introduced by Mr. Bermett:
S. 223. An Act authorizing married women under the age of twenty-one years to join with their husbands in the conveyance of real estate in certain cases.
Introduced by Mr. McClurg:
S. 227. An Act for the relief of Isaac D. Armstrong, treasurer of Clinton county, in the State of Indiana.
[Became a law without Executive approval, under the provision of the Constitution in such cases made and provided.]
Introduced by Mr. Williams:

S. 233. An Act to enable any child heretofore adopted or which may hereafter be adopted by any person under the laws of any State of the United States to take and hold real estate in this State as if the child had been adopted under the laws and within the State of Indiana.
Introduced by Mr. Cason:

S. 241. An Act to amend an amendment of an act entitled "an act in relation to witnesses, and to repeal section 238, of article 13, of the act entitled 'an act to revise, simplify and abridge the rules, practice, pleadings and forms in cases in the courts of this State ; to abolish distinct forms of actions at law ; and to provide for the administration of justice in a uniform mode of pleading and practice, without distinction between law and equity,' approved June 18, 1852, and to repeal all laws inconsistent therewith, and providing when the act shall take effect and be in force, which took effect and went into force March 17,1861."
[So as to apply in suits brought by heirs.]
Introduced by Mr. Dykes:
S. 249. An act defining the powers of companies organized to construct canals for hydraulic purposes.
Introduced by Mr. Allison:

S.256. An Act to amend the fortieth clause of section thirty of an act entitled, "an act granting to the citizens of the town of Evansville, in thecounty of Vanderburg, a city charter," approved January 27, 1847, and declaratory of the meaning of the second section of the same act.
Introduced by Mr Allison:

S. 269. An Act entitled an act requiring County Auditors to make examination of the records in their offices in relation to school fuuds, and make report, and providing compensation therefor, and declaring an emergency.
Introduced by Mr. Oyler:

S. 281. An Act to amend an act entitled "an act to fix the amount of the salary of the State Librarian, and repealing all former laws conflicting therewith, and to dispense with an Assistant Librarian and Clerk," approved March 4,1859, and also increasing the powers and duties of the State Librarian.
[Raising his salary from 800 to $1200.]
Introduced by Mr. Niles:
S. 284. An Act to prevent unauthorized printing at the expense of the State.
Introduced by Mr. Cason:
S. 289. An Act to provide for the acknowledgment of the execution of official bonds and to declare the effect and obligation of such bonds as between the obligors and the State.
Introduced by Mr. Cullen:

S. 293. An Act to provide for the periodical enumeration of the white male inhabitants of this State over the age of twenty-one years; to prescribe the duties and fix the compensation of officers in relation thereto, and, also, to prescribe the penalties for the violation of official duty in connection with said enumerations, as well as the manner in and the courts by which said penalties shall be enforced.

["In the year 1866, and again in the year 1871, and at the end of each successive period of six years, after the last mentioned year, an enumeration of the white male inhabitants, over the age of twenty-one years, of this State, shall be made in obedience to the requirements of the Constitution, and according to the provisions hereinafter contained."]
Introduced by Mr. Downey:

S 300. An Act to amend the fifth section of an act entitled "an act providing for an organization of Circuit Courts, the election of judges thereof, and defining their powers and duties," approved June 1,1852.
[Circuit Courts shall have "concurrent jurisdiction of all misdemeanors, except where the fine can not exceed three dollars."]
Introduced, by Mr. Douglas:

S. 303. An Act to legalize and declare valid and effectual all the orders, judgments and other proceedings made, rendered and had", by and before the Court of Common Pleas of Whitley county, in this State, held in the court house of said county in the month of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty five, and then and there before the regular judge of said court.
Introduced by Mr. Finch:

S. 313. An Act to amend the first and fourth sections of an act entitled "an act to reorganize the Evansville Insurance Companies, chartered under the several acts of February 8, 1836, and: January 21, 1850."
Introduced by Mr Cobb:

S. 314. An Act to authorize the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners to invest any moneys belonging to said Fund in the Indiana State Bonds or Stocks or in United States Stocks, and when invested in Indiana State Bonds or Stocks to provide for the cancellation of such bonds or stocks and for the issuing & new non-negotiable bonds for the benefit of the School Fund.

div.head: HOUSE BILLS.
div.p: Introduced by Mr. Harrison:

H. R. 12. An act to amend the first section of an act entitled "An act for the better protection of religious meetings, agricultural fairs, and other lawful assemblages of the people," approved March 3d, 1859.
Introduced by Mr. Harrison:
H. R. 21. An act to amend the twenty-second section of an act entitled "An act defining misdemeanors, and prescribing punishment therefor," approved June 14,1852.
[So as to include indecent exposure of person.]
Introduced by Mr. Woods:
H. R. 22. An act to legalize the sale of certain school lands in Lake county.
Introduced by Mr. Higgins:

H. R. 27. An act to legalize the acknowledgments of all deeds, mortgages and other instruments required to be recorded, taken and certified by notaries public, who took and certified such acknowledgments after the expiration of their commissions.
Introduced by Mr. Woods:
H. R. 29. An act to amend section 15 of an act entitled "An act concerning inclosures, trespassing animals and partition fences," approved June 4, 1852.

[By prefixing these words: "A lawful partition fence shall in all cases be such as to enclose and restrain sheep, unless by mutual consent of the parties interested, they agree to build a fence only to restrain or enclose horses, mules or cattle."]
Introduced by Mr. Harrison:

H. R. 33. An act to amend the eighth section of an act entitled "An act to regulate and license the sale of spirituous, vinous, malt and other intoxicating liquors, to prohibit the adulteration of liquors, to repeal all former laws contravening the provisions of this act, and prescribing penalties for violation thereof," approved March 5th, 1859.

[So that it shall read: "Any person being licensed under the provisions of this act, who shall sell or barter, directly or indirectly, any intoxicating liquors on Sunday, or upon the day of any State, county, township, or municipal election in the town ship or city where the same may be holden, shall be fined not less than ten nor more than fifty dollars."]
Introduced by Mr. James:
H. R. 41. An act to legalize sales by guardians under orders defective in not prescribing notice.
Introduced by Mr. Coffroth:
H. R. 43. An act to repeal an act entitled "An act to establish Courts of Conciliation, to prescribe rules and proceedings therein, and compensation of judges thereof," approved June 11th, 1852.
Introduced by Mr. Stivers:
H. R. 52. An act to render uniform the assessments of personal property in the several townships of the different counties.
Introduced by Mr. Howard:

H. R. 53. An act to amend section fourteen of an act entitled "An act to provide for the more uniform mode of doing township business, prescribing the duties of certain officers in connection there with, and to repeal all laws in conflict with this act," approved February ISth, 1859.
[So as to allow the Township Trustee two dollars and a half for every day or part of a day necessarily employed.]
Introduced by Mr. Higgins:

H. R. 58. An act to amend the 5th and 6th sections of an act regulating interest on money, and to repeal an act entitled "An act concerning interest on money, approved May 27, 1852. the fifty first section of the act defining misdemeanors and prescribing punishment therefor, approved June 34, 1852, and all other laws and parts of laws in conflict with this act," approved March 7,1861.

[Amends section five by striking out all after the words "recover costs," and inserting these words: "but that in all cases in which money or any other thing of value shall have been voluntarily paid as interest for the loan, use, or for usance of money, the same shall not be recovered back, either directly or by way of set off, or counter claim or payment." And amends section six by striking therefrom these words: "or if illegal interest shall hare been paid, the principal with legal interest, deducting the illegal interest paid."]
Introduced by Mr. Newcomb:

H. R. 59. An act to authorize Railroad Companies to occupy and use for railroad purposes the property of Canal Companies, with their consent, and to secure them in such occupation and use, and for the protection of the hydraulic powers of each Canal, and to authorize the lessees of the water privileges in said Canal to organize a company or companies for the maintenance thereof, in case of the failure of said Canal Company to maintain the same.
Introduced by Mr. Thacher:

H. R. 62. An act empowering incorporated cities and incorporated towns to plant and maintain shade trees along the streets, alleys, public squares and commons thereof, and to provide for the protection of the same at the expense of the adjoining property holders.
Introduced by Mr. Miller, of Clinton:

H.R. 64. An act entitled an act to amend the 406th section of an act entitled "An act to revise, simplify and abridge the rules, practice, pleadings and forms in civil cases in the courts of this State; to abolish distinct forms of action at law, and to provide for the administration of justice in a uniform mode of pleading and practice, without distinction between law and equity," approved June 18, 1852.
[By adding these words: "Provided, That any such judgment shall have remained without execution having issued thereon for the space of five years."]
Introduced by Mr. Miller, of Clinton:
H. R. 67. An act to entitle attorneys to hold liens on judgments.
Introduced by Mr. Gregory, of Warren:

H. R. 69. An act authorizing boards of county commissioners, in this State, to make donations and receive subscriptions for the purpose of erecting a monument to the memory of those from their several counties who have lost their lives, and who may lose their lives, in the present war for the restoration of the Union.
Introduced by Mr. Groves:
H. R. 75 An act to empower railroads to build branches to neighboring coal mines.
Introduced by Mr. Johnson:
H. R. 78. An act to provide for the sale of certain lands belonging to the State of Indiana, in the counties of Jasper and Newton, and to give preemption to actual settlers thereon.
Introduced by Mr. Stringer:

H. R. 79. An act to amend an act entitled "An act providing for the election or appointment of Supervisors of Highways, and prescribing certain of their duties, and those of county and township officers in relation thereto," approved March 5, 1859.
[Amends sections 1, 6, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 20 and 29, and adds sections numbered 30, 31 and 32.]
Introduced by Mr. Meredith:
H. R. 82. An act concerning the creation of corporations for the purpose of maintaining High Schools within the State, and giving the requisite powers to such corporations.
Introduced by Mr. Rhoads:

H. R. 84. An act to legalize the action of the Board of County Commissioners of Vermillion county, and of the District and State Boards of Equalization in adopting the appraisement of real estate of 1859 as the basis for the assessment of taxes for the year 1864, and each year thereafter till a new appraisement shall be made.
Introduced by Mr. Woods:

H. R. 86. An act giving the consent of the State of Indiana to, and authorizing the digging or constructing of a ditch or canal from the Little Calumet river to the Grand Calumet river, both in Lake county, in this State, and requiring the Attorney General to defend such suits or actions at law as may be brought against the parties who may be prosecuting said works.
Introduced by Mr. Hershey:

H. R. 88. An act to authorize high, schools, academies, colleges, universities, theological institutions and missionary boards formed under the general laws of the State, to change their corporate names.
Introduced by Mr. Branham:
H. R. 95. An act to enable railroads to alter their lines in certain cases.
Introduced by Mr. Cook:
H. R. 106. An act to authorize the construction of warehouses for the inspection, storage and sale of tobacco.
Introduced by Mr. McVey:

H. R. 117. An act to amend sections thirty nine, forty-two, forty-five and fifty-four of an act entitled "An act for the incorporation of Insurance Companies, defining their powers, and prescribing their powers," approved June 17, 1852.
Introduced by Mr. Rhoads:
H. R. 119. An act to create a State Normal School, and declaring an emergency.
[To be located where the largest donation is made.]
Introduced by Mr. McVey:
H. R. 121. An act to cure defective acknowledgments of deeds in certain cases.
Introduced by Mr. Olleman:

H. R. 123. An act to declare forfeited the right of way of certain railroad companies to branch roads, no part of which has been completed, and upon which no work has been done for ten years; and declaring that the right of way aforesaid shall revert to the land owners along the route thereof.
Introduced by Mr. Stringer:
H. R. 124. An act to amend section thirty of an act regulating the fees of officers, and repealing former acts in relation thereto, approved March 2,1855.
Introduced by Mr. McVey:

H. R. 125. An act to amend sections one and two of an act entitled "An act to provide for the re-location of county seats, and for the erection of public buildings in counties in case of such re-location," approved March 2d,1855.
Introduced by Mr. Woods:
H. R. 126. An act to amend section five of an act entitled "An act to authorize the construction of levees and drains,'' approved June 12, 1852.
Introduced by Mr. McVey:

H.R. 135. An act to amend the 651st section of the act entitled "An act to revise and simplify and abridge, the rules, practice, pleadings and forms in civil cases in the courts of this State; to abolish distinct forms of action at law, and to provide for the administration of justice in a uniform mode of pleadings and practice, without distinctions between law and equity," passed June 18, 1852.

[By adding these words: "and the court rendering judgment shall order the sale to; be made, and the officers making the sale shall sell the property without any relief whatever from valuation or appraisement laws."]
Introduced by Mr. Foulke:
H. R. 149. An act to enable the Board of Directors of any incorporated turnpike company to change the time of holding the election of directors.
Introduced by Mr. Miller of Tippecanoe:

H. R. 158. An act to secure a just valuation and taxation of all railroad property within this State, to legalize the valuation, assessment, adjustment and payment of taxes, for. such property, made subsequent to the year 1859.
[Became a law without Executive approval, under the provision of the Constitution in such cases made and provided.]
Introduced by Mr. Colover:
H. R. 164. An act to provide for locating and working highways situated upon, contiguous to, or near by county lines.
Introduced by Mr. Thacher:
H. R. 177. An act to amend section 143 of an act entitled "An act amendatory of an act to provide for the publication of delinquent taxes," approved May 31st, 1861.
[Doubles the printer's fees.]
Introduced by Mr. Branham:

H. R. 187. An act authorizing and requiring the Commissioners of the State Debt Sinking Fund to make settlement with the Sinking Fund Commissioners for $422,000 of the War Loan Bonds, purchased by the Sinking Fund Commissioners, with moneys belonging to the Common School Fund; also the sum of $165,000, moneys belonging to the Common-School Fund, advanced by the Sinking Fund to pay interest on the State debt; also the sum of $33,536 09, Saline Fund, and $29,947, belonging to the Bank Tax Fund. Directing the transfer to the Common School Fund of the State of Indiana, of so much of the two and one-half and five per cent, certificates of stock of the State as will, at the price paid for the same, amount to the aggregate of tire sums mentioned in this act, authorizing and directing the proper officers of State to issue a bond of the State for the amount thereof, bearing six per cent, interest, payable semi-annually. Principal payable and redeemable at the pleasure of the State; directing the Treasurer of State to pass to the credit of the General Fund the several amounts herein specified, and declaring that an emergency exists for the immediate taking effect of this act.
Introduced by Mr. Lassalle:

H. R. 189. An act to amend section fifty-two of an act entitled "An act to amend an act to authorize and regulate the business of general banking, passed the House and Senate of the General Assembly, the Governor's objection thereto notwithstanding, on the 3d day of March, 1855."
Introduced by Mr. Newcomb:
H. R. 196. An act to extend the time allowed by law for the completion of gravel roads for the term of one year, in cases therein specified.
Introduced by Mr. Gregory, of Warren:

H R. 199. An act to provide for the distribution of the interest on the School, Sinking and Trust Funds of this State, held for the support of common schools, to repeal all laws in conflict therewith, and declaring an emergency.
Introduced by Mr. Coffroth:

H.R. 207. An act regulating Foreign Insurance Companies doing business in this State; prescribing the dudes of the agents thereof, and of the Auditor of the State in connection therewith, and providing penalties ior the violation of the previsions of this act.
Introduced by Mr. James:
H. R. 210. An act to fix the time of holding the Jourt of Common Pleas in the county of Grant, and repealing all laws in conflict therewith.
Introduced by Mr. Cowgill:
H. R. 211. An act to enable common carriers to dispose of unclaimed freight and baggage.
[If unclaimed for the space of three months; only five days in case of perishable article, or live stock.]
Introduced by Mr. McVey:

H. R. 212. An act to legalize the appraisement of real estate made under the provisions of the act entitled "An act to provide for the appraisement of the real estate, and prescribing the duties of officers in relation thereto," approved December 21, A. D. 1858, and the assessment and levy of taxes made, and hereafter to be made, on such appraisement.
Introduced by Mr. Lasselle:
H. R. 231. An act to protect lawful public notices and prescribing a penalty for injuries thereto.

["Any person who shall wilfully or maliciously tear down, remove, destroy or deface any legal advertisement, handbill, or other public notice, lawfully posted up in any place not belonging to nor occupied by such person, shall be deemed guilty of misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in any sum not exceeding ten dollars."]
Introduced by Mr. Goodman:

H. R. 237. An act to amend section thirty-five of "An act to provide for a general system of common shools, the officers thereof, and their respective owers and duties and matters properly connected
therewith, and prescribing the fees for certain officers therein named, and for the establishment and regulation of Township Libraries and to repeal all laws inconsistent therewith, providing penalties therein prescribed," approved March 6,1865.
Introduced by Mr. Shuey:
H. R. 239. An act to authorize manufacturing companies to erect a dam across the St. Joseph river in Elkhart county.
Introduced by Mr. Buskirk:

H. R. 253. An act to amend the eighth section of an act entitled "An act to fix the time of holding the Common Pleas Courts in the several counties in this State, the duration of the terms thereof, and making all process from the present Common Pleas Courts returnable to such terms, and declaring when the same shall take effect, and repealing all jaws inconsistent therewith," approved March 5th, l859, and which eighth section was amended and approved March l1th, 1861.
Introduced by Mr. Coffroth:
H. R. 254. An act to amend the 5th, 14th and 17th sections of an act entitled an act incorporating the town of Huntington, approved February 16th, 1848.
Introduced by Mr. Newcomb;
H. R. 255. An act supplemental to an act entitled "An act for the incorporation of Insurance Companies, defining their powers, and prescribing their duties," approved June 17, 1852.
Introduced by Mr. Trusler:
H. R. 256. An act for the incorporation of Hydraulic Companies, and defining their powers and duties.
Introduced by Mr. Hoover:
H. R. 263. An act to provide by law to prevent conductors running railroad trains from obstructing any public highway or street, to the hinderance of travel, and prescribing penalties therefor.
Introduced by Mr. Gregory, of Montgomery:
H. R. 270. An act fixing the per diem and mileage of members of the General Assembly, secretaries, clerks, doorkeepers, and other employees thereof. [$5 00 per day.]
Introduced by Mr. Lassalle:
H. R. 276. An act to authorize County Auditors to issue fee bills for the collection of costs accrued before the Boards of County Commissioners.
Introduced by Mr. Newcomb:

H. R. 277. An act to amend sections two and five of an act entitled "An act providing for an organization of Circuit Courts, the election of Judges thereof, and defining their powers and duties," approved June 1, 1852, and providing for Crimiaal and Civil Circuit Courts.
Introduced by Mr. Newcomb:

H. R. 278. An act creating the Sixteenth Judicial Circuit, and providing for the election of a Judge and Prosecuting Attorney thereof, and providing compensation therefor, and declaring its jurisdiction, and providing for a transfer of actions thereto.
Introduced by Mr. Newcomb:
H. R. 279. An act to amend sections nine and ten of an act entitled "An act prescribing the powers and duties of justices of the peace in State prosecutions."
Introduced by Mr. Newcomb:

H. R. 280. An act to amend section fourteen of an act entitled "An act to limit the grand jurors, and to point out the mode of their selection, defining their jurisdiction, and repealing all laws inconsitent therewith," approved March 4,1852.
Introduced from the Joint Committee on the State Debt:

H. R. 285. An act to provide a State Debt Sinking Fund for the payment of the principal and interest of the five and two and one-half per cent, stocks of the State therein named, and giving priority of payment to the holders of the two and one-half per cent, stocks of the State of Indiana, prescribing the duties of the Auditor, Treasurer and Agent of State in relation thereto, providing fora clerk of said State Debt Sinking Fund and fixing his salary, and providing a penalty fer the violation of its provisions; abolishing the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, and all offices connected therewith, and the office of the Agent of State, in the city of New York; to invest the moneys belonging to the Sinking Fund in the stocks of the State, transferring the business of said Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners to the Auditor and Treasurer of Stale, providing that the tax therein levied shall be taken and considered as part of the tax levied under an act entitled "An act to raise revenue for State purposes for the years 1865 and 1866," approved March 2, 1865, and declaring an emergency for the immediate taking effect of this act.
Introduced by Mr. Cowgill:

H. R. 299. An act to legalize the official acts of certain officers t herein named, and the acts of their deputies, as such, while the principals were performing military service in the army of the United States.
Introduced by Mr. Shoaff. of Allen:

H. R. 320. An act to regulate swing bridges across the several canals, feeders, rivers and streams in this State, and prescribing a penalty for injuring the same, or interrupting the free passage thereof, and matters properly connected therewith, and declaring an emergency.
Introduced from the Committee on Ways and Means:
H. R. 328. An act making specific appropriations for the years one thousand eight hundred and fifty-nine, sixty-one, sixty-three, sixty-five and sixty-six.
Introduced from the Committee on Ways and Means:
H. R. 329. An act making general appropriations for the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-six, repealing certain sections of an act therein, named, and declaring an emergency.

div.head: JOINT RESOLUTIONS,
div.p: Introduced by Mr. Rice:

JOINT RESOLUTION, H. R., NO. 11. A Joint Resolution for the relief of George W. Archer, refunding to him the purchase-money and interest thereon paid for certain real estate sold as Swamp Land by the State, when the title was in one Michael John.
Introduced by Mr. Gregory of Warren:

JOINT RESOLUTION, H.R., NO. 20. A Joint Resolution instructing our Senators and requesting our Representatives in Congress, to secure the passage of a law, by which the soldiers and officers of the war for the suppression of the rebellion, shall be placed, as near as possible, upon an equal footing in the bounty, or bounty and monthly pay, as is just and right, according to the length of time each has served the country in said war; and recommending the granting of pensions to soldiers of the late war of 1812, who have remained loyal to the country.

div.head:
SKETCHES OF THE JOURNALS AND DEBATES OF THE 44TH GENERAL ASSEMBLY
Convened at the Capitol, in Extra Session, under the Requisition of the Governor.
INDIANA LEGISLATURE.
div.p: The Senate and House of Representatives of the 44th General Assembly of the State of Indiana, met in Extra Session, under the official requirement of the Governor, dated September 13, 1865: That the members thereof "meet in their respective Halls, in the State House, in the city of Indianapolis, at 2 o'clock P. M. on Monday, the 13th day of November, 1865."

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: Lieutenant Governor CONRAD BAKER called the Senate to order at twenty minutes past two o'clock, in the following words: "Senators will please come to order. The Secretary will call the roll."
The roll was called and the following Senator answered to their names:

div.p: The LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR. There is a new Senator present, I believe - from Henry.

Mr. THOMAS REAGAN, then came forward to the Secretary's desk, presented credentials setting forth that he "was duly elected Senator to the General Assembly of the State ef Indiana, to fill the unexpired term of Milton Peden, who forfeited his seat in said Senate by accepting a commission in the service of the United States," and was qualified by taking the oath at the hands of the President of the Senate.

div.head: OFFICERS OF THE SENATE,
div.p: Mr. CASON offered the following:

Resolved, That the Senate do now proceed to elect by ballot a Secretary, Assistant Secretary, and Doorkeeker of the Senate, these offices being hereby declared vacant, and that the election proceed in the order above named.
Mr. CASON. As there are several Senators absent, and as it would be satisfactory to have them all present. I move that the resolution lie upon the table till to-morrow morning at nine o'clock.
The motion was agreed to.

div.head: OFFICERS' ASSISTANTS.
div.p: Mr. BENNETT. Before any Doorkeeper, or other officers of the Senate are electedso that thay may not consider it a personal matter, I beg leave to introduce the following resolution:

Resolved, That the President of the Senate appoint a committee of three Senators whose duty it shall be to superintend the employment of all assistants to the officers of the Senate; and that no person shall be allowed to draw pay for services as such assistant, unless his employment is authorized by such committee.

Mr. COBB. I am opposed to that resolution. I don't think it a proper one. I think that no three Senators ought to be invested with the power to control the action of this Senate in relation to the appointment of their employees I presume if we select such officers as will properly do their duties, there will be no occasion, and it seems to me out of place, to appoint a supervisory committee over their actions. I have never known anything of the kind here; and it seems to me the resolution ought not to pass. For these reasons I move to lay the resolution on the table.
Mr. BENNETT. I hope the Senator will not move to lay the resolution on the table until I have time to make an explanation.
Mr. COBB. I will withdraw the motion.

Mr. BENNETT. If I were to introduce this resolution after the election of Doorkeepers and Clerks, they would have some cause to say it was a personal matter; but I introduce it now, so that they can accept their offices with the understanding that this Senate will control the appointment of their assistants. At the last term, as we see by an official publication in today's paper, there were some thirty or forty clerks and a larger number of doorkeepers and assistants - almost two employees to every Senator upon this floor. And other clerks and doorkeepers may do the same. I don't know who will be elected, but by this resolution a committee is to control the appointments. It is to let the clerks and doorkeepers select their assistants, who will apply to that committee to see whether they are needed; if so, then the officer appoints whom he pleases. I don't desire that the committee shall say who he shall appoint, but I desire it to say how many are needed. At the last session we had nearly two employes to every Senator, and the country holds us responsible for these expenses. I introduced a resolution at the close of the session on this subject, and I thought then, as I believe now, that hundreds of dollars were stolen. I felt indignant, but it was too late. We let it go till the last day of the session, and we had to let the proceedings sleep. I want to stop these things at the start, I want to guard every avenue to the public treasury.

Mr. COBB. I want to inquire whether or not this resolution controls the appointments by this committee of the employes urder the officers elected by the Senate? From the language of the resolution I understood that it does.
Mr. BENNETT. The resolution says "to superintend." I don't think the language susceptible of being misunderstood.
Mr. CULLEN. With the Senator from Lawrence, [Mr. Cobb] I don't like the wording of the resolution. I move to strike out the word "superintend" and insert the word "confirm."
Mr. BENNETT. I accept the amendment.
[A message from the House announced the organization of that body.]
Mr. VAWTER. At the commencement of the last session I introduced a resolution fixing the pay of officers by the session. I now move to strike out from the resolving clause and insert the following:

That the Senate will elect a Principal Secretary, whose salary for this seession shall be one thousand dollars, and one Assistant Secretary, whose salary for the session shall be one thousand dollars, and one Dookeeper, whose salary for this session shall be one thousad dollars, and that no allowance whatever shall be made for assistants to either of said officers.

Mr. CULLEN. I believe there is a law now, passed among the acts of the last Legislature, stating what officers we shall have and what salaries they shall receive, and is it proposed to do away with that law by this resolution?

Mr. VAWTER. I answer by saying that we have done that every session since the adoption of the Constitution. The law says the officers shall receive four dollars a day, while every sesion they have been paid from four to five dollars per day.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN the amendment waa laid on the table yeas 22, nays 20

Mr. WILLIAMS. I move to amend by
striking out from the resolving clause and inserting the following:
Resolved, that the[...............?..................] session of the General Assembly of the State of Indiana, be continued in office during the present Session.

Mr. WILLIAMS. In 1861 at the extra session that followed the regular one, as does in the Senate here, the principal Secretary was; appointed to a Government position, and the others vacated their places, and we filled them by our action. The President of the Senate held his place, however; and that session was continued as though it was the same session with the regular one that preceded it. What was the action in the other House? They seemed to think that the officers held over for two years, but inconsequence of the condition of the country, they tendered their resignations, and a portion was re-elected, and a portion was not. They took it that their organization in January should continue so Iong as the members supposed themselves entitled to seats upon the floor; just as I consider we have the right here till the second Tuesday in October, 1866, and that the organization effected last January has the right to continue. If any here are objactable, we have probably the right to remove them, but we have no right to say these gentlemen shall be thrown out of their places.

Mr. OYLER. I acknowledge that the Senator from Knox [Mr. Williams,] has far more legislative experience than I, but I have yet to learn that the action of the House in the other end of this Capitol ought to have any controlling influence over the Senate. As a precedent it may have some force, yet to me it has but little. As has been remarked at the last session, we had some 73 appointees, and the moment we indorse the appointment of one we indorse the appointment of the whole 73. And I say we don't need them. If we sustain the appointment of these 73 men we don't do our duty to the State of Indiana. I am loth to say that I was placed in a position to indorse them last session, but I am not disposed to repeat it now.
The LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR. The amendment is not germain to the subject, and therefore is out of order.
On motion by Mr. BROWN of Wells, the further consideration of this subject was postponed till 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon.

div.head: COMMUNICATION WITH THE GOVERNOR.
div.p: The LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR. Is it the pleasure of the Senate to reciprocate the message just received from the House?
Mr. DUNNING offered the following:

Resolved, That the House of Representatives be informed that the Senate is ready to receive any communication that His Excellency, the Governor, may wish to make to the two Houses, and that a committee of two be appointed to wait upon His Excellency.
The resolution was adopted and Messrs. Dunning and Wright were appointed said committee.

div.head: SENATORS PLACES IN THE CHAMBER.
div.p: On motion by Mr. WILLIAMS it was -
Resolved, That all Senators having selected seats at the last session of the General Assembly are entitled to retain them, if they should so desire, during the present session.

div.head: LEAVES OF ABSENCE.
div.p: Mr. VAWTER. I ask leave of absence from the Senate for two or three days. I have paired off witn the Senator from Johnson [Mr. Oyler] on all political questions.
Mr. CULLEN. I desire to obtain leave of absence for Judge Dawney, who is engaged in a murder trial. He will perhaps be here the latter part of the week.
These requests were severally granted.

div.head: NEWSPAPERS.
div.p: Mr. CULLEN offered the following:

Resolved, That the present acting Doorkeeper be authorized to procure for the use of Senators three copies each of the Indiana State Journal, Indianapolis Daily Herald, Evening Gazette, and Daily Telegraph - two copies of each to be stamped ready for mailing.
Mr. HANNA. I move to amend by including the Volksblatt.
Mr. CULLEN. I accept the amendment.
Mr. BENNETT. I move to amend by way of substitute as follows:

Resolved, That the Doorkeeper be authorized to contract with the publishers cf the Indianapolis Journal, and the Indianapolis Herald, for one hundred and sixty-five copies each of their daily papers, for the use of the Senate during the present session, and that two thirds of the copies of each of said papers be folded and stamped ready for mailing; provided such papers are furnished at the prices paid by regular subscribers; and provided further that the said contract may at any time be rescinded by the Senate, in case said papers do not publish the full proceedings of this session of the Legislature. Said copies of such papers to be distributed by the Doorkeeper, as follows: To the President of the Senate, three copies of each; to each Senator and elected officer ot the Senate, three of each. And that the Doorkeeper furnish the chairman of the Committee on Finance a copy or statement of such contract.

Mr. BENNETT. In this newspaper business we usually get about three times as many papers as necessary, and we ought to specify in our resolution who they are to go to. The reason I propose to rescind the contract is this: the editors, finding it a heavy expense to keep up their reports, in a few days begin to drop off and curtail them. At the middle of last session there was a resolution introduced to drop the Sentinel because of its meagre reports. I voted against that resolution, because it might be supposed I voted upon political grounds had cast my vote for it. But it did not publish the proceedings of this Senate as we desired. A few sessions ago it was the reverse - the Sentinel gave good reports and the Journal comparitively none. In the session of 1859, the Journal had no reports at all scarcely, and the Sentinel at that time had full reports. I do not think these papers are of any use to us or our constituents, unless they contain full reports of what we are doing. I am opposed to taking every paper in Indianapolis for fear they will get mad at us. We might as well take the paper from Union county. We are not to hunt up the Volksblatt or any other blat. We want just such papers as will print our proceedings in full, but as the Senate is composed of two political parties, as a matter of jusitice, and for the sake of harmony, I say divide this, and seIect one Democratic and one Republican paper.
If they do not publish the full proceedings - just such as the Journal published last session, and the Sentinels few years ago - I am for rescinding the contract. I am not voting for a resolution to take these papers to accommodate the Journal or the Herald, but because we need them, and our constituents are willing to pay for them, if they furnish ample reports. If they are willing to give full reports, I am willing to pay them for it. No paper can afford to publish the full proceedings of this Senate unless we patronize them liberally. Then I am willing to take three copies each, for I believe in addition to the general interest they give to their circulation, that will pay them. I am willing to go far enough for that, and then I want to stop. I am opposed to putting in the Telegraph, Gazette or any other paper, for they do not employ reporters here, and if they did, we do not need their papers. I do not care whether they abuse me for it, or anybody else. We have a right to do as we please. If these papers do not comply with their contract, the finance committee can report adverse to paying for them. I have seen too much swindling about this thing, and I have got tired of it.

Mr. GULLEN. This is rather a substitute than an amendment to my resolution, which proposes to take three copies for each Senator. By mathematical calculation you can see how many papers that will be. I suppose if the Doorkeeper contracts for more, he will be responsible, and not the Senate. I do not know how my friends' constituents are, but mine are reading people, and I have been solicited by this and that, man on my way to the Capital to drop them a paper occasionally, that they might see what is going on, and I have invariably said I would do so. There seems to be a disposition on the part of some men to strain out a goat and swallow a camel. I hold that the Senate has no right in justice to say that they will take the Journal and Sentinel, and leave the others out, I know as a matter of fact the Evening Gazette was about as important a paper to Senators as any other, and the proceedings of the Legislature was published about as complete as it was in either of the other papers. That in my recollection of the matter. This is a trifling expense, and if we take any paper let us take them all. The reason the other papers do not publish our proceedings is that the Senate and House of Representatives are continually bestowing their favors and patronage upon their pets. Now, I propose to place these papers upon an equality and give them all a fair show, and give to our German constituents, of which I have a fair quantity, papers to read in their own language. Our people are desirous of understanding what is going on here, and if they can get a paper from us they take it as a great kindness.
Mr. HANNA. I am informed that the Telegraph has a reporter upon this floor and upon the floor of the other House.
Mr. CULLEN. Then I say let us give these papers a fair show.

Mr. THOMPSON. I am in favor of the resolution offered by the Senator from Rush, [Mr. Cullen.] The German population in this State now, almost constitute one-third of the voters, and it is an important matter that this Senate should show a kindly disposition toward this people. Our Governor has mada a long address and circulated it in Germany, and many of them are coming to this country, and how important it is that this Senate should encourage them to come and to read in their own language the doings of the State Legislature. I am willing to take the responsibility. If we could send a paper to every family in the State I would be glad of it, and should esteem ourselves a head and shoulders above every other State in the Union.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN the amendment was laid on the table - yeas 25, nays 15.
Mr. BROWN of Wells moved to amend, by way of substitute, as follows:

Resolved, That the Doorkeeper of the last session be authorized to contract with the publishers of the following papers: Daily Journal, Herald and Telegraph - for three copies each for each member and elective officer of the Senate, two of said copies wrapped and stemmed for mailing; also, two copies of the Weekly Volksblatt, (wrapped and stamped for mailing) for each member and elective officer of the Senate, said contract to be rescinded at the pleasure of the Senate.

Mr. BROWN of Wells. I do not think any member should hesitate to vote for this resolution. I presume all of us have German constituents who want to read the doings of the Legislature. As to the other papers, they have come to be a necessity, and so long as they report our proceedings, I think it nothing more than due to them that we should subscribe for these papers. I think the resolution occupies medium ground, and ought to satisfy the friends of both measures.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN - yeas 22, nays 20 - the amendment was laid on the table.
Mr. CULLEN. It may be well enough to guard my resolution by saying that the papers shall be furnished at the regular rates to subscribers.
There being no objection, the resolution was so amended.Mr. BENNETT moved to strike out of the resolution the names of all the papers except the Herald and Journal.

Mr. COBB, I hope the amendment will be adopted. We have a large German population intelligent enough to have learned the English language, and most of them can read the English newspapers, and do not resort to the German newspapers to get the news of the day. That being the case, as far as the German papers are concerned, there is no necessity for taking them. We need some newspaper for the purpose of presenting us with the news of the day; and we want to know what the organs of both parties say in regard to legislative matters. They are supposed to reflect the desires and sentiments of their respective parties, and these papers ought to be taken I think, not because we want to accommodate the publishers, and not particularly because we want to send these papers to the people to be read, for I submit whether any Senator can send enough papers to do good in any of these counties. It is a great humbug. What do three newspapers a day amount to? If any gentleman wants to keep posted concerning our action here, he will take a daily purpose for the purpose of informing himself. I
have got thirty or forty dollars in my pocket that have been sent up by my constituents to send them papers from here. I hope this amendment will be adopted. I see a disposition among Senators to curtail expenses, and if there ever was a time, now is the time to retrench. We have a debt of enormous proportions which must be adjusted soon, and four or five or six hundred dollars will help do it, and we ought to bring our legislation down within the limits of necessity.

Mr. RICHMOND. I fully indorse the remarks of the gentleman from Lawrence [Mr. Cobb] upon this question. I think this Senate should take two of these papers, and no more. As a general thing the papers I have sent my constituents have never reached them. This taking of five or six papers here is paying for that which will accomplish no good, and therefore, I am in hopes that the motion of the Senator from Union [Mr. Bennett] will prevail.
The motion to strike out was agreed to by yeas 24, nays 16.
Mr. CULLEN moved to postpone any farther consideration of this subject till Wednesday, 3 o'clock P. M.

Mr. BENNETT. This is a short session, and I hope we will settle this question right off, far we need these papers to-morrow. It is a thing no man need think aboutit has been discussed for the past one hundred years.

Mr. THOMPSON. I hope the Senate will let this matter lay over until Wednesday, and I think when they look over the ground, they, will see the propriety of taking the Gazette. If the Senate is determined to give the industrious Germans of the State the cold shoulder, I would like them to consider it until Wednesday.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT, the motion to postpone was laid on the table.
The resolution as amended was adopted - yeas 26, nays 15.

div.head: COMMUNICATION WITH THE GOVERNOR.
div.p: Mr. DUNNING submitted the following report:

MR. PRESIDENT - The committee appointed to wait upon the Governor and learn when it will suit his convenience and deliver his message to the General Assembly, would beg leave to report that they, with a like committee on the part of the House, have conferred with his Excellency, and that he has designated to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock as the hour when he will deliver the same.

div.head: CHAPLAIN SERVICE.
div.p: A message from the House announced the passage of a resolution by that body authorizing a joint committee to invite some clergy man to open the session with prayer.

Subsequently, on motion by Mr. VAN BUSKIRK, the message was considered, the resolution concurred in, and the President makes the committee on the part of the Senate to consist of Messrs. Van Buskirk, Cobb, and Beeson.

div.head: STATIONERY FOR THE SENATE.
div.p: Mr, MASON offered the following:

Resolved, that a Committee of three Senators be appointed by the President of the Senate, to consider and propose the best and cheapest plan to supply tho members of this senate with stationery during this session.

Mr. CULLEN. At the last session, the Senator from Laporte, [Mr. NILES,] a gentleman in whom we all have implicit; confidence, (I may say in his absence,) made a report from a committee who investigated this subject, and it seems to me another report is unnecessary. The report of last session covered a mode of furnishing money for getting paper, which I am decidedly favorable to, and I consider this resolution not at all necessary.

Mr. MASON. I simply want to get some basis to act upon. It is true that there was some mode prescribed in the committee's report at the other term; but if this committee does not report in a way to suit the Senate, some member can move to strike out and insert something else. The report last session provided $100 for each member, but it is very different now, as our daily wages are $5 instead of $3.
Mr. BENNBTT. I offer the following substitute:

Resolved, That the President of the Senate for his own use, that each Senator for his own use, that each elected officer of the Senate for his own use and that of his appointees, and that each chairman of a committee for the use of his committee, be and are hereby authorized to procure from the State Librarian such stationery as they may severally desire, not exceeding in value the sum of - dollars each, for the entire session, upon their own order. That, for the use of the Senate, the Principal Secretary of the Senate, shall procure from the State Librarian, upon his order, aprroved by the President of the Senate, such stationary as may be needed to transact the business of the session. And the said Librarian shall keep a strict account of all stationery for such purposes, by him purchased, and to whom issued, and three days before the close of the present session he shall report to the Secate the amount purchased, for whom, and at what price, and also a list of persons to whom issued, and the amount in value drawn by each. And for the purpose of keeping euch accounts he may employ a clerk.
Mr. BENNETT. I cannot see how swindling can grow out of that. The librarian has on hand quite an amount of stationery which ought to be issued in this way, and we hold him responsible.
Mr. THOMPSON. I move to fill the blank with fifty cents.
Mr. CULLEN. I move to fill the blank with $25.
Mr. VAN BUSKIRK. I move to amend the amendment by filling the blank with $15.

Mr. OYLER. I think the Senate should not adopt that amendment. The active, energetic members are the men who use the stationery, and there are members on this floor who will need more than $15 worth. According to the resolution the order of each one will be filled by the Librarian, and his works will show whether he has used what he has drawn for his own purposes or for the State. It may be enough for some, and enough for me, I have no doubt, but others it wiil not supply.
On motion by Mr. BROWN, of Wells, the resolution and amendments were referred to a select committee of three, with instruction to report to-morrow.
The LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR made the committee to consist of Messrs. Brown, of Wells, Mason and Oyler.
And then the Senate adjourned till 9 o'clock to-morrow morning.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The House of Representatives of the General Assembly of the State of Indiana convened this day at 2 o'clock P. M., in their hall in the Capitol, in accordance with the requisition of His Excellency, Governor Oliver P. Morton, dated September 13th, 1865.
The Speaker (Hon. J. U. Pettit) assumed the chair, and called the House to order, and directed the clerk to call the roll of members, to ascertain a quorum.

From the county of Ripley - B F. Ferris.
From the county of Rush - D. M. Stewart,
From the county of Scott - Thomas M. Sullivan.
From the county of Shelby - James Harrison.
From the county of St. Joseph - John A. Hendricks,
From the county of Steuben - Stephen C. Pabin.
From the county of Tippecanoe - Jos. M. Hershey, J. L. Miller.
From the county of Vermillion - B. E. Rhoads.
From the county of Vigo - F. M. Meredith, J. B. Woodruff.
From the county of Wabash - John U. Pettit.
From the county of Warrick - Robert Porigo.
From the county of Wayne - John Sim, Ehhu Cox.
From the counties of Hancock and Shelby - Geo. C. Thacher.
From the counties of Elkhart and Lagrange - Michael F. Shuey.
From the counties of Switzerland and Ohio - Augustus C. Welch.
From the counties of Hendricks and Boone - John. F. Burnes.
From the counties of Johnson and Morgan - Ezra A. Olleman.

div.p: The Clerk reported 68 members present.
The SPEAKER. The Clerk having reported a quorum present, I declare that the House of Representatives of the State of Indiana is now ready to proceed to business.

div.head: NEW MEMBERS ELECT.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM laid before the House the credentials of Major Richard A. Litson, elected a Representative from the county of Jefferson, in the place of Captain Wright, resigned.
Mr. GOODMAN presented the credentials of John Meikel, elected a representative from the county of Dubois.
Mr.BOYD presented the credentials of James S. Wright, elected a Representative to fill the unexpired term of Mr.Emerson.
Mr. COFFROTH presented the credentials of Pascall N. Pinney, elected a Representative from Johnson county, in the place of Mr. Banty, resigned.
Mr. SIMS presented the credentials of Calvin Cowgill, elected a Representative from the counties of Wabash of Kosciusko, in the place of Mr. Whiteside, resigned.
Mr. MILLER presented the credentials of John J. Caldwell, elected a Representative from the County of Clinton, in the place of Cornelius J. Miller, resigned.
Mr. HIGGINS presented the credentials of Gen. Newell Gleason, a Representative from the County of Laporte, in place of Mr. Willis, resigned.
Mr. NEWCOMB presented the credentials of Stephen Davidson, elected a Representative, from the County of Fulton, in the place of Nelson G. Sheffer, deceased.
The SPEAKER. If there be noobjection tho gentlemen whose credentials have been presented and read, will come forward and be sworn ia office.

There being no objections, these Representatives elect came forward and received the oath to support the Federal and State Constitutions, and to faithfully discharge their duties as members of the House of Representatives of the General Assembly of the State of Indiana.

div.head: THE ORGANIZATION.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM. Mr. Speaker - I move there be a committee of three appointed to inform the Senate that the House is organized and ready to proceed to business.
The motion was agreed to, and the Speaker appointed Messrs. Branham, Brown and Newcomb.

Mr. BROWN suggested that the proper and usual order in the practice of the House, was to dispatch the Clerk to inform the Senate of the organization of the House, and on his motion the foregoing vote was reconsidered, and the Clerk was directed to acquaint the Senate of the organization of the House of Representatives - by message.
Mr. NEWCOMB submitted the following:

Resolved, That in the opinion of the House the
election of the Hon. John U. Pettit as thereof, at the regular session in January last, constituted him tho legal Speaker of the House during the present session of the General Assembly, and that he be recognized as such.
The resolution was agreed to without a division.
Mr. HENRICKS. Though probaby a little late, desired to have the yeas and nays, on the adoption of the resolution. The time may come when we might want to get out of it.
The SPEAKER. The yeas and nays can be ordered by unanimous consent.
Mr. GRIFFITH. I supposed when the Clerk was directed to inform the Senate of the organization, that the fact stated in the resolution was fully recognized.

Mr. BROWN saw no necessity for the adoption of the resolution. He thought it an established fact that the election of Speaker was for the term of office of Representatives, and not for one session only; that the organization of the body was for the term and not for the session. Such was the practice in the Congress of the United States as well as in this State. The Speaker was elected to serve during the entire term for which the people elected him. We all know that there are two sessions for every Congress, and that the Speaker is elected to serve during the term for which the members of that body are elected. When Congress meets for the second session, the same organization holds; and if the President convenes an estra session, the organization had at the first session still holds good. The gentleman need have no fear of Democratic members here in that matter. I say to him that we have considered this thing, and intend to stand by it, because we believe that the doctrine is justified by all parliamentary history that these officers elected at the last session are still the legal officers of the House, and are the only persons that can exercise their functions, unless the House for good cause shall remove them, or any one of them. I think, therefore, that the resolution of the gentleman from Marion is a useless one. He showed, further, that the Republican House in the Legislature of 1861 established the precedent for which he contended.

Mr. NEWCOMB had considered the past history of the body, and thought that perhaps some such expression of the House ought to go to record. In the session of 1858 the Speaker was elected at the special sessionthe special session coming first, and at the regular session in tbe January following, the question was raised whether the Speaker could hold, and after considerable discussion the debate was cut short by the Speaker and officers resigning, and their re-election. In 1861 the Speaker announced that he would not take the Chair, and as soon as the roll was called he tendered his resignation and was re-elected. I think myself that the Speaker is entitled to hold during the term; and to show that the House recognizes the rule it is proper that the resolution should go to record. That is my only object in offering it.
The SPEAKER The Chair hears no objection to the order of the yeas and nays.
Mr. BROWN desired to amend the resolution by inserting with that of the Speaker the names of all the officers of the House.
The SPEAKER. Will the gentleman from Jackson send it up in writing?
Mr. NEWCOMB. With the consent of the House I will withdraw the resolution, and submit the following:

Resolved, That the Speaker, principal Clerk, assistant Clerk and Doorkeeper, elected at the regular session of this House, at the regular session in January last, ara entitled to hold their respective offices during the official continuance of the present General Assembly.
Mr. BROWN acquiescing, withdrew his amendment, and Mr. Newcomb's substitute was adopted by yeas 68, nays 0.
Pending the call of names -

Mr. GRIFFITH explained. I will be content with such action as the House may take; and yet as matter of principle and precedent, I can hardly vote for the resolution. If I thought all the Democracy would vote aye, I should vote no. But as I do not want to interfere with them, I vote aye.

div.head: COMMUNICATION WITH THE GOVERNOR.
div.p: A message was now received from the Senate by Mr. Whittlesey, their Secretary, formally announcing their preparations for business and readiness to hear the Governor's message.

div.head: REVISION OF THE RULES.
div.p: Mr. HIGGINS submitted the following:
Resolved, That a committee of five be appointed to revise the Rules of the House, and that the rules of the last House be the Rules of this until others are adopted.

Mr. BROWN hoped the resolution would not be adopted, and insisted that the continuance of the organization of the House carries with it the rules of the last session. The rules at the last session were the rules at this time, and if they needed amendment it must be done as at the last session.
Mr. KILGORE. I desire to ask the gentleman whether we have not the power to revise the rules?
Mr. BROWN Most certainly.
Mr. KILGORE. That is precisely what we are about to do.

Mr. BROWN. If I understand the resolution, it is such a one as is always offered upon the organisation of a new House. It proceeds upon the doctrine that there is now no rules whatever for the government of this House, else why does it propose to have the rules of the last session continued in force till we shall establish original rules at this session for our government? I think that this is the spirit of the resolutions, and that it is wrong for the reasons I have given.

Mr. HIGGINS. But I desire a revision of the Rules. It will be recollected that thera were a great many amendments to the rules made as the last session - so many that no member can now readily tell what they are. If the latter clause is objectionable to the gentleman, I am willing to strike it out, and retain only the part which proposes to revise the rules.

Mr. BOYD. Would not that carry with it a necessity for reprinting the rules? These frequent revisions of the rules do us no good. They were generally no better after a revision than before, and in his judgment, not so good. And if there were still on hand a sufficient
number of the old rules, be was opposed to the resolution.The resolution was rejected.
Mr. BROWN moved an order, that 200 copies of tbe Rules of this House be printed and placed on the desks of members.
Mr. BOYD still urged the same objection as before; but, if he could know there were not on hand a sufficient number of copies, he would favor the motion of the gentleman from Jackson.
Mr. BROWN. There were none at all.
Mr. KILGORE. Mr. Speaker, I demanded a division of the House just now, but was not recognized by the Chair. I think this printing the Rules, and then revising them afterwards is an absurdity.

Mr. BROWN, if in error about the matter of revieioD, would not insist. He understood that the question of revision was decided in tho rejection of the resolution of the gentleman from Laporte. His inference was that the House does not want the rules revised. Then the next question is to get these rules here so that gentlemen may know what they are. He would say to the gentleman from Lawrence, that he had sent to the Librarian, and he pays he has not got them. He did not think fifty copies could be obtained in the State.
Mr. HENRICKS. The gentleman from Delaware [Mr. Kilgore ] demanded a division of the House on the adoption of the resolution of the gentleman from Laporte [Mr. Higgins.]

The SPEAKER. If there is no objection the Chair will go back to that. The Chair hears none. As many as are in favor of the adoption of the resolution of the gentleman from Laporte, will please to rise and stand till they are counted.
The vote on the division of the House then resulted - affirmative 42, negative 30.
So the resolution was adopted.

div.head: COMMUNICATION WITH THE GOVERNOR.
div.p: Mr. STRINGER submitted the following:

Resolved, That the Speaker appoint a committee of three on the part of the House, to act with the committee on the part of the Senate, to wait on the Governor, and ascertain at what time it would please him to deliver his message to a convention of both houses.
Mr. HENRICKS. Mr. Speaker, I move, by way of amendment to the resolution, that we take from the table the message of the Senate in this matter.
The SPEAKER. The resolution has precedence.
Mr. STRINGER withdrew the resolution, and accept the motion of the gentleman from St. Joseph [Mr. Henricks].
The motion wes agreed to, and the message was reported by the Clerk.
Mr. HENRICKS. I move that the House concur in the message from the Senate, and that a committee of three be appointed on the part of the House, to act on that joint committee.
The motion was agreed to, and subsequently the Speaker appointed Messrs. Henricks, Brown and Stringer to act on said committee.

div.head: THE LAWS AND JOURNALS.
div.p: Mr. GROVES submitted the following:

Resolved, That the Doorkeeper be instructe to procure from the Secretary of State copies of the House Journals and laws of the session, and place one copy of each on the desk of each member of the House.

Mr. BOYD. If these are to be furnished for the benefit of members, and members are to do with them as they please - leave them here or take them home - I certainly shall object, because of the cost attaching. We have got the laws and journals, and I contend that it is the duty of every member here to bring his statutes, laws and journals along with him.
Mr. KILGORE. I have just had an interview with the Secretary of State, and he tells me there are about ten tons of documents there, and he wants to get rid of them.
Mr. RHOADS. I desire to amend the resolution so as to include the Senate Journal.
The amendment was agreed to.
And then the resolution, as amended, was adopted.

div.head: THE STANDING COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. GRIFFITH submitted the following:
Resolved, That the committees of this House be the same as those of the last session, and that they be announced by the Speaker as they then existed.

Mr. LANE. In all due courtesy to the gentleman, I move to lay that on the table. There are a great many new members of the House not yet assigned to act on any committee. He withdrew the motion for explanation.

Mr, GRIFFITH. It is but carrying out the programme we have initiated. We have adopted a resolution recognizing the officers of the former session as the officers of this, and should we not recognice the committees? But I am willing it should go to the table.

Mr. NEWCOMB. I think it well enough to lay it on the table. My understanding is, that we continue over and remain so far as officers and committees are concerned, precisely as we stood in the former session. I take that for granted. It is suggested that there are some gentlemen who are on no committee. Such can be assigned by the Speaker. I presume we understand ourselves as proceeding upon the principle that everything stands as at the last session.
Mr. GRIFFITH withdrew the resolution.

div.head: THE CALENDAR OF BUSINESS.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Principal Clerk be directed to place upon the files and calendar of this session of the House, all bills and joint resolutions pending at the adjournment of the General Assembly, in the same order in which the same stood at the termination of said regular session.

div.head: UNFINISHED BUSINESS.
div.p: Mr. HIGGINS submitted the following:

Resolved, That the Judiciary Committee be instructed to inquire into and ascertain whether the laws passed in pursuance of an act entitled, "An act providing for the completion of the unfinished business of any session of the General Assembly by the next successive special session of the General Assembly," approved March 4, 1865, are good and valid in law, and that said committee report at 10 o'clock to-morrow.
Mr. NEWCOMB. I move to amend by striking out the last clause. That is crowding the mourners too fast, I think.
Mr. HIGGINS accerted the amendment.
And so the resolution was adopted.

div.head: EXPENSES FOR CLERKS AND POLICE.
div.p: Mr. BOYD submitted the following:

Resolved, That the Auditor of State be requested to furnish for publication in the Indianapolis Daily Journal an itemized statement of the expenses for clerks and doorkeepers, together with all the attaches of the House of Representatives during the last session of the General Assembly.
Mr. KILGORE moved to lay it on the table. But withdrawing for explanation -

Mr. BOYD simply desired to say that he had seen a similar publication with reference to these expenses for the last session of the Senate in the Journal of to-day, and thought it was due to members of the House to lay alongside of that statement the similar expenses incurred by the House. For one, he would not be ashamed of any statement of expenses that has thus accrued in the House, or that attached to any committee with which he had been connected. And it was due to our constituents that this publication sbould be made.
Mr. KILGORE. Is the resolution simply to have the statement published in the Journal?
Mr. BOYD Simply to have it published.
Mr. KILGORE. At the expense of the State?
Mr. BOYD. So far as that is concerned, I presume the Journal company will not charge anything.
Mr. THACHER. I move to amend so as to require the statement to be published also in the Daily Herald.
Mr. NEWCOMB. Does it ask that the report be made to the House?
Mr. BOYD. No. He is to send the statement to the Journal.
Mr NEWCOMB. I think we had better direct the Auditor to report to this House.
Mr. BOYD supposed the Journal would not object to the publishing.
Mr NEWCOMB. Of course not. I move to amend so that the Auditor shall report to this House,

Mr. PRATHER. It occurs to me, we shall incur unnecessary expense by authorizing this report to be printed. As my friend from Lawrence seems to be very tenacious on the question of expenses, I think he had better withdraw his resolution. If we authorize this printing by resolution, these gentlemen of tho Journal Company will be sure to charge for it. My word for that.
Mr. HARRISON considered that the question as to whether the printicg is to be had, ought to be decided after the report is made.
Mr. THACHER withdrew his amendment.
The resolution as modified by Mr. Newcomb was then adopted.

div.head: APPOINTEES OF THE LAST SESSION.
div.p: Mr. MILLER submitted the following:

Resolved, That all the appointees of the last session of the House of Representatives be continued in their respective positions or offices during; this special session which they held during the last regular session.
Mr. MONTGOMERY. I move to lay it on the table.
Mr. NEWCOMB asked whether it could be in order since we have just passed an order that the officers shall appoint whom they please?
The resolution was laid on the the table.

div.head: THE GOVERNOR'S MESSAGE.
div.p: Mr. HENRICKS,from the Joint Committee appointed to wait on the Governor, &c., reported that they had performed that duty, and that the Governor had informed the Committee that he will be ready to deliver his message to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock.

div.head: CHAPLAIN SERVICE.
div.p: Mr. STUART submitted the following:

Resolved, That a committee of three on the part of the House be appointed to act in concert with a like committee on the part of the Senate, to invite some regular minister of the gospel to attend and open with prayer the sessions of the Legislature, immediately preceding the delivery of the Governor's message.
The resolution was adopted, and the Speaker appointed Messrs. Stuart, Church and Ferris to constitute said committee on the part of the House of Representatives.
Mr. OSBORN moved an adjournment.
Mr,STUART proposed to amend the motion so that the adjournment shall be till to-morrow morning, 10 o'clock.
Mr.THACHER proposed 9 o'clock.
Mr. SULLIVAN, of Scott, proposed half past nine o'clock.
The latter amendment was agreed to.
And so the House (at 4 o'clock P. M.) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The Senate met at 9 o'clock A. M.
The Journal of yesterday was read and approved.

div.head: RESIGNATION OF SECRETARIES.
div.p: Mr. HANNA presented the resignation of A. T. Whittlesey, Principal Secretary of the last session.
Mr. COBB presented the resignation of J. S. Broadwell, Assistant Secretary of the last session.
These resignations were accepted by consent.

div.head: ELECTION OF OFFICERS.
div.p: On motion, by Mr. CULLEN, the resolution [Mr. Cason's] for the election of officers, made the special order for this hour, was taken up.
Mr. BROWN of Wells, offered the following, by way of substitute.

Resolved, That, without intending to establish any new precedent for the organization of the Senate for special sessions, a Committee of three Republicans and three Democrats be appointed as a commitee of conference to select officers for the organization of the Senate at the present session.
On motion by Mr. TERRY the substitute was laid on the table - yeas 22, nays 20.
Mr. BROWN, of Wells. offered the following amendment by way of substitute:
