div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES - MONEY.
div.p: Mr. NILES, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill H. R. 58, amending the Act regulating interest on money, etc., recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill was read the second time.

div.head: JUSTICES OF THE PEACE.
div.p: Mr. BENNETT, from the Judiciary Committee, returned a Senate resolution of inquiry concerning the number of Justices of the Peace, etc., recommending that its reference be changed to the Committee on Organization of Courts.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: VACATING OF TOWNS, STREETS, ETC.
div.p: Mr. HANNA, from the Committee on Corporations, returned Mr. Richmond's bill [S. No. 152] touching the laying out and vacating of towns, streets, alleys, etc., recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: BLACKFORD COUNTY LINES.
div.p: Mr. RICHMOND, from the Committee on Couuty and Township Business, returned Mr. Bonham's bill [S. 140] amending an act dividing the State into counties, etc., recommending passage.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: PROTECTION OF MEETINGS.
div.p: Mr. CASON, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill H. R. No. 12, amending an act for the protection of lawful assemblages of the people, recommending passage.The report was concurred in, and the bill was read the second time.

div.head: HORSE THIEVES AND OTHER FELONS.
div.p: Mr. CULVER, from the Committee on Corporations, returned Mr. Niles' bill [S. No. 175] authorizing the formation of companies for the detection of horse thieves, etc , recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill was read the second time.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT the bill and report were laid on the table that he might have time to examine the bill and propose amendments thereto.

div.head: HOTEL COMPANIES.
div.p: Mr. HANNA, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill [S. No. 185] for the incorporation of Hotel Companies, recommending passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time.

div.head: DEPOSITIONS, ETC.
div.p: Mr. BENNETT returned the bill [H. R. 32] to provide for taking Affidavits, etc , recom mending indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: RAIL AND OTHER PUBLIC ROADS.
div.p: Mr. ALLISON, from the Judiciary Committee, returned his bill [S. No. 229] extending time for organization of purchases, reorganization of Companies, etc., recommending passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time.

Mr. CULLEN regarded this as an important and rather a sweeping law. In order to give time to look into it, and without being considered as an opponent of the bill, he moved its reference to the Committee on Corporations.
The motion was agreed to.

div.head: THE WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS.
div.p: On motion of Mr. NILES, the House amendments to the bill S. No. 196 (printed in full in these Reports of the 14th inst.) were taken up.

Mr. BENNETT understood that this bill was gotten up and hurried through here to interfere with a case now pending before the Supreme Judges, and he was opposed to any such kind of legislation. He was in favor of the bill, but opposed to the emergency clause amendment of the House.

Mr. NILES, as far as the history of the bill is concerned, was not informed, except that the Judges are solicitous that it should pass. He was satisfied it was not instigated by any party concerned in any case before the Supreme Judges.

Mr. OYLER. The bill will be of little or no avail, so far as the present session of the Supreme Court is concerned, unless the emergency clause is attached to it. There is a case now before the Supreme Court in which some 80 witnesses are summoned who are unable to pay their expenses, and it is a burden grevious to be borne - one which should not be allowed by the Legislature.

Mr. CULLEN was somewhat acquainted with the case referred to. Judge Elliott had not yet entered upon the trial; the State of Indiana is not ready and will not be ready; so the emergency clause will do no harm in this case.

Mr. McCLURG would not do injustice to a party litigant, but it does seem from the light
thrown upon the question that the bill certainly ought to pass. The case referred to would occupy the time of the Supreme Court too long.
Mr. VAWTER (interposing.) I am informed by one of the leading parties to the suit that they will not have many witnesses.

Mr. McCLURG. But the business of that Court has been much behindhand, and it would be doing gross injustice to parties all over the State to claim the attention and the time of the Supreme Court in trying this case. He hoped the bill would pass as it came from the House.

Mr. ALLISON was satisfied that this bill had been introduced for the purpose of depriving the Supreme Court of jurisdiction over this case. He happened to know that the defendant was now in jail, having already applied to the Common Pleas Judge of that district, who very coolly answered that he had no jurisdiction in the case. The defendant did not see fit to take his case before the Judge at home for some cause - probably for fear the Judge was prejudiced - and he then had no remedy but to come to the Supreme Court. Without casting any reflection upon any gentleman here, Mr. A. thought this bill was introduced for the purpose of sending this party back and compelling him to lay in jail until the next term of that District Court.
Mr. NILES (interposing) was confident that the bill was drawn up by one of the Judges of the Supreme Court, and introduced at their instance and request.

Mr. ALLISON. That may be true - the Supreme Court may be glad to get rid of this labor. But I am opposed to the emergency clause; and if it be true that the State will not be ready, and the case can not be tried, it does away with the necessity for the emergency clause, because this is the only case of any importance requiring time. And I feel authorized to say that gentlemen are misinformed in regard to the number of witnesses - there will only be a few witnesses examined, and I cannot conceive that it will take up more than one or two days. But I do not believe that the time of the Judges is so valuable that the liberty of a citizen shall be put in jeopardy for the want of a trial. The witnesses are here already and the case can be tried at once. If this bill is passed they will have to go home and be dragged off to some other court, which will cost them more time and money.

Mr. COBB had a resolution drawn up which he intended to offer, when we came co that or der of business, requesting the House of Representatives to return this bill in order that the Senate might make some amendments to it. Upon reflection he was satisfied the Senate passed that bill too hasty.
Mr. NILES (interposing) was confident the original bill was in the handwriting of Judge Frazier, and that it contained an emergency clause.

Mr COBB should certainly oppose the passage of the bill with an emergency clause for the reasons urged by the Senator from Jefferson [Mr. Allison]. He did not believe it a duty to relieve the Judges to the injury of litigating parties. We had better leave the burden upon the Supreme Court until the case now pending before them shall be disposed of.

Mr. CORBIN believed it wrong to abridge the right of habeas corpus. The very reason given for the passage of the bill, with the emergency clause, - that parties are here with witnesses and attorneys - is one of the strongest reasons against passing it at all. These parties come up here because they believe they could not have a fair hearing before other courts having concurrent jurisdiction with the Supreme Court. There may be great inconvenience felt by the Judges in being compelled to sit upon such cases, but how much greater inconvenience is felt by that individual who is compelled to lay in jail because there are no courts open to hear his case. Parties never apply to Judges of the Supreme Court for a writ if they can get it done properly, in their judgment, at home. And why? For the simplest reason in the world: It will cost them one hundred times more.

Mr. CASON. I am informed that this case is continued until to-morrow, the probability is there will be an order issued to take depositions, and that the Judge is willing to hear the case. I would make this proposition to Senators: that we postpone the further consideration of the amendments of the House of Representatives until 2 o'clock Tuesday, and make it the special order for that hour.
It was agreed to by common consent.

div.head: GETTYSBURG CEMETERY.
div.p: During the discussion just reported the following message was received from the Acting Governor, by the hand of Charles P. Jacobs, Esq , his Private Secretary:

opener.salute: To the Senate and House of Representatives:

div.p:
I herewith respectfully transmit to the General Assembly the report of Colonel James Blake, Commissioner of the Soldiers' National Cemetery, at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, appointed as such by the Governor of the State, together with the printed documents referred to in the report, and marked A. B. C. and D., respectively, and commend the same to your careful consideration. I also transmit herewith a printed pamphlet entitled "Soldiers' National Cemetery, at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania," giving the correspondence in relation to the enterprise, which resulted in the incorporation and establishment of this Cemetery. From the documents submitted, it will be seen that the amount originally assessed as the quota of Indiana in defraying the expenses of the undertaking was $4,625 83, in part payment of which the sum of $1,156 was, on the 1st day of June, 1864, remitted by the Governor to the Treasurer of the Association, leaving a balance of $3,469 80 still due from this State, for which last named sum requisitions have long since been made but have not been honored for want of the necessary appropriations to meet the requisitions. Gettysburg is the only battle-field of the late war in the North, and the remains of some eighty of the heroic soldiers of Indiana have
been carefully interred in the National Cemetery, which has been established on the ground where they fell in the defense of the country. I respectfully recommend that immediate provision be made for the payment of the balance of the assessment originally made as the quota of this State, amounting, as before stated, to the sum of $3,469 80. It will be seen by Colonel Blake's report, that owing to the increased price of labor and materials, he estimates that the original assessment will be insufficient to meet our share of the cost of the undertaking by the sum of some $2,400. Whether an appropriation should be now made to meet this estimated deficit, is respectfully submitted to the General Assembly without any recommendation on that branch of the subject. Colonel Blake, with the patriotism and public spirit which has characterized his long and valuable life, at the request of the Governor, without compensation, took upon himself the duties of Commissioner for this State, visited Gettysburgh, and participated in the proceedings of the Board of Commissioners, in July last, performing the trusts confided to him in the most acceptable manner.
I would be doing injustice to my own feelings, did I not thus officially express the high appreciation in which his services are held.

closer.signed: CONRAD BAKER, Lieutenant Governor acting as Governer.

div.head: ISSUING OF EXECUTIONS.
div.p: Mr. BENNETT, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill [H. R. No. 64] to amend section four hundred and six of the General Practice Act, approved June 18, 1852, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read he second time.

div.head: NOTARIES PUBLIC.
div.p: Mr. CASON, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill [H. R. 27] legalizing certain acts of Notaries Public after the expiration of their commission; recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time.

div.head: POSTAGE STAMPS.
div.p: On motion of Mr. OYLER it was -

Resolved, That the Librarian be and he is hereby authorized to draw an order on the Auditor for $200, to be paid out of the appropriation for Legislative expenses, for the purpose of purchasing postage stamps for Senators, as per a resolution of the Senate.

div.head: JUSTICES JURISDICTION.
div.p: Mr. RICHMOND, from the Committee on Organization of Courts, returned the bill [S. No. 22] giving Justices jurisdiction in all cases where the value of property does not exceed $200, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time.

div.head: ATTORNEY'S LIENS.
div.p: Mr. CORBIN, from the Committee on Benevolent Institutions, returned the bill [H. R. No. 67] to entitle Attorneys to hold liens, on judgments, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time.

div.head: TRUST ESTATES.
div.p: Mr. ALLISON, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill [S. No. 170] to authorize parties to sell and convey trust estates and to reinvest the proceeds thereof ; recommending its indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. NILES said, he introduced, but did not prepare this bill, and had not committed himself, in its favor. It was once reported on favorably, but he was glad when it was recommitted.

div.head: COURTS OF CONCILIATION.
div.p: Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on Organization of Courts, returned the bill [H. R. 43] to repeal an Act to establish courts of conciliation, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time.

div.head: RAILROAD FARE.
div.p: Mr, CASON, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the resolution of inquiry concerning the reduction of fare on railroads, not to exceed three cents per mile; recommending that it lie on the table, as legislation thereof is inexpedient.

Mr. CASON. The Committee thought it would be unconstitutional to attempt to regulate the rates of fare of corporations having no such restrictions in their charter. He did not think the Legislature should take upon itself the control of the private affairs of corporations or individuals.
The Senate refused to concur in the report, upon a division - affirmative 14, negative 21.
On motion by Mr. MOORE, the resolution and report were referred to a Select Committee of five, which the President made to consist of Messrs Moore, Williams, Brown of Wells, Corbin and Culver.

div.head: THE SALE OF RAILROADS.
div.p: Mr. REAGAN, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill [S. No. 206] supplemental to the act of March 3, 1855, recommending its passage.The report was concurred in and the bill read the second time.

div.head: SHERIFF AND CORONER DEEDS.
div.p: Mr. ALLISON, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill [S. No. 72] prescribing the form of deeds to be used by Sheriffs and Coroners, recommending that if lie on the table.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: OFFICERS OF ELECTION.
div.p: Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on Elections, returned the bill [S. No. 221] for the punishment of officers of elections for receiving illegal votes ; recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill read the second time.

div.head: DISQUALIFYING VOTERS.
div.p:
Mr. CULLEN, from the Committee on Elections, returned the bill [S. No. 220] disqualifying certain persons from voting in this State, recommending
its reference to the Judiciary Committee, that the constitutional question therein contained may be reported upon. The report was concurred in.

div.head: WHITE RIVER NAVIGATION COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. WARD, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill [S. No. 211] supplemental to An Act to incorporate the White River Navigation Company, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill read the second time.

div.head: GRAND JURORS.
div.p: Mr. CULLEN, from the Committee on the Organization of Courts, returned the bill [S. No. 156] to amend section 14 of An Act to limit the number of grand jurors, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and tbe bill read the second time.

div.head: INDIANAPOLIS INSURANCE COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. WARD, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill [S. No. 199] to amend An Act to incorporate the Indianapolis Insurance Company, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in.
On motion of Mr. ALLISON, the bill was considered as engrossed, read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 34, nays 5.

div.head: BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
div.p: Mr. BROWN, of Wells, desired leave to offer the following:

WHEREAS, The Daily Journal has, through its columns, informed the Senate that it would discontinue the publication of the BREVIER REPORTS, and whereas, its columns of this morning give evidence of the execution of such determination, and the substitution of but meagre reports of the Senate proceedings, therefore -
Resolved, That the Senate hereby discontinue its subscription to said paper from and after this date, and that the Secretary inform the proprietors of said paper of the passage of this resolution.
Mr. BENNETT objected to the introduction of the resolution at the present time; it would probably induce discussion that would take up the remainder of the session.
The Senate refused to suspend the order of business for the purpose of considering the resolution by yeas 14, nays 25.
And then the Senate adjourned (under the rules,) till 2 o'clock P. M. to-morrow.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: When the House met at 9 o'clock A. M., the SPEAKER directed the Clerk to call the roll to determine a quorum.
When a quorum was determined, and the order taken to read the Journal of yesterday -
On motion by Mr. COX, the reading of the Journal was dispensed with.
Mr BRANHAM said the Journal should show how Mr. Buskirk occupied the Chair yesterday.
On motion by Mr. GRIFFITH, the Journal was corrected so as to show that the Chair was taken by Mr. Buskirk, by request of the Speaker and the general consent of the House.
So the Journal was authenticated.

On motion by Mr. BRANHAM, by consent, leave of absence was granted to the members of the Committee on Ways and Means, and of the Joint Committee on the State Debt, till that matter shall be arranged for report.

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: Mr. SIM presented the memorial of the Indiana yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, on behalf of colored citizens - against legal discriminations on account of color - especially negro disabilities in the Courts and Common Schools, etc., which was read and referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. RICE, Mr. COX, Mr SIM, and Mr. CHAMBERS, each presented a Temperance memorial, which, without reading, were referred to the Temperance Committee.

Mr. CALDWELL, Mr. NEWCOMB, Mr. HENRICKS, and Mr. WOOD, each presented memorials from their County Boards, for the repeal of the soldiers' relief law, which were referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

div.head: LIQUOR LAW.
div.p: Mr. SHUEY, from the Committee on Temperance, returned his bill [H. R. 218] amendatory of the liquor law of March 5, 1859, with an amendment inserting after the word petition, in the 65th line of the first section, this: "In the absence of other proof;" and when it is so amended recommending its passage, and that all other pending amendments be laid on the table.

Also, from the same Committee, he returned Mr. Harrison's bill [H. R. 33] amendatory of the eighth section of the same act with an amendment striking out the word "five" and inserting the word "ten" in lieu.
These reports lie on the table.

div.head: NEW BILLS - INSURANCE.
div.p: Mr. HENRICKS introduced a bill [H. R. 233] for an "act more effectually to protect the people of the State of Indiana against losses by fire.

Mr. H said there was quite a number of provisions in the bill. Its general object being to pay the atnount of loss or damage by fire out of the State Treasury, according to the amount for which such lost property has been assessed for taxation. It was to accomplish quite a number of objects. One was that all property be assessed at a fair valuation; and another was that the taxes so assessed shall be paid. He moved that the bill lie on the table and that 200 copies be printed.
Mr. PRATHER thought he understood the bill. We have a law providing that the Assessor shall do the business contemplated here.

Mr. HENRICKS said it involved a new principle of insurance. It would save large amounts of money to the people of the State now paid to Insurance Companies. All such money so paid operated as a direct tax on the people. He gave an example of the profits of true Goshen Mutual Insurance Company, which in a few years reaped a profit of $30,000 which was divided amongst the officers.
Mr. PRATHER withdrew his objection.
And then the printing was ordered.

div.head: FEES AND SALARIES.
div.p: Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, introduced a bill [H. R. 234] for an act to repeal an act to ascertain the amount of fees and salaries in the Supreme, Circuit and Common Pleas Courts of this State; Sheriff of the Supreme Court, and other Courts of the State, and providing penalty for violation; approved June 3d, 1861.
It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

div.head: SCHOOL COMMISSIONER.
div.p: Mr. RHOADS introduced a bill [H. R. No 235] for an act to provide for the appointment of a Commissioner who, in conjunction with the various County Auditors in the State, shall examine the records of the various school funds held by the County Auditors; providing for the salary of the said Commissioner; and that the Superintendent of public instruction be the final referee in cases of disagreement between the Commissioner and a County Auditor, [Said Commissioner shall enter on his work as early as the first of March, 1866; continue one year and receive a salary of three thousand dollars.]
It was referred to the Committee on Education.

div.head: POSTAGE STAMPS.
div.p: Mr. SHUEY submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, authorizing the State Librarian to draw from the State Treasury out of the moneys appropriated for Legislative expenses the sum of $500, to procure postage stamps for members of the House of Representatives.

div.head: INSURANCE,
div.p: Mr. KILGORE (by request) introduced a bill [H. R. 236] for an act to amend the 23d section of the act for the incorporation of Insurance Companiesdefining their powers and prescribing their duties; approved June 17, 1852.
It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

div.head: STATIONERY.
div.p: Mr. HARRISON submitted a resolution reciting that the value of the amount of stationery which each member and officer of the House is entitled to receive is fifteen dollars and ten dollars, respectively; therefore, resolved that the Librarian be required to charge members and officers of the House the regular jobbing or wholesale price for stationery.
Mr. BROWN. There had been no effort on the part of the Librarian to charge more than the wholesale price.

Mr. HARRISON was informed by members of both Houses that for the best article of legal cap the Librarian requires $12 a ream; for the next best $10, and for Congress paper about the same. Now it was well known that the best article of legal cap paper can be bought at Stewart & Bowen's, or at Merrill's, for $9 a ream, etc. At that rate of charging, each member, instead of $15 would get about $10 or $12 worth of stationery. He submitted that the Librarian has 20 right to go into a speculation upon us.
Mr. BROWN thought there must be some mistake in this matter.

Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, said the Librarian's explanation was that he was not making a cent. There were about forty reams of paper in the Library," purchased at cost, as it ruled at the last session. The only question was whether the State or members should lose this depreciation.
Mr. BROWN had long and well known the Librarian - could confide in his honesty and integrity. He moved to lay the resolution on the table.
It was so ordered.

div.head: RAILROAD ENGINEERS.
div.p: Mr. BROWN submitted the following:

Resolved, That a committee of five be appointed to Inquire into the expediency of establishing by law a Commission to license competent engineers, providing that no person shall run or have charge of any locomotive engine used in drawing any train of cars in this State unless such person shall first be licensed by said Commission, showing that he is a man of good moral character, and fully possessed of all the qualifications requisite for a locomotive engineer:

He said he had drawn a bill for that purpose at the last session, but it was not satisfactory to to him, and being now in bad health, he suggested that this labor be performed by the House. He would furnish his skeleton to the committee. This principle was recognized in the legislation of Congress. Passengers were frequently murdered in their travel solely on account of defective moral or intellectual qualifications in the engineer.
The resolution was adopted.

div.head: NEGROES BEFORE THE LAW.
div.p: Mr. COX presented the memorial of George H. Chapman and 5,000 others, citizens of Wayne county, recommending the repeal of the Black Laws, together, with such legislation as will secure to colored people the right to testify in courts of justice, and the benefits of the Common School system.
It was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

div.head: HABEAS CORPUS.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB, (by unanimous consent,) called up the consideration of the bill [S. No. 196] concerning the writ of habeas corpus, and, on his motion, the constitutional restriction was suspended, upon his statement and explanation of its merits, and the bill was read the second time by title.
On motion by Mr. BUSKIRK, the constitutional restriction was further suspended - yeas 79, nays 0, and the bill was read the third time and passed the House of Representatives - yeas 80, nays 1.

Mr. COFFROTH suggested that as this was a bill amending the Civil Practice Act, the title should be amended so as to indicate the amended section, whereupon, on his motion, (by unanimous consent,) the bill was referred to the Judiciary Committee, with instructions to report a title.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE.
div.p:
Mr. HOGATE (by consent) moved that so
much of the message of the Acting Governor as relates to the matter of an Agricultural College be referred to the Committee on Agriculture.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, proposed to amend the motion and refer the matter to the Committee on Education. It was so referred at the last session.
Mr. SHUEY hoped the amendment would not prevail. The Committee on Education did very little in this matter at the last session. He would try another.
Mr. CHAMBERS thought it should be referred to a special committee of one from each Congressional District.
Both Mr. Gregory's and Mr. Hogate's motions were rejected, and Mr. Chambers' was adopted.

div.head: TABLE OF STANDING COMMITTEES
div.p: Mr. BOYD submitted the following:
WHEREAS, We have no printed list of the Standing Committees of the House of Representatives, therefore -
Resolved, That the State Printer be instructed to print 200 copies of the list of Standing Committees in conjunction with the Rules, heretofore ordered to be printed.
It was adopted.

div.head: COMMON SCHOOLS.
div.p: The SPEAKER now returned to the consideration of bills of the House of Representatives on the second reading.
Mr. GREGORY of Warren's negro and mulatto school bill [H. R 208] coming upwith the amendments and favorable report by the Committee on Education -
Mr. BURTON desired to have time and leave to submit a minority report.

Mr. NEWCOMB moved to recommit with instructions that the Committee on Education inquire into the expediency of reducing the present rate of taxation, 16 cents. We had passed a bill for the distribution of the proceeds of the Sinking Fun,d, which is the interest on about $4,000.000.

Mr. NEWCOMB then changed his motion to a motion to refer to the Committee on Ways and Means. He stated his knowledge that there were about $4,000,000 of these funds, the interest on which would average 6 per cent. We had got along hitherto with a tax often cents on the hundred dollars, and he had voted to raise it to 16 cents. He still thought that with the interest on these funds the tax could be reduced again to 10 cents.
Mr. OLLEMAN moved that the bill and instructions be referred to the Committee on Education.
Mr. RHOADS moved to lay Mr. Newcomb's motion on the table.
Messrs. BROWN and GROVES demanded the yeas and nays, which resulted - yeas 22, nays 58; so the House refused to lay the motion on the table.
Mr. CHAMBERS desired to amend the motion, so that the Committee be instructed further to report to-morrow morning.
Mr. RHOADS demanded the yeas and nays, and they were ordered, and the bill was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means - yeas 52, nays 26.

Mr. BURTON asked and obtained unanimous consent to submit a minority report on the bill from the Committee on Education, that it might go along with the bill to the Committee on Ways and Means.The report reasons generally and particularly against legislation for the benefit of the black race.
Mr. BROWN moved to refer the minority report to the Committee on Ways and Means with the bill.
Mr. KILGORE moved to lay Mr. Brown's motion on the table. It would be an insult to the Committee to send such a report.
On the question raised as to whether the majority report went with the bill to the Committee.
Mr. NEWCOMB said he did not move that.
The SPEAKER (Mr. Gregory of Warren in the Chair) held, that the motion would govern the reference.

Mr. BUSKIRK. If we are to be prohibited from expressing our views here as Representatives of the people, it is time we should know it. He simply but emphatically and firmly declared the rights of members in this regard.

Mr. KILGORE contemplated no insult. He understood that the House had the right to disapprove and correct sentiments expressed in any report. In this matter which requires no investigation - about which onr minds were made up thoroughly - it was an insult to insist on a solemn investigation before we can act upon it intelligently.

Mr. BROWN recited the object of the bill which had been referred. It authorizes seperate schools for both white and black children. He deprecated those who would elevate the African at the expense of the free white people of the State. Instead of an insult, the minority report looked to the protection of the white people of the State. Still he had no idea that this subjected, inferior race would be elevated. The superior race might be depressed and degraded, but the tendency of placing the negro along side of the stronger race would be downward continually. Even the negro himself had too much sense to be placed on an equality with the white man.
Mr. KILGORE, withdrawing his motion to lay on the table, now moved to reject the report of the minority.

Mr. BUSKIRK rehearsed the provision, that school money for these colored schools was to be distributed, not according to the taxes paid, but according to the number of children. The motion to reject was made because the matter of the report does, not meet the approval of the gentleman from Delaware. He submitted to the will of the majority, but if the minority were not to be heard in the unrestricted expression of opinion, it was the end of legislation here, so far as he was concerned.

Mr. SHUEY accorded to all minorities to make such reports as they please; provided they are couched in respectful language. And if anything
would lead him now to vote in favor of this motion, and against his conviction, it woul be the implied threat of bolting by the gentle man from Monroe.

Mr. COFFROTH interposed the consideratio that there was little distinction between repressing a report and repressing debate. He submitted a question of order under rule 32, contending that the motion to refer has precedence over the motion to reject.

Mr. SHUEY. If by the rules, the majority may reject a report, that does not afford a justification for bolting. He abhorred the sentiments of the minority report, yet he should vote for its reference. He wanted it to go to record as an emanation from the remains of the Democratic party. As he had been educated so far from being degraded, a man is elevated by his efforts to raise up the lowly and the help less.
Mr. LASSELLE made the point, that it is not in order to reject any proposition, except a bill.
Mr. KILGORE confessed the point and with drew the motion to reject. He then renewed the motion to lay the motion to refer on the table.
Mr. BUSKIRK submitted, that, as the majority report is not with the Committee, there is no propriety in the reference of the minority report.

The yeas and nays being taken thereon pending the call many members explained that they voted in the affirmative, because the majority report did not go with the bill to the Committee. Others contending that the report went necessarily with the bill, and the majority report simply recommended the passage of the bill, and the minority report was held to be an amendment of the majority report. The vote resulted in a refusal to lay on the table - yeas 34, nays 51.
Mr. HIGGINS moved that both the majority and minority reports go to the Committee on Ways and Means.
Mr. RHOADS moved to lay this motion on the table.
On motion by Mr. PRATHER, the House here took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: On motion by Mr. COFFROTH it was -
Ordered, That when the House adjourns this evening, it shall be till to-morrow, 2 o'clock P. M.
He made this motion on account of the present necessity for work in the Committees.
The order was adopted.

div.head: ABSENCE.
div.p: On motion by Mr. Branham, Mr. Olleman, and on motion of Mr. Brown, Mr. Montgomery had leave of absence for a few days, on account of illness.

The SPEAKER returned to the unfinished business of the morning, viz: Mr. Rhoads'motion to table Mr. Higgins' motion to refer both the majority and minority reports on Mr. Gregory of Warren's Negro School bill, 208, and decided that the said reports were not properly before the House.

div.head: HABEAS CORPUS.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned the Senate bill, No. 196, with amendments and recommendations viz: First, that the bill be reconsidered, and that it be amended by adding an emergency clause. Secondly, amend the title so as to read, "An Act to amend the 716th section of the General Practice Act of June 18, 1852, go as to deprive the Supreme Court and the Judges thereof of original jurisdiction in cases of writs of habeas corpus, and enlarging the powers of the Circuit and Common Pleas Judges in relation thefeto, in this act provided and prescribed."
The vote on the passage of the bill was reconsidered, and the first amendment was adopted.

Mr. BUSKIRK proposed further to amend by addings appropriately, this: "Provided such jurisdiction shall not be taken away in cases now pending." He stated that he desired to provide for the case of the application from Ripley county before Judge Ray, which is set down for to day; the witnesses are here, and it can be better and more economically disposed of here bhan by sending back to the Circuit Judges. Besides, he had understood that the local Circuit Judge had declined to act in this case, and the Common Pleas Judge held that he had no jurisdiction. So the applicant was compelled to come here.
Mr. COFFROTH. The case to which the gentleman referred would occupy the Judge during the entire term of the Supreme Court, therefore he opposed the amendment.
Mr. MILLER inquired whether this case is from a distance?
Mr. BUSKIRK. From Ripley county.
Mr. MILLER. The State pays no cost of witnesses, and it would be but justice to the witnesses to send the case back, if the case is not soon disposed of.

Mr. NEWCOMB understood that all the witnesses were not yet here; and unless it could be disposed of before these amendments could go back for the concurrence of the Senate, he thought it best that the case should go back to the Circuit Judge.

Mr. Buskirk's amendment was rejected. The bill, as proposed to be amended by the Judiciary Committee, was then again finally passed the House by yeas 80, nays 0, and the title was amended according to the recommendation of the Judiciary Committee.

div.head: THIRTEENTH ARTICLE.
div.p: The House took up the special order, viz: Mr. Meredith's Joint Resolution [H. R. No. 1] to amend the Constitution of the State by striking out the Thirteenth Article thereof, with the conflicting recommendations by the majority and minority of the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. BUSKIRK said, Mr. Meredith, the author of the Joint Resolution, was entitled to pen the debate, but was prevented from doing
so by indisposition. It was upon his motion that the subject was made a special order for this day, and this afforded a pretext for him to take the floor.
[He addressed the House at length in opposition to the Joint Resolution. His speech is reserved for correction. It will appear hereafter ]
Mr. MEREDITH took the floor, but gave way for -
Mr. KILGORE, on whose motion the further consideration of this special order was postponed till Thursday, 10 o'clock A. M.

div.head: THE CALENDAR - GRAND JURIES.
div.p: Mr. Buskirk's grand jury bill, No. 220, introduced the 18th inst., corning up on the second reading -

Mr. BUSKIRK moved that it be referred to the Judiciary, with instructions to report ic back and recommend its passage. He said the present grand juries have only jurisdiction of felonies. The amendment here proposes to give to the Circuit Court original exclusive jurisdiction of felonies, and concurrent jurisdiction in the Common Pleas and Justice's Courts in cases of misdemeanor. The new Constitution changed our Grand Jury system, and we have tried the experiment thereon for twelve years. The result has been that the men who commit misdemeanors, assault and battery, or carry concealed weapons literally go untried and unpunished. As the law now stands, if the rights of property of a citizen are invaded, he has to complain himself, and generally employs a lawyer to prosecute, on account of the inefficiency of prosecuting attorneys ; and the result is that men suffer wrong rather than go to the trouble and expense of a prosecution. It was a cruelty to punish men who commit murder and steal, when the State permits the lesser offences to go unpunished. We must commence with those who first violate the law. Some poor man may be wronged, his property may be invaded ; and the man that does it is powerful and vindictive. Therefore the poor man will not commence a prosecution. Then let him go before the Grand Jury. In his judgment the protection of the morals of our State require that Grand Juries should have jurisdiction in the Common Pleas and Justice's Courts. His Excellency Gov. Morton concurred in this view ; and when Mr. B, went to his room to thank him for it, the Governor said he had been too long a lawyer upon this question, but had learned that, if we would protect our people, we must commence with those who are guilty of misdemeanors.

Mr. COFFROTH agreed entirely with Mr. B. in the opinion, that our mode of punishing misdemeanors, is simply licensing them. However, he did not think it worth while to take a test vote, for he supposed there were not five men in the House, who would vote against the bill. He suggested the propriety of simply referring the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary. He moved so to amend the motion.
Mr. BUSKIRK accepted the modification, and the bill was referred to the Judiciary Commiittee, without instructions.

div.head: NATIONAL CEMETERY AT GETTYSBURG.
div.p: A message was now received from the acting Governor, by the hand of his private secretary, transmitting the report of Colonel James Blake, State Commissioner of the soldiers National Cemetery, at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania ; also a pamphlet, embracing the correspondence which resulted in the establishment of that Cemetery.

The message recommends an appropriation of $3,469 80 to pay the balance of the assessment, for the State of Indiana, for this object ; submitting the consideration, that Gettysburg is the only battlefield of the rebellion, in the Northern States ; and that eighty of the heroic soldiers of Indiana, have been interred there, on the ground where they fell.
Mr. RHOADS moved that the message be laid on the table.
Mr. HENRICKS proposed that so much of it as refers to an appropriation, be referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.
Mr. RHOADS accepted, and it was so ordered.

div.head: JUSTICES' DOCKETS.
div.p: Mr. Cook's Justices' docket bill, No. 229, coming up -
Mr. HENRICKS moved that it be indefinitely postponed.
Mr. LASELLE had considered it but little, but thought it an exceedingly proper bill.

Mr. COOK said that the law requires the Justice to furnish for his docket a good bound book containing 200 pages, and to turn it over to his successor; and the fees were so inadequate, that in most cases it was a hardship.
Mr. GROVES was opposed to laying this expense on the counties. He would prefer to raise the fees of the Justices. He hoped the bill would be postponed.
Mr. HENRICKS withdrew his motion to postpone, and moved that the bill be laid on the table.
Mr. KILGORE made an ineffectual motion to adjourn - affirmative 31, negative 46.
Mr. GRIFFITH demanded the yeas and nays, which were ordered and taken, and the House refused to lay the bill on the table - yeas 46, nays 36.
On motion by Mr. KILGORE, the House (at 4 1/2 p. M ) adjourned till to-morrow at 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: SUPERVISORS OF HIGHWAYS.
div.p:
Mr. TERRY, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill [H. R. 79] to amend
the Supervisors' act of March 5, 1859, with amendments thereto, recommending passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill was read the second time.
Mr. BENNETT moved to amend the bill so as to allow the Supervisor to employ men to work out commutation money at wages not to exceed two dollars per day.

Mr. COBB was in favor of putting the figure at such an amount as will compensate every man who performs labor on the highways. No better safeguard can be thrown around officers than to make the law clear.
Mr. WEIGHT. No Supervisor ought to be allowed to pay more than the man pays who does not work his road tax out.
Mr. CORBIN thought there should be some discretion left with the officer - the people themselves can regulate these things.
Mr. CULLEN. The amount of commutation money should be the standard to pay for work on the road.
Mr. CASON was anxious that this bill should become a law.
Mr. McCLURG was willing to leave discretionary power in the hands of the Supervisor, and would be glad to see the amendment passed.
Mr. WILLIAMS would leave it altogether discretionary with the Supervisor, and moved to strike from the amendment the words "not to exceed two dollars."
On motion of Mr. CULLEN, this amendment was laid on the table upon a division - affirmative 21; negative 18. And the amendment was laid on the table by yeas 29, nays 13.
Mr. RICHMOND moved to increase the price of commutation from $1 50 to $3 00.
On motion of Mr. COBB, this amendment was laid on the table.
The bill was then ordered engrossed.

div.head: A MESSAGE FROM THE ACTING GOVERNOR.
div.p: During the consideration of the bill just ordered to be engrossed, the Executive Messenger communicated the following:

opener.salute: To the Senate and House of Representatives:

div.p: At the commencement of the present Special Session, His Excellency, the Governor, in his message invited your attention to the necessities of the speedy establishment of an institution in which Indiana soldiers and seamen, disabled by wounds or disease contracted in the service of the United States, shall be cared for and maintained during the continuance of the disabilities under which they are laboring. He also said, in the same connection, that the United States General Hospital at Jeffersonville is one of the most complete establishments of the kind in the country, and is well adapted to the purposes of a Soldiers' Home, and that he had written to the Secretary of War and Surgeon General for information as to whether the Government would be willing to turn over this hospital to the State of Indiana, to be used in the establishment of such an institution, should the State desire it, and that the answer, when received, would be communicated to the General Assembly.

Since the departure of Gov. Morton a communication has been received from the office of the Surgeon General in reply to his letter of inquiry mentioned in his message, in which it is stated that upon application to that effect by the State of Indiana, the Surgeon General will recommend that the general hospital at Jeffersonville be turned over to the State authorities upon the same terms as the Tripler Hospital was turned over to the State of Ohio. A copy of this communication from the Surgeon General's office is herewith respectfully submitted.I have no difinite information as to the terms upon which Tripler Hospital was turned over to the State of Ohio, but believe that the only terms required was a guarantee on the part of the State that the property donated should be faithfully applied to carry out the object for which it was given.

I have written to the Surgeon General since the receipt of this communication for information as to the precise terms upon which Tripler Hospital was donated to the State of Ohio. If the land upon which the General Hospital at Jeffersonville is situated, comprising, as I am informed, about one hundred and sixty acres, can be procured for a reasonable price, this offer of the government to turn over the Hospital buildings, with the appurtenances, would seem to afford a solution of the Soldiers' Home question, so far as its location is concerned. Indeed, if such an institution is to be at all provided by the State or the people, and of this I do not permit myself to doubt, we can not afford to decline the offer of buildings and improvements of the value of not less than three hundred thousand dollars, adapted to the accomplishment of the very object we have in view, whether the owners of the land will or will not consent to sell the land for a reasonable price. If they refuse thus to sell, the remedy of the State is plain. It is to provide, by Legislative enactment, for the taking of the property, and for the assessment of the just compensation to which the owners would be entitled under the Constitution. With these suggestions, the whole subject is again commended to your careful consideration.
Whenever an answer is received from the Surgeon General as to the terms upon which Tripler Hospital was turned over to the State of Ohio, it will be communicated to the General Assembly.

closer.signed: CONRAD BAKER, Lieutenant Governor, Acting as Governor.

div.head: FAMILIES OF SOLDIERS, ETC.
div.p: Mr. BENNETT, from the Select Committee thereon, returned the bills [S. No. 197 and S. No. 198] for the repeal of the Act for the relief of families of soldiers, etc., (described in these Reports of Nov. 14,) recommending indefinite postponement of No. 197 and the passage of No. 198.
The report was concurred in, and S. No. 198 was read the second time.
Mr. CORBIN moved to amend the bill by striking out so much of section 3 as occurs after the word "cease," in the fourth line.
On motion by Mr. RICHMOND, the amendment was laid on the table.
On motion of Mr. CULLEN the rules were suspended - yeas 36, nays 6 - and the bill read the third time.

Mr. CORBIN. One of the strongest arguments used by its friends in fayor of the passage of the bill for the relief of the families of soldiers, was that the burthens should be equally distributed; but where is the equality of the distribution now? And where is the theory they urged with so much vehemence, when they now come in and propose to repeal that law, and when they vote down almost unanimously an amendment proposinr to put it upon the same ground they urge as a reason why the bill should pass? If it was just to make an equal distribution at the time of the passage of the bill, upon what ground has it ceased, and why should there not be an equality of distribution now? If there was justice in it then, there is justice in it now. There is reason why the bill should be repealed, but there is a great injustice in not having that fund distributed in accordance with the provisions of the law. And then there has been a species of log rolling for the passage of this bill. The petitions presented here were printed in Indianapolis, and they have been sent to every county in the State. Here is where the whole thing originated. They were printed at the Journal office - all there petitions were.

Mr. BENNETT. The reason we want to repeal this bill now is that the war for which it was made and designed is over, and there are not now the number of beneficiaries there were before. I knew the counties of Union and Fayette would pay a greater amount into the State Treasury than they would receive from it, but I thought it nevertheless my duty to vote for the bill. There being no soldiers now to pay it out to, the surplus money put into the Treasury from such counties as Union and Fayette will go into the Treasury of Marshall or some other county, and there be used as other county monies, and to that I am opposed.

Mr. CORBIN (interposing). The expenditure has already been made for the support of these families, and that county perhaps may be in debt to the amount required under the provisions of this bill, and why should the money be withheld?

Mr. BENNETT. If the war had continued, and the soldiers remained in the field up to this day, it would be wrong to change it; but it has happened fortunately for this country that these soldiers have come home; and it is not possible that the people have expended all the money they would have expended had the war continued to this time.
Mr. CORBIN (interposing). If it is right provided they have paid it all, is it not half right if they have paid half?

Mr. BENNETT. If they have expended more money than they have collected there might be some reason in the argument; but unless they have violated this law, they have not paid out more than has been collected.
Mr. OYLER remarked that the question was on the passage of the bill, and the necessity for it, he thought, was felt by the Senate.
Mr. THOMPSON was heartily in favor of the passage of the bill. The bill was finally passed the Senate by yeas 41, nays 1.

div.p: Mr. CASON, from a majority of the Committee on Federal Relations, submitted a lengthy report reasoning in favor of the passage of the concurrent resolution offered by Mr. Bennett (printed in these reports of the 15th inst.), and recommending that the substitute offered by Mr. Brown, of Wells, lie upon the table.

div.head: REFEREES IN DIVORCE.
div.p: On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, the regular order of business was suspended, and the divorce bill [S. No. 16] was taken up on the second reading.
It was passed to the third reading.

Mr. NEWCOMB now moved a suspension of the constitutional restriction, to enable him to move the third reading of the bill to-day. He read from the remarks of Senator Brown, of Wells, thereon, as in the BREVIER REPORTS of the last session of the General Assembly, showing how divorces are procured by means of divorce agencies. And from conversation with members from the northeast part of the State, he found these statements fully sustained.

Mr. LASSELLE'S first objection to the bill was that it strikes down uniformity in pleadings. That was his main objection. He knew that a very wrongful system of practice had been gotten up by attorneys in these cases so as to get them referred and decided by themselves. It was not only wrongful but villainous, involving perjury. Such a system had no doubt prevailed im some parts of the State, It was a disgrace to the Courts and the profession of the law. But it seemed to him there were other and better means of reaching these cases by criminal law - those men who regard oaths so lightly - let them be reached by the criminal law. He thought, therefore, there was 110 necessity for this bill. There was sometimes a necessity for referees - where there is an honorable Court and honorable attorneys - the reference saves the Judges a great deal of time and trouble and facilitates business. He would not strike down this principle of uniformity in procedures because a few unprincipled lawyers and Judges abuse it.

Mr. BUSKIRK. His friend admits the evil, but fails to suggest any other remedy than the one proposed in this bill. Until his friend proposes a better, he considered it was best to pass this bill. This practice of referees in these cases was unknown in his part of the State. We ought to put a stop to this obtaining divorces by fraud and perjury.

Mr. LASSELLE. Uniformity is the beauty and boast of the laws and practice of the State of Indiana, It had worked an immense benefit to the State and people, and if we lose sight of this principle we shall soon get into confusion and embarrassment from one end of the State to the other. He never heard of the practice of referring these cases in his district.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, demanded the previous question; and the main question, to-wit: Shall the bill pass? was ordered.

It was passed by the House of Representatives without amendment - yeas, 72; nays 12;
the title: To amend Section 349 of the Civil Procedure Act of June 18,1852.

Mr. MILLER explained his vote. The bill was wrong in principle. Its very heading shows that practice and pleading shall be uniform in all our courts. This made exceptions. He thought it very doubtful whether we could do this under the Constitution. He voted no.

Mr. BUSWELL explained. This bill of the Senator from Wells - his county - was gotten up to cure an evil which existed only in the 10th Judicial Circuit. This thing of referring divorce cases to attorneys was introduced and practiced by a judge that the people had got rid of. And now he did not think there was any occasion for the passage of this law.
The passage of the bill was then announced as above.

div.head: PUBLIC NOTICES.

div.head: R. R. PASSENGER FARE.
