div.head: LIQUOR LAW.
div.p: Mr. Shuey's Liquor Law amendment bill [H. R. 218] amending sections 3 and 4, and providing penaltiescoming up - with a recommendation by the Committee on Temperance, to amend, by striking out the words, "of good moral character."

Mr. SHUEY said the Committee recommended to lay that on the table. There was an amendment reported. It was ascertained by reference to the Journal of Monday: Insert after the word "petition" this: "In the absence of other substantial proof."

Mr. RHOADS proposed to amend the amendment of the Committee by striking out the words, "at least one half of the legal voters," and inserting this: "A majority of the inhabitants exceeding fourteen years of age." There were some transactions in society in which women were as much interested as men. They suffer more from dissipated men than the legal voters in the township or ward; and it seemed to him that they should be consulted in the matter of resisting this tide of evil. A woman of good ordinary sense has the capacity of judging in this matter; and little boys and girls are just as able to decide upon it as their father or any legal voter. He would therefore require that their names be attached to the petition.
Mr. TRUSLER (interposing) how will it be determined when they get a majority.

Mr. RHOADS. He would provide for that by another amendment, to this effect: The applicant shall be required to make proof that he has a majority of all such persons, He did not propose to have this determined negatively, but he would put the onusprobandi upon the applicant, to prove that his petition is signed by a majority of all the inhabitants over fourteen years of age.
Mr. GRIFFITH was in favor of the principle of the amendment. He submitted whether it would not be more effective to say, "A majority of all the inhabitants over eighteen years."

Mr. ROACH thought not; but that fourteen years were sufficientknowing just as well what the consequences will be if they sign, or forbear to sign it. They will readily know that if groceries are established, their neighbors and fathers and brothers will be dragged down to ruin. And in view of the fact that they are directly the sufferers, it was eminently proper that they should be consulted as to the license. With such an amendment we would have all the guards we could obtain by legislation against this traffic.
Mr. BROWN made the point that the amendment of Mr. Roach is not in order, because of the pendency of two amendments when his amendment was presented.
The SPEAKER ruled, that amendments not recommended by the Committee fall. He referred to the 58th rule, - second paragraph.
Mr. ZEIGLER said the object of the bill was to accomplish a certain end. Would a petition from women and children have as much influence with County Commissioners as the petition of voters?
Mr. ROACH. The question of numbers, not influence, is to decide the question of license.
Mr. ZEIGLER still contended that influence was in the question.

Mr. BUSKIRK understood the general purpose to be to protect minors, etc. As for men, they will get liquor if they want it. He was opposed to minors, and women being introduced into our political struggles. But as to young men and boys voting, there was not a town in the State which you can not obtain a majority of these boys and young men in favor of license. He also spoke against the amendment which will probably yet be proposed by the gentleman from Henry.

Mr. LOCKHART hoped that this bill would not be encumbered with amendments. There were eight licensed groceries in his town Waterloo, DeKalb countyand two of them obtained license against the remonstrance of every person in the town. He made no temperance speech, but was not without feeling in the matter. Let us have an efficient bill.
Mr. BROWN moved to lay Mr. Roach's amendment on the table.
It was so ordered - affirmative, 69; negative, 5.
Mr. BROWN moved to further amend by striking out the word "white," in 86th line of the 3d section.
Mr. COFFROTH was not in favor of extending any further privileges to the black race; neither did he want to degrade them. Therefore, he would move to lay Mr. Brown's amendment on the table.
It was laid on the table - yeas 58; nays 23.

Mr. LANE proposed to amend further by striking out all that relates to signers of petitions in the towns. His object was to leave this matter to the township; for he would have no fears then that groceries would annoy people living in the country. He was personally opposed to licensing the traffic at all. He recited a case where a man in his county obtained license against the unanimous remonstrance of the township. It showed the necessity of more stringent legislation.

Mr. SHUEY said the bill was a compromise between the radicals on this question, and the friends of the present law. He would have the assent of all the legal voters. But we got the best bill we could. He was satisfied that the
friends of prohibition would get more by adopting this bill in its present shape, than they conld in any other way. He hoped the friends of the bill would not tear it in pieces and destroy its efficiency by amendments. It had been carefully examined in committee, and had the approbation of Attorney General Williamson. It provides that the County Commissioners in order to ascertain whether a majority have signed the petition shall go to the returns of the last preceding general election " in the absence of other sufficient proof."

Mr. GRIFFITH was in favor of the amendment of the gentleman from Putnam (Mr. Lane.) The gentleman from Elkhart (Mr. Shuey) had said it was a compromise, and questioned whether we could pass it with radical elements in it. He was willing to try it. He recited the incident of the women of his town conspiring against the groceries and turning out all the whisky their barrels contained; and when they were fined for the invasion the fine was paid by a voluntary subscription. He wanted to "provide as much as possible againt the evils of intemperance, and therefore he would adhere to the amendment of the gentleman from Putnam (Mr. Lane.)

Mr. COWGILL referred to a township in his county casting about 800 votes, with a little town in it casting not more than seventy-five or eighty votes. He was of opinion that there might be a majority of that town who would sign a petition to authorize the traffic, whilst if it were left to the people of the township the applicant could not get one-fourth of the voters. For the protection of the people of that township and every other township, he insisted that Mr. Lane's amendment was a very proper one to be incorporated into this bill.
Mr. BONNER spoke also in favor of Mr. Lane's amendment. He gave particulars about Greensburgh to justify his vote in that direction.
Mr. GOODMAN moved an adjournment.

div.head: BACK PAY AND BOUNTIES.
div.p: The SPEAKER obtained the informal consent of the House that the Select Committee to which was referred his Soldier's bill No. 156, have leave to file their report with the Clerk, that it may go upon the Journal of the House in its order.
On motion of Mr. LOCKHART leave of absence was granted to Mr. Major till Monday noon.
And then the House (at 5 o'clock, p. M.) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The Senate met at 2 o'clock P. M.
On motion by Mr. OYLER, the reading of the Secretary's Journal of yesterday was dispensed with.

div.head: MICHIGAN CITY HARBOR.
div.p: The following message was received from the Acting Governor by the hand of Chas. P. Jacobs, his Private Secretary:

opener.salute: To the Senate and House of Representatives:

div.p: I beg leave respectively to call your attention to the propriety of passing a joint resolution asking Congress to make a "donation of lands to the Company incorporated under the laws of this State to construct a harbor a Michigan City.

Some forty years ago there was cut off from the Territory of Michigan of a strip of land ten miles in width, which was added to the State of Indiana, for the purpose of affording her a Lake Harbor. For the purpose of constructing a harbor at Michigan City, the Government made appropriations extending through a series of years, amounting in the aggregate to about $135,000, but these were given in such small sums, and at intervals so distant from each other, as to render them comparatively ineffectual.

Yet, with all these drawbacks, a harbor was made which, for some years, gave to our State quite an amount of shipping. On the completion of the Michigan Central Railroad, the harbor at Michigan City was abandoned by the Government, and for want of repairs, and being exposed to the storms of the Lake, the upper works which had been erected were gradually loosened and fell, and the sand drifting across the cribs, finally choked up the mouth of the creek, and the harbor became inaccessible to any but small fishing vessels. Citizens of Indiana, convinced that the State should have a port on our great inland seas, as well as Ohio and Illinois, formed a Company under the laws of the State, for the purpose of rebuilding this harbor. To this Company Congress ceded all the Government work that remained, and gave permission for the work to be prosecuted, as had already been successfully done by a Company at Milwaukee, under a like cession by the Government. The Michigan City Harbor Company are thoroughly organized and already stock has been subscribed to the enterprise, amounting to $135,000, and assurances have been received by the Company that the L. N. A. & C. R. R. Co. will take stock to the amount of $100,000, so soon as it is ascertained that the balance necessary to complete the work can be procured.
Competent engineers, employed to examine the work, have estimated that the entire amount required to complete and secure to our State a permanent Lake Harbor, will not exceed $300,000.

On the benefits to be derived by our State from the establishment of a Port of Entry and Departure, on its Northern borders, it is difficult to place too high an estimate. In the transportation of wheat from points north of the Wabash, fifteen cents per bushel will be saved to the producer, that being the difference between Railroad and Lake transportation.Salt from Saginaw, which is so extensively used by our packers, with this harbor completed, could be delivered at Michigan City as cheaply as at Chicago, thereby resulting in an immense saving to the people of Indiana who reside north of the "Wabash.

The iron mines of Lake Superior too would be opened to our State. And in view of our coal beds, and the vast quantities of bog ore which is so valuable when mixed with the Lake Superior iron, the proprietors of mines on Lake Superior would erect blast furnaces and rolling mills in Indiana, shipping their crude ore to this State for that purpose, and thereby furnish a market for the coal and iron deposits of our State. There would also be a saving of some
forty per cent, on pine lumber, as it could be delivered at Michigan City at the same rates as at Chicago.

The limits of this communication would not permit an enumeration of all the advantages to result to the State from the construction of a harbor on its northern borders, a few of them only have been alluded to. In asking Congress togrant to the Company a donation of lands, toaid in the construction of the harbor, the General Assembly would only be soliciting that numerous precedents furnished by land appropriations in aid of other public works should be followed. I respectfully recommend the passage of a joint resolution requesting Congress to make a donation of lands to aid in the completion of the work.
On motion of Mr. OYLER, the message was referred to a special committee of three.

div.head: COURT SESSIONS.
div.p: Mr. VAX BUSKIRK, by leave, introduced a bill [S. No. 242,] for An Act changing the time for holding Common Pleas Court.
Also, a bill [S. No. 243,] for A.n Act changing the times for holding the Circuit Courts in the Fourth Judicial Circuit.
Which were read the first time.

div.head: FEES AND SALARIES.
div.p: The Senate proceeded to the consideration of the special order for this hour, being the bill S. 126 to amend An Act regulating fees and salaries, approved March 2, 1855.

Mr. BENNETT said this was a people's bill, and explained why the advance in each particular fee is made. Where the bill refers to Prosecuting Attorney's fees, they are doubled. Constable's fees, in most of the particulars, named, are increased one-half; and so are the fees of Justice's of the Peace. Juror's and and witnesses' fees are increased about one-third, and the Coroners are allowed five cents for mileage.
Mr. MOORE moved to strike out all that refers to raising the per diem of County Commissioners.

Mr. NILES remarked that he opposed the bill for a general increase of fees and salaries which was pending at the last session; but the office of County Commissioner is a very important one and we need the best men we have among us to fill it. He did not think we ought to ask men competent for such an office to give their time to the public for less than five dollars a day.

Mr. ALLISON. The Commissioner is one of the most important, if not the most important office in the county, and unless you pay enough to command the attention of good men the result will be a bad management of county affairs.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT - yeas, 32; nays 11 - the amendment was laid on the table.
Mr. MASON moved to strike out "five" and insert "four" where it refers to the per diem of the County Commissioner.
On motion of Mr. BENNETT this amendment was laid on the table by yeas 22; nays 29.

Mr. COBB moved to strike out the fee allowed to prosecuting attorneys for appearing in divorce cases, where thev are not successful. If successful he was willing they should be paid for the defensethe present law makes it their duty to defend all such cases.
Mr. OYLER was favorable to the idea of giving the prosecuting attorney ten dollars if successful, and no fee if not successful.
Mr. BENNETT. There are no kind of cases in this State in which we are so much imposed on as these divorce cases, and we ought to have them attended to by the prosecuting attorney.
The amendment was agreed to.
Mr. WILLIAMS moved to strike out all that refers to prosecuting attorneys. He thought the fees already provided are ample.
Mr. OYLER hoped the amendment was not to be adopted.

Mr. McCLURG confessed, as a necessary order of things, in consequence of the meagre pay of prosecuting attorneys, that the office is filled with a third or fourth rate class of legal talent. This should be remedied; and he was, therefore, in favor of raising the fees of prosecuting attorneys in every possible way.
Mr. NILES believed an increase of fees were really due to prosecuting attorneys; that it would be productive of great public benefit if they were better paid.
The amendment was rejected upon a division - affirmative 16, negative 20.

Mr. BROWN, of Wells, moved to amend so that prosecuting attorneys shall receive a fee of $10 in all cases for Divorce. The law provides that the prosecuting attorney shall only appear where there is no attorney employed for the defense; and that only occurs in fraudulent divorce cases. This amendment would add another check to this class of cases.
On motion by Mr. OYLER the amendment was laid on the table.

Mr. BENNETT moved to amend by allowing the Prosecuting Attorney ten dollars if successful. This fee will come off of persons seeking divorces, and they are the ones who should pay and are generally willing to pay well.
Mr. NILES and Mr. MASON favored the amendment.
Mr. COBB doubted its propriety.

Mr. THOMPSON was anxious to see the divorce law of the State remodeled; but thought wrong to speak of parties who may apply for divorces as persons committing a crime. The avenues to justice on this point should be as open and as fair as in any other, and he opposed the blocking up of the way with any unnecessary fees.
The amendment was agreed to upon a division - Affirmative 20; negative 19.
Mr. DYKES moved to amend by increasing the jurors' fee from $1 50 to $2 00 per day.
Mr. BENNETT. There ought to be a difference between the fee of jurors who live in town and those who live in the country, and the proper way will be to add mileage to the fee.

Mr. ALLISON suggested the difficulty where a juror lives only a mile or two from town; in which case the mileage would amount to nothing, and yet the juror would have to board in town. He preferred $2 a day for them all, and then add mileage if Senators see fit.
The amendment was agreed to, by yeas 31, nays 12.
The bill was then ordered engrossed for the third reading.

div.head: OFFICES FOR STATE OFFICERS.
div.p: Pending the consideration of the bill just ordered to the engrossment, the Executive Messenger reported the following message from the Acting Governor:

opener.salute: To the Senate and House of Representatives:

div.p: I herewith respectfully transmit a communication from the Treasurer, Auditor and Secretary of State, and the Clerk of the Supreme Court, in relation to the exposed condition of the public records, archives and papers of the State, especially as pertaining to the offices of the Auditor, Treasurer and Secretary of State. In consideration of the inevitable burdens in the shape of taxation, which must be borne by the public for some years to come, I would gladly avoid, if a sense of duty would permit, any suggestion, the effect of which might be to increase the levy for State purposes. But when the extreme clanger of destruction to which the public records are now exposed, and the fact that the rents now paid for rooms and offices would in a few years procure safe depositories, and the additional fact that the value of these records oan not be estimated in dollars and cents are all considered, sound economy as well as duty to the public would seem to require that some action should speedily be taken to avert so great a calamity as the destruction of the archives of the State would be. It will be seen by the communication before referred to and herewith transmitted, that the State officers suggest two distinct plans for providing offices, without expressing a preference for either. One of these plans is to purchase the Banking House at the intersection of Illinois street and Kentucky avenue, the other to build new offices on the grounds owned by the State, immediately north of the State House. I have given the subject some consideration, and, in my judgment, safety, economy, and good policy would dictate the purchase of the building before mentioned, if it can be procured on reasonable terms. The consideration in its favor are that without any addition thereto, it is believed the building could be made to accommodate the Auditor, Treasurer and Secretary of State on the first floor, and furnish a room for each of the Judges of the Supreme Court and an audience room for their consultations and for the hearing of oral arguments, on the second floor. It also contains two superior vaults, in which the more valuable of the public records could be kept.
It is isolated and comparatively free from exposure to fire, and possessing a metallic roof in view of its position might almost be considered as fire proof.

By its purchase the public records could at once be removed to a place of security, the payment of rents for rooms and offices would at once cease, and the General Assembly would at the outset know the whole amount necessary to be expended to accomplish the object.

Besides all this if the lot and building should be purchased at a fair price and the State should hereafter not need the same, there is not even a remote probability that the property could not at any future time be sold for its original cost. If, however, on the other hand, the plan of building offices should be adopted, the building would not probably be completed short of a year from this time, during which rents would continue to be paid, and the public records would continue to be exposed to destruction. The expenditure also would doubtless be much greater than would be required to purchase the building before alluded to, and whatever the estimates might be, the ultimate actual cost of the building would be a matter of conjecture, and would never be ascertained until the work was completed. At my request a diagram has been prepared, showing the number and situation of the rooms and vaults of the Bank building before mentioned, and also the size and shape of the lot upon which it is situated, which diagram is herewith respectfully submitted. In view of the whole subject, I earnestly recommend that a Joint Committee of both Houses be at once appointed to visit and inspect the offices of the Auditor, Treasurer and Secretary of State, and their surroundings, to inquire into the amount of rents paid by these officers, and by the judges of the Supreme Court for their Chambers, and to consider the suggestions of the State officers contained in the communication herewith submitted, with instructions to the Committee to report at an early day in favor of such action as all the circumstances and the public interest may require.

closer.signed: CONRAD BAKER,Lieutenant Governor, Acting as Governor.

div.p: On motion by Mr. NILES, the message was referred to a Joint Committee of three Senators and five Representatives.

div.head: THE LIQUOR TRAFFIC.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem, laid before the Senate a communication from the Grand Camp of the Host of Templars, enclosing the draft of a bill they pray may be enacted as a Liquor Law, which was referred to the Committee on Temperance.

div.head: DISQUALIFYING VOTERS.
div.p: Mr. VAN BUSKIRK presented a petition from citizens of Decatur county praying for the passage of a law disfranchising person who deserted the country during the late war; which was read and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

div.head: JUSTICES OF THE PEACE.
div.p: Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on Organizations of Courts of Justice, returned Mr. Bonham's resolution (printed on page 69) with an adverse report, and recommending the passage of -
Senate Bill No. 244 for An Act to amend An Act for the election of Justices of the Peace, approved June 9, 1852, which was passed to the second reading.
[The bill gives one justice to each township one additional for each Incorporated town or city, and one additional for each township where the population exceeds ten thousand.]

div.head: SEWERS IN TOWNS.
div.p: Mr. BROWN, of Wells, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges of the Inhabitants of this State, returned the bill [S. No. 208] to provide for the construction of sewers in incorporated towns; recommending its passage with amendments.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time.
On motion by Mr. THOMPSON, the bill was recommitted to the Committee on Corporations.

div.head: TURNPIKES.
div.p: Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on Roads, returned the bill [S. 217] to amend An Act allowing County Boards to organize turnpike companies, etc., recommending its passage with amendments.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. CULLEN explained the importance of the early passage of the bill, and moved that it be considered as engrossed and read the third time now.

Mr. VAN BUSKIRK knew of a hardship or two that would be brought about by the passage of this bill, to which he would like to call the attention of the Committee; and therefore he would like to have the bill recommitted.
Mr. OYLER could see 110 good that would grow out of the delay; although he would not make any serious objection to the motion to recommit.

Mr. VAN BUSKIRK mentioned a case or two where this bill would operate unjustly. Persons living near a town or near where these roads converge - their property is liable to be taxed twice or thrice over without receiving a corresponding benefit. Then it would be well to have at least two grades of taxation; let the property within a half mile of the road be taxed a certain rate, and property between a half and a mile from the road, a lesser rate.

Mr. CULLEN. Efforts to make a graduated tax in such cases have so far failed - you cannot make a law that would be general and just on this subject, because the price of construction of roads differ in different localities. He would gladly co-operate with the Senator in an amendment that would obviate the difficulty mentioned.
After further remarks by Messrs. VAN BUSKIRK, CULLEN and MASON -
Mr. VAN BUSKIRK withdrew his expressed desire for a recommitment.
The motion to consider the bill engrossed being agreed to, it was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 40, nays 1.

div.head: SESSION HOURS.
div.p: On motion of Mr. BENNETT it was -
Ordered, That when the Senate adjourn it adjou ns till 9 o'clock to-morrow morning.

div.head: NEW JUDICIAL TRIALS.
div.p: Mr. MASON introduced a bill [S. No. 245] for An Act in relation to the admission of testimony of jurors in gran ting new trials,which was read the first time.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The SPEAKER tool the chair at nine o'clock A. M., and directed the roll call to determine a quorum; and a quorum being ascertained, he directed the clerk to read the Journal of yesterday.
On motion by Mr. SHUEY, the reading of the Journal was dispensed with.

div.head: MICHIGAN CITY HARBOR.
div.p: A message was now received from the Acting Governor, by Mr. Jacobs, his private Secretary, on the propriety of the passage of a Joint Resolution for a grant of land, to the company formed for that purpose, to aid in the construction of a harbor at Michigan City.
On motion by Mr. HIGGINS it was referred to a Special Committee of five.

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: Mr. CROOK presented a memorial from sundry citizens of Daviess county praying for a change in the law so as to require applicants for license to sell liquor to procure a majority of the legal voters to sign his application before license is granted; or that no license shall be granted where a majority remonstrate against it.
Mr. WOOD presented a similar petition from citizens of Lake county.
Mr. MEREDITH presented a similar memorial from citizens of Vigo county.
Mr. GLAZEBROOK presented a similar memorial, by Jeremiah E. Weaver and 122 other citizens of Bourbon, Marshal county.
Mr. JAMES present a similar memorial from sundry citizens of Grant county.
These were severally referred to the Committee on Temperance.

Mr. BOYD presented sundry memorials of workingmen of Vigo and other counties of the State, praying for a reduction of the hours of labor from ten hours to eight hours a day. These petitions are signed by ten thousand persons.
They were referred to the Committee on Agriculture.
Mr. BURWELL presented the memorial from the Commissioners of the county of Wells, for repeal of the soldiers' relief law, etc.
Mr. JOHNSON presented a similar memorial from the Commissioners of Jasper county.
Mr. MEREDITH presented a similar memorial from the Commissioners of Vigo county.
Mr. RHOADS presented a similar memorial.
This class of memorials were referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.
Mr. RICE presented a memorial for the repeal of the black laws, and for such legislation as will secure to the blacks the right of suffrage and the benefit of common schools.
It was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. BURTON presented the petition of Nathan Brown, an old and respected citizen of his county, who thinks he has discovered the true cause of milk-sick, asking the Legislature to make him a reward for his discovery. He moved to refer the memorial to a special committee of three with powers to investigate, etc.
Mr. KILGORE moved to lay the memorial on the table. He thought if this respectable old man had really made this valuable discovery, and was withholding it from the world, he must be a very bad man.
Mr. BURTON demanded the yeas and nays.
Mr. KILGORE then withdrew the motion.
Mr. SULLIVAN, of Scott, proposed to increase the number of the committee to five.
It was so ordered.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. MILLER, from the Committee on Ways and Means, returned Mr. Ferris' soldiers' relief repeal bill [H. R. 213.] with sundry amendments, substituting new matter.
The report lies on the table.

div.head: JOHN GREGORY.
div.p:
Mr. TRUSSLER, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned Mr. Gregory of Warren's
bill [H. R. 169] to legalize the acts of John Gregory, Notary Public, recommending indefinite postponement.
The bill was postponed accordingly.

div.head: FOREIGN EXECUTORS.
div.p: Mr. KILGORE, from the same Committee., returned Mr. Miller's bill [H. R. 91.] to direct the discharge of bonds given by foreign executors and guardians upon application to sell real estate, recommending indefinite postponement.

Mr. MILLER. There was no way undar our laws by which a foreign executor' can be released from his bonds. The bill was drawn by a respectable citizen of his county, and he thought it deserved consideration.
The House refused to postpone,and the report lies on the table.

Mr. RICE, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned Mr. Spencer's bill [H. R. 166] to amend section 148 of the act of June 14, 1852, for the settlement of decedents estates, recommending indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: WIDOWS.
div.p: Mr. R. also returned Mr. Thacher's bill [H. R. 157] to amend section 21 of the act regulating descents, &c., approved May 14,1852, recommending indefinite potponement. He said it was the opinion of the committee that the widow is already entitled to the deficit of the three hundred dollars out of the real estate if there is not enough of the personal.
Mr. SHUEY. It was the opinion of the courts and lawyers in his district, that the widow is hot so entitled; and where the law is doubtful he thought we ought to enact one that is positive.
Mr. LASSELLE. A decision of the Supreme Court under the law of 1843 (similar to the present law,) is to the effect that the widow is not entitled to this deficit out of the realty.
Mr. BUSKIRK. But had not the Supreme Court more recently decided that the widow is entitled to the dificit of $800 out of any money on hand, or out of money derived from the sale of real estate?
Mr. LASSELLE thought not.
Mr. SPENCER concurred with Mr. Buskirk.
Mr. BROWN was of the same opinion. A rightful interpretation of the Statutes could lead to no other conclusion. He was opposed to encumbering the Statutes with matter that makes no change in the law.

Mr. LASSELLE. Judge Stuart, of his district, was of opinion that the widow is not entitled to the deficit of $300 out of the realty. He gave instances of hardships to widowrs under the present law. He would give her this $300 at all events. He moved that the bill be referred to a select committee of three.
It was so ordered.

div.head: FOREIGN EXECUTORS.
div.p: Mr. MEREDITH suggested, a return to the vote by which the House concurred in the indefinite postponement of Mr. Spencer's bill. He did not want to slaughter bills without consideration.
Mr. SPENCER, Mr. GREGORY of Warren and Mr. HUMPHREYS each spoke to the matter.
Mr. SPENCER moved a reconsideration of the vote by which the House concurred in the report.

Mr. RICE said that the Committee had reported adversely to the bill because the fees of the administrator ($1 50 a day) were inadequate. Where there was inadequate pay, you could not get competent men. The executor or administrator should be paid according to the amount of the estate and the intricacies attending the settlement.
Mr. SPENCER said an amendment could be made in regard to compensation. A Committee could fix the fees as well as the Court.

Mr. BROWN. What becomes of the fees when the estate will not pay them? He did not think that the Legislature could properly fix a rate of compensation; the duties were so various. In one case the estate may be able to pay, and in another, where the labor is the same, the estate is not able to pay. The law should be that the judges should make allowances to the lawyers and administrators in the settlement of estates. Lie thought we had better introduce a resolution discharging the Judiciary Committee and referring the bill to the gentleman from Posey (Mr. Spencer.) He moved to lay the motion to reconsider on the table.
It was so ordered - affirmative 66, negative 9.
The Speaker now announced the following Special Committee on Mr. Thacher's bill [H. R. 157], namely: Messrs. Lasselle, Miller and Humphreys.

div.head: RAILROADS.
div.p: Mr. SIM submitted the following:

As the opinion of this Legislature, that one of the greatest dangers impending on the country arise? From the general tendency to the centralizaion of power, aud the consolidation of wealth in the hands of large corporations, wholly irresponsible to the people;

Resolved, That such a tendency is daily illustrated among us in the mangement of railroad incorporations throughout the country, who, combining and confederating together, have advanced rates to such an extent as to be extortionate upon the traveling and trading community.

Resolved, That it is the duty of the present Legislature to take immediate measures to protect the public from the combinations, consolidations and extortions of the different railroad companies of the State, and to that end they should fix a reasonable tariff of charges for all roads, and compel them to receive and transport freight in the order it may be offered, and without favoritism of any kind, and in default thereof their charter should be declared forfeited to the use of the State.
It was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. WOODS made an ineffectual motion to reconsider this vote.

div.head: NORTHERN PRISON.
div.p: Mr. GRIFFITH moved for leave of absence for the Committee on the Northern State Prison from Tuesday till Thursday next.
After debate on the propriety of the Committee going up to the Northern Prison, in which Messrs. CHURCH, BUSKIRK, BURWELL, GRIFFITH and BROWN, took part.
On motion, by Mr. BROWN, the application for leave of absence was laid on the table.

div.head: NATHAN BROWN.
div.p: The SPEAKER announced the Special Committe on the memorial of Nathan Brown, namely - Messrs. Branham, Sullivan, of Scott, and Burton.

div.head: NORTHERN PRISON.
div.p:
Mr. KILGORE, moved to reconsider the
vote by which the House refused leave of absence to the Committee on the Northern State Prison.

Mr. NEWCOMB thought there was no necessity to send up the Committee. We could just as well tell here whether the contract on that prison is extortionate or not. He was prepared to vote against the appropriation proposed.
Mr. CHURCH moved to lay the motion to reconsider on the table.
It was so ordered - yeas 51, nays 34.

div.head: T. W. O. BRAFFITT.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House the resignation of Capt. T. W. O. Braffitt, assistant clerk, to take effect to-morrow - he having been tendered the place of cashier of one of the Richmond Banks.

div.head: THIRTEENTH ARTICLE.
div.p: The SPEAKER now announced the special order, viz: the consideration of Mr. Meredith's joint resolution [H. R. No. 1] proposing to amend the Constitution of the State of Indiana, by striking out the thirteenth article thereof - the question being on the second reading.

Mr. MEREDITH being entitled to the floor, tread a speech in favor of the joint resolution and in reply to the opening speech in the debate by Mr. Buskirk. He contended that the opinions of members of the Constitutional Convention could not guide us now in legislation on the negro question. John Pettit had changed his views on this question. He was now a petitioner before this House for the repeal of the Black laws. Mr. Blythe had also changed, and there was little doubt but if Mr. Rariden had lived to this day, he would stand with Mr. Pettit to-day on this question. Wise men sometimes change their minds - fools never. Since the time of the Constitutional Convention, slavery had made war on the Union, and now all the loyalty of the land are determined to dispose of the institution at once and forever. Where was the justice in trampling on the rights of the negro? They were God-given, and should be held sacred by all honorable men. It had been suggested that all that is required on this question is the abrogation of the laws made in pursuance of this 13th Article; but he would have the abrogation of the article itself. He deprecated the disabilities of the negroes under the black laws, from considerations drawn from the heroic valor evinced by them in the war which has put down the late rebellion. He combatted the proposition of Mr. Buskirk, that the two races could not live together prosperously. The negro should at least have the right to make contracts, and to have a home on our soil. Not long since the gentleman's party alleged that the negro was worthless in war; but now he was alarmed at his prowess - alarmed at a vision of the negro host charging upon him for social equality and amalgamation. The repeal of this article would not give the negro the right of suffrage, nor the benefit of the common schools. In conclusion, he rehearsed the tedious routine through which a proposition to amend the Constituion would have to pass, before the object could be consummated, alleging that it was a measure evidently dictated by the civilization of the age:
Mr. LOCKHART demanded the previous question.
Mr. PRATHER and Mr. BUSKIRK desired the gentleman to withdraw the demand.
Mr. LOCKHART acquiesced.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren,renewed the demand for the previous question.
Mr. BROWN submitted that the proper mode of amendment to the Constitution was by a concurrent resolution; not by a joint resolution.
Mr. COFFROTH demanded the yeas and nays.
Mr. HIGGINS made the point of order that the yeas and nays could not be taken on a demand for the previous question.
The SPEAKER (Mr. Miller in the Chair) held that the point was well taken.
Mr. BROWN appealed from the decision of the Chair.
Mr. GREGORY of Warren, withdrew the demand.
Mr. NEWCOMB moved to postpone the further consideration of the special order till seven o'clock P. M.
Mr. GRIFFITH and Mr. LOPP opposed the motion.
The motion to postpone was rejected - affirmative 47; negative 34.
Mr. RHOADS demanded the previous question.
Mr. BROWN demanded the yeas and nays.
The SPEAKER decided the demand for the yeas and nays to be out of order.
Mr. BROWN appealed
Mr. NEMCOMB deprecated the gag and cutting off debate on these important questions.
Mr. BUSKIRK stated that the yeas and nays were admissible on seconding the previous question, but not on the next succeeding question, viz: Shall the main question be now put?
The SPEAKER thereupon changed the ruling, and the yeas and nays were ordered, and being taken, the House refused to second the previous question - yeas, 17; nays, 72.
