Jacobs, his private Secretary, transmitting a communication from the Treasurer, Auditor and Secretary of State, and the Clerk of the Supreme Courts, relative to the exposed condition of the papers and archives of the State; recommending the purchase of the bank building, lately occupied by the Bank of the State, for their better security.]

Mr. HARRISON said: As one of the minority of the Committee on Constitutional Amendments, I deem it due to myself, and especially to the constituency that I have the honor in part to represent, that I should state my objections to the passage of the Joint Resolution under consideration. The resolution proposes an amendment to the Constitution of the State, by striking from that instrument the Thirteenth Article thereof, which prohibits negroes or mulattos from coming into, or settling in the State after its adoption. A period of about fourteen years has elapsed since the article inaugurating this policy was separately submitted to a vote of the peopto under the title of Exclusion and Colonization of Negroes. It is matter of history how emphatically it was approved by the popular voice, there being over ninety thousand majority
in its favor. There are two questions that naturally arise in the argument of this question. First, what were the circumstances existing at the time that rendered its adoption necessary? And secondly, do not the same circumstances and necessity that existed at that time still exist?

The answer to the first question as to why existing circumstances rendered the adoption of the 13th article of the Constitution necessary? can perhaps better be found in the debates and arguments of many of the very able men who were members of the Constitutional Convention than elsewhere, and certainly than in anything that I might say. The gentleman from Monroe (Mr. Buskirk) in his very able speech on Tuesday last, quoted and set forth at some length extracts from several of the speeches and arguments of some of the ablest members of the Convention, and I shall not attempt to elaborate upon the circumstances and reasons assigned by them for their action in recommending the adoption of a constitutional policy so clearly conducive to the separation and ultimate prosperity of both races, further than that the circumstances then existing demanded (as in my humble judgment they still do) that Indiana should not be flooded and overrun with a vagabond population of negroes and mulatoes, to their own detriment and well-being, to corrupt, contaminate and demoralize our people, and to compete with and degrade the labor of our foreign-born white citizens. I do not propose to argue the question of the inferiority of the negro; that can be better done by some one more competent to the task. I believe it is a conceded fact that human nature is the same at all times, and that truth is immutable and unchangeable. Ethnology, or the history of the different races of men, has assigned to the negro a place in the scale of human intelligence, of progress and of civilization, from which human laws and association can not exempt him. I, sir, am not one of those, if any such there be, who hate and despise the negro, because of his inferiority and his color, for the very good reason, that that is something he is not responsible for. Had he have been consulted in that regard, it would perhaps have been ordered otherwise. The Preamble to the Constitution sets forth briefly and concisely its objects and purposes, in these words: To the end that justice be established, public order maintained, and liberty perpetuated; "We, the People of the State of Indiana, grateful to Almighty God for the free exercise of the right to choose our own form of Government, do ordain this Constitution.

Will justice be more securely established, public order more effectually maintained, or liberty more permanently perpetuated, by striking from the Constitution the 13th Article thereof? It does seem to me, Sir, that no better plan could be devised to produce public disorder, disorganize society, and to spread demoralization among our people, than to increase our negro population. The adoption of the joint resolution under consideration, will most assuredly have that efffect by breaking down the constitutional barrier and inviting hither swarms of this worthless class of persons to us. In an economical and industrial point of view, this measure is inexpedient and can not be desirable to our people. The industry and labor of the North should be fostered and protected, and not embarrassed and degraded by an element of this kind.

The labor of our foreign white population and increase of all our white population is profitable in the North, while the labor of the negro is profitable in the South, and is not in the North, hence it is the manifest interest of both sections, and both races, that the negro remain in the South where the climate is congenial to him and where his labor cannot well be dispensed with. His Excellency, the Governor, in his message both at the regular and present session, recommended the establishment of a Bureau of Foreign Emigration in Europe, with an agency attached, in order to facilitate emigration to our State, in order to supply a deficiency among our laboring classes. In view of this the adoption of the resolution under consideration is not in my judgment advisable, for the reason that this measure will be an obstacle in the way of foreign emigration to our State. The industrious German and Irish emigrant would not regard our State as a favorable location when they learn that their labor will come in competition with and will be degraded by the labor of the negro. If,however,the resolution must pass at this time, I would suggest that it is defective and does riot go far enough,it should have recommended a Bureau of Negro Emigration in the Southern States, in order to meet and counteract the Foreign Bureau of Emigration recommended by His Excellency the Governor. I am aware that it is assumed by some that negroes are citizens. I deny the assumption that they are citizens of this State, much less are they citizens of the United States. The term citizen is defined by Webster in these words: In the United States, a person native or naturalized, who has the privilege of exercising the elective franchise, or the qualifications which enable him to vote for rulers, and to purchase and hold real estate.

The supposed necessity for the passage of the resolution, I presume, is that if slavery is not abolished, it will be by the ratification of the proposed amendment to the Constitution of the United States, by three-fourths of the States; incase the constitutional amendment is so ratified and the status of the negro shall be defined and settled by Congress, in that event the negroes would become citizens under such disabilities as the States respectively might by law impose. It will be time enough, for us strike from our Constitution the 13th article, after the amendment to the Constitution of the United States abolishing Slavery shall have been ratified by three-fourths of the States; at any rate, sufficient unto the day - in my judgment - is the evil thereof.

In conclusion permit me to say that Indiana is, and always has been, a loyal State in the Union. The reconstruction policy of the Federal Executive, does not in any manner require immediate legislation on our part in this matter. The question of the reconstruction of the governments of the States lately in rebellion, the pacification of the people thereof, will, for a considerable time, agitate the public mind in both sections, and will, for some time, occupy the attention of Congress. The scourge of civil war has to some extent impeded the advancement of the material elements that are essential to the growth and
prosperity of the State. Indiana has, during all this time, enjoyed a degree of prosperity equal to that of any odier State in the Union. The minority of the Committee in their report, state that the passage of the joint resolution under consideration is inexpedient. How are the circumstances different now as regards the 'negro, from what they were at the adoption of the Constitution, and what has occurred that makes the proposed change necessary or desirable by the people ? I, sir, recognize the fact that slavery has been virtually destroyed and abolished by the war, and I, for one, would not aid in restoring it, if such a thing were possible. Yet we have, during the present session, been told by high authority in this Hall, that slavery is'not yet abolished. If this be true, and I am inclined to think it is, as a legal proposition, the status of the negro is yet to be determined by the reconstruction policy of the Executive and by Congress.

div.head: CAPTAIN T. W. O. BRAFFITT.
div.p: Mr. LOCKHART presented the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That T. W. O. Braffitt, upon retiring from the position of Assistant Clerk, has the thanks and confidence of the House of Representatives for the gentlemanly and faithful manner in which he has discharged his duties.
Mr. MILROY made an ineffectual motion for an order to furnish Gavin & Herd's Statutes to new members.

div.head: EMPLOYES BELOW.
div.p: Mr. HENRICKS said he had a communication from the Librarian, stating that certain employes in the cellar have not been placed on the record. He asked leave, therefore, to offer the following:

Resolved That the namss of those persons appointed to the furnace and wood department be furnished to the Librarian, their compensation to begin on Tuesday, November 10 and that they be placed ou the list of the employes of the House.
Mr. STRINGER made an ineffectual motion to refer the resolution to the Committee on Employes.
It was then adopted.
On motion of Mr. COFFROTH the House then took a recess till two o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER announced the special order for this hour, viz: The consideration of Mr. Pettit's bill [H. R. 156] imposing on the clerks of the several Circuit Courts the duty of preparing applications for back pay, for back pay, and bounties, balance of bounties, half-pay and pensions, creating a State Agent for soldiers' claims represent the same; imposing on certain officers, the duty of preparing and certifying documentary evidence in connection with such memorials, prescribing the duties of such officers, and imposing penalties for violating their duties.
The Clerk read the amendments proposed by the Select Committee on the 22d inst.

The amendments prescribe, 1st, An additional compensation of one dollar if they supply additional or supplemental evidence. 2d, If the evidence is obtained outside of the State, the expense incurred shall be at once repaid to the Clerk by the County Treasurer out of the general fund. 3d,The postage, etc., incurred by the clerks in perfecting such applications to be paid out of the proper treasuries of the county. 4th, Said clerks to prepare applications for receiving pensions. To administer the oaths, take the acknowledgment thereof, authenticate and transmit the same to the proper pension agent, receive the amount due and deliver the same on request to the person entitled thereto - the fee 50 cents. 5, It shall be the duty of said clerks to expeditiously inform the party interested when he is notified of a requirement of another application or additional evidence. 6th, A State Agent for Military Claims, to be appointed by the Governor, to reside at Indianapolis, whose office shall continue till the first of January, 1867, at a compensation of one hundred and fifty dollars a month, etc. 7th, An emergency clause.
Amend the title by inserting after the word "pensions," "Receiving and delivering certificates of back pay, bounty, half pay, pensions and pension money.

Mr. PETTIT (Mr. Henricks in the Chair,) said: he would attempt to indicate what was meant to be accomplished by this bill. It had resulted from a conference of many gentlemen who had been actively connected with the official service of the State. In contemplation of what is still wanted of public benificence to the soldier, it had been proposed that a bill should be brought in furnishing simpler means of making payment of what is due to them from the Government. By the provisions of the bill those applications have their beginnings through the Circuit Clerks; they are then transmitted to Washington, and when allowance is made, whether for half pay, back pay, bounty or pension, the returns of the certificates must go to the soldier's own home. It proposed to make each of the clerks of the Circuit Court an officer for these purposes. The prepared papers are transmitted, not directly into the Department at Washington, but to the State Agent there, who will gain time to the agent in case there be any inaccuracy in the application. This was what was proposed by the bill - a simple process. It prescribes the duties of these public officers so strictly that it would seem they would not, if they could, avoid their performance. Without expressing here any estimate of how much might have been gained by the pessage of this bill a year ago. He thought it might Ibe said to be of great advantage to our returned soldiers, for he was informed that perhaps as many as thirty or forty thousand applications for claims for back pay, bounty, pensions, and pension money, will arise in the State in the course of the present year; and he did not hesitate to say that .he cost to this large number of claimants will be about ten dollars apiece, which runs up the immense total of three hundred or four hundred thousand dollars loss diminished from the beneficence of the Government toward our soldiers; and in as many as four instances out of five, the persons from whose allowance these sums are taken, are the least able to afford the loss of any considerable amount of money. It was proposed to institute this system to exhibit a proper sense of gratitude to our brave, suffering soldiers on the part of the State, and at the same time add but little to the burdens, of the State.

This work was to be done by existing public officers. There was now an agent of State paid
out of the military fund at Washington. This bill proposes another agent at Washington, - and there will be an oath for fidelity - so that the expense to the State will hardly be enlarged, and will save to the soldiers and their families no inconsiderable amounts. The pledges of the State to the soldier would hardly be redeemed as they ought to be. if we allow any considerable diminution of their pay in the process of collecting. The fee to the Clerk is $2,00, - in no case (when there is additional labor) - shall it exceed $3.00. He would have been better pleased with a bill admitting of no expense to the applicant.

Mr. BURWELL thought the bill unnecessary if not impracticable. First, it proposes to make claim agents of the county clerks, arid they would have to take out license. It was also a proposition to make an attorney of a county officer. This was impracticable, because the great majoruV of claimants would still make their applications through an attorney who has been made a claim agent. And as to facility, the applications were attended to in their turn in the Pension Bureau: and notices of imperfections in the forms could be transmitted with the same facility to the attorney as to the clerk. There would be nothing gained in time by the appointment of a State agent, or agents, at an expense of $ 1,800, and $2,500. This bill would also devolve dxpense upon the counties. It would be a fine thing for' the State Printer, supplying blanks; and it would be a fine thing for some young man aspiring to the position of State agent. He recited two failures of applications which he had made through the Military State agent. Soldiers and their widows will not make their applications through the State agent, but they will apply through their attorneys at home, in whom they have confidence, and upon whom they can have recourse in case of fraud or default. There might have been a necessity for these agencies during the war, but now since the war has closed, there was no juet pretext for them whatever.

Mr. SPENCER, The original bill provides an agency at Washington at $2,500, with office rent, clerk hire, etc. The amended bill provides agents both at Washington and Indianapolis, with rent and clerks - the cost of the two offices would be '$4,300 a year - the clerks agd perquisites would amount to $20,000 or $30,000 annually. He objected to this Provost Marshal system, unless it were extended to every Congressional District. He recited the lawful' manner of doing this business b means of claim agents duly commissioned submitted other objections to the bill.

Mr. HUMPHREYS objected to the fifth section of the bill, and generally to the extent and expensiveness of its machinery. He would have a bill for the benefit of claimants, not for the benefit of attorneys. He could not vote for the bill as it now stands.

Mr. KILGORE said he wanted to see the bill pass. He had been some time in the business, of collecting soldiers'claims; thought this bill a decided improvement on the old law, and considered it necessary. In his opinion, it would expedite the collection of claims. He said irresponsible men all over the State were engaged in collecting claims who would in many cases abscond with the money. He cited the fact that he brought to this city an order on one of these agents for $250 for one of his friends, and on going to his office, he found said agent had left, carrying away with him a large amount of money thus collected. He regretted that all these objections to the bill came from lawyers. But we should not forget the soldier in a selfish desire to promote our own advantage.

Mr. MILLER should have voted for the bill at the time it was introduced; but the war having closed, and the soldiers returned and under the influence of their friends, in far the greater number of cases, applications would be made through regular agents. If the objections came from lawyers, the advocates of the bill were lawyers also. He instanced the small attention that is paid to the Sanitary Commission agency, to show the impracticability of the bill. Would it save anything to the soldiers? The system was to be supported by taxation, and taxes were paid by soldiers as well as others. Again, there was not one clerk out of a dozen that would be qualified to make out the papers, and not one in a dozen would be entrusted with an application. He would vote for a bill requiring attorneys to make out claimants' papers without charge. He also summed up the expense at Washington at $4,000. Then coming back here the blanks must be made out in Indianapolis, though he supposed they could be obtained without charge, of the Government at Washington. The different orders of blanks would cost a vast amount - separate forms to each of the 95 clerks of the several counties. He would do anything for the soldier. The debt to the soldiers could never be overpaid. But he opposed the bill, because he thought that instead of benefitting the soldiers it would benefit the officials in those bureaus.

Mr. CHURCH. Much that remains to be done in this claims business was on account of irregularity in the papers. He favored the bill, because of these irregularities it was necessary to have somebody here at Indianapolis where the records are. There was also a necessity for an agent at Washington to facilitate applications. So that, perhaps, the delay of years might be prevented. He saw no more difficulty in a clerk qualifying himself for this business, than for three or four lawyers to do the same thing. He was not certain but the State could get all their blanks for the benefit of the soldier free of charge, at the department at Washington. So that objection was disposed of. He showed how the bill would save expense to the soldier. He controverted Mr. Burwell's allegation that the county clerk, under this bill, would have to take out a license and pay $10 for it.
Mr. SPENCER sustained it.

Mr. CHURCH stated other cases of delay likely to occur where this business is done by attorneys. Then it was necessary that this bill should be passed in order that the claims in the hands of the Sanitary Commission might be completed.
Mr. MILROY objected to the bill on the score of economy. He was opposed to any measure that would increase the number of State officers

Mr. LISTON was opposed to the bill - thinking that it was expensive, without corresponding benefit. Claim agencies in Indiana were played out. It were better for each claimant to
pay $10 to his lawyer, than for the State to go to the expense of the machinery of this bill. It would not facilitate the progress of claims. That could be done only by increasing the clerical force in the proper Departments at Washington.

Mr. WRIGHT said his experience was, that State Agents' acts were far more readily attended to than a mere letter from an agent at home. It was but justice to the maimed soldiers, that this bill should pass. It might cost something, but we at home, and the soldier who has returned safe, would not grudge the pittance that will relieve the applicant for back pay. He would as soon trust the State Agent at Washington or at Indianapolis as his own county lawyer. He supposed they would be friends and lovers of the soldiers, and lovers of the cause in which the soldiers have been engaged.

Mr. BROWN had held throughout, that the men engaged in the war should be supported without respect to the political leaders that brought on the collision and conducted it afterwards. It was a grave public duty. He would give freely in this direction; and the question was, is this bill for the benefit of the soldier? He took the view of the gentleman from Jefferson (Mr. Listen.) The claim business was played out. What remains of this business is what relates to pensions; and he showed that no lawyer need be employed to do this. Any soldier had sense enough to draw his own pension money. He recited the routine of applications for claims in Washington: and that the the time necessarily expended in the Indiana agency at Washington would be so much clear lost time for the applicant. He saw no use for an additional State agent at the capitol of the State, - the business being now as well done by the Adjutant General. He recognized his duty to curtail public expenses; but if it were of advantage to these claimants, he would not oppose the bill on account of its cost. So far as the legal profession is concerned, he cared nothing about that in connection with this claims business. It was no part of the business of the profession to wait on claims.

Mr. RICE. The object of the bill was for the benefit of the soldier - will it accomplish the purpose? He showed that it might do the applicant positive harm. It would throw back the business which is now detained in the Department an account of informalities. It required a high order of legal talent in this business. It was a great wrong to throw the soldiers upon the clerks of the counties for the adjustment of their unfinished business in so many cases as where the clerk has been opposed to the war, and where he is incompetent. It was also throwing a burden on the County Clerks without adequate compensation, it would work injustice to the clerks as well as to the soldiers. He would allow these claimants to go to those in whom they have confidence.

Mr. GLEASON referred to the fact that there were many intricate claims coming forward, requiring a high order of legal talent. If so, was not that an argument calling for the aid of the State in the matter of expense? He thought it was a mistake that there was little or nothing remaining of this claims business. There were many inaccuracies requiring investigation of the record. Something like this bill he thought was necessary, and should be passed.

Mr. CHURCH. As to the legal acumen necessary in this business, the information was in the hands of the agents at Indianapolis and Washington, These can communicate with the clerks as well as the lawyers and agents at home.
Mr. GRIFFITH made an ineffectual motion for an evening session - affirmative 38 negative 40.
Mr. HOOVER demanded the previous question.

Mr. PETTIT (entitled to close the debate) said he was more and more confirmed in his opinion of this bill. The most forcible objection was urged by Mr. Humphreys, as to the machinery. There was another like to it mentioned by Mr. Miller and Mr. Brown, that the bill was too late. Why, sir, we have eighteen regiments still in the service of the United States. Then there were 83,000 of the hospital wrecks and their heirs, and the heirs of many that have fallen by the hand of guerrillas. He submitted, also, that ten per cent. of the the claims already presented had been abandoned on account of the incompetency of agents. It was true that the straight claims business had been disposed of. His bill took hold of the worst wrecks of the war - the prisoners of Andersonville - stripped of everything. This business ought to be entrusted to those who are able to see that the rights of these men are respected. The bill would save to the soldier twenty-five per cent. of his thirteen dollars per month, which he would pay to his attorney, for doing simply that which the Government does for the soldier. He gave particulars of the intricacies of obtaining matter essential to establish a claim. In reply to Mr. Litson, he stated that it was a rule at Washington, that individual claim agents should be excluded from the records. It was not so as to a State Agent. He stated this upon the information of a gentleman familiar with these things at Washington. The State Agent would not be acting as a lawyer, simply to promote the interests of claimants, but to aid the Government to do what is right; and so, it was his information, that claims would be realized in three or four weeks. It was an important purpose of the bill to keep proper persons here and at Washington beside the military records to furnish the necessary information to complete the papers for claims. Then there was the advantage of having an officer of character over that of an irresponsible clerk. The bill comes in fulfillment of the pledges which we gave to our men when we called upon them to enlist.
Mr. BURWELL asked whether the machinery for information in the Adjutant General's Office would be continued after the passage of this bill?

Mr. PETTIT. There being nothing more for him to do, the Adjutant General would of course discharge his clerk. It were better not to expend so much of the military fund, but name the officers ourselves.
Mr. MILLER. To whom were these Sanitary Agents responsible? When does their term expire?

Mr. PETTIT. The functions of the Sanitary Commission will expire on the first of
January; and he thought the whole people of the State ought to rise up in acknowledgement of the valuable service it had performed. When he had concluded he renewed the demand for the previous question.
The demand was seconded, and the main question was ordered.
The bill was then again ordered to engrossement and third reading, and read the third time.
The bill failed for want of a constitutional majority - yeas 47, nays 34 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Atkinson, Bonner, Boyd, Rurnes, Church, Cowgill, Cox, Crook, Davidson, Ferris, Foulke, Gleason, Gregory of Montgomery, Gregory of Warren, Griffith, Groves, Hamnck, Henricks Hershey, Hogate, Hoover, Howard, James, Johnson, Kilgore, Lane, Litton, Lockhart, McVey, Newcomb, Olleman, Patterson, Prather, Reese, Riford, Sabin, Shuey, Sim, Stewart, Sullivan of Posey and Vanderburg, Trusler, Veach, Welch, Sim, Woods, Zeigler and Mr Speaker - 47.

NAYS - Messrs Abbett. Brown, Burton, Butwell Caldwell, Colling, Glazebrook, Goodman, Gregg, Hargrove, Humphreys, Hunt, Lee, Lemon, Lopp, Milroy, O'Brien, Osborn, Perigo, Pinney, Rhoads, Rice, Richardson, Roach, Shoaff of Jay, Spencer, Stenger, Stringer, Stuckey, Sullivan of Scott, Weikel, White and Woodruff - 34

Mr. LITSON explaining his vote said: His remarks a while ago were made for the purpose of suggesting amendments. He was in favor of the principle of the bill, but as it seems to be the determination of its friends to give us this bill or none at all, I'll take what I can get. I vote aye.
Mr. LANE made an ineffectual motion for a recess till 7 1/4 o'clock.
The SPEAKER, (Mr. Hendricks in the chair,) laid before the House a report from the Auditor of State.
Mr. KILGORE moved an order, which was adopted, to go into the election of an Assistant Clerk of the House to-morrow morning at 11 o'clock.
And then, on his motion, the House (at 5.15 p. M.) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem, called to order at 9. o'clock.
On motion by Mr. GIFFORD, the reading of the Secretary's minutes of yesterday was dispensed with.
Mr. BENNETT made an ineffectual motion to consider bills on the third reading.

div.head: LEAVE OF ABSENCE
div.p: Was obtained for Mr. Corbin till Wednesday, and for Messrs. Barker and Noyes till Tuesday.

div.head: SELECT COMMITTEES.
div.p: The PRESIDENT, pro tem., announced the following committees: On the Michigan City Harbor - Messrs. Oyler, Niles, Corbin, Noyes and Hanna. On Offices for State Officers - Messrs. Mles, Cobb and Bennett, on the part of the Senate.

div.head: STATIONERY FOR MEMBERS.
div.p: Mr. MOORE offered a resolution, reque sting the State Librarian to furnish stationery to members at what the same can be purchased for at the book stores of this city.
After more than a half hour's debate -
On motion of Mr. BONHAM the resolution was laid on the table - yeas, 27; nays, 12.

div.head: POSTAGE STAMPS.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem, stated in behalf of the Doorkeeper that the Auditor of State declines issuing a warrant on the Treasury under the resolution last adopted by the Senate for postage stamps, and wants to be justified by having the resolution differently worded.

On motion by Mr. BENNETT - he considering the resolution unnecessary as Senators have already voted themselves three dollars worth of stamps - the vote adopting the resolution was reconsidered and it was then laid on the table.

div.head: COMMON SCHOOLS.
div.p: Mr. VAWTER offered a resolution which was adopted, directing the Finance Committee to inquire into the expediency of amending the school law concerning text books, the length of the term of free schools, etc.

div.head: FARMERS AND MECHANICS INSURACE COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. ALLISON offered a bill [S. No. 246] for An Act to repeal section 17 of "An Act incorporating the Farmers and Mechanics Insurance Company," approved January 26, 1850; which was read the first time - again by title and referred to the Committee on Corporations.

div.head: PLANK, GRAVEL AND MACADAMIZED ROADS.
div.p: Mr. CULLEN introduced a bill [S. No. 247] for An Act authorizing Plank, Macadamized and Gravel Road Companies to appropriate earth, stone, timber, gravel, sand, etc.; which was read the first timeagain by title and referred to the Committee on Roads.

div.head: ANIMALS AT LARGE.
div.p: Mr. CULVER introduced a bill [S. No. 248] to restrain from running at large certain animals herein named - [cattle, sheep, swine, horses, etc] - which was read the first time.

div.head: CANALS FOR HYDRAULIC PURPOSES.
div.p: Mr. DYKES introduced a bill [S. No. 249] for An Act defining the powers of Companies authorized to construct canals for hydraulic purposes; which was read the first time - again by title and referred to the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements.

div.head: TAXATION OF RAILROADS.
div.p: Mr. NILES introduced a bill [S. No. 250] for An Act to secure a just valuation of R. R. property in this State for assessment and taxation; which wTas read the first time - again by title and referred to the Special Committee on R., Rs. - Mr. Niles being added to that Committee

div.head: HIGHWAYS.
div.p: Mr. VAWTER introduced a bill [S. No. 251] for an act to amend sections fifteeen and twenty-four of the Highway Act, approved June 17, 1852, which was read the first time.

div.head: MANUFACTURING AND MINING.
div.p: Mr. CASON introduced a bill [S. No. 252] for an act to amend section two of "An Act for the incorporation of Manufacturing and Mining Companies," etc., by extending the provisions of said section to similar companies heretofore organized, and legalizing conveyances heretofore received by such companies for such purposes; which was read the first time - again by title and referred to the Committee on Corporations,

div.head: COUNTY OFFICERS.
div.p: Mr. McCLURG introduced a bill [S. No. 253] to relieve county officers in certain cases for the year 1865, for violation of the provisions of An Act concerning sheep killing dogs, etc., which was read the first time.

div.head: THE STATE TREASURY.
div.p: Mr. CULVER introduced a bill [S. No. 254] for An Act to amend Sec. 2 of "An Act to provide a Treasury System for the State of Indiana," etc., [adding these words: "or National Ranks regularly organized under the Laws of the United States"] which was read the first time, - again by the title and referred to the Committee on Finance.

div.head: ORGANIZATION OF RELIGIOUS SOCIETIES.
div.p: Mr. COBB introduced a bill [S. No. 255] for An Act to amend Sec. 2 of "An Act supplemental to An Act for the incorporation of high schools" etc., which was read the first time.

div.head: EVANSVILLE.
div.p: Mr. ALLISON introduced a bill [S. No. 256] for An Act to amend the charter of the city of Evansville; which was read the first time again by title, and referred to the Committee on Corporations.

div.head: PRIVATE CEMETERIES.
div.p: Mr. BENNETT introduced a hill [S. No. 257] for An Act for the establishment and preservation of private cemeteries, etc., which was read the first time - again by title, and referred to the Committee on the Rights and Privileges of the Inhabitants of the State.

div.head: DECEDENTS' ESTATES.
div.p: Mr. HANNA introduced a bill [S. No. 258] to amend section 96 of An Act for the settlement of decedents' estates, etc., approved June 17, 1852, which was read the first time - again by title, and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

div.head: OATH OF CHALLENGED VOTERS.
div.p: Mr. BENNETT introduced a bill [S. No. 259,] for An Act to amend section 21 of an Act regulating general elections, etc., approved June 17,1852; which was read the first time - again by title, and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary. [Adding to the usual oath these words: "that you did not at anytime leave your residence, in this or any other State, to avoid military duty in the service of the "United States, and that you did not voluntarily enlist or serve in the army or navy of the so-called Confederate States; or in any way, voluntarily, directly or indirectly, aid or abet the government of the same."]

div.head: CHANGE OF VENUE.
div.p: Mr. CULVER introduced a bill [S. No. 260] for An Act to amend section 207 of the the General Practice Act, approved June 18, 1852, which was read the first time - again by title, and referred to the Judiciary committee.

div.head: CLINTON COMMON PLEAS.
div.p: Mr. McClurg's bill No. 231, (described on page 63) was read the second time and ordered engrossed for the third reading.

div.head: WORK FOR COMMITTEES.
div.p: The following described Senate bills were read the second time and referred to appropriate committees:

list.item: Mr. Williams', No. 230, in relation to the organization of the General Assembly - to the Committee on Finance.
Mr. Cobb's, No. 232, for the relief of Talbott & Costigan - to the Committee on Claims.
Mr. Williams', No. 238, concerning adopted children - to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. Cason's, No. 234, amending city incorporation laws - to the Committee on Corporations.
Mr. Culver's, No. 235, concerning County Auditors - to the Committee on County and Township Business.
Mr. Ward's, No. 236, requiring Railroad Companies to transport live stock and charge a uniform rate therefor - to a Special Committee of one from each Congressional District.
Mr. Noyes', No. 237, property to be sold under process of law without valuation or assessment - to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. Bonham's, No. 238, prescribing an oath for practicing lawyers - to the Judiciary Committee.

div.p: The following described bills were read by title only: -

list.item: Mr. Clurg's, No. 239, concerning conflict in sessions of Circuit with Common Pleas Courts, was read by title only, and referred to the Committee on Organization of Courts.
Mr. Dykes', 240, to amend the Liquor Law (described in proceedings of day before yesterday), was read by title only, and referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. Cason's, No. 241, in relation to witnesses (introduced yesterday), was read by title only and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. Van Buskirk's, No. 242, changing the time for holding the Common Pleas Court, was read by title only, and referred to a Select Committee, viz: Messrs. Van Buskirk, Mason, Cullen, Reagan and Marshall.

Mr. Van Buskirk's No. 243, changing the time for holding the Circuit Court in the fourth Judicial District, was read by title only, and referred to a Select Committe consisting of the Senators from that Judicial District.
The Committee on the Organization of Courts' bill, No. 244, fixing the number of Justices of the Peace, was read by title only, and referred to the Committee on Organization of Courts.
Mr. Mason's, No. 245, concerning new trials, was read by title only, and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

div.p: On motion by Mr. BENNETT, the reference of the bill S. 204, in relation to witnesses, was changed from the Judiciary to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
On motion by Mr. MASON, the bill S. 66, changing the time for holding Common Pleas Courts, was recommitted to the Select Committee heretofore appointed thereon.

On motion by Mr. WRIGHT, the bill H. R. 55, to authorize certain persons to dig a canal from the Calumet River to Lake Michigan, for the purpose of draining a portion of the swamp lands of Lake and Porter counties, was referred to the Judiciary Committee without reading - even by the title.
And then the Senate took a recess until 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Leaves of absence were obtained for Messrs. Cobb and Hyatt till Tuesday, and for Mr. Staggs till Monday.

On motion by Mr. WRIGHT the bill H. R. 63
was read by title and referred to the Committee on Corporations; and the bill H. R. 187 was read by title and referred to the Committee on Finance.
On motion by Mr. MASON the bill S. 205 was recommitted to the Committee on Organization of Courts.

div.head: VERNON, JENNINGS COUNTY.
div.p: Mr. Vawter's bill [S. No. 21] amending the charter of the town of Vernon, Jennings county, was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 88, nays 0.

div.head: JUSTICES' JURISDICTION.
div.p: Mr. Oyler's bill [S. No. 22] amending section ten of the Justices' Act so that they may have jurisdiction in all cases where the value of property does not exceed $200 was read the third time, and passed by yeas 35, nay 0.

div.head: STALLIONS & JACKS.
div.p: Mr. Douglas' bill, [S. No. 27,] amending sec. 4 of the misdemeanor acthaving reference to the standing of stallions or jacks within 200 yards of any dwelling, was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 34, nays 3.

div.head: REGISTRY OF VOTERS.
div.p: Mr. Thompson's bill, [S. No. 64,] to provide for the registry of voters, declaring their residence, punishing fraudulent voting, etc., was read the third time and made the special order for Wednesday next, at two o'clock, P. M.

div.head: DECEDENTS' REAL ESTATE.
div.p: Mr. Hord's bill, [S. No. 87,] to amend sec. 17 of An Act prescribing who may make a will, etc., approved May 31, 1852, was'read the third time and laid on the table.

div.head: COSTS OF APPEALS.
div.p: Mr. Hord's bill ]S. No. 106] to amend section 119 of the Protective Act, approved June 17, 1852, so as to strike out so much thereof as requires the appellee to pay the costs of the appeal when the decision of the Court below is decided to be erroneous, was read the third time, and passed by yeas 36, nays 1.

div.head: COUNTY SHERIFFS.
div.p: Mr. Cason's bill [S. No. 138] to amend section 30 of An Act regulating the fees of officers and repealing former acts in relation thereto, Approved March 2,1855 [making it incumbent on each county to furnish fuel, stationery, and office room for their sheriffs, as well as other officers, by inserting at the proper place in the above named section the words "and sheriffs"] was read the third time and failed to pass for want of a constitutional majority - yeas 20, nays 18.

div.head: BLACKFORD COUNTY LINES.
div.p: Mr. Bonham's bill [S. No. 140] to correct a mistake in defining the boundaries of Blackford county, was read the third time and laid on the table.

div.head: THE LIQUOR TRAFFIC.
div.p: Mr. Wood's bill [S. No. 142] denning the crime of drunkenness and prescribing the penalty therefor [shall be fined not less than one nor more than ten dollars] was read the third time and passed by yeas, 32; nays, 7.

div.head: VACATING TOWNS, STREETS, ETC.
div.p: Mr. Richmond's bill [S. No. 152] to amend section 7 of An Act touching the laying out and vacating towns, streets, alleys, public squares and grounds, etc., approved May 20, 1852, was read the third time and laid on the table.

div.head: GRAND JURORS.
div.p: Mr. Downey's bill [S. No. 156] to amend section 14 of An Act to limit the number of grand jurors, &c., approved March 4, 1852, and to change the form of oath of grand jurors, was read the third time.

Mr. OYLER explained the object of the bill to be the giving to grand juries jurisdiction and cognizance of misdemeanors as well as felonies, with the exception of that class where the fine cannot exceed three dollars.
Mr. BROWN, of Wells, saw in this bill one step towards the abolishing of the common pleas system of the State, and the consolidation of business in the Circuit Court.
On motion of Mr. VAN BUSKIRK, the bill was laid on the table (till its author shall appear in his place) by yeas 21, nays, 18.

div.head: LOTS, STREETS, PUBLIC SQUARES, ETC.
div.p: The Committee on Corporation's bill [S. No. 164,] touching the disposition of lots, streets, alleys, public squares and grounds, within the corporate limits of any incorporated city, heretofore vacated, or hereafter vacated, was read the third time and laid on the table.

div.head: HORSE THIEVES AND OTHER FELONS.
div.p: Mr. Niles' bill [S. No. 175,] to authorize the formation of companies for the detection and apprehension of horse thieves and other felons, and for mutual protection, and for repealing all laws inconsistent therewith, wras read the third time and passed - yeas 38, nays 2.

div.head: SESSION HOURS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BROWN, of Wells, it was -
Ordered, That when the Senate adjourn it adjourns to meet to-morrow morning at nine o'clock.

div.head: HOTEL COMPANIES.
div.p: Mr. Dunning's bill [S. 185] for the incorporation of Hotel Companies, was read the third time and passed by yeas 36, nays 0.

div.head: SALE OF RAILROADS.
div.p: Mr. Oyler's bill [S. No. 206] supplemental to An Act to authorize, regulate and confirm the sale of Railroads, etc., approved March 3,1855; and for the purpose of making the same more definite and certain, was read the third time, and passed by yeas 29, nays 5.

div.head: WHITE RIVER NAVIGATION COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. Oyler's bill [S. No. 211] supplemental to An Act to incorporate the White River Navigation Company, approved February 13,1851, wras read the third time, and passed by yeas 34, nays 0.

div.head: OFFICERS OF ELECTIONS.
div.p: Mr. Bonham's bill [S. No. 221] for the punishment of officers of elections for receiving illegal votes, was read the third time and passed by yeas 35, nays 1.

div.head: INCREASE OF OFFICER'S FEES.
div.p: Mr. Bennett's bill [S. No. 226] increasing the fees of County Commissioners, Prosecuting Attorneys, Constables, Justices, Jurors and witnesses, was read the third time.

Mr.COBB moved to recommit the bill to
the Committee on Organization of Courts with Instructions to strike out "ten dollars" where it occurs relating to prosecuting Attorneys and insert "$5;" and all that portion referring to witnesses and jurors before Justices of the Peace and make it as the old law stands. He characterized the witnesses, constables and jurors fees - the fees as fixed before a Justice of the Peace in this bill - as enormous.

Mr. NILES since this bill has passed the second reading had remarked to several Senators that he thought we were going rather too fast on this subject and now it might be better to have this bill again considered by the Committee.
Mr. BENNETT ineffectually moved to lay the motion to recommit on the table.

Mr. BROWN, of Wells, moved to amend the instructions by including juror's fees in the higher courtsso as to let them remain as they are at present. The tendency of an increase of fees would be to increase the class of professional jurors, of which every lawyer has a horror.

Mr. DUNNING (Mr. Cullen in the Chair) opposed the amendment. We ought to have the best of men for jurors. He, too, had a horror of professional jurors, but if Judges of Courts were to instruct the Sheriffs, as Judge Eckles does, not to summon any man who he has reason to suspect comes for the purpose of getting on a jury, and to report the name of any man who solicits a place upon a jury, it would cut short that class of persons.
Mr. COBB modified his instructions by making them matter of inquiry.
The motion to recommit was agreed to. And then the Senate adjourned till 9 o'clock tomorrow morning.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: Mr. SPEAKER took the chair at nine o'clock A. M., and directed the clerk to read the Journal of yesterday.
On motion by Mr. GRIFFITH the reading of the journal was dispensed with.

div.head: PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House the memorial of Gabriel Godfrey and other Miami Indians praying for the removal of legal disibilities of Indians in regard to testimony in Courts and to the common schools.
On motion of Mr. HAMRICK it was referred to the Committee on Education.

The SPEAKER laid before the House the memorial of J. A. Craft in behalf of the Grand Camps of the Host of Temperance, with an accompanying bill for the suppression of tippling houses, praying for its consideration and passage.
Mr. SHUEY moved that the memorial and bill be referred to the Committee on Temperance, and that two hundred copies of the bill be printed.
Mr. CHURCH could not readily understand why there should be an order to print this draft of a bill by the Host of Temperance.

Mr. SHUEY. There was perhaps 110 question on which the public mind is so much excited at the present time, as temperance. It was indicated in memorials and importunities from all parts of the State. And when we regard the immense number represented in these memorials, and the moral interests involved we should accord to these men - in whom he had implicit confidence - thatreespect which is truly their due, as to a large and highly re, spectable organization. They were tax payers as well as we, and they wish every member to see their plan.

Mr. BURWELL presumed this mighty host is a very respectable body, and they may have prepared a very good bill, but he was opposed to printing it with out knowing anything about it. It was not objectionable that this host, or any other host, should present a bill, but the printing was unusual and ought not to be expected.

Mr. LANE also thought it best first to know what the bill contained. He moved to lay the motion to print on the table.It was so ordered, and then the memorial was referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. LANE presented a petition from sundry citizens of Putnam county for amendment of the liquor law, which was referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. RICE presented a similar petition from sundry citizens of Park county.
Mr. NEWCOMB presented a similar memorial from 2,340 citizens of Indianapolis on the same subject.
They were referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. STENGER presented the memorial of the Commissioners of Dearborn County for the repeal of the Soldier's Relief Law, except, etc., which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

Mr. MILLER presented the memorial of John Pettit and others, citizens of Tippecanoe County, for the repeal of the Black Laws, and such legislation as will secure to the colored people the right to testify in Courts of Justice, and the benefit of common schools; which was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. LITSON presented the memorial of sundry citizens of Jefferson County for legislation admitting of swinging gates in highways in certain cases; which was referred to the Committee on Roads.
Mr. WEIGHT submitted 20 memorials for claims, which, without reading, were referred to the Committee on Claims.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned Mr. Gregory, of Warren's, school tax bill [H. R. 183] reporting that legislation thereon is inexpedient at this time, because the bill itself is objectionable; and inasmuch as the State school tax has been increased about 60 per cent., any further increase would be onorous and objectionable. The Committee recommended that the bill lie on the table.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. N., also, from the same Committee, returned Mr. McVey's Constitutional Convention bill [H. R. 90] with the expression of opinion that legislation on that subject is inexpedient at this time, and recommending indefinite postponement.

Mr. NEWCOMB stated that the specific object of the bill was to provide that the vote of soldiers be taken. That necessity having
happily passed with the war, the Committee submit a recommendation to postpone.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. N. also, from the same Commitee. returned Mr. McVey's appraisement bill, [H. R. 212,] recommending its passage.
The report and bill lie on the table.

div.head: DEFAULTING COUNTY OFFICERS.
div.p: He, also, from the same Committee, returned Mr. Reese's defaulting county officers bill [H. R. 205,] reporting the opinion that the bill is unconstitutional, and that legislation on the subject is inexpedient. The Committee recommended that the bill be indefinitely postponed.
The report was concurred in.
He also from the same Committee returned Mr. Thacher's master Commissioner's bill [H. R. 142,] recommending its indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. MILLER from the Committee on the organization of Courts of Justice returned the bill [S. 210] to amend section 584 of the civil procedure act; also the bill [S. 145] providing Judge's compensation in certain casesrecommending their passage.
The reports lie on the table.
Mr. CHURCH from the same Committee, returned Mr. Humphrey's practice bill [H. R. 87] recommending that it do pass.
The report lies on the table.

Mr. BURWELL from the same Committee returned Mr. Olleman's fines and fees bill [H. R. 154] recommending that it lie on the table, for the reason that House bill No. 81 on the same subject has been recommended for passage.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. BURWELL, from the Committee on Organization of Courts, to whom was referred a resolution for the purchase and distribution of Gavin & Hord's Revised Statutes to Justices of the Peace and Township Trustees, reported that it be laid on the table.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. GREGORY of Warren, from the Committee on Education, returned Mr. Meredith's High School Corporations bill [H. R. 82], recommending its passage.
Also, Mr. Rhoad's School Commissioner bill [H. R. 235], recommending its passage.
They lie on the table.

Mr. TRUSLER, from the Committee on Military Affairs, returned the joint resolution No. 10 for legislation in Congress to place persons injured in irregular action against guereillas on the same footing as to pensions with those engaged in the regular service, - reporting that as the same subject is embraced in the legislation of the last session, they recommended that it be indefinitely postponed.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. LOCKHART, from the Committee on Railroads, returned Mr. Cowgill's unclaimed freight bill [H. R. 211], with amendments, changing the time of notice from thirty to sixty days, and declaring that the proceeds of such sales, less charges, shall go to common school fund.
The report lies on the table.
Mr. JAMES, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill [S. 141] amending sections 2, 5 and 6 of the act concerning the organization of voluntary associations, recommending its passage.
The report lies on the table.

Mr. HAMRICK, from the Committee on Corporations, returned sundry memorials from citizens of Lawrenceburgh, and because the matter prayed for are pending before this body, they recommend that they be laid on the table.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. STEWART, from the Committee on the Library, submitted a special report of the State Librarian on the condition of the State Library, stating that there is not sufficient room in the library for the accumulating trophies, &c.
Mr. STEWART supposed the report would go into the Journal.
It was so ordered.

Mr. GRIFFITH, from the Committee on the Northern State Prison, to which was referred the resolution respecting the mileage of sheriffs for conducting convicts to prison, reported a bill in accordance therewith.
The report lies on the table.

div.head: NEW BILLS - COMMON SCHOOLS.
div.p: Mr. GOODMAN introduced a bill [H. R. 237] for an act to amend section 35 of the common school act, approved March 6, 1865. [School meetings may direct either a greater or a less number of branches to be taught in their schools than the law requires.]
It was passed to the second reading, and referred to the Committee on Education.

div.head: GUARDIANS.
div.p: Mr. COFFROTH introduced a bill [H. R, 238] for an act to authorize foreign gnardians to take possession of the personal property of their wards, and receipt for moneys belonging to their wards, in this State, and sue for and recover such money owing to said wards in this State.
It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

div.head: ST. JOSEPH RIVER DAM.
div.p: Mr. SHUEY introduced a bill [H. R. 239] for an act to authorize the Manufacturing Company to erect a dam across the St. Joseph river in Elkhart county.
It was referred to the Committee on Manufactures.

div.head: SHEEPKILLING DOGS.
div.p: Mr. MILROY introduced a bill [H. R. 240] for an act to relieve County Auditors, County Treasurers, Township Trustees, Assessors and other officers from the penalty attaching to the violation of the Act to discourage the keeping of useless and sheepkilling dogs, etc.
It was referred to the Committee on County and Township Business.

div.head: TURNPIKE TOLLS.
div.p: Mr. HAMRICK introduced a bill [H. R. 241] for an act to amend section thirteen of the act of May 12, 1852, authorizing the construction of plank, McAdamized and graval roads.
It was referred to the Committee on Roads.

div.head: ROAD TAX.
div.p:
Mr. SEWTART introduced a bill [H. R, 242] for an act to amend sections three and fourteen of the act to allow County Commissioners to authorize turnpike roads where three-fifths of the land-owners within the prescribed limits [three-fourths of a mile on each side of the proposed road] petition for the same, etc., approved March 2,
1855. [It allows them to tax the land but pnce, and allows them to enter and take gravel, and have it condemned afterwards.]
It was referred to the Committee on Corporations.

Mr. MILLER introduced a bill [H. H. 243] for an act to authorize the appointment of a Commissioner to co-operate with other National and State authorities in presenting the agricultural, manufacturing, artistic, and other advantages of the State of Indiana to the Universal Exhibition to be held in Paris in the year 1866, and also its advantages as a place of settlement; and providing for the expense of such Commissioner [said Commissioner to recieve $200 per month.]
It was referred to the Committee on Agriculture.

Mr. BUSKIRK introduced a bill [H. R. 244] for An Act to provide for and regulate the issuing of liceases to locomotive engineers in the State of Indiana. [The Governor to appoint two competent engineers, one residing north add the other south of the National Road, to constitute a Board of Inspectors who shall hold office five years - license to continue for the term of one year - $10 fee for each license - $5 for each renewal. It shall be unlawful for railroad companies to employ unlicensed engineers. Penalty $500 to $1000.]
It was passed to the second reading and referred to the Select Committee on Mr. Brown's resolution relative to the same matter.

div.head: STATE PRISON SOUTH.
div.p: Mr. CROOK submitted the following:

WHEREAS, Under the present law regulating the Indiana State Prison (South) the Directors thereof ask an appropriation from the State Treasury of each session of the Legislature to defray The expense of said prison;
AND WHEREAS, The convicts in said Prison have been leased for a term of years expiring in 1867, at the remarkable low rates of forty cents per day; therefore,

Be it Resolved, By the House of Representatives (the Senate concurring) That the Hon D. E. William on, Attorney General of this State be instructed to inquire into the validity of the said contracts, and report to this General assembly whether in his opinion the State can in any way be relieved from said contracts.
It was adopted.

div.head: COMMON SCHOOLS.
div.p: Mr. RHOADS introduced a bill [H. R. 245,] for an act to amend sections 12, 14, 18, 20, 21, 40, 42, of the common school act of 1865. [It proposes to change the time of making reports.]

On the motion of Mr. R., the constitutional provision requiring the bill to be read by sections was dispensed with - yeas 84, nays 2; whereupon it was read by title and referred to the Committee on Education.

div.head: COUNTY COMMISSIONER'S FEES.
div.p: Mr. OSBORN introduced a bill [H. R. 246,] for an act to amend section 10 of an act regulating the fees of officers, and repealing former acts in relation thereto, approved March 2, 1855. [Instead of each day's attendance $3, it proposes $4.]
It was referred to the Committee on Fees Salaries.

div.head: OFFICERS AND EMPLOYES.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB submitted the following:

Resolved, That the Speaker be authorized to draw his warrant for the per diem of the officers and employes of the House, to be paid out of the appropriations heretofore made, or which may be hereafter made to defray the expends of the General Assembly at the following rates, to-wit:

list.item: To the Principal and Assistant Clerks and their Assistants, to the number authorized by the House, heretofore adopted, $5 per day each.
To the Principal Doorkeeper, $5 per day.
To his assistants, George W. Busby, M. J. Thomas, A. W. Stringer, Peter Wilkins and J. W. Cocbrane, $4 each per day.
To A. G. Cochrane, Folding Clerk, and to George Douglas, Assistant Folder and Mail Carrier, $4 per day each.
To John T Warner, Spittoon-cleaner, and waiter - $3 per day.
To the 5 pages appointed by the Clerk and Speaker $2 per day each.
The speaker's clerk $4 per day.
To the firemen in the Basement employed by the State Librarian on behalf of the House - $3 per day each.

div.p: It was adopted.
Mr. HENRICKS made an in effectual motion to reconsider, to enable him to move to increase the firemen's compensation to $4 a day.
The vote was subsequently reconsidered, and the pay was made $4 per day for five firemen employed by the Librarian on behalf of the House and Senate.

div.head: DELINQUENT TAXES.
div.p: Mr. GROVES introduced a bill [H. R. 247] for an act concerning the collection of delinquent taxes for the State of Indiana. [It regulates collection fees, etc. - the abstract was furnished by the Treasurer of Perry Co].
It was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, introduced a, bill [H. R. 248], for an act to amend sec. two of the act for the incorporation of manufacturing and mining companies and companies for building purposes; approved May 22, 1852. [Extending the limitation or restriction of the act as to the amount of the capital stock of such company, and legalizes things in this regard].
It was referred to the Committee on Corporations.
Mr. GREGG introduced a bill [H. R. 249] for an act to amend section 5 of the act regulating licensing and selling of liquor, &c. [License money to go into the County Treasury.]
It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. SULLIVAN, of Scott, introduced a bill [H. R. 250] for an act to repeal the act approved March 2, 1865, to discourage the keeping of useless and sheep-killing dog, and to repeal the act to license dogs, approved March 11, and providing that nothing in this act shall conflict with the act for the protection of sheep.
It was passed a first reading and referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. LASSELLE introduced a bill [H. R. 251] for an act to provide for taking an enumeration of' all the white male inhabitants of the State over 21 years of age, and prescribing penalty for negligence of any officer in relation thereto.
It was referred to a special committee of three.
On motion by Mr. CHURCH Mr. Higgins obtained leave of absence till Monday.

Mr. FERRIS introduced a bill [H. R. 252] for an act to incorporate an additional section into the common school act of last session. [No person shall be excluded by law from attending common schools on account of being more than 21 years of age.]
It was referred to the Committee on Education.

Mr. THACHER (by unanimous, consent) submitted a report from the Committee on Printing, returning his bill [H. R. 177] amending section 148 of the act of May 9, 1861, amendatory of the act for the publication of delinquent taxes, with an amendment striking out "25," and inserting "15" in lieu; and so amended recommending its passage.
The report lies on the table under the rule.
The SPEAKER now announced the special committee on Mr. Brown's railroad engineer resolution, viz: Messrs. Brown, Kilgore and Coffroth.

div.head: ELECTION OF ASSISTANT CLERK.
div.p: The Speaker announced the special order for this hour to-wit: the election of Assistant Clerk of the House in place of T. W. O. Braffett, resigned.
Mr. PRATHER made an ineffccual motion for a call of the House - affirmative 22, negative 54.
Mr. KILGORE nominated for Assistant Clerk, Robert O. Dormer.
Mr. BROWN put in nomination for the same place, Capt. Byford E. Long.
The SPEAKER appointed Mr. Brown and Mr. Kilgore to act as Tellers.
The Tellers reported -
Mr. Dormer receiving ............ 54 votes.
The SPEAKER thereupon declared Mr. Dormer duly elected Assistant Clerk of this House, and Mr. D. coming forward, received the oath of his office, and entered upon its duties.

div.head: THIRTEENTH ARTICLE.
div.p: On motion by Mr. GREGORY of Warren, the order of business was suspended, and the House took up the consideration of Mr. Meredith's joint resolution [H. R. No. 1] for expunging the 13th Article of the Constitution.
Mr. GRIFFITH being entitled to the floor, spoke at length in favor of the resolution. - See appendix.

Mr. MILROY apologized for his offhand style. He insisted that the purity of the ballot box should be protected by Legislation. Here we were called upon to invite into our midst, as voters, a race confessedly inferior, and always incapable of self-government. Our fathers had disfranchised Indians and negroes on account of this. He inveiged against this negro fanaticism in our politics - where fanaticism obtains, justice dies. The consummation of the objects of this fanaticism would lead to a war of races and the extinguishment of the black race. Let it succeed - if the Republican Party dare to press it - and it will damn them forever.

Mr. PRATHER next took the floor, defining his position, and reconciling it on the 13th article in the Constitutional Convention of 1850, with his present position on the same matter. He referred to the determination of the dominant party of that day to force slavery on the whole country, and for that reason he voted for this 13th article. He referred to the violation of the compromise of 1850 by the Democratic party, in the repeal of the Missouri Compromise and in the Lecompton controversy; and then referred to the fact that those very men who refused to stand by their Government in the late rebellion were refusing now the just rights and legal protection of those who did stand by the Government on all the bloody fields of the rebellion. On account of these considerations, as well as on account of its intrinsic justice, he should support this proposition to strike out the 13th article of the State Constitution.
Mr. SHUEY moved that the further consideration of this special order be postponed till Tuesday, butOn the amendment of Mr. LANE it was made the special order for Tuesday, 7 o'clock P. M.

Mr. BUSKIRK (by consent) introduced a bill [H. R. 253] for An Act to amend the 8th section of the Common Pleas act of March 5, 1859, which 8th section was amended March 7. [It changes the time of said Courts in the counties of Morgan, Johnson, Monroe, Shelby and Brown.]
It was referred to a select committee of three.
Leave of absence was obtained for Messrs. Howard, Abbett, Chambers and Vcach till next week.

div.head: LIQUOR LAW.
div.p: Mr. LANE called up the consideration of Mr. Shuey's bill [H. R. 218] amendatory of the license liquor law the question being on the adoption of Mr. Lane's amendment.

Mr. BROWN thought it better for the bill and its friends not to press its consideration till some day next week. Those who are opposed to the bill have been waiting for its completion before they submit their objections. He hoped the motion to force its passage now would not prevail.
Mr. LANE. A similar bill was introduced during the last session. Petitions have come in for it, and there was no subject for which the people of the State were so generally asking.

Mr. LOCKHART also referred to the flood of petitions on this subject, and desired the bill to be taken up. It should be passed before the winter meeting of the County Commissioners. He repeated his former reasoning for this bill.

Mr. SHUEY stated the condition of the bill there being two amendments pending. He wished to consider the amendments. He was not willing to press the bill to its passage today, but would move when in order that it be postponed and made a special order for Tuesday.
Mr. PRATHER suggested that the bill be printed.
Mr. BUSKIRK suggested that it be taken up, the amendment disposed of, and then that it be made a special order. There was no purpose to impede legislation in this direction.

[The SPEAKER announed the following Special Committee on Mr. Buskirk's bill [H. R. 253] viz: Messrs. Buskirk, Miller and Harrison.]Mr. Lane's motion was then agreed to and Mr. Shuey's bill No. 218 was taken up.

The SPEAKER (Mr. Hendricks in the Chair.) The first question is on the adoption of the
amendment offered by the gentleman from Putnam, striking out all that relates to towns.
Mr. BUSKIRK, submitted to Mr. Lane that the object might be defeated in particular cases which he gave.
Mr. LANE. These were isolated cases.

Mr. SHUEY. The bill was shaped simply with respect to his own knowledge and experience. He had no doubt that the saloonkeepers of his town would, if they were here, work for the passage of the amendment of the gentleman from Putnam. He deprecated amendments. The Committee's amendment, was to supply an omission in his original draft. Its effect was to leave it open to the Commissioners to inqure as they please as to the number of legal voters.

Mr. LANE was not so wedded to his amendment as to withdraw his support from the best bill we can obtain, if it fails. He believed that the suffrages of the country people were safer on this subject; and some fifteen petitions had lately come in here asking for the precise matter of his amendment.

Mr. CHURCH said it was a fact that the bad effects of this traffic were nowhere so bad as in these little villages. Certainly the people of the townships surrounding these little towns were directly interested in the matter of licenses. He should support this amendment and the bill life would support the bill if it took never so much whisky every day to keep him in his place here; because his people distinctly desired it.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, should support the amendment because it would put the applicant to a little more trouble.
On motion by Mr. RHOADS, the House took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER (Mr. Henricks in the Chair) stated the question to be on Mr. Lane's amendment.
It was adopted: also the amendment of the Committee on Temperance, without a division.

Mr. RHOADS proposed to amend farther: in section 4, line 8, after the word "required," insert this: "and that the said petition contains the signatures of a majority of the legal voters in such township, city or ward." The object was to throw the proof on the applicant.
Mr. NEWCOMB said it was mere verbiage.
Mr. RICE would prefer prohibition; but suggested that for this bill it would be better to throw the proof upon the temperance people.

Mr. RHOADS read from an article in this morning's Herald to show that the enemies of this legislation and the gentleman from Park had fallen into the same line of argument. He wished to place this provison of the bill beyond doubt. He would be glad, if this bill pass, that what the Herald article predicts shall be realized in ten months, viz: the withdrawal of all the saloon keepers from the cities.

Mr. NEWCOMB. The Commissioners, after all, will determine for themselves what satisfies their mind. The declaration that this was to be in effect a prohibitory law, was the strongest argument he had against it. He would just as soon repeal all laws on the subject, as to pass a prohibitory law.
On motion of Mr. HIGGINS, the amendment was laid on the table.
Mr. SHUEY moved to postpone the further consideration of the bill till Tuesday, 2 o'clock P.M.
Mr. SPENCER moved to amend by adding an order to print 200 copies.
It was agreed to.
Mr. BROWN hoped it would be postponed to a later day. As a friend of Temperance, he doubted the propriety of the passage of the bill at all.
Mr. COWGILL also advised delay, for want of information as to the details of the bill.
Mr. SHUEY then proposed to postpone till Wednesday, 2 o'clock, P. M.
Messrs. Stringer, Riford and others, obtained leave of absence till Tuesday.

div.head: STATE TAXES.
div.p: Mr. HANNA introduced a joint resolution [S. No. 21] on the subject of State taxation.
It is as follows:

WHEREAS, By certain acts of Congress, approved March 3, 1864, June 30, 1864, and other enactments, certain bonds and certificates of indebtedness (meaning National currency, treasury notes, etc.) issued by the authority of the Government of the United States, are declared exempt from State, county and municipal taxation, to the great injury and oppression of those who have nu such bonds and certificates for non-taxatior; and, whereas, the said class of bonds and certificates, not being taxed, throws upon ether property the whole
burthen of taxation, and reoders it unjust and oppressive to the great majority of our citizens; and, whereas, these bonds and certificates ammount to many millions, from which neither the State, the counties, nor the incorporated cities or towns of the State derive any revenue whatever; and, whereas, in the opinion of this General Assembly, it is lawful and proper that all of its citizens should be taxed for the support of the State and Federal Governments according to the means which they possess, whether their wealth consists of farming lands, houses, factories, shops, mercantile establishments, money on hand or at interest, bonds or securities of the Federal or State Governments, shares of stock in the National Banks, or other banks, or whatever else of permanent value they own or control, and from which they receive support or income; and, whereas, it is the bounden duty of this General Assembly to secure to all classes of its constituency exemption from opression in the payment of an undue share of taxes, and to provide against the existence of privileged classes in our midst, who seek, by specious and artful laws, to be exempted from a fair share of the public burthens, but that all shall bear these burthens according to their actual ability, without refererce to the kind or nature of the wealth which they possess; and whereas, in times like the present, at the close of a bloody and expensive war, when the people of the nation, the States, the counties, and the municipalities are straggling with large and crushing pubic debts, and never-ending taxes, it is the duty of every man to exhibit his patriotism and love of country by voluntarily coming forward, and placing his weath, of whatever kind, on the tax-duplicate of his State, county, or municipality, and bear his honest share of the public burthen;

AND WHEREAS, The people of Indiana, always anxious to maintain the National and State credit, and to bear all fair and honest burthens which may be laid upon them for that purpose, are yet firmly of the opinion that these taxes should be equal, and that all property and wealth within the State shouId he taxed, without reference to its quality or kind and that all our citizens should pay in proportion to the wealth which they possess ; and as we regard the solemn duty of this General Assembly to supply, by appropriate legislature, a remedy for the evils entaded upon by the unwise enactments of the Medeval Congress. therefore,

Resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Indiana, That the Auditor of State be directed to place in the hands of the Auditors of the various counties of the State, properly prepared blank forms, to be used by the Assessors in their respective town-ships whose duty shall be to place upon the tax duplicate the income received by residents or citizens of Indiana, from all United States' bonds, coupons, certificates of indebtedness from the same, and all and every description of income from the various classes of United States bonds, namely: five-twenties, seven-thrirties, ten-forties, treasury notes, certificates of deposit with the United States, and all other income derived from the Government, except the income paid to officers, or soldiers of the regular or volunteer army and navy of the United States, and all such incomes shall be taxed 25 per cent. for State and county purposes.

And be it further Resolved, That the Auditor of State shall also prepare and furnish to County Auditers, at the same time, and on the same paper, blank forms to be used in assesing the value of all shares of stock held by residents and citizens (and non-resident holders, if there be such) In any of the National Banks of this State. and all these shares of stock and surplus earnings on board shall pay a tax equal to that levied on other property for State, county, township and school purposes, and no more.

Mr. OYLER desired the resolution to be treated with all due respect, and to receive due consideration ; and therefore, moved that it be read again by title, and referred to a committee of one from each Congressional District.
The motion was agreed to.

No. 261] for An Act to amend sections 2 and 5 of An Act entitled An Act concerning the organization of voluntary Associations and repealing former laws in relation thereto, approved Feb. 12, 1855; which was read the lirst timeagain by its title and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

div.head: GETTYSBURG CEMETERY.
div.p: Mr. CHAPMAN introduced a bill [S. No. 262] for An Act to make an appropriation to pay the balance of the quota of this State of the expenses of the Soldiers' National Cemetery at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, as assessed by the Board of Managers of said Association, $3,469 83,] which was read the first time - again by its title and referred to the Committee on Finance.

div.p: Mr. DUNNING, [Mr. Moore in the chair,] ntroduced a bill, [S. No. 263,] for An Act to repeal An Act, entitled "An Act to discourage the keeping of useless or sheep-killing clogs, and providing penalties for the violation of any of the provisions of said Act by officers and others, and also repealing An Act to lisence dogs, approved March 11, 1861, and providing that nothing in this Act shall be so construed as to conflict with the provisions of An Act entitled 'An Act for the protection of sheep.' approved June 15, 1862, approved March 2, 1865;" which was read the first time - again by title, and referred to the Committee on Agriculture.

div.p: On motion by Mr. GIFFORD, the Senate proceeded to the consideration of House Bills on the first reading.
The bill H. R. No. 21, to amend sec, 32 of An Act defining misdemeanors, and prescribing punishment therefor, approved June 14, 1852; was read the first time.
Mr. BROWN, of Wells, moved to read the bill by title for the purpose of reference.
Mr. VAWTER raised the point of order that such procedure was in direct violation of the rules of the Senate.
This question of order was discussed by Messrs. OYLER, VAWTER and BROWN, of Wells, -
when Mr. BROWN withdrew his motion.
And then the Senate adjourned till to-morrow morning 9 o'clock.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The House was called to order at 2 o'clock. P.M., by the Assistant Clerk (Mr. Dormer) and Mr. Henricks, of St. Joseph, was called to the Chair.

On motion of Mr. COFFROTH, it was ordered
that the reading of the journal of Friday be dispensed with, and that the House proceed with the regular morning business.
Mr. NEWCOMB presented a memorial for a claim by B. F. Wingate, of the city of Indianapolis, which, without reading, was referred to the Committee on Claims.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. MAJOR, from the Committee on Fees and Salaries, returned Mr. Burne's Attorneys' Docket Fee Bill [H. R. 224] with a recommendation that it be laid on the table.
The report was concurred in.

div.p: Mr. BURNES, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned Mr. Miller's black laws repeal bill, No. 214, without amendment, and recommending its passage.
It lies on the table.

div.p: Mr. B., also from the same Committee, returned the resolution submitted by Mr. Kilgore. with reference to the expediency of colored persons testifying in the Courts, and reported that inasmuch as there is a bill pending before this body embracing the subject matter of the resolution, they recommend that it be laid on the table.
The report was concurred in.

The report, bill and amendments lie on the table under the rule.

div.p: Mr. HOGATE, from the Committee on Agriculture, returned Mr. Cox's bird bill, [H. R. 223] recommending its passage.
It lies on the table.
