If what has been said on this floor be true, these Sinking Fund Commissioners have violated a plain provision of law, and no matter how high these gentlemen may stand personally, they are unworthy the places they occupy; and he would cast his vote to take the funds as speedily as possible from the control of these men - who are our servants, and who should execute the law as we write it. He desired to see the bill amended, and might possibly vote for both amendments now before the Senate. He did not know upon what authority it was stated that there would be no adjustment of the State debt this session. Whether it be in fact due or not, sound policy would require us to commence making provisions for its payment.

Mr. ALLISON contended it would do no harm to throw around these funds every possible guard; and could see no objection to the amendment offered by the Senator from Laporte. He referred to the statement made by the Senator from Lawrence, that there might
not be an adjustment of the State debt this session, and insisted that the debt should be paid on the 19th of January next, or some provision made for its settlement.
The substitute [Mr. Niles'] for the Committee amendment was then rejected by ayes 19, nays 27.
The question recurring on the first amendment, proposed by the Committee on Finance.

Mr. CHAPMAN. While the Committee have all confidence in the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, they thought it better to throw every guard around this fund. The fund has already lost some $18,000 in the last six months by lying idle, and this is one of the reasons for desiring to get it invested in six per cent, bonds. He explained the reasons for the amendments offered by the Committee.

Mr. DUNNING (Mr. Richmond in the Chair) spoke in opposition to the amendment. Referring to the State debt, he said he felt some pride in haying it paid. He was a warm advocate of the internal improvement system of the State in 1836. and was proud to-day to acknowledge the part he took in saddling that system upon the people of the State. It was the entering wedge to that spirit of improvement which has made the State powerful in times of peace and great and patriotic in time of war. He was prepared to vote for the settlement of that debt, if it is due, notwithstanding the fact that the people are at the present time heavily taxed. But if we are not to adjust that debt now, let not the interests of the children of the State stand still - let not this money lie idle if the vaults of the banks here or elsewhere, but let it be placed where it will be drawing interest at six per cent.

Mr. HANNA. The bill did not quite meet his views. He could not see that this amendment gives superior protection to the rights of citizens, and preferred the House bill in this particular. It was his deliberate judgment that by party maneuvering, or other causes, the settlement of the State debt will perhaps pass by this General Assembly, and if it does, it don't require any great foresight to know that the stocks of Indiana will become depressed from the very hour the Legislature adjourns. Then these Commissioners can go into the market and buy up these bonds and stocks, and when the State comes to a settlement, they will attain their full value in the market, and the school fund will derive the benefit. And if there is to be a speculation of this sort, he wanted it should be made right there.

Mr. CASON recited the provisions of the bill and proposed amendments, pointing out inconsistencies as between them, and expressing the opinion that this matter has not yet been considered with that care it should be. It is because he desired to shield the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners and enhance the value of the school fund, that he contended for the passage of a measure that will provide a secure investment for the moneys on hand. He opposed the loaning of this fund to individuals, and for this and other reasons urged the adoption of the amendment.
On motion of Mr. CULLEN the amendment was laid on the table by yeas 25, nays 20 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Barker, Bennett, Bonham, Bowman, Brown of Wells, Cobb, Corbin, Cullen, Finch, Fuller, Gaff, Gifford, Hanna, Ford, Hyatt, Jinkens, McClurg, Marshall, Mason, Moore, Newlin, Oyler, Richmond, Staggs and Mr. President - 25.
NAYS - Messrs. Allison, Beeson, Bradley, Brown of Hamilton, Cason, Chapman, Davis, Dykes, English, Milligan, Niles, Noyes, Reagan,Terry, Thompson, Van Buskirk, Vawter, Ward, Woods and Wright - 20.
Pending the roll call -

Mr. BENNETT explained that he voted to lay the resolution on the table for several reasons; one was his opposition to that provision which requires the Lieutenant Governor to superintend these Sinking Fund Commissioners in this matter. While he had the highest confidence in the Governor, he also had high confidence in the Commissioners, and was not disposed to insult them by connecting another officer with them because there is some $600,000 in their hands.
Mr. THOMPSON explained that he was not willing to vote for laying the amendment on the table, because there is no security required by law of those individuals to whom the fund may be loaned.

Mr. WILLIAMS, for the first time in his life, asked to be excused from voting. Part of the amendment he was in favor of: - he was in favor of preventing the loaning of these moneys to individuals; but was opposed to placing the Lieutenant Governor as a superintendent over the Commissioners.
The Senator was excused.
And so the amendment was laid on the table.
Mr. WILLIAMS, believing that the Committee would be able to make a report satisfactory to a majority of the Senate, moved to recommit the bill and pending amendments to the Committee on Finance.
Mr. CULLEN made an ineffectual motion - yeas 23, nays 23 - to lay the motion to recommit on the table.
Mr. BROWN, of Wells, made an ineffectual demand for the previous question.
The motion to recommit was agreed to.
And then the Senate adjourned (under the rules) till 9 o'clock to-morrow morning.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The SPEAKER took the Chair at 9 o'clock A. M., and directed the Clerk to read the Journal of yesterday.
On motion by Mr. WRIGHT, the Journal was authenticated without reading.

div.head: PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
div.p: Mr. TRUSLER presented the memorial of the County Commissioners of Fayette county, for repeal of the Soldiers' Relief Law after 1866.
It was referred to the Special Committee on the Soldiers' Home.
Mr. FOULKE presented a petition of Fred. Walter and 600 others, asking for amendments of the Liquor License Law, so as to restrict the icense to drink it affords to minors; and -
Mr. MONTGOMERY presented a Temperance petition; which were referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. THACHER presented a petition from the Commissioners of Shelby county, asking for the repeal of the Soldiers' Relief law; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

Mr. FOULKE presented the memorial of Thos. M. Hall for a claim for recruiting service.
He was called to service before the completion of his papers. It was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.
Mr. RICE presented the memorial of a citizen of Parke county, proposing to have the laws so changed as to have the roads worked by contract.
It was referred to the Committee on Roads.
Mr. LASSELLE presented a memorial from member of the Logansport Bar on account of a change in the time of Courts; which was referred to the Committee on Courts.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM, from the joint committee to whom was referred so much of the Governor's Message as relates to the State debt, reported a bill.
Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned his Insurance bill [H. R. 255] recommending its passage.

He also, from the same committee, returned Mr. Whiteside's publication service bill [H. R. 18] with an amendment, adding appropriately this: "Or such notice may be served on the attorney of the person asking for new trial," &c.
He also returned Mr. Caldwell's jury instructions bill [H. R. 227] recommending its indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.
He also returned Mr. Lasselle's pleadings bill [H. R. 228] recommending that it be laid on the table.

Mr. LASSELLE reasoned against concurrence in the report. There was great hardship in the pleadings where the maker of the note is dead. A note should be received in evidence, unless it is denied under oath. The same hardship might arise in cases of assignments.

Mr. NEWCOMB showed that it was more consonant with justice, that an administrator, etc., should be compelled to prove that the paper is genuine, than to deny under oath that which he may know nothing about.
Mr. LASSELLE. All notes ought to be received as prima facie evidence.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. N. also returned the Insurance bill [S. 31] recommending that it be laid on the table.
The report wras concurred in.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, from the Committee on Education, returned Mr. Goodman's School bill, [H. R. 237] recommending that it be indefinitely postponed.
Mr. GOODMAN stated reasons in his part of the State demanding this change in the law requiring extra qualifications of teachers.
Mr. COLLINS thought this provision of the law ought to be suspended for at least one year.
Mr. BROWN read the 136th section of the law, prescribing what branches shall be taught.

Mr. BUSKIRK had heard complaints against the high standard for qualification of teachers. He read the 34th section prescribing the standard of qualifications for license. There was another section which prescribes that none shall teach without license. He had heard the complaint illustrated by a farmer thus: The fodder had got so high that the calves, sheep and lambs would starve.

Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, said the Committee on Education had been untiring in their efforts to make an acceptable school bill. They were unanimous in the opinion that this bill was not required. Would you give the control of this matter to an ordinary school meeting, often governed by excitement? He read the 34th section. No man should teach children without some knowledge of physiology. He referred also to the 47th section, with reference to the duty of trustees. The Superintendent of Public Instruction had informed the committee that he could easily issue a circular to the Examiners that would settle this difficulty. If you would educate right, start right. The law did not contemplate a profound knowledge of physiology. He would have practical, hard, common sense teachers, knowing something of the laws of health, and the law of the land.
Mr. RICE. Could an individual get license without knowledge of physiology?
Mr. GREGORY. He might; but the Examiner would hardly do right, if the teacher knows nothing of the laws of health.

Mr. BRANHAM thought the school law ought to be modified in this respect. They had got the tree so tall that it was out of sight to first limb. He demanded the previous question, and there was a second, and the main question was ordered, whereupon -
The House refused to concur in the report of the committee.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, from the Committee on Education, returned Mr. Ferris' school bill [H. R. 252,] taking away restrictions as to age, recommending its indefinite postponement.
Mr. FERRIS reasoned in favor of his bill, that children under six years and over twenty-one years may attend school.
Mr. COFFROTH thought the gentleman was right as to persons over twenty-one years.
Mr. RHOADS said the committee concurred as to that.
Mr. COFFROTH. We could reach it, then, by refusing to concur in the recommendation.

[A message was now received from the Governor transmitting a communication, signed by S. H. Buskirk and others, of Monroe comity, proposing donations for the establishment of the State Agricultural College at Bloomington, viz: The Geological and Mineralogieal Cabinet of the late Dr. David Dale Owen, which could not be procured for less than $15,000, and a farm in the neighborhood worth $75,000.
On motion of Mr. BUSKIRK, it was referred to the special committee on that subject.]
Mr. WOODS agreed with the gentleman from Huntington, as to his desire to amend the school law - speaking in behalf of those young men who have been deprived of schools by service in the war.

Mr. BROWN hoped the law would not be changed according to the provisions of the bill. Older persons in the schools would engross the time of the teacher to the detriment of the children: and the first object of the school fund would be defeated.

Mr. LASSELLE thought the report should not be concurred in. The Constitution provides that the schools shall be "equally open
to all." He caused the Article to be read by the Clerk.
Mr. RHOADS. Were blacks included in this "all?"
Mr. LASSELLE. No: all white people. He commended the school system of Indiana, with all its imperfections of detail, as the best in the country.
Mr. GROVES demanded the previous question, and there was a second - whereupon -
The House refused to indefinitely postpone the bill.
Mr. GREGORY of Warren, also returned the Colored School Children petition of D. Lockwood and others, reporting that a majority of the Committee had reported a bill on that subject.
Mr. MAJOR, from the Committee on Fees and Salaries, returned Mr. Lasselle's County Auditor bill [H. R. 276] recommending its passage.

Mr. ABBETT, from the Committee on Claims, reported on the claim of Speigle, Thomas & Co., that it be referred to the Committee on Ways and Means with instructions to incorporate the same in the Specific Appropriation bill.

Mr. BURNES, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned Mr. Kilgore's Fish bill [H. R. 174] with an amendment excepting from its provisions the modes of taking fish by hook and line, gig and snarethe penalty not less than $10 nor more than $100.
Mr. LANE, from the Committee on Manufactures and Commerce, returned Mr. Shuey's St. Joseph River Dam bill [H. R. 239], recommending its passage.

Mr. STRINGER, from the Committee on Roads, returned Mr. Bonner's Road Company bill [H. R. 271;] also, Mr. Colover's Road bill [H. R. 164;] also the bill [H. R. 191,] recommending their passage severally without amendment.
Mr. BONNER, from the Committee on Roads, returned Mr. Hamrick's road bill [H. R. 241] with amendments, striking out "seven" and inserting "four," striking out "fifteen" and inserting "ten" in lieu.
He also returned Mr. Hoover's road bill [H. R. 263] with an amendment of title; adding this: " And prescribing a penalty therefor."
Mr. STRINGER, from the same Committee, returned sundry petitions for amendment of the law so as to authorize swinging gates on the highways in certain cases, reporting a bill on that subject.
Mr. STIVERS, from the Committee on County and Township Business, returned the Weights and Measures bill [S. 122] recommending its passage.
He also returned Mr. Milroy's bill [H. R. 240] to relieve county officers from penalties attaching to the Dog law of March 2,1865, recommending its passage.
Mr. CALDWELL, from the same Committee, returned the bill reducing the number of Justices of the Peace and Constables to one in each township, with a favorable recommendation.
Mr. HAMRICK, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the Corporation bill [S. 103] with an amendment in section 17.

He also returned Mr. Coffroth's Foreign Insurance bill [H. R. 207] with an amendment in Section 1. The provisions of this bill shall not be construed so as to exclude horse insurance and detective companies insuring against thieves.
Mr. HARRISON, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the Town bill [S. 163] recommending its passage.
He also returned Mr. Gregory of Warren's bill [H. R. 248] repealing limitations as to capital of manufacturing companies, recommending its passage.

Mr. FOULKE, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the Parks and Fair Grounds bill [S. 34] recommending that it be laid on the tablethe matter being embraced in the general bill defining municipal powers.
Mr. BUSKIRK, from the select committee thereon, returned his Court bill [H. R. 253] recommending its passage.
Mr. LOCKHART, from the select committee thereon, returned Mr. McVey's County Seats bill [H. R. 125] recommending its passage.
All favorable reports lie on the table under the rules.

div.head: NEW BILLS.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB introduced a bill [H. R. 277] for an act to amend sections 2 and 5 of the act providing for the organization of Circuit Courts, the election of Judges thereof, and defining their powers and duties; and providing Criminal, Circuit and Civil Courts. [He submitted this, he said, as the first of a series of four bills Nos. 277, 278, 279, 280) to provide a court for the speedy trial of criminals in Indianapolis, by which members of the Legislature may be protected in their pockets.]

Also a bill [H. R. 278] for an act creating the Sixteenth Judicial Circuit, and providing for the election of Prosecuting Attorney thereof; and providing for the transfer of actions thereto. [The Circuit is Marion countyopen for criminal trials, and shall try criminal cases alone.]

Also, a bill [H. R. 279,] for an act to amend sections 9 and 10 of the Act prescribing the powers and duties of Justices of the Peace in State prosecutions. [Persons charged with felony and misdemeanors (if there be a criminal court,) shall be held to appear therein.]

Also, a bill [H. R. 280,] for an act to amend section 14 of the Act to limit the number of Grand Jurors, and point put the mode of their selection, defining their jurisdiction, and repealing all laws inconsistent therewith, approved March 4, 1852. [Grand juries in Criminal Courts shall have cognizance of all felonies and misdemeanors, excepting such as are exclusively within the jurisdiction of Justices of the Peace.
These bills were referred to the Committee on the Organization of Courts.
Mr. WOODS introduced a bill [H. R. 281] for an act to amend sec. 12 of the act to authorize the construction of levees and drains, approved June 2, 1852 [Authorizes companies for draining purposes.]
On motion by Mr. COLLINS, it was referred to the Special Committee on that subject.

Mr. GRIFFITH introduced a bill [H. R. 282] for an act to regulate the mileage of sheriffs conveying convicts to the State Prison North; to amend sec. 7 of the act authorizing the removal of prisoners from the Southern to the Northern Prison, directing what convicts shall be sent to the Northern Prison, etc., approved
June 1,1861; and repealing the act regulating the mileage of sheriff's,, approved June 17, 1852. It was to establish uniformity, he said, in the sheriffs' mileage for conducting convicts to the Prison. It also adds another tier of counties to the Northern Prison district. There might be some inaccuracies as to distances; and he would move that it be referred to the Committee on the Northern Prison.
Mr. DUNHAM moved to amend the motion so as to refer it to the two Committees on the Northern and on the Southern Prisons.
It was so referred.
Mr. LASSELLE introduced a bill [H. R, No. 283] for an act to amend sections 1 and 2 of the act of January 31, 1855, fixing the times of holding Circuit Courts in the Eleventh Judicial Circuit.

He moved that it be referred to the Committee on Organization of Courts; but upon representation of Mr. Coffroth, it was referred to a Special Committee of Representatives from the counties interested, viz: Carroll, Grant,, Miami, Wabash, Huntington and Cass.

Mr. STENGEE introduced a bill [H. R. 284] for an act providing for the election of boards of directors of railroads, authorized by the laws of this State. [The Director shall have been a resident of the State for live years, etc.]
It was referred to a Select Committee of five.

The bill reported this morning from the Joint Committee on the State Debt [H. R, 285] for an act to provide a State debt sinking fund, for the payment of the principal and interest of the War Loan Bonds, and the five and the two-and-a-half per cent, stocks of the State therein named; prescribing the duties of the Auditor, Treasurer and Agent of State in relation thereto; providing for a clerk of said sinking fund, and fixing his salary; and providing a penalty for the violation of its provisions, and declaring an emergency, - [penalty not less than $100, nor more than $1,000, - ] was now read and passed to the second reading.
On motion of Mr. BEANHAM, it was
Ordered, That the bill lie on the table, and that 300 copies thereof be printed - 100 for the use of the Senate and 200 for the use of the House of Representatives.

The bill reported this morning from the Committee on Roads [H. R. 280] for an act to authorize County Commissioners to grant the right to erect swinging gates on county, township or private roads, - was now read, passed to the second reading, and referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Messrs. O'Brien, Shoaft of Allen, and Richards each obtained leave of absence on account of illness.

Mr. Cowgill's Common Carriers bill (H. R. 211) introduced on the 16th inst., coming up on the second reading, with the amendments reported by the Committee on Railroads, requiring 60 days instead of 30 days notice, etc.
The amendments were concurred in.
Mr. COWGILL thought that it would be better to make the storage five months instead of three months before notice of saleto make it conform to the Committee's amendment.
Mr. LOCKHART said five mouths was contemplated. The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Gregory of Warren's joint resolution (No. 20), for a memorial to Congress for equality as to the additional bounty and monthly pay of soldiers, coming up -
Mr. NEWCOMB proposed to amend so as to memorialize for a direct tax to pay these additional bounties.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, regarded the amendment as a proposition to destroy the joint resolution.
Mr. MILLER opposed the amendment for a tax. He would have a grant of land for the purpose.

Mr. NEWCOMB would include the suggestion in his amendment, viz: "Or that, in lieu of a money bounty, a grant of land he made for the bounty of such soldiers." Such a measure as that contemplated in the joint resolution would reduce the value of Government bonds. There were amongst us those desirous of further reducing the value of these bonds, by taxing them, in violation of the act of Congress. This consideration, taken together with the alternative proposition to grant lands, lie thought, ought to carry the amendment.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren. The resolution was now broad enough to authorize a grant of thanks.
Mr MILLER proposed to amend the joint resolution by inserting appropriately: "If consistent with the interests of the country."
It was adopted.
The vote on Mr. Newcomb's amendment discovered no quorum.
On motion by Mr. COLLINS, the House then took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER announced the special order, viz: the consideration of Mr. Shuey's temperance bill, No. 218.
On motion by Mr. SHUEY, it was postponed and made the special order for to-morrow at this hour - affirmative 45, negative 24.
Mr. RHOADS moved to reconsider the vote of the House of yesterday rejecting the amendment of Mr. Newcomb to Mr. Shuey's temperance bill.
It lies over under the rule.

Mr. LANE (by unanimous consent) introduced a joint resolution [H. R. 21] instructing our Senators and requesting our Representatives in Congress to give their influence to secure the passage of a law increasing the pension of privates and non-commissioned officers in the service of the United States, [to $16 per monthso as to make uniformity,] which was passed to the second reading.
Mr. COOK (by consent) presented the petition of John Rolliner and 1,100 others, for an amendment of the license law so as to hold minors responsible for impositions.

Mr. STEWART (by unanimous consent) submitted a concurrent resolution instructing our Senators and requesting our Representatives to secure such a modification of the act of April 19, 1816, appropriating the 16th section for common school purposes, as to provide that where said 16th section has been disposed of, some section contiguous thereto shall be granted for the use of schools.

Mr. STEWART stated the discrepancies between Congressional and civil townships, involving considerable labor. It was intended to do away with the resulting unnecessary labor on the part of the Township Trustees, Auditors and Superintendents. It had been
examined and approved by the Superintendent of Public Instruction; and that officer was anxious for the measure. It would save about six pages in the school law.
The resolution was adopted.

On motion by Mr. PETTIT (Mr. Henricks in the Chair) his back pay and bounty bill No. 156 was taken up. He knew that debate was not in order; but he would have unanimous consent to submit an amendment, so as to limit the office of the Washington Commissioner to two years. He also desired to amend so as to give the Governor the power of removal over these officers as well as the power of appointment.
Mr. SPENCER objected.
Mr. PETTIT would then submit the bill again to the vote.
The yeas and nays resulted - yeas, 45; nays, 35.
Mr. BURWELL, when his name was called, alleged that he should vote no, because it was a proposition to create new offices "to eat out the substance of the people."
So the bill fails for want of a constitutional majority.

div.head: THIRTEENTH ARTICLE.
div.p: The SPEAKER announced the consideration of Mr. Meredith's joint resolution No. 1, for amendment of the State Constitution, by striking out the thirteenth article thereof - the question being on the third reading.

Mr. BROWN moved to postpone and make it the special order for Saturday, 2 o'clock P. M. If this course were taken, some gentlemen would have opportunity to express their views against this proposition. To force it to a final vote now would violate plighted faith on the part of the majority.
Mr. DUNHAM. For one he was perfectly willing that the majority should pass it, reserving to ourselves the right of appeal to the people.

Mr. BROWN. That was but a difference of opinion between two great men. (Laughter.) But if gentlemen think best to press the vote this dark and lowering afternoon - the tint of the atmosphere corresponding with the color of the proposition - let them do it and stifle debate to the disregard of plighted faith.
Mr. NEWCOMB replied to the imputation of disregarding plighted faith. There would be time for us all to ventilate our rhetoric on some kindred question.
Mr. Brown's motion was rejected.
The joint resolution was passed the final reading in the House - yeas 51, nays 41 - as follows:

Yeas - Messrs. Atkinson, Bonner, Branham, Burnes, Caldwell, Chambers, Church, Cook, Cowgill, Cox. Ferris, Foulke, Gleason Gregory of Montgomery, Gregory of Warren, Griffith, Hamrick, Henricks, Hershey, Higgins, Hogate, Hoover, Johnson, Kilgore, Lane, Litson, Lockhart, Major, Meredith, Miller, Montgomery, McVey, Newcomb, Olleman, Prather, Reese, Rhoads, Rice, Riford, Sabin, Shuey, Sim, Stewart, Sullivan of P. & V., Trusler, Upson, Welch, Wright, Woods, Zeigler and Mr. Speaker - 51.

Nays - Messrs. Abbett, Boyd, Brown, Burwell, Buskirk, Coffroth, Colling Croan, Crook, Davidson, Dunhan, Glazebrook, Goodman, Groves, Hargrove, Harrison, Howard, Humphreys, Hunt, Lasselle, Lee, Lemon, Lapp, Milroy, O'Brien, Osborn, Patterson, Perigo, Pinney, Richardson, Roach, Shoaff of Allen, Spencer, Stenger, Stringer, Stuckey, Sullivan of Scott, Thacher. Weikel, White and Woodruff - 41.
On motion of Mr. ZEIGLER, Mr. Stivers had leave of absence on account of illness.

div.head: TAXATION FOR SCHOOLS.
div.p: The Senate Joint resolution No. 3, proposing amendment to the State Constitution in the 23d section of Article iv. so as to admit of legislation to enable cities and town to raise money by taxation for the support of Common Schools, without respect to a uniform rate, coming up on the third reading, it was passed the House of Representatives - yeas 56, nays 31.

Mr. Harrison's bill [H. R. 33] to amend the 8th section of the Liquor License Law of 1859, [for the protection of Sundays and election days the penalty $5;] coming up on the second reading with the Committee's amendment, making the penalty $10 instead of $5["not less than $10, nor more than $50."]
Mr. HARRISON showed that the sole object was to get a penalty.
The amendment of the Committee was adopted.
The bill was then passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 77, nays 7.

[Mr. COFFROTH demanded that the names, affirmative and negative, be called over by the Clerk. It was so ordered. - He made this request, because, on looking over the journal of last session he had discovered that he was recorded as voting in favor of Mr. Newcomb's bill [H. R. No. 47] investing the Trust funds in the bonds of the State; whereas, he was not present when the vote was taken, but was preparing himself and expecting to make active opposition to that bill. It was still pending in the Senate.]
Mr. Thacher's Delinquent Tax-list bill [H. R. 177] coming up (with the amendment heretofore reported) on the third reading.
The amendment was adopted.
Mr. THACHER explained that it was to raise the printer's compensation from 30 cents to 60 cents; and to make the rate uniform throughout the State.
The bill was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 51, nays 27.

Mr. Griffith's joint resolution No. 17, to amend sec. 3 of art. 4 of the State Constitution so as to provide for annual sessions of the General Assembly, coming up - it was ordered to engrossment and third reading.
Mr. BUSKIRK considered that the proposition was right.
Mr. DUNHAM thought we had enough of legislation - such as it is.
Mr. COFFROTH doubted at this time the propriety of any amendment to the fundamental law. We have just emerged from war, etc.

Mr. GRIFFITH. The State of Ohio was compelled to make a similar amendment to their new Constitution. He thought it was manifestly the wisest course here now to give the proposition a trial before the people.

Mr. MILLER agreed with Mr. Dunham. A called session would dispose of business cheaper, in less time, and to better satisfaction, than when a new organization is made and new officers are to be elected.

Mr. NEWCOMB had always regarded this
system of biennial sessions as a wasteful one. A called session always exposed the Governor to unpleasant partisan imputations. He reasoned at length in favor of the proposition, replying in detail to the objections.
Mr. MILROY spoke in favor of the proposition.

Mr. BUSKIRK pursued the argument in favor of the joint resolution - alleging losses to the school and other funds for lack of a just taxation; and heavy losses to the State on account of executive usurpations in the absence of legislation.

Mr. DUNHAM expressed his opinion and experience. He submitted whether there had not been as odious usurpation when the Legislature has been in session as when not in session? If laws passed once in two years will not restrain them, laws passed every year would not. "The world is governed too much; " and herein Was and always had been the difficulty in the State of Indiana, The great general principles of legislation stand from age to age. He was for the stability, the un-changeability of laws once received and accepted as wholesome and just.

Mr. SHUEY replied, showing the insufficiency of time for legislation, as the Constitution now stands. The evils complained of were referable to hasty legislation, on account of the restriction as to time.
The joint resolution was rejected - yeas 39, nays 48.
On motion by Mr. KILGORE, the House (at 4:45) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT, pro tem., commanded order at 9 o'clock A. M.
On motion by Mr. GIFFORD, the reading of yesterday's journal was dispensed with.

The PRESIDENT, pro tem., laid before the Senate an invitation to be present - Thursday, December 7, 2 o'clock P. M.at the laying of the corner stone of the new Temple, to be erected in Indianapolis by the Hebrew congregation.

Mr. NOYES presented a communication from the State Librarian, calling attention (by request of the owner) to the fact that General Alvin P. Hovey possesses and offers for sale the only complete set of the laws and acts of Indiana extant, from the date of its territorial organization.
It was referred to the Committee on the State Library.
Mr. BEESON presentated a petition praying for repeal of the black laws, which was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

div.head: NEGRO TESTIMONY.
div.p: Mr. MILLIGAN from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned the bill S. No. 219 defining who shall be competent witnesses to testify in any court of Judicial proceeding in this State, [without distinction of color,] recommending its passage, with an amendment adding the words "or blood," after the word "color."

Mr. BROWN of Wells, was a member of this Committee, but they determined to make this report at a meeting when he was not present. It was his intention to prepare a minority report. He would like to have the matter passed over until he could have time to prepare his report. He moved that the bill and report be laid on the table and made a special order for Tuesday next at 2 o'clock, P. M.
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. VAN BUSKIRK, from the Committee on Education, returned the bill, S. No. 255, to amend sec. 2 of An Act for the incorporation of high schools, etc., recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill read the second time.

div.head: THE COMMON SCHOOL FUND.
div.p: Mr. CHAPMAN, from the Committee on Finance, returned the bill, H. R. 47, to increase the powers of the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, and to authorize said Board to loan any moneys belonging to said Funds in Indiana State Bonds or stocks, and providing for the canceling of such bonds or stocks, and the reissuing of new non-negotiable bonds or stocks, payable to said Funds; with sundry amendments, recommending its passage.

The first Committee amendment, striking out all after the word "discretion," in the seventh line of the first section, including the word "to," in the fifteenth line of the same section the discretion given to the Commissioners to loan money to individuals;and striking out the word "fund" in the 18th line of the same sec. to the word "whenever" in the 23d line; being read -
Mr. OYLER raised a point of order that substantially the same amendment was voted down by the Senate on yesterday; and could not be again brought before the body in this way.
Mr. WILLIAMS read from Jefferson's Mannal to sustain the action of the committee in this particular.
The PRESIDENT, pro tem., decided that the point of order was not well taken.
On motion of Mr. BROWN, of Wells, the amendment was laid on the table by yeas 24, nays 22 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Barker, Bennett, Borbam, Bowman, Brown of Weils, Cobb, Corbin, Cullen, Douglas, Fitch, Fuller, Gaff, Gifford, Hanna, Hord, Jinkens, McClurg, Mason, Moore, Newlin, Oyler, Richmond, Staggs and Mr. President - 24.

NAYS - Messrs Allison, Beeson, Bradiey, Brown of Hamilton, Cason, Chapman, Davis, Dykes, Hyatt, Marshall, Milligan, Nites, Noyes, Reagan, Terry, Thompson, Van Buskirk, Vawter, Ward, Williams, Woods and Wright - 22.
The second amendment proposed by the Committee was then read. It is as follows:

"Strike out all of the second sec. and insert the following: 'Sec. 2 On or before the fourth Monday of April, 1866, and on or before the fourth Monday of April in each year thereafter until all the assets of the Sinking Fund shall have been invested in the bonds and certificates of stocks of the State, it shall be the duty of the Board of Sinking Fund ommissioners to make out a correct list of the bonds and stocks held by them, and deliver the same with said bonds and stocks to the Auditor of State, who shall give his receipt for the same, setting forth the amount of such particular kind of bonds and stocks, and upon receipt of the name, he shall enter them in a register prepared for that purpose, the amount, number, and rate of interest paid by the State on the same, and when to entered it shall be the duty of the Auditor of State, in the presence of the Treasurer and Secretary of State, to burn the same, and they shall enter upon said register an account of the same, signed by the Auditor, Treasurer and Secretary of State, and the proper Officers now authorized by law to issue bonds shall issue to the Common School Fund a new non-negotiable
bond payable at the pleasure of the State, for an amount, equal to the aggregate of all the bonds and certificates so surrendered, which bond shall bear interest at the rate of six per cent, per annum, payable semi-annually, on the fourth Monday of April and 15th day of October in each year thereafter, which bond shall be registered in a book kept by the Auditor for that purpose, setting forth the date and amount of the same."
On motion of Mr. CULLEN, this amendment was also laid on the table, by yeas 27, nays 22, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs Barker, Bennett, Bonham, Bowman, Brown of Wells, Cobb, Corbin, Cullen, Culver, Douglas, English, Finch, Fuller, Gaff Gifford, Hanna, Hord, Jinkens, Marshall, McClurg, Mason, Moore, Newlin, Oyler, Richmond, Staggs and Mr. President - 27.

NAYS - Messrs. Allison, Beeson, Bradley, Brown of Hamilton, Cason, Chapman, Davis, Dykes, Hyatt, Milligan, Niles, Noyes, Reagan, Terry, Thompson, Van Buskirk, Vawter, Ward, Williams, Woods and Wright - 22.
The third committee amendment was read, as follows:
Amend the title as follows: Strike out the word "board" in the fourth line, all including the word "and" in the fifth line.
On motion of Mr. COBB, this amendment was laid on the table by yeas 28, nays 20.
The fourth and last committee amendment was read, as follows:
Strike out the word "said" in the eleventh line, and insert the words "the common school."
On motion of Mr. BROWN, of Wells, this amendment was also laid on the table by yeas 27, nays 21.

Mr. WILLIAMS. The first section of this bill is very lame - it jeopardizes this fund. He did not distrust the capacity or honesty of the Commissioners, but he objected to that provision which empowers them to lend this fund in accordance with laws heretofore passed. By passing this bill you repeal all laws heretofore passed coming in conflict therewith, then what law is there governing the loaning of this money?

Mr. COBB. The law of 1859. In his judgment the provision for the loaning of this fund is not in conflict with that law. But if this bill does repeal that Act, it is a fair deduction of law that it revives the old law.
Mr. ALLISON. Our own Supreme Court have decided that no act of the Legislature shall be revived by a subsequent enactment, unless it is so expressly stated.

Mr. WILLIAMS was sorry to see Senators running against the Constitution, which says: "No act shall be revised or amended by mere reference to its title," (and this bill does not go even that far,) "but the act revised or section amended, shall be set forth and published at full length."
Mr. COBB made an ineffectual demand for the previous question - affirmative 21, negative 22.
Mr. BRADLEY moved to strike out that portion of the bill which gives authority to the Sinking Fund Commissioners to loan the money.
Mr. CULLEN raised the point of order that a similar proposition having been voted down by the Senate, this amendment is not in order.
Messrs. BRADLEY and VAWTER contended that the point of order was not well founded.
The PRESIDENT pro tem, was inclined to think the amendment in order, and so decided.

Mr. BEESON was forcibly struck with the propriety of this amendment, and believed a sense of duty as a representative of a portion of the State, required that his voice should be heard in opposition to the loose manner in which that bill, as it now stands, is placing the most sacred fund that belong to future generations. He believed the intention of the people of the State and of members of this Legislature was that these Sinking Fund Commissioners should invest the means belonging to the various funds of the State in their hands in the outstanding indebtness of the State and bring it home. He found the ablest Attorneys on this floor disputing as to the restrictions or powers conferred by this bill; and proceeded to make a lengthy argument earnestly urging the adoption of the amendment.
Mr. WRIGHT could not consent to vote for this bill unless some restrictions are thrown around it.
Mr. VAN BUSKIRK thought all doubts should enure to the benefit of this fund; and in order that this matter may be inquired into, he moved the reference of the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. McCLURG favored the motion to refer, not as an opponent of the bill, but wishing for a fair investigation of the question as to what effect this act would have upon the law of 1859; and as to the weight of other points which have beeen raised during the discussion.

Mr. OYLER resisted the motion to recommit because of the necessary delay, not to this bill only but to other matters of legislation; and because he believed all the light that can be thrown on this matter is now before the Senate. He moved to lay the motion on the table.
This latter motion was rejected by yeas 21, nays 27.
The question recurring on the motion to recommit -

Mr. COBB could see no good to result from a recommitment of the bill. He was willing to risk this fund where the bill places it, and believed the effect of referring it to the Judiciary Committee would be to jeopardize its passage; and that the object of the motion was to defeat the bill.
Mr. VAN BUSKIRK disclaimed that. On the contrary, he desired the bill should pass, with proper restrictions.

Mr. COBB. These Commissioners have been blamed for retaining so large a sum of money contrary to the provisions of law; but they did so upon the advice of Governor Morton, and other friends of the fund. And he understood there was an arrangement already made by which they can invest this money in bonds at a benefit to the fund of about $200,000, in case this bill passes. He argued at length the merits of the bill.Mr. CASON disclaimed the statement that the object of reference was to kill the bill - its oldest and warmest friends are now desiring the reference. He hoped the motion would prevail, and that the Judiciary Committee may bring in a report deciding the question by what law this fund is to be loaned. A conversational debate across the chamber brought out the concession from Senators, both opposed and in favor of the bill, that gentlemen in the'House of Representatives who drove the bill through that body last session were now anxious to see it "squelched."
The motion to recommit was agreed to, by yeas 26, nays 22.

div.head: LEAVES OF ABSENCE
div.p: Were granted to Mr. Chapman till Tuesday, Mr. Wood till Wednesday, Messrs. Bonham and Finch during next week, and Mr. Geff indefinitely.
And then the Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The Senate met at 2 o'clock.
Leaves of absence were obtained for Mr. Terry till Wednesday, and for Mr. Reagan, on account of a death in his family.

Mr. CULLEN, from the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements, returned the bill S. 249, defining the powers of companies authorized to construct canals for hydraulic purposes; recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill read the second time.
Mr. COBB, from the Judiciary Committee returned the bill S. 237, requiring all property hereafter sold under process of law to be sold without appraisement; recommending that it lie on the table.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. NILES, from Judiciary Committee, returned the bill S. 223 to authorize married women under the age of 21 years to join the husband in conveyancing of lands of the husbands.
The report was concurred in and the bill was read the second time.
Mr. BROWN, of Wells, offered the following:

Resolved. That the Auditor of State be and he is hereby requested to communicate to the Senate at his earliest convenience, the current expenses of the State Government each year, commencing with the fiscal year 1851, and ending with the date of his report, specifying the particular account upon which such expenses were incurred and paid.
The resolution was adopted.

div.head: BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
div.p: Mr. CORBIN offered the following:

Resolved, That the Auditor is hereby directed to draw his warrant on the Treasurer of State in favor of A. E. & W. H. Drapier for BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS furnished last session, in compliance with resolutions then passed; to be paid out of the fund appropriated for Legislative expenses.
The resolution was adopted.

div.head: NEW BILLS.
div.p: Mr. OYLER introduced a bill [S. No. 268] for An Act to invest the Circuit Courts of this State with exclusive original jurisdiction in applications for Divorces, and to prescribe the terms upon which Divorces may be granted in cases where the causes of divorce relied on accrued elsewhere than in this State.

Mr. ALLISON introduced a bill [S. No. 269] for An Act requiring County Auditors to make examination of the records in their offices in reference to the school funds, and make a report, and providing compensation therefor, and declaring an emergency.

Mr. CASON introduced a bill [S. No. 270] to amend sees. 8 and 10 of An Act regulating the fees of officers, and repealing former acts in relation thereto, approved March 2, 1855. [Increasing the fees of Auditors and County Commissioners].

Mr. DOUGLAS introduced a bill [S. No. 271] for An Act to amend section 1 of An Act authorizing Justices of the Peace, Notaries Public, &c., to administer oaths generally, &c., approved March 9, 1861. [Including County Auditors.]
Mr. DYKES introduced a bill [S. No. 272] for An Act to amend section 12 of An Act to provide for a general system of common schools, &c., approved March 6,1865.
Mr. WEIGHT introduced a bill [S. No. 273] for An Act to legalize the action of the State Board of Equalization at their sessions of 1864.
Mr. HORD introduced a bill [S. No. 274] concerning pleadings in the matter of claims against the estate of decedents.

Mr. RICHMOND introduced a bill [S. No. 275] for An Act providing for extending the terms of Circuit Courts by adjournment when the pending business shall be unfinished, etc. [The Judge to receive $8 per day for holding said terms.]
Mr. BONHAM introduced a bill [S. No. 276] for An Act to amend section 26 of An Act providing for the election and qualification of Justices of the Peace, etc.

Mr. CULVER introduced a bill [S. No. 277] for An Act providing for the location of an Agricultural College in Tippecanoe county, and supplemental to the Agricultural College Act, approved March 6. 1865.
Mr. HORD introduced a bill [S. No. 278] for An Act to amend section 35 of the valuation and assessment act, approved June 21, 1852, and providing when the same shall take effect.
These bills were read the first time and severally, passed to the second reading.
Pending the introduction of bills -
Mr. BENNETT presented a petition praying for the repeal of the so-called black laws, which was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. HANNA, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill, S. 229, supplemental to An Act authorizing the purchase of railroads, plank-roads, etc., under mortgage sales, etc., approved March 5, 1859, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: WELLS COUNTY COURTS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BROWN, of Wells, his bill, S. 265, in relation to the Wells' Circuit Court, was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 44, nays 0.

div.head: ADOPTED CHILDREN.
div.p: Mr. NILES, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill S. No. 233 to enable any child adopted under the laws of any State in the United States to hold real estate by descent, as if said child had been adopted under the laws of the State of Indiana, recommending its passage.
On motion by Mr. WILLIAMS, the bill was considered engrossed, read the third time, and finally passed the Senate by yeas 38, nays 2.

div.head: ISAAC D. ARMSTRONG.
div.p: On motion of Mr. McCLURG, his bill S. No. 227, for the relief of Isaac D. Armstrong, Treasurer of Clinton county, [$1,502 State funds stolen from him,] was read the third time.

Mr. DUNNING [Mr. Allison in the chair] did not want to encumber the passage of this bill, and would not do so, but would like to
have it amended, by unanimous consent of the Senate, so as to include the case of the Treasurer of Brown county, which he urged last session, in the provisions of this bill.
Mr. COBB gave notice that if this bill passes he should offer a similar one for the relief of one of his constituents - an ex-treasurer - a case as meritorious as this one can possibly be.
Mr. DUNNING withdrew his amendment, and gave notice that should this bill pass he would introduce a bill providing for the case of Mr. Williams, ex-treasurer of Monroe county.
Mr. BEESON referred to the case of an ex-treasurer of Henry county - as honest a man as ever the sun of Heaven shone upon - for whose relief he would introduce a bill in case this one passes.
Mr. McCLURG urged the passage of the measure, giving additional reasons why the bill should be passed.

Mr. TERRY referred to a petition which had come up here praying for the relief of Mr. Mann, late Treasurer of Fulton county, who was robbed of some $4,000 belonging to the State; and whose family are now in want because of his having to pay this loss out of his own means. And it is thought by some his death was hastened by this misfortune. If any case of this kind is relieved by legislative enactment this should be one among the first to receive attention.
After further remarks by Messrs. NILES, CULLEN, BENNETT and VAN BUSKIRK -
The bill was finally passed the Senate by yeas 31, nays 10.

div.head: TAXATION OF RAILROADS.
div.p: Mr. CORBIN, from a majority of the Select Committee thereon, returned the bill S. No, 250, to secure a just valuation of Railroad property, recommending its passage, with amendments.
The amendments were agreed to.
Mr. VAWTER, from a minority of the same Committee, read a lengthy minority report dissenting from the conclusions of the majority.
The bill was read the second time; and -
On motion by Mr. CORBIN it was recommitted to the same Committee.

div.head: THE INCURABLE INSANE.
div.p: Mr.NILES, from the Committee on Benevolent Institutions, returned the bill S. No. 201 to provide for the care and treatment of the incurable insane of the State, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in.
On motion of Mr. BRADLEY the bill was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 40, nays 0.

div.head: THE JUDICIAL SYSTEM.
div.p: Senate bills No. 183, to establish a probate court in each county of the State; No. 266, providing for the organization of circuit courts, etc., and 267, redistricting the State for Judicial purposes, were read by title only and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

div.head: DECATUR AND OTHER COUNTY COURTS.
div.p: The bill S. No. 66, amending section 11 of An Act fixing the times of holding common pleas courts, approved March 5, 1859, coming up in regular order, it was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 42, nays 2.

div.head: BLACKFORD COUNTY LINES.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BONHAM the bill S. 140 to amend section 8 of An Act dividing the State into counties, defining their boundaries, etc., was taken up.

Mr. BROWN, of Wells, since this bill was up the other day had ascertained that the citizens of Jay county, sought by this bill to be attached to the county of Blackford, were unanimously opposed to the arrangement. He called attention to a Constitutional provison which bears upon this bill - section 7, article xv. The county of Jay comes in under the second clause of this section. That provision of the Constitution would make a bill of this kind unconstitutional if passed. He moved to recommit the bill to the Judiciary Committee, that they may inquire into the matter and report thereon.

Mr. BONHAM recited the provisions of the bill, and contended that its object was to correct a mistake, and consequently could not be effected by the constitutional question raised by the Senator from Wells.
The motion to recommit was agreed to.
On motion by Mr. CORBIN, the bill H. R. 158 was referred to the special committee on railroad appraisement.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The SPEAKER took the Chair at 9 o'clock, A. M., and directed the roll-call, to determine a quorum; and sixty-nine members having responded -
On motion by Mr. BONNER, the journal of yesterday was authenticated without reading.
Mr. HOWARD and Mr. SIM presented memorials for temperance, and Mr. BOYD a memorial for claims; which were referred without reading.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. HIGGINS, from the Committee on Ways and Means, returned Mr. Henrick's Gettysburg National Cemetery appropriation bill [H. R. 269,] recommending'its passage.

Mr. COWGILL, from a majority of the Committee on the Judiciary, returned Mr. Foulke's Indian and Negro testimony bill [H. R. 25] with amendments: - amending title by inserting this: "And so much of all other laws as render persons incompetent on account of color." Inserting in the bill a clause to this effect: " And so much of all other laws as render persons incompetent to testify in the Courts on account of color;" and to this effect: The testimony of no person shall be discredited on account of negro, Indian or mixed blood, but creditibility shall be determined by the Court and jury, etc.
On motion of Mr. BROWN, further time was granted to the minority of said Committee to report on this bill.
Mr. COWGILL, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the Joint Contract bill [S. 44] with a motion that it be laid on the table.
It was so ordered.
He also returned Mr. Kilgore's insurance bill [H. R. 236], recommending its passage.
Mr. TRUSLER, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned the legalizing bill [S. 36], recommending its passage.

He also returned Mr. Wood's joint resolution [H. R. No. 4] proposing to so amend the Constitution in article 4, section 23, that the people of cities, towns, townships and school districts may tax themselves for schools without regard to a uniform rate, recommending its indefinite postponement, for the reason that the House has passed a resolution from the Senate on the same subject.

Mr. WOODS stated the distinction between his joint resolution and that from the Senate his resolution authorizing the special taxation In "townships and school districts" as well as "cities and towns." The Committee were only to put the joint resolution in form. He showed the importance of extending this privilege to the townships and school districts - as now authorized in the State of Illinois, where these common schools were advanced so as to be justly regarded as the best schools in that State.
Mr. COWGILL replied, that it would make distinctions in schools, and overthrow the system.
Mr. WOODS. There was a salutary practical illustration of it in the State of Illinois.
Mr. LANE looked favorably on the joint resolution; it would be inconsistent to favor the cities to the neglect of the townships and school districts.
Mr. NEWCQMB would have voted for an amendment to include townships and school districts, just as readily as he did for the Senate resolution.
On his motion the joint resolution was recommitted to the Committee on the Judiciary .
Mr. TRUSLER, from the Judiciary Committee, returned Mr. Newcomb's absentee's estate bill [H. R. 77] recommending its passage.
Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the Aurora Turnpike bill [S. 60], recommending its passage.
Mr. MILLER, from the Committee on Ways and Means, returned Mr. Groves' Delinquent tax bill [H. R. 247], recommending its passage.
Mr. SPENCER, from the Committee on the Organization of Courts, returned Mr. Church's change of venue bill [H. R. 261], recommending its passage.
Mr. CHURCH, from the Committee on Swamp Lands, returned the Swamp land bill [S. 104], recommending that its consideration be indefinitely postponed.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. BOYD and Mr. VEACH, from the Committee on Claims, returned the claims of John F. Kibby ($450) and Charles Kimber (for $60) recommending their incorporation in the Specific bill.
The reports were referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.
Mr. MAJOR, from the Committee on Fees and Salaries, returned Mr. Stiver's Dog law bill [H. R. 268], recommending its passage.
He also returnded Mr. Wright's Clerk's per centage bill [H. R. 266], recommending its indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. BURNES, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned the Roads' Committee Swing-gate bill [H. R. 286] recommending its passage.

Mr. HAMRICK, from the Committee on Corporations, returned Mr. Stewart's town corporation bill [H. R. 170] recommending that itbe laid on the table, as its object is embraced in a bill now in the files of the House.
The report was concurred in.
He also returned Mr. Olleman's turnpike bill [H. R. 230] recommending that the bill be laid on the table.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. LOCKHART, from the Committee on Railroads, returned the railroad bill [S. 114] recommending its passage.
Mr. SHOAFF, of Jay, from the Select Committee thereon, returned his court bill [H. R. 272] recommending its passage.
He also returned his Common Pleas bill [H. R. 275], recommending its passage.

Mr. HIGGINS, from the Committee on Public Expenditures, returned Mr. Gregory of Montgomery's per diem and mileage bill [H. R. 270] with amendments: The Principal Secretary of the Senate and of the House $5 per diem and mileage as a member. The per diem of the Principal, Assistant Secretary and Clerk, and the Principal Doorkeeper, $5 per day for everyday employed; their appointees $4 per day; the Pages $2; Clerk of the Committee on Ways and Means $5; other Committee Clerks $4 per day for the time actually employed.

On motion by Mr. HENRICKS, the vote on the final passage of the joint resolution [S. No. 3] for amendment to Article 5, section 23, of the State Constitution, was reconsidered, and it was referred again to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions to amend so as to include the words, "townships and school districts."

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: Mr. MAJOR introduced a bill [H. R. 287] for An Act to amend the 43d section of the Act providing for the settlement of decedents' estates, approved June 17, 1852. [The widow to take $500 instead of $300.]
It was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. KILGORE introduced a bill [H. R, 288,] for an act providing for extending the term or Circuit Courts by adjournment, where the pending business may be unfinished; prescribing rules for the extension of such terms, and for calling special terms, and prescribing compensation to such Judges for holding special terms.
It was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. HOWARD introduced a bill [H. R. 289,] for an act to amend section 2 of the act regulating the fees of officers, and repealing, etc., approved March 2, 1855. [It regulates Clerk's fees.]
It was referred to the Committee on the Organization of Courts.

Mr. SIM introduced a bill [H. R. 290] for an Act to amend section 51 of the act to provide for the election and qualification of Justices of the Peace, etc., approved June 9, 1852. [Any juror for refusing or neglecting to attend shall be liable to like penalties and to be proceeded against in the same manner as a witness refusing to attend.]
It was passed to the second reading.

Mr. VEACH introduced a bill [H. R. 291] for an Act to fix the times of holding Court in the 6th Judicial District, and repealing all laws in conflict therewith. [Affecting the counties of Sullivan, Vigo, Clay, Putnam, Greene, Monroe, Morgan and Owen.]
On motion of Mr. BUSKIRK, it was referred to a select Committee of five members from the District.

Mr. KILGORE, introduced a bill [H. R. 292] for an act to limit the liability of Innkeepers. [They shall not be liable for losses sustained by their guests, unless upon delivery or offer of delivery of the lost goods for custody, etc.]
It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. HUMPHREYS submitted the following:

Resolved, That the Committee on the Organization of Courts of Justice be instructed to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the Court of Common Pleas, transferring the civil and criminal business therein to the Circuit Courts, and establishing instead thereof a Court having exclusive Probate Jurisdiction.
On motion by Mr. PRATHER, it was referred to the Select Committee of one from each Congressional District,, raised by a resolution offered by Mr. Goodman.

On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, the House (by consent) took up the consideration of Mr. Gregory of Warren's per diem and mileage bill [H. R. 270], introduced November 28, and described in these reportsthe question being on the amendments of the Committee on Public Expenditures, reported this day.

Mr. NEWCOMB moved to concur in the first amendment of the Committee on Public Expenditures, and non-coneur in those relating to mileage for Principal Secretary and Clerk; and add that the Speaker of the House and President of the Senate be allowed each a clerk at $4 a day.
After debate by Mr. SIM, Mr. HENRICKS, and Mr. BUSKIRK,On motion by Mr. BROWN, the bill and pending amendments were referred to a Special Committee consisting of Messrs. Newcomb and Henricks.
Mr. BROWN introduced a bill [H. R, 293] for an act to amend sec. 4 of the act containing several provisions regarding landlords, tenents, lessors and lessees, approved May 20,1852.
It was passed to the second reading.

Mr. PETTIT (Mr. Hamriek in the Chair) introduced a bill [H. R. 294] for an act to provide for securing to the Common School fund sums forfeited on recognizances, and the modes for declaring their forfeiture.

Mr. P. explained that if these forfeited recognizances were properly husbanded, an addition might be made annually to the school fund of from $50,000 to $100,000. But the present system not only entirely failed to bring anything into the fund, but if the person arraigned is able to get bail, he may constantly defy the demands of justice. It was also a principal object of the bill to prevent these conspiracies between criminals and their wealthy friends. It was to make the forfeiture absolute the second time the culprit runs away, so that it cannot be relieved except upon remission of the Governor.
It was passed to the second reading, referred to the Judiciary Committee, and 200 copies ordered to be printed.

Mr. GRIFFITH submitted an order, which was adopted, for 200 copies of the Message of the Acting Governor, transmitting the Report of Andrew Wallace, President of the Board of Trustees of the State Benevolent Institutions, and the Report of the Board of Control of the Northern Prison, together with said documents.

Mr. LASSELLE introduced a bill [H. R. 295] for an act to amend section 1 of the act to exempt property from sale in certain cases, approved February 17, 1852. [Any amount of property not exceeding $150 (in addition to the $300) shall not be liable to execution after the 4th day of July, 1866.]
It was passed to the second reading and referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. RICE introduced a bill [H. R. 296] for an act defining vagrancy, and prescribing punishment therefor. [Penalty not exceeding $100confinement in the county jail not exceeding six months.]
It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. MILLER introduced a bill [H. R, 297] for an act to provide that any forfeited recognizance in criminal proceedings shall become an absolute judgment against the bail, and collected without suit thereon.It was passed to the second reading.
Messrs. Upson, Gregory of Warren, Boyd, Lockhart and Cook obtained leave of absence till next week.

div.head: BOUNTY AND PAY.
div.p: Mr. GREGORY of Warren's equal footing joint resolution, No. 20, coming up, with the amendments submitted yesterday by Mr. Miller and Mr. Newcomb -
Mr. GREGORY moved to lay Mr. Newcomb's amendment (for taxation) on the table.
No quorum voting thereon, a call of the House was ordered and proceeded. When eighty members answered, further proceedings were suspended under this order.

Mr. GREGORY was then heard in support of his resolution to equalize bounty and pay between the veterans and those who more recently enlisted in the late war. On his motion, Mr. Newcomb's amendment was laid on the table.
Mr. GRIFFITH proposed to amend by adding to this effect: And also grant pensions to the surviving soldiers of the war of 1812 who may have remained loyal to the government.
It was agreed to.
The joint resolution was then ordered to the engrossment and third reading.
Mr. Gregory of Warren's repeal fee bill [H. R. 234] - and
Mr. Coffroth's foreign guardian bill [H. R. 237] - coming up, they were paseed to the engrossment.

Mr. Rhoads' School bill [H. R. 245] amending sundry sections of the School laws, so as to change the time in which township trustees and school examiners shall make their reports, and reducing the fees of nuditors, coming up (the constitutional restriction being suspended - yeas 71) it was read by title and passed to the engrossment and third reading.

div.head: PER DIEM AND MILEAGE.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Select Committee thereon, returned Mr. Gregory of Warren's per diem and mileage bill [H. R. 270] with amendments:

list.item: Inserting in the title: "And other employees."

Amend the amendment of the Committee
on Public Expenditures, so as to make the pay of Principal Clerks $5, appointees $4, Speaker's and President's clerks $4, from the date of appointment. Folding Clerk $4 per day for time employed.
Amend further the said Committee's amendment so as to leave out the mileage for the Principal Secretary and Principal Clerk.

div.p: The report was concurred in; and so the bill was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Gregg's School-money Diversion bill [H. R. 249] coming up -
Mr. DUNHAM moved to indefinitely postpone.

Mr. NEWCOMB explained and defended the provisions of the bill. It was an act of simple justice that liquor license money should go into the County Treasury. He was willing to increase the school fund, but not in this roundabout manner. Why should his constituents be taxed with the evils of the license law, in jail fees, poor house expenses, and the denial of justice in civil actions, because of the amount of criminal business,for the benefit of schools in counties where society is not affected by drunkenness?

Mr. DUNHAM said his objection was not that the money should go to the county where the license is paid. But his objection was the diversion of the school fund. If the gentleman would change his bill so that this money shall be apprpriated to the school fund in each county, he would go for ithave the money appropriated in the township where collected.
Mr. NEWCOMB would move to commit it to the Judiciary Committee for modification.
Mr. SHUEY The object of the author of the bill would include the modification suggested.
The bill was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
On motion by Mr. GROVES, the House then took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The Speaker announced the special order, viz: the consideration of Mr. Shuey's Temperance bill [H. R. 218] - the question being on the third reading.

Mr. GREGORY, of Montgomery, took the floor, speaking of the deep popular feeling on the subject of Temperance, exhibited in the numerous memorals for the discouragement and suppression of tippling saloons. These were the great objects of popular complaint, and the Legislature should hear the popular voice in this regard. It was the protection of society that was involved in this question. When a Government was not founded in just moral principles, it contained within itself the elements of its own destructionto which he instanced the institution of slavery. Immorality would disregard law; and intemperance was immoralitythe parent of many vices. The suppression of intemperance would dispense with much of the expense of the execution of the criminal laws.He inveighed against the liquor trafficer as worse than the murdererthe assassin. Theft, arson, incendiarism, were venial crimes in comparison with those that poison the youth of the land with liquor. And yet these men received the protection of law. They opened the gates of hell in every street and alley, and on every cross-roads in the land. Should not the popular voice be regarded? He was pained to see, in numerous motions to postpone and to amend, that the voice of the people was not to be regarded here. He cared not for the political power supposed to be involved, and plead simply for the morality of the question He replied to the constitutional and commercial objections to the prohibition of liquor. Total prohibition was the same in principle as the prohibition of the traffic on election day. But if society could not be protected by direct legislation, he asked for the people the power to protect themselves in the provisions of the pending bill. He made an earnest appeal for the passage of the bill without further amendment. The County Commissioners would meet next Monday, and the opportunity to re-strain the traffic for the coining year by the passage of this bill was now lost; but still he would have the bill. Better late than never.

Mr. DUNHAM. No man appreciated the virtues of Temperance and Sobriety more highly than he. However we might differ as to the means of accomplishing the common relief on this subject, still we all desired to come to it. He knew that his views of the subject were not popular. He would change our whole system of legislation on this liquor question. He would not license, but would leave the whole matter in the hands of the people at large. License conferred respectability. This tippling business, like all others, should be regulated by the laws of trade. Such would be his plan. Day before yesterday he saw a large delegation of ladies in this House, to press the adoption of this measure by their influence. And no man was insensible to that influence - it was recognized in the speech of his friend (Mr. Rice) before him. He then referred to the home and family influence of woman as superior for good to all acts of legislation on this subject.

Here was the orbit of the influence of woman, which was to shape the character of the nation. Wherever the mother's sigh and the sister's prayer were unheard, there was no hope of reformation in such a subject. He would vote to-day for an appropriation for a hospital to which such men should be sent; and there was neither religion nor statesmanship in leaving society to take care of itself in this regard. But could legislation reach the case? The iron heel of military power could not restrain the appetite to drink. You could not restrain it any more than you could restrain the flood of waters in the Ohio river. Then, if we can not do what we would, we must do what we can; if we can not dam up the tide we may turn it.

If gentlemen believe that they can control this appetite they ought to do it; but, if they do not, then tie it up by license. He voted against the Sunday liquor bill the other day not that he did not regard the Sabbath, (for he did,) but because he regarded the Constitution which prescribes that legislation shall not regulate religion - shall not prefer one sacred day above another. But he undertook to say that this bill if it became a law, could not be enforced. He concurred with the gentleman who said in this debate, that you can not enforce a law when it is not demanded by the public sentiment. Was it not then to provoke and teach the violation of law, to enact a law that can not be enforced? He illustated by the neglect
of the 13th Article of the Constitution, uid the legislation in pursuance thereof; he also instanced the temperance mobs of men 'iii'd women despite the legal sanctions. He regarded this temperance legislation as a chronic habit in this State, and about as inveterate as the habit of the common drinker.

Mr. ZEIGLER was not alarmed at the cry of constitutionality. The Constitution had been constantly violated for the past five years, if we listen to some. Should we refrain wholly from legislation, because laws do not accomplish the ends they aim at? He alleged his own favorable opinion of this bill, and answered objections, replying specially to Mr. Dunham and Mr. Newcomb, deprecating the amendment of the latter; and he concluded by reciting the considerations that commanded his vote for the bill. It would remove a perplexing responsibility from the County Commissioners. It gave control of the traffic directly to the people. It was no objection to say it was an experiment; because no good could come of invention without experiment. Then this bill was demanded by the people: and if it had been pressed at the opening of the session, he believed it would have been passed by an overwhelming majority.

Mr. NEWCOMB said he could have had plain sailing on this question, if he had gone with the current; and if he yet should vote for the bill, it would be, not because it was supported by his own judgment, but in obedience to the desires of his constituents. Was it singular that he should be interested in perfecting a bill in which his constituents were deeply interested? and especially was his propositions to amend to be deprecated when gentlemen conceded that the original bill would not do the cities any good? and was it not also conceded that it was hardly needed in the rural districts? The printed matter of the petitions for this bill indicated that this form of demand for a bill was not the spontaneous action of the people. With the same means at his command he could get a stronger expression in favor of his amendments.

We must act practically. Can we enforce this bill? Where and when in a city was drinking ever suppressed by voting down license. lie recited and defended the provisions of the substitute, which he admitted to be an experiment. He would have much preferred, if he could, to have followed the judgment of others in his action here, and so avoided the imputations that have been cast upon him. We ought to do nothing in legislation, unless we think we can make some improvement. He replied to Mr. Dunham. For himself, he would prefer to repeal all license laws, making the liquor vender responsible for the consequences of his acts.

Mr. SHUEY said it was impossible to-day to get an expression of the representatives of the people on this bill, and regretted the necessity that would compel its friends to ask for a further postponement. He suggested Monday, 2 o'clock p. M. He had prepared the bill with reference to the wants of the people in his county. He candidly admitted that this bill could hardly be enforced in the cities. It would not be as efficient in the cities as the amendment of the gentleman from Marion. But there was a preponderating interest in this matter outside of the cities.

Mr. BROWN said his mind was made up, and he was ready for the vote. There was an admission that the bill would do no good in the cities. He would therefore waste no more time about it. He would dispose of it finally and at once, and go to more needful legislation. He did not like the bill, and he had before signified his earnest opposition to the amendment of the gentleman from Marion. He was satisfied with the act of 1859, whose provisions he recited. The fault was not with the act of 1859, but with the people in that they did not call proper men to the bar to prosecute those who violate the criminal laws; the fault was with those who refused to execute the laws as they are; and there was an utter fault somewhere in circulating petitions for a bill, and sending up here the particular form of a bill, which its friends admit can not be enforced. The right to sell whisky was as distinct as the right to sell milk. Legislation was to restrain and punish the abuse of the right to the detriment of society.
Mr. LANE desired to postpone the vote to Tuesday at 2 o'clock.
Mr. KILGORE preferred postponement. He would go on the record against the bill in the hope of getting a better.

Mr. DUNHAM and Mr. COFFROTH preferred that the House come to the vote this evening. The bill (said the latter) had got into such a position that there must be a district vote on it. One section, that which provides imprisonment for a second violation, was corroborated by his judgment. The difficulty about the enforcement of license laws in the city, was in the want of adequate penalty. There was nothing in the constitutional objection. But his only purpose was to induce the friends of the bill" to come at once to the vote.
Mr. GRIFFTH urged postponement till Tuesday.
Mr. BRANHAM desired unanimous consent to move to make the bill No. 285 a special order. ["Object: "Object."]
Mr. BROWN made an Ineffectual motion to lay the motion to postpone on the table.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem, commanded order at 9 o'clock A. M.
On motion by Mr. GIFFORD, the reading of yesterday's Journal was dispensed with.

div.head: STATE AGENT - SINKING FUND - STATE DEBT.
div.p: Mr. BRADLEY, by leave, introduced a bill [S. No. 279] for An Act to abolish the Indiana State Agency in the city of New York, the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners of this State, and all the offices connected therewith; and to invest the monies belonging to said fund, and the State Debt Sinking Fund, arid other funds, in the stocks and bonds of the State; and to transfer the business of said Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners to the offices of the Auditor and Treasurer of State, and also to provide for the adjustment of the debt of the State, by issuing coupon bonds for the present five per cent, registered stocks of the State.
It was read the first time, and on motion by Mr. B., 300 copies were ordered printed for the use of the Senate and House of Representatives.

div.head: APPORTIONMENT FOR REPRESENTATION.
div.p: Mr. CULLEN, from the Committee on Elections, returned Mr. Bennett's bill [S. No. 209] and Mr. Culver's bill [S. No. 189] for Acts to apportion Senators and Representatives for the next four years; recommending the passage of the former and that the latter bill lie on the table.
Mr. WILLIAMS had a substitute in preparation for the bill S. No. 209; and moved that the bills and report be laid on the table and made the special order for Wednesday next at 2 o'clock P. M.

Mr. OYLER said the bill did not meet with his approval. It disfranchises, in the lower House, his immediate constituents, which he was not disposed to submit to. As far as the Senatorial representation is concerned, I have no objection to that, although it is not as much as we are entitled to; but we have enjoyed a little excess of our rights in the House, as an offset to that. I therefore shall feel disposed to oppose the bill as long as I can. From my position as a member of the Committee on Elections, I do not want the Senate to understand me as endorsing that report.

Mr. VAWTER. I am one of the minority of that Committee. A bill acceptable to the minority was handed to the Senator from Vigo, I understand, and he is not here now.
