div.head: LIQUOR LICENSE LAW.
div.p: On the motion of Mr. MILROY, the special order viz, the consideration of Mr Shuey's Temperance bill [H R, 218] was taken up the queniion being on the third reading.
Mr RHODES called up bis motion to reconsider the vote by which Mr. Newcomb's substitute was rejected.
Mr BROWN made an ineffectual motion to lay the motion to reconsider on the table.
The House then refused to reconsider.
Mr. HENDRICKS moved to recommit the bill, with instructions to incorporate provisions similar to those described in his bill [H. R. No. 306] introduced this day.
Mr. SPENCER Those instructions were simply a rehash of the substitute by the Senator from Marion, which we have just voted down.
If there was merit or substance in anything proposed on this subject, it was the bill of the gentleman from Elkhart.
Mr HENRICKS explained the instructions which he proposed.
Mr GRIFFITH. Does it not militate against the amendment of the gentleman from Putnam?
Mr. HENRICKS. It throws part of the labor on the friends of Temperance.

Mr. GRIFFITH was opposed to leaving open the floodgates of vice for the sake of expediency. He would do right regardless of questions of political expediency. Without the great moral principle to which he referred, we could never have got rid of slavery. He would have the majority to govern in this matter of license. The motion to recommit was hostile to the original bill and the amendment by the gentleman from Putnam, (Mr. Lane.) He spoke generally to illustrate the importance of the principle he had announced As between prohibition and license, he was hardly prepared for prohibition - against sales for mechanical, medicinal and sacramentals purposes. What is morally wrong could not be legally right, and he did not want to see any question of political expediency involved in the consideration of this bill.

Mr SHUEY supposed that the bill was now in the least objectionable form. It assumed the traffic wrong - evil, and only evil, and that continually. Then it says, if a majority of the district are opposed to the traffic, that settles the question against it. Were gentlemen afraid of the people? The people had asked for the very terms of this bill in numerous petitions. Neither he nor the Committee were tenacious as to the form of the bill. He rather favored the provision by which the commissioners shall not issue
a license where a majority remonstrated. He would fight it out on this line, that a majority shall govern.

Mr. BROWN was surprised to see the gentleman from Elkhart (Mr. Shuey) yield the leading principle of his bill. Did the geatleman fear defeat? It was better in the language of the gentleman from Montgemery (Mr. Gregory) to sustain the right and trust to time for justification. It had been better for the gentleman's reputation as a statesman if he had maintained his original position. But he would leave the gentleman in the bands of his enemies - his friends gave him up. The instructions submitted by the gentleman from St. Joseph had their paternity from the gentleman from Marion (Mr .Newcomb ) It came of the desire of that gentleman to go to Congress. To the argument that it, was a Democratic measure, he replied, that laws were for the protection of minorities. Majorities could take care of themselves He illustrated the hardness which this remonstrating clause would work against the rights of retailers. As for the first ciaesof retailers, it was only a school for crime. The drinker begins with his cider and beer, and ends in confirmed inebriation.
Mr. BUSKIRK demanded the previous question, but would yield for explanation.
There was a second, and the main question was ordered.
Mr. BUSKIRK demanded the yeas and nays on Mr. Henrick's motion to recommit, and they were ordered, and being taken, resulted - yeas 38, nays 47 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Bonner, Boyd, Branham, Caldwell, Church, Cowgill, Cox, Davidson, Ferris, Foulke, Gleason, Goodman, Groves, Hamrick, Henricks, Hershey, Higgins, Hoover, Kigore. Lane, Major, Miller, McVey, Newcomb, Olleman, Rhoads, Rice, Riford, Roach, Sabin, Shoaff of Jay, Sim, Stewart, Stringer, Sullivan of Posey and Vanderburg, Woodruff, Wods and Mr Speaker - 38.

NAYS - Messrs. Abbott, Atkinson, Bird, Brown, Burnes, Burton, Burwell, Buskirk. Chambers, Coffroth, Collins, Cook, Croan,Crook, Glazebrook,Gregg, Gregory of Montgomery, Gregory of Warren, Griffith, Hargrove, Harrison, Hogate, Howard, Humphreys, Johnson, Lemon, Litson, Lopp, Meredith, Milroy, Montgomery, Osborn, Patterson, Perigo, Prather, Reese, Richardson, Shuey, Spencer, Stuckey, Thacher, Veatch, Weikel, Welch, White, Wright and Zeigler - 47.
So Mr. Henrick's motion was rejected.
Mr KILGORE moved to lay the bill on the table.
Mr STRINGER desired the unanimous consent of the House to offer a temperance petition numerously signod and just received from his constituents and have it referred.
Mr. GRIFFITH objected.
The House refused to lay the bill on the table yeas 27, nays 56.
Mr. BUSKIRK demanded the previous question on the recurring question, Shall the bill pass the third reading? and there was a second, and the main question was ordered.
The bill was then read through by the Clerk.
The final vote thereon resulted - yeas 34, nays 52 - as follows:

YEAS Messrs. Abbett, Atkinson, Bonner, Branham, Burnes, Caldwell, Chambers, Cox, Crook, Davidson, Ferris, Gregory of Montgomery, Griffith, Hamrick, Hershey, Hogate, Hoover, Johnson, Lane, Major, Miller, Montgomery, Reese, Rhoads, Sabin, Shuey, Stewart, Stringer, Stuckey, Sullivan, of P. & V., Welch, Woodruff, Wright, Zeifder - 34.

NAYS - Messrs. Bird, Boyd, Brown, Burfori, Burwell, Buskirk, Church, Coffroth, Collins, Cook, Cowgill, Croan, Foulke, Glazebrook, Gleason, Goodman, Gregg, Gregory, of Warren, Groves, Hargrove, Harrison, Henricks, Higgins, Howard, Humphreys, Kilgore, Lasselle, Lemon, Litson, Lopp, Meredith, Milroy, McVey, Newcomb, Olleman, Osborn, Parterson, Perigo, Prather, Rice, Richardson, Riford, Roach, Shoaff, of Jay, Sim, Spencer, Thacher, Veach, Weikel, White, Woods, Mr. Speaker - 52.
So the bill was rejected.

Mr BOYD asked to be excused from voting. He did not wish to com mitt himself to the bill or against it. He could support the majority clause, but he could not support the good moral character clause. The House refused to excuse him.
Mr. CHURCH and Mr. GROVES explained: They would vote against the bill, because the present license law was better, and they regarded the proposition of the gentleman from St. Joseph as a better bill.

Mr COWGILL would not vote for the passage of a law that he was not satisfied would be beneficial to the State. He was satisfied that if the party with which he was identified shall pass this bill, it will endanger the success of that party at the next election. ["That's honest."] His forty years political experience abundantly established the fact, that the people will not sustain anything like a prohibitory liquor law. If the Democratic party shall get a majority in the next Legislature, he believed it would be a greater evil to the country than any other which could befal it

Mr. GLAZEBROOK had ever been opposed to anything looking to a prohibitory liquor law. He made two speeches against the law of 1855. The gentleman had said the passage of this bill would work the downfall of the Republican party, but he warned that party of still more danger ahead in the negro question. He never dodged a vote. He would vote for an acceptable liquor bill, but not for this.

Mr. NEWCOMB had become satisfied from experience in legislation, that no law that proposed prohibition should ever be passed by one political party. He had seen the maneuvering of his Democratic friends to bring us to a square vote, and he was ready to vote squarely. Whenever they were willing to unite for the furtherance of Temperance, he would go with them; but he did not want to see his party take the burden alone. If they could etand the law as it is, he could. He voted for the prohibitory law ten years ago, which was overthrown, the Democratic party taking ground and succeeding against it, and he said then that he would not vote for another prohibitory law unless the Democrats also supported it. He voted against this bill because he regarded it as prohibitory. It would be a dead letter on the Statute book.
Mr. SIMS The bill was regarded as unconstitutional. It would remain a dead letter - just like the black laws.

Mr. ABBETT. The bill does not precisely meet my approbation. It is not what I desire. Every principle of my nature revolts at the license system. But having been an advocate of
the cause of temperance my entire life, upon the passage of this bill I cannot consistently vote against it; because I think it will in some degree suppress intemperance. It is believed by iny political opooneuts, that if this bill is passed it will throw the balance of power in the State into the hands of the Democratic party; and if there was no other consideration this side of Heaven that would induce me to vote for this bill, it certainly would be that of placing that party in power again.
Messrs. LASSELLE, COX, and HARRISON also explained, and Mr. RHOADS and Mr GLEASON were prevented by objections.
So the bill was lost.
On the motion of Mr. SHOAFF, of Jay, the House took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.
