div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM called up the special order, viz: The consideration of the Joint Committee's bill [H R No 285] to provide a State Debt Sinking Fund for the payment of the War Loan bonds, and the five and the two-and-a-half per cent. State Stocks therein named, etc.
It being on the second reading.
The bill was read through by the Clerk.
[On motion by Mr. BROWN, Mr Pinney obtained leave of absence on account of illness ]
On motion by Mr BRANHAM, the House resolved into Committee of the Whole - Mr. Henricks in the Chair - and took up the consideration of the State Debt Sinking Fund bill just read.
The first section coming up -

Mr. BRANHAM proposed to amend by inserting appropriately a clause to this effect: Together with all moneys derived from the sale of Public Works, and all funds belonging to the State Debt Fund, and all the revenue heretotore appropriated ro the State Debt Sinking Fund.

Mr. COFFROTH said the biil was homoge neous. The various provisions were for the single object of paying the State Debt within some nine or ten years; and it ought to be either supported or defeated as a whole. He proceded to give his reasons for voting against, the bill, upon a motion that the bill be reported back to the House with a recommendation that it be rejected. The bill proposed a tax of fifteen cents on the $100 to pay off the debt, including the War Loan Bonds, It was not a political - a partisan measure. The tax-gatherer was no respector of persons. The bill provides that the Auditor, Treasurer and Secretary of State constitute a Board for this purpose. Was the debt now due on the fives and two and a-half per cent. Bonds. If it were due, there was propriety in paying it at once. But the Governor tells us that it is not, and the two leading journals here tell us that it is not due. Without inquiring further, he took this as an accepted fact for the argument, that if the debt is not due, then we should make the best arrangement we can with our creditors. There were then two considerations against the passage of the bill. One was that the taxes were already too high. The people at this time, in the short-crop localities, were in some cases actually mortgaging their farms for tax money. The people of Indiana were required to raise the enormous sum of $15,000,000 in taxes during the present year. The other reason of opposition was, that one-fifth of the property of the State of Indiana was exempt from taxation. If he was right, this was a good reason for bis opposition.

He found that, there were seventy national banks, holding $14,000,000 of national stocks. He was informed that the other deposits of these banks, by the National Treasurer, was as high as one million, making $15.000.000. And besides these, there were other stocks not taxable, held by capitalists in the State that would swell this aggregate to $50 000,000 - these were the holders of "five-twenties," "seven-thirties" and "ten-forties " But in addition to this, he showed, from the decision of the Supreme Court, in the case of Whitney against the city of Madison, that all bank stock with a basis of national stocks were exempt from taxation. Then there was on this basis a circulation in the State of, say $50,000,000 more, and this made the round sum of $100,000,000 exempt from taxation. He read from the act of Congress to show this: greenbacks, national currency, etc., every dollar in money, is exempt from taxation. Then comes the question: Is there any propriety in providing by taxation to pay the State debt now, when we can not call upon the capitalists of the State to pay a dollar of it? Was it right, proper, fair or honest? He submitted that it was not. He submitted further, that this state of things shall not always exist. Congress may repeal, and allow the States to tax national stocks, may retrace a step which they have taken in an unfortunate and unguarded mo meat. Replying to the consideration that this act of of Congress was right, that it was to obtain the needful means to carry on the war, he alleged his opinion it would hive been as easy to draft the money of the country as to draft the muscle and the life of the country. Money was not more valuable than blood. He submitted the further consideration, that the State's creditors had agreed to take the five and two and a half per cent interest And this was about as high a rate as othe investments pay. He instanced investments in agriculture. He submitted, also, that the four thousand millions of debt of the Government of Great Britain paid but three per cent interest So we could not pay this six percent, rate of interestwe could not do it now, and if we could not pay it now, in the present fancied, unusual tide of
prosperity, we would be compelled inevitably, and in a short time, he thought, to come down ourselves to a rate of interest that could be paid, and this would then be repudiation These were his reasons for opposition. We should not compel the laborers and traders of the State to pay this interest, whilst the bankers and capitalists were exempt.

Mr. BRANHAM. The gentleman from Huntington was mistaken when he supposes we intend to increase the taxes. The tax proposed by the friends of the bill was precisely what it is now, - the only change being that the bill sets apart a specific amount of the levy for a specific purpose. Every member was aware that, in the adjust merit of the debt with the State's creditors in 1846 and 1847, it was agreed to levy a tax of twenty five cents on the-one hundred dollars on all the taxable property of the State, and so much on every poll, till the interest and principal of the debt should be paid. That was as much a part of the contract, as that was by which the bond-holders surrendered half of the bonds. It made no difference whether the debt is due in 1866, or 1876, or 1906, we solemnly declare that the debt should be paid. And now what did this bill propose? It proposed to do precisely what we then bound ourselves by a solemn act of the legislature to do; and the man who votes against the bill, votes not to fulfill that obligation.

It was true that we take the ground that the debt is not due in the sense in which a note is due in bank; but it you fix upon the time when the debt shall be paid, principal and interest, you determine the matter. We propose now to do what the Legislature stipulated to do in 1864; and in order to make it a little more explicit thm the "Butler bill," we set apart a specific amount - fifteen cents on the hundred dollars of the levy.

He did not propose to enter into the discussion as to whether it was right to tax Government bonds. He supposed this right is as old as Governments themselves. Who could compare the condition of he State in 1845 with her condition now, and object to the provisions of this bill? It proposed to tax no more than the Butler bill; and the tax was not so much as the law makes it to-day.
Mr COFFROTH admitted that there was 25 cents on the hundred dollars for State purposes; but there was no necessity to tax so high as that.
Mr BRANHAM said there was but 25 cents now levied for State purposes proper - 15 cents set apart for the fund.

Mr COFFROTH admitted Mr. Branham'a statement in regard to the Butler bill arrangement; but this went to the extent of an admission that the State debt is now due. But the bill did not propose to pay till the end of ten years.

Mr BRANHAM had introduced a similar bill in 1861, but it was overrode by war. All the energies of the State were required to sustain the Government, We propose, now the war is over, to go back where we began and pay the debt.

Mr. COFFROTH There was no time from 1853 to 1861 in which we were not in a better condition to pay this debt, than we are now. And he submitted whether, at this time, we shall inaugurate a system of taxation to pay this debt where one-fifth of the wealth of the State is exempt from the levy?
The Committee rejected Mr. Coffroth's motion, affirmative 30, negative 50; and the question recurred on Mr. Branham's amendment.
It was adopted.

Mr. BUSKIRK proposed to amend the first section further by striking out all that relates to the War Loan Bonds He showed that the War Loan Bouds were coupon bonds, and required by the bill to be first paid. The five percent bonds were given for half the canal debt, and the 2 1/2 per cent, bonds were given for half the unpaid interest. The State having; first come under this debt in 1846, it should be paid first. The War Loan Bonds were issued under the act of May, 1861. But the act of June, 1861, set apart the moneys for State debt sinking fund purposes, and pledged them for the payment of the new debt created by the War Loan Bonds. He insisted that the Legislature had no right to make this diversion of the Sinking Fund. He recognized the obligation to pay the registered bonds first. He did not say that the issuance of the War Loan Bonds was not right, but objected to paying them first, and to the diversion of the Sinking Fund by the act of June, 1861. Therefore he would strike out from the section all that relates to the War Loan Bonds.

Mr. BRANHAM This was not a matter in which the Committee had any option. The act of the Legislature of June 1861 was on record. He voted against it; but the argument was that we were preserving the claims of creditors whilst we preserved the Government. This was the reason of the act The War Loan Bonds were taken by their holders upon the condition, that all the available means of the State be pledged for their payment. There was no estimating the amount of damage to the State credit by a failure of this condition. If was on account of this neglige ce of State pledges that the financial credit of the State was at so low an ebb.

Mr. NEWCOMB As he understood the Butler bill, it did not require a Sinking Fund, but it did require 25 cents on the hundred dollars. The operation of the motion of the gentleman from Monroe would be to provide for the payment of 2 1/2 per cent, bonds, while on the 6 per cent half the interest will continue to be paid. He was opposed to any shadow of violation of a pledge made under the circumstances which created the War Loan Bonds in 1861.

Mr. LANE referred to the emergency which created the War Loan Bonds, to show their sacredness. The gentleman from Huntington underrated the ability of the State. They could pay 15 cents now as easy as they could have paid 7 cents a few years ago. The producers got twice as much for their products.

Mr COFFROTH said the price of corn was about the same now as in 1851-52; and the price of pork was downward Then the price of living was twice as great as now, Then the people were not saddled with such immense public debts -
taxes for county, State and national purposes He feared, from manifestations in the Committee, that he was mistaken when he supposed the whip of partv bad not been cracked over this bill. He showed further that those who took the war bonds were parties to the State's wrong which pledged to them the funds which were already pledged to our former creditors. He thought the proposition of the gentleman from Monroe ought to be sustained.

Mr. NEWCOMB There was too great an effort to accustom the public ear to this craven cry, that the people cannot pay their taxes. Why linger? Why pay our debts two or three times over in interest? We had already paid this debt once and a half. He alleged that, with this bill and the legislation now proposed, we would reduce instead of increasing the tax For State purposes it was proposed to be 25 cents on the one hundred dollars, and for all purposes it would not exceed 41 cents, - whereas it was 80 cents under the present levy. He illustrated the folly of waiting to pay this debt till the national stocks and issues of the Government may be taxed, - when as the gentleman from Huntingdon himself says, the Supreme Court, have decided that there is no power in the State that can tax them. He would gladly exchange a few Government bonda in his possession nt par for real estate. He expressed his confident belief that our great national debt: would be paid. He showed that the income of farms under the value of $10,000, or $20.000 were exempt from the income tax. He made this statement in reply to the clamor that the labor of the country paid all the taxes He also recited the taxes levied on manufactures and imuorted articles Shoddy pays the heaviest tax here The man of poor means does not buy so much dutiable goods as the rich man. Farmers would be astounded to learn from the speech of the gentleman from Huntington that they were an oppressed and bankrupt, class. If people don't want to pay so much tax, let them get a cheaper article. He did not doubt the people's ability to pay this debt, contracted when some of us were boys. It would have been paid before now, but for the action of our politicians. He gave way for -
Mr BUSKIRK He moved that Committee rise, report progress and ssk leave to sit again to morrow at 10 o'clock A M.
And accordingly the Committee rose and the Chairman reported.
The recommendation of the Committee of the Whole was concurred in.
On motion by Mr BRANHAM, Mr. Johnson obtained leave of absence on account of illness in his family.
On motion by Mr. SPENCER, the House then (at 5 P. M.) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem, called the Senate to order at 9 o'clock, A. M.
On motion by Mr. GTFFORD the reading of yesterday's journal was dispensed with.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. BEESON from the Committee on Agriculture, returned Mr. Niles' bill, S. No. 174, to provide for the protection of wild game, defining the time in which the same may be taken or killed, and declaring the penalty for the violation of this act, repealing all laws inconsistent therewith and declaring an emergency; recommending its passage.
He, also, from the same Committee, returned the bill, H. R. 29, to amend sec. 15 of the act concerning trespassing animals and partition fences; recommending its passage.
These bills were passed to the third reading.

Mr. HANNA, from the special Committee on Agricultural Colleges, returned Mr. Dunning's bill, S. No. 40, for the establishment of an agricultural college at Bloomington, together with petitions and other papers referred to this Committee, without recommendation and asking to be discharged from the further consideration thereof.

Mr. DUNNING, (Mr. Richmond In the chair) by direction of the same Committee, submitted a report arguing in favor of locating the Agricultural College at Bloomington. He also offered an amendment by way of substitute for his bill (which was not read).
On motion by Mr. CULVER the reports were laid on the table and made the special order for Wednesday next at two o'clock P. M.

Mr. STAGGS, from the Committee on Agriculture, returned Mr. Williams' bill S. No. 194 for the publication of semi-annual reports of the State Board of Agriculture; recommending that it lie on the table.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: RAILROAD APPRAISEMENT.
div.p: Mr. CORBIN, from the Special Committee on Railroads, returned Mr. Niles' bill S. No. 250 and the bill H. R. 158 on the subject of Railroad Appraisement; recommending that the bill S. 250 be laid on the table, and that the bill H. R. 158 be amended by way of a substitute striking out from the enacting clause and inserting new matter.
Mr. VAWTER inquired when this Committee met.

Mr. CORBIN. At a time when the Senator met with them. The Committee, with the exception of the Chairman, have agreed upon this report, and he as Chairman has called no meeting. I informed him yesterday of the intention of the Committee, so that he is not deceived or unadvised of the course to be pursued.

Mr. VAWTER. On yesterday about this time I was notified that the intention was to make this report. I staid here till Saturday evening, and at no time were these bills placed in my possession. I have not been requested by any member of the Committee to call them together, and to my certain knowledge there has been no meeting of that committee since the reference of House bill 158. I had a mind to let the matter pass, but there was an extraordinary statement made here in my absence the other day. It was stated on the floor of the Senate that a certain report I made was made under the supervision of the officers of State; and the Senator made the statement as he understood and believed it. Whether it was designed as a personal reflection upon me, I do not know. I have just as profound a contempt for any person who will make any such
attempt, in my absence at least, as is necessary. If it was designed as a compliment to the report, I might take it as a compliment. That report was prepared at this table and ghown to no person except the Senator from Lawrence. I make this statement in vindication of myself. If that report is a true one I desire to have the merit of it; if untrue, I am willing to take the responsibility of it. He then raised a point of order that the report was unparliamentary, etc.

Mr. CORBIN. I will state to the Senator from Jennings the circumstances under which the remarks were made, which I think will be satisfactory to him unless he is a very unreasonable man, which I think he is pot. The question came up in reference to calling on the Auditor of State for a statement in reference to the condition of suits brought against railroad companies. I stated I did not think it neccessary, because the Senator's report embodied what I conceived to be the whole facts connected with it. And I believed the Auditor was cognizant of the facts, because I had seen the Senator in conversation with the Auditor. My remarks were not made for the purpose of casting any reflection upon any body.

Mr. VAWTER. The statement as made by the gentleman now is certainly legitimate: but on yesterday, when I returned to the city, I found the gentleman was reported a little different from that. There had been nothing in the intercourse between the gentleman and myself that would authorize a statement that the Auditor had prepared my report; and I think if the statement was made it should be corrected. I am satisfied that the statement now made by the gentleman is legitimate.
Mr. CORBIN then spoke to the point of order, contending that it was not well grounded.
Messrs. WILLIAMS, NILES and VAWTER sustained the point of order in a few remarks.
The PRESIDING OFFICER decided the point of order not well taken.
Mr. VAWTER appealed from the decision of the Chair, in the following words:

The Select Committee on Railroad Appraisement having returned Senate bill No. 250, a bid to secure a just valuation of railroad property, etc., etc., wiih a reccommendation that it lie upon the table, and having reported back House bill No. 158. with the recommendation that the engrossed amendment - being an amendment striking out from the enacting clause adopted on this day of March, 1864, and which was not at any time reconsidered by the Senate - be struck out from the enacting clause, and an entire new bill, embodying the features of House bill No. 158, be inserted in lieu thereof; and the Senator from Jennings having raised the point of order whether it was competent at this time to make such an amendment, and the Chair (the Senator from Howard) having overruled the point of order, I respectfully appeal from said decision.
The question being: "Shall the decision of the Chair stand as the judgment of the Senate," it was so ordered by yeas 21, nays 14.
On motion by Mr DUNNING the report and bill were laid on the table.
Mr. BEESON, from the Committee on Agriculture, returned Mr. Culver's bill S. No. 248, to restrain certain animals from running at large; recommending its passage.
Mr. FULLER, from the same Committee, returned Mr. Hyatt'sbill, S. No. 218, amending the dog law; recommending its passage.
These bills were passed to the third reading. On motion of Mr. BEESON it was -

Resolved, That the Committee on Finance be instructed to allow no claim that is not presented to them at least ten days before the final day of adjournment, unless the same may have accrued within ten days of the close of the session.
On motion by Mr. WILLIAMS, it was -

Resolved, That the Auditor of State report to the Senate whether the $10 000 apropriated as a miscellaneous fuud has been drawn from the treasury, and if so by whose order, and for whose benefit; giving a detailed statement, if not inconsistent with the public good.

Mr. BROWN, of Hamilton, introduced a bill [S. No. 299] for An Act supplemental to AD Act authorizing the construction of Plank, Macadamized aud other roads, approved May 12,1852. [Concerning assessments to be made in the construction of gravel roads.] It was read the first time.

div.head: BILLS FINALLY PASSED THE SENATE.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BRADLEY, the Senate proceeded to the consideration of bills on the third reading:

Mr. Allison's bill, S. No. 161, requiring the Boards of County Commissioners in the several counties of the State to examine the books, papers and vouchers of any county officer in their respective counties who may be charged with having received a greater amount of fees than he is legally entitled to receive, to determine the amount thereof, if any, and to cause suit to be brought for its recovery, and declaring an emergency; coming up in regular order -
It was read the third time, and finally passed the Senate by yeas 33, nays 4.
Mr. Allison's bill, S. No. 187, to amend section 53 of An Act to reduce the laws incorporating the city of Madison into one Act, approved February 14,1848; coming up in regular order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 30, nays 6.
Mr. Brown, of Wells', bill, S. No. 208, providing for the construction of sewers in incorporated towns - [on the same principle upon which sidewalks are constructed] - coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 37, nays 2.

Mr. Cobb's bill, S. No. 213, amending section 33 of the city corporation repealing act of May 9, 1857 - [County Commissioners (and not Common Councils) may regulate terries, etc.] - coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 38, nays 1.

Mr. Vawter's bill, S. No. 214, designating what officers shall be elected by each House of the General Assembly, and fixing the compensation, - [providing for but one Clerk and Doorkeeper for each House. The Secretary of the Senate to receive for a regular session $2,000, for an extra session $1,600; the Doorkeeper for a regular session $1,200, for an extra session $1,000. The Clerk of the House to receive for a regular session $3,000, for an extra session $2,400; the Doorkeeper for a regular session $1,500. for an extra session $1,200;] coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 34, nays 5.

Mr. Herd's bill, S. No. 215, amending section 77 of the General Practice Act of June 18,1852 - [concerning objections to Judges in any action
pending in the several courts]coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 33, nays 2.
Mr. Bennett's bill, S. No. 223, authorizing married women under the age of 21 years to join their husband in the conveyance of their husband's lands; coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 36, nays 1.
Mr. Hord's bill, S. No. 225, providing for taking depositions of parties in civil actions in their own behalf; coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 37, nays 0.

Mr. Cobb's'biil, S. No. 228, amending section 1 of the uniform Township Business Act of Februry 18, 1859 - [concerning the laying off and dividing of counties into townships by County Commissioners - they shall give 20 days public notice] - coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 40, nays 0.
Mr. Allison's bill, S. No. 229, supplemental to the road-purchase act of March 5, 1859, (described on page 63 of the BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS;) coming up in order -
It was read the third time -

Mr. ALLISON explained that the bill simply applies to plank and McAdamized roads sold under mortgage sale or deed of trust who have failed to comply with the act of 1859giving them three months further time in which to organize. It is intended to apply to but one single casein Jefferson and Ripley counties.
Mr. CORBIN objected to the bill on the principle that it might interfere with cases already adjudicated in which there may be vested rights. It is a very bad precedent in legislation.
After further remarks by Messrs. ALLISON, NILES and BROWN of Wells -
The bill was finally passed the Senate by yeas 34, nays 3.
The Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: On motion by Mr. ALLISON, Mr. Williams was called to preside, in the temporary absence of the President pro tem.

The PRESIDING OFFICER laid before the Senate a communication from the Auditor of State, in answer to a resolution of inquiry (see page 138 of the BREVIER REPORTS) concerning suits against Railroad Companies for payment of taxes.
It was referred to the Special Committee on Railroads.
The special order for this hour being Mr. Bennett's bill, S. 209, to apportion the State for Senatorial and Representative purposes, was laid on the table.

Mr. Williams' bill, S. No. 230, in relation to the organization of the General Assembly - [the Secretary of State shall organize the Senate, and the Auditor of State the House of Representatives] - coming up in regular order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 34, nays 1.
Mr. Cason's bill, S. No. 234, supplemental to An Act for the incorporation of towns, approved June 11, 1852; coming up in order -
It was read the third time.

Mr. CASON. This bill provides that upon the petition of trustees of towns to the Court of Common Pleas, there may be Commissioners appointed to have streets extended, the ame as they are extended now by cities.
The bill was then passed by yeas 38, nays 0.
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 37, nays 0.
Mr. Vawter asked and obtained leave of absence till Friday morning.
Mr. Cason's bill, S. No. 241, amending an amendment of An Act in relation to witnesses, and repealing section 238 of the General Practice Act, approved June 18, 1852; coming up in order -
It was read the third time.
Mr. CASON explained that this bill precludes either party from testifying in real estate suits in which heirs are a party in interest.
The bill was passed by yeas 34, nays 4.

The Committee on Organization of Courts' bill, S. No. 244, amending An Act for the election of Justices of the Peace, approved June 9, 1852, - [There shall be one Justice in each township; one additional for each incorporated city, one additional for each township where the population exceeds 10,000]; - coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 32, nays 7.

Mr. Allison's bill, S. No. 246, repealing section 17 of the Fireman's and Mechanic's Insurance Companies' charter act - [repealing the section which prohibits the Directors from becoming Directors of other companies]; - coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 27, nays 12.
Mr. Dykes' bill S. No. 249, defining the powers of Companies authorized to construct canals for hydraulic purposes; coming up in order -
It was read the third time and referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Subsequently the Committee returned the bill with sundry amendments.
The amendments were agreed to; and the bill was finally passed the Senate by yeas 39, nays 1.
Mr. Cason's manufacturing and mining bill, S. No. 252 (described on page 99 of the BREVIER REPORTS) coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 29, nays 7.
Mr. McClurg's bill, S. No. 253, to relieve county officers for the year 1865, for violation of the provisions of An Act concerning sheep killing dogs, etc.; coming up in order -
It was read the third time.
Mr. OYLER opposed the passage of the bill; for it is not to be supposed that any court would punish an officer for not performing a duty of which he had no intimation.
The bill failed to pass for want of a constitutional majority - yeas 25, nays 13.
Mr. Culver's bill, S. No. 254 authorizing the State revenue to be paid in National Bank notes; coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 37, nays 1.

Mr. Cobb's bill, S. No. 255, amending section 2 of An Act supplemental to An Act for the incorporation
of high schools, etc., approved March 5, 1859; coming up in order -
It was read the third time.
Mr. COBB explained that the principal change, as far as the Trustees are concerned, is that they are not subject to the denomination wich has the supervision of the literary institution.
The bill was passed by yeas 35, nays 4. Mr. Allison's bill, No. 256, amending the charter of the city of Evansville; coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 39, nays 3.
Mr. OYLER offered the following:

WHEREAS. The President of the United States and the governor of the State of Indiana have designated Thursday, the seventh day of December, as a day of general Thanksgiving to Almighty God for his great mercies to this Nation, State and people;
Be it Resolved, That when the Senate adjourns, it adjourns to meet on Friday next at 9 o'clock, A, M.
The resolution was adopted.
Mr. WILLIAMS offered the following:
WHEREAS, there used to be in the lady's lobby of the Senate Climber two sofas;
AND WHEREAS, It would be very convenient and pleasant for ladies visiting the Senate Chamber, as also to the Senators who may be sick or disabled, to have them returned; therefore,
Resolved, That the Doorkeeper be authorized to return them instarter.
The resolution was adopted.
Mr. BROWN, of Wells, offered the following:

WHEREAS, By sections 10, 11 and 46 of the general appropriation law, approved March 6, 1865, there was appropriated for the Adjutant General's Office the sums of $9,200 for the unfinished business; $12,000 for the current business of 1865, and $12,000 for the current busings of 1866, therefore -

Resolved, That the Adjutant General be and he is hereby respectfully requested, if not inconsistent with public interests, to report to the senate at his earliest convenience what portion of said sums of $9,200 and $12,000 for 1865, have been drawn from the treasury, specifying by whom drawn, and upon what particular account and service; also what part of said sum of $12,000 for 1866 may probably be necessary for the business of his office dining that year.
The resolution was adopted.

On motion by Mr. WRIGHT the bill H. R. 18, to provide for the sale of certain lands belonging to the State of Indiana in Jasper and Newton counties, and give preemption to actual settlers thereon; was read the third time, and finally passed by yeas 33, nays 3.
On motion by Mr. CHAPMAN, it was -

Resolved, That the Judiciary Committee be instructed to inquire into and report by bill or otherwise, whether incorporated towns and cities may tax fair pounds for the grading of streets aid the improvement thereof, and for other municipal purposes.
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 38, nays 1.
Mr. Cason's' bill, S. No. 261, amending sections 2 and 5 of the Voluntary Association Act of February 12,1855; coming up in order -
It was read the third time.

Mr. CASON explained that this bill amends the law in reference to Voluntary Associations so as to include Agricultural societies; and extend to such societies the powers granted by the statutes as well as the common law.
The bill passed by yeas 39, nays 0.
Mr. Chapman's Gettysburg Cemetery bill S. No. 262, (described on page 108 of the BREVIER RERORTS;) coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 36, nays 1.
Mr. Oyler's divorce bill, S. No. 268, (described on page 132 of the BREVIER REPORTS;) coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 29, nays 8.
Mr. Allison's bill, S. No. 269, requiring County Auditors to make examination of school fund records, etc.; coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 32, nays 5.
Mr. Dykes' bill, S. No. 272, amending section. 12 of the common school law of March 6, 1865 - [authorizing the local tax to be as high as 50 cents instead of 25 cents;] - coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 29, nays 8.
Mr. Allison's bill, S. No. 290, concerning school houses, and defining who shall control them - [the trustees of the city or town;] - coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 36, nays 1.
The Special Committee's bill, S. No. 280, concerning the "Universal Exposition" of Paris, France, in April, 1867, (described on page 138 of the BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS; ) coming up in order -
It was read the third time.
On motion by Mr. MILLIGAN, the bill was recommitted with instructions to strike out "$5,000" for traveling expenses to the Commissioner and insert "$3,000" in lieu.
Mr. Thompson's hard labor prison bill, S. No. 297, (introduced yesterday) was read the third time.
Messrs. ALLlSON and OYLER pointed out objections thereto, and -
On motion by Mr. ALLISON, it was laid on the table.

Mr. Bonham's joint resolution, S. No. 15, instructing our Senators and requesting our Representatives in Congress to use their influence for the bringing about of a speedy adjustment of the claims of deceased soldiers; coming up in order -
It was read the third time and finally passed the Senate by yeas 35, nays 0.
On motion by Mr. CASON the official bond bill S. No. 289 (introduced yesterday) was read the second time and passed to the third reading.

Mr. CORBIN, from the Special Committee thereon, returned his Terre Haute and Richmond Railroad resolution (described on page 73 of the BREVIER REPORTS) making it a joint resolution by substituting new matter.
Mr. ALLISON, (from the Committee on Education,) returned Mr. Dunning's bill S. No. 295 authorizing a school examiner for incorporated towns; recommending its passage.
And then the Senate adjourned till Friday morning 9 o'clock.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p:
The SPEAKER took the Chair at 9 o'clock, A. M., and, (when a quorum was determined
by the roll-call,) directed the Clerk to read the journal of yesterday.
On motion by Mr. BURNES, the reading of the journal was dispensed with.

div.head: PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM presented the memorial of F. D. Bland and others, by order and in behalf of the First Baptist Church in the city of Madison, asking for a change in the Liquor License Law.
Mr. STRINGER presented a memorial signed by Jeremiah Cory and 1,033 others, with reference to the same matter.
Mr. ABBETT presented the memorial of about 2,000 citizens of Bartholomew county on the subject of Tippling.
The foregoing were referred to the Committee on Temperance.

Mr. RICE presented the memorial of S. F. Maxwell and others, citizens of Parker county, representing that the State Agricultural College ought be connected with the Indiana State University - not sectarian in its character - and that the wishes of the memorialists from Monroe county ought to be complied with.
It was referred to the Select Committee of one from each Congressional District on that subject.
Mr. STRINGER presented the memorial of the Commissioners of Boone county for repeal of the Soldiers' Family Relief law; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned the Adopted Child's bill [S. 233], and the Clinton County Common Pleas legalizing bill [S. 231] recommending their passage.

He also returned Mr. Shoaff of Allen's bill [H. R. 264] to amend the fourth and repeal the 7th clause of the Divorce Act of May 13, 1852, with amendments striking out, and repealing the seventh clause of the seventh section of said act, and amending the title conformably.
He also returned Mr. Cowgill's legalizing bill [H. R. 299], also the appeals bill [S:. 106]; recommending their passage.
He also returned Mr. Miller of Clinton's Sheriffs Deed bill [H. R, 74]; recommending that it be indefinitely postponed.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. ATKINSON, from the Committee on County and Township Business, returned the bill [H. R. 309] authorizing County Commissioners to make appropriations in aid of the location and construction of Manufacturing and Machine Shops, with an amendment inserting appropriately this: "Upon the petition of one-fourth of the legal voters;" and so recommending its passage.
Mr. HAMRICK, from the Committee on Corporations, returned Mr. Trusler's Hydraulic Company bill, H. R. 256; recommending its passage.
Mr. BUWELL, from the Select Committee thereon, returned the Wells' Circuit Court bill, S. No. 265; recommending its passage.
Mr. CHAMBERS, from the Select Committee on so much of the Governor's Message as refers to the subject of An Agricultural Col. lege, reported a joint resolution.
These reports lie on the table.
Mr. Buskirk submitted the following:

WHEREAS, the Commitee of one from each Congressional district, to whom was referred the subject of an Agncultural College entertain doubts whether they can act on the subject of the location thereof, therefore -

Be it Resolved, That said Committee investigate and report to the House at an early day a bill locating said Agriculture College at some point in this State [and that all bills introduced on the subject be referred to said Committee.]
Mr. MILLER said there was a committee, the Committee on Education, charged with the matter of location - had looked into the matter; and he thought it should not be taken out of their hands.
Mr. OLLEMAN thought it better taken away from the Committee on Education; and all should be referred to the Select Committee.
Mr. BUSKIRK would just as soon the Committee on Education should act, as the Select Committee. He wanted action. He amended his resolution in accordance with the suggestion of Mr. Olleman.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, would like to have all the donations that have been proffered go to this Select Committee. He made a motion to amend (as in brackets above.)
Mr. BUSKIRK concurred. He wanted action a location somewhere.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, thought the resolution was right.
And so it was adopted.
Mr. GROVES submitted the following:
Resolved, That, the Committee on Rights and Privileges inquire into the expediency of so amending the dog law, that each family may own and keep one dog without taxation.
On motion of Mr. RHOADS, it was laid on the table.
Mr. LOPP submitted the following:

Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary inquire into the propriety of passing a law by which landholders on the Ohio river may be protected agianst persons fishing in said river in front of their farms.
On motion of Mr. GROVES, it was laid on the table - affirmative 59, negative 15.
Mr. FERRIS submitted the following:
Resolved, That during the remainder of the present session of the General Assembly, no member of this House shall have leave of absence unless in case of sickness of himself or his family.
Mr. OLLEMAN made an ineffectual motion to lay it on the table - yeas 42, nays 46.
The resolution was then adopted - affirmative 45, negative 38.

Mr. FOULKE submitted an order, which was adopted, reciting that, whereas, on the the 18th of February, 1863, the House Committee on the Affairs of the State Prison North made a report in which they recommended an appropriation of $150 to H. M. McElry for services as architect on said Prison, which on the 20th of February was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, but owing to the condition of the House it was never returned: and, whereas, the said McE. has transferred his said claim to John Jackson; therefore,
Resolved, That an appropriation of $ 150 with interest thereupon from February, 1863, be made to the said John Jackson.

On motion by Mr. SHOAFF of Jay, Mr. Collins
had leave of absence till Monday on account of illness of his wife.
On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, his Indianapolis Circuit Court bills [H. R. 277, 278, 279, 280, and 300] were taken up and made the special order for Friday 10 o'clock.

div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, the House, according to previous order, resolved into Committee of the Whole - Mr. Henricks in the Chair - and resumed the consideration of the Joint Committees State Debt Sinking Fund bill [H. R. 285,] - the question being on the amendment of Mr. Buskirk, proposing to amend the first section by striking out all that relates to the war loan bonds.
Mr. NEWCOMB being entitled to the floor yielded it for the present.

Mr. BUSKIRK did not propose to go into a discussion of the merits of the bill. He deprecated political questions in this connection. Gentlemen were mistaken in supposing either that he was finding fault with the Legislature of 1861 authorizing the war loan bonds, or that he was opposed to paying them. But he denied the authority of the Legislature to make the diversion of the State debt funds, and he was opposed to taxing the people at such a time as this to pay bonds which have 17 years to run. The gentleman from Jefferson had told us correctly yesterday, that the financial credit of the State was bad because it had broken faith with creditors. There was a violation of plighted faith by the Legislature of 1861, pledging the Sinking Fund for '61, '62, and '63 to pay the war loan. But the Sinking Fund Commissioners had expended two-thirds of a million in the purchase of State bonds mostly five and two and a half per cents., and not to the redemption of the war loan bonds.

Mr. BRANHAM. Did the act of 1861 direct that the fund should be so applied? The first levy for 1861 did not belong to the sinking fund. If the war loan bonds could not be got at par, they did not violate the act of 1861.

Mr. BUSKIRK. The gentleman had stated that the act of June, 1861, was a useless act. There was no necessity for it. These war bonds ($2,000,000,) were for the benefit of the Federal Government, and that Government is bound to pay them. The Federal Government had paid what had been redeemed - over one million. He thought we would be discharging our duty to give the Federal Government opportunity to pay the balance of them.
Mr. Buskirk's amendment was rejected affirmative 30, negative 43.
Mr. PRATHER proposed to amend the first section by adding after the word "State," in the 20th line, this: "and 50 cents on each taxable poll."
Mr. FERRIS. If he understood the bill, it does not levy this 15 cents on the hundred dollars, but merely sets apart that.
Mr. COFFROTH. This amendment would compel shoddy to pay something.
Mr. BRANHAM hoped the bill would regain without this. There would be a sufficient poll tax for State purposes authorized in another bill.
The amendment was rejected.

Mr. BRANHAM proposed to amend in the 5th section, after the word "shall," insert this:"endorse on the back of the certificate the amount paid thereon, and the balance unpaid, and immediately forward."
It was adopted.
Mr. BRANHAM and Mr. DUNHAM suggested clerical amendments which were agreed to.

On motion by Mr. BRANHAM, the Committee now rose and the Chairman reported the bill to the House recommending the adoption of the amendments of the Committee of the Whole, and that so amended, the bill do pass.

The Clerk read the amendment by the Committee by the Whole to the first section in line 22, adding this: "and together with all moneys in the State Treasury belonging to said fund, derivable from the general fund, and the revenues derived from the State Debt Sinking Fund."
Mr. BUSKIRK proposed to amend the amendment by adding his exemption of the war loan bonds.It was rejected - yeas 29, nays 58.
The Committee's amendment was then adopted.
The further amendments to sections 5 and 9 recommended by the Committee were also adopted.
Mr. BRANHAM moved that the bill be considered engrossed and read the third time.

Mr. COFFROTH submitted a question of order that the bill could not be advanced by this motion, because the bill is not the special order for the day; and that the bill goes to its place in the calendar.

Mr. PETTIT (Mr. Henricks in the Chair) resisted the point of order, by the consideration that the Committee of the Whole had recommended that the bill be the special order for 10 o'clock to-day, and that that recommendation was concurred in and became the resolution of the House.
But on consulting the journal, and on further debate by Mr. BROWN and Mr. DUNHAM -
Mr. PETTIT acquiesced so far as, that this point of order would be well taken on the question of the third reading.
The SPEAKER (Mr. Henricks in the chair) held that the motion of Mr. Branham could be entertained so far as to order the engrossment; and that debate on the merits of the bill is in order.
Mr. BRANHAM modified his motion so as to order the engrossment and make the bill the special order for Friday at 10 o'clock.

Mr. PETTIT desired to notice some few things that had arisen in the debate. The principal matter was the objections of the gentleman from Huntington. He was in favor of the bill because the public debt was not legally due as an obligation of the State. The gentleman from Huntington himself seemed ia doubt as to this point. He considered the method and the history of this State debt arrangement.

It commenced in 1844, and was not completed till 1846. He noted the caution and deliberation with which negotiations were made between the bondholders and the State, and it was hardly possible that the language they used was not precisely what was intended. That language was - payable at the pleasure of the State at the end of twenty years. Until that twenty years had expired the State has no right to require its creditors to receive their
pay. If that debt becomes positively due on the 19th day of January, 1866, what becomes of that clause, "at the pleasure of the State?" It was legal language, susceptable of but one legal import.

The message of Governor Whitcomb, the report of committees in 1846, and 1847, were appealed to, to justify his conclusion. It was contemporaneous construction that the State would make these bonds a perpetual annuity depending upon the ability and the will of the State when they should be paid. They were made to stand upon the State's honor and conform to her ability and will to pay them after the expiration of the 20 years, and the measure of duty was the ability of the State. Instead of informing us when this debt is due and payable, these objectors merely referred to the fact that taxation is running up, and that one-fifth of the property of the State is exempt from taxation. But if the question of duty is governed by abilitythe question of the State's; ability is the only question before us. The grand levy was upon 516,000,000 of property.He understood Mr. Coffroth to allege that one-fifth of this, ($100,000,000,) was exempt from taxation. He examined the items which made up this sum in the statement of Mr. Coffroth. He did not believe there were fourteen millions of stock of the United States held by the National Banks in the State. On the distribution of the first hundred and fifty millions, the share of the State would not exceed six or seven millions. The storage of the capital of the seventy National Banks in the State would not exceed $$125,000.Mr. COFFROTH said the bonds of these banks and their stocks were the same.

Mr. PETTIT. That was a just admission. He read from the National Banking act to show that the stocks of the State are legitimately taxable capital - that the real property and the shares of these National banks shall be taxed. He was not denying that the bonds were not subject to taxation; but he showed now these bonds in the banks were charged with tax as shares. Deposits were taxed as the property of depositors.But the gentleman from Huntington says all U. S. currency is exempt from taxation. He read the 18th section of the Act of Congress, (read also by the gentleman from Huntington,) to show the meaning of the words, "obligation or other security of the United States" - reading also in other sections of the act, to show that where in the 13th section it is declared that this clause shall mean postal currency, etc., it means that when these description of currency were counterfeited, the guilty party shall be a felon, and punished as such. The currency of the U. S. was not a prommissory note, but money, and taxable as gold. He referred also to the act of Congress of 1865, reading the first section, and the second section of the act before referred to, to ascertain what notes are exempt from taxation by State and municipal authorities. These notes were "seven -thirties."

The Federal law says although the bonds may not be taxed, yet the bank shares shall be. He avoided discussion of the inducing motives which led to this exemption from taxation. It did not come gracefully for those to complain of our public burthens, when it was remembered, that, but for their lack of zeal in the support of the Government, we should have had no war, and no public debt. He closed by alleging his opinion that the levy proposed in the bill would accomplish the end desired by the Committee. All classes of levies in any county in the State could not anywhere exceed 300 cents on the hundred dollars. The second sec. of the County Debt act of last session put a limit to the amount of levy and assessment - sufficient to pay at least one-fourth the amount of such legalized bonds in each of the years of 1865, 1866,1867, and 1868. Now let us say, if the people have ability a part of the levy shall be applied to the extinction of this oldest of our public debts at the earliest possible day.
Mr. COFFROTH took the floor, but gave way for a motion to adjourn.
On motion by Mr. GRIFFITH, the House took a recess till two o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. HENRICKS (by request of the Speaker) took the chair at 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: LOCOMOTIVE ENGINEERS.
div.p: On motion of Mr. BROWN, his Locomotive Engineer bill, [H. R. 301], a special order for this hour, was taken up and read the second time by the Clerk.

On motion by Mr. BROWN, sundry clerical errors were corrected, and it was further amended by reducing twenty days notice to ten days; also, in the 10th section, inserting this: "Or in the Circuit Court or Court of Common Pleas in this State in any county through which the road passes." [Examiners' compensation in fees ($10) for license.]

Mr. BRANHAM desired an amendment that drunkenness disqualifies an engineer absolutely - to come into the fifth section: and that no person be licensed who becomes intoxicated by spirituous liquors;" which was adopted.
On the motion of Mr. BUSKIRK, (the constitutional restriction being suspended for the purpose,) the bill was considered as engrossed, ordered to the third reading, and read the third time.
Mr. BRANHAM suggested, that hardships would work in the case of a division of opinion between the two examiners.
Mr. BROWN. The applicant would not be licensed in such a case.

Mr. BRANHAM also objected to the sixth section. It was loose in its construction, inflicting a penalty where an unlicensed person "attempts to run a locomotive." It was a provision that could not be enforced. There were numerous instances in which firemen have to move engines into or out of the yard, or in case of approaching trains.

Mr. DUNHAM stated the case of the killing of a child lately in New Albany by a fireman switching a train after the train had been brought into the depot. He thought well of the bill. The legal import of the word "attempt," was well enough understood.
Mr. COFFROTH asked unanimous consent to move to strike out the words "or attempt to perform."
Mr. STRINGER objected.

Mr. SHUEY objected to that portion of the bill which fixes a penalty of $500 for employing an engineer in violation of this act - reaching to the individual property of each and every
owner or stockholders. He was willing to subject to the penalty the property of those directly in the management by which the violation of law is made.

Mr. COFFROTH said, no good lawyer would hold that the individual in the firm who has suffered in damages from the act of the firm has not his remedy in an action against other members of the firm for their pro rata share of the damage.
Mr. SHUEY moved to recommit the bill, with instructions to strike out that provision which makes the individual property of stockholder liable.
Mr. BROWN spoke generally in opposition to the motion, replying to objections and supporting the provisions of the bill requiring liability of stockholders.

After further debate Mr. NEWCOMB showing that we can't give any part of the penalty to the informer: and Mr. OLLEMAN objecting to the fee of $10. It was too high: and Mr. DURHAM suggesting an amendment to meet the objection of the gentleman from Jefferson (Mr. Branham) adding appropriately this: "Or a person regularly indentured to learn the skill, science or duty of an engineer, and under the immediate superintendence or control of the engineer.
On motion by Mr. COFFROTH, (Mr. Shuey's motion being withdrawn) the further consideration of the bill was postponed, and it was made the special order for Friday morning 10 o'clock.

Mr. THACHER submitted an order, which was adopted, reciting Thanksgiving to-morrow by proclamation of the President, etc., and resolving that when this House adjourns today it shall be till Friday next at 9 o'clock A. M.
On motion by Mr. BUSKIRK, it was ordered that the Speaker appoint a member of the Special Committee on the Agricultural College for the llth District in the place of Mr. Collins, on leave of absence.

div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: On the motion of Mr. BRANHAM, the House now resumed the consideration of the Joint Committee's State Debt Sinking Fund bill [H. R. 285] - the question being on Mr. Branham's motion for the engrossment, and to make the bill the special order for Friday 10 o'clock.

Mr. Higgins (by unanimous consent) presented the memorial of Milton Mercer, of Goshen, G. H. Wells and J. S. Beach, of Terre Haute, Wm. D. Allen, of Greencastle, and John Galloway, of Cambridge City, representing that they are owners of half a million of the two and a half per cent. bonds of the State - that they purchased them, paying 60 to 70 per cent, for them twelve years ago, with full knowledge of the facts and the law in the case, believing that they would be redeemed on the 19th of January, 1866. They ask such legislation as may provide for the payment of these bonds according to the ability of the State.
The memorial was laid on the table.
The bill was then ordered to the engrossment and made the special order for Friday morning, 10 o'clock.

div.head: ELKHART DAM
div.p: On motion by Mr. SHUEY, his St. Joseph River Dam bill [H. R. 285] was taken up, ordered to the third reading, read the third time and passed the House of Representatives - yeas 77, nays 9.

div.head: BLACK LAWS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. Newcomb, Mr. Foulke's bill [H. R, 25] to repeal the act to prohibit the evidence of Indians and persons having one-eighth negro blood in all cases where white persons are parties in interest, approved February 4, 1853; and so much of all other laws as renders persons incompetent as witnesses in courts of law - the question being on the third reading.

Mr. BUSKIRK moved to recommit the bill with instructions to add this: "Provided that the privileges granted by this act shall not extend to and embrace, or be enjoyed by any negro or mulatto who has come into the State since the adoption of the present Constitution."

Mr. BUSKIRK submitted two reasons for his amendment. The resident negroes were constitutional negroes and better qualified to remain. The second was, because he would offer no immunity to those persons violating the laws.

Mr. NEWCOMB. The object of the bill was to get at the truth in courts of Justice. There were negroes whose testimony would be taken as readily as any white man's. Not very long ago we had a statute disqualifying a man for testifying who has been guilty of any infamous crime. Other States had disqualified those who disbelieve in future retributions. But all these things were done away.

Our statutes provided that no man shall be disqualified from testifying on account of crime. Then why, on account of color? This bill proposes to admit the Indian and negro to testify, no more for the benefit of the negro than for parties in interest. We have a Constitution which says that no special law shall regulate practice in the Courts.
Mr. DUNHAM. Exclusion of a class was not special legislation.

Mr. NEWCOMB. The gentleman was mistaken. If the gentleman believes we may exclude a class, would it not be competent to exclude Democrats as a class? He gave other considerations in opposition to the amendment.
Mr. HUMPHREYS would not vote for the amendment. He understood that it admitted all negroes to testify who resided in the State at the time of the adoption of the Constitution.
Mr. BUSKIRK. Were not those old resident negroes con stitutional negroes ? [Laughter.]
Mr. BURWELL saw no propriety in the amendment. It was all humbug.
Mr. SIM demanded the previous question, and there was a second, and the main question was ordered, viz: Shall the bill be referred with Mr. Buskirk's instructions?
The motion was rejected - yeas 19, nays 70 and the question recurred on its final passage.

Mr. COFFROTH said the gentleman from Marion had agreed to pair off with him in debate on this question. Notwithstanding that gentleman had almost violated the agreement, still he was not yet disposed to debate, and would deemand the previous question on the passage of the bill.
Under the operation of this demand, the bill was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 55, nays 35 - as follows:

YEAS - Messr. Atkinson, Bonner, Branham, Burnes,
Caldwell, Chambers, Church, Cook, Cowgill, Cox, Crook, Davidson, Ferris, Foulke, Gleason Goodman, Gregory of Montgomery, Gregory of Warren, Griffith, Hamrick, Henricks, Hershey, Higgins, Hogate, Hoover, Klgore, Lane, Litson, Lockhart, Major, Meredith, Miller, Montgomery, McVey, Newcomb, Olleman, Prather, Reese, Rhoads, Rice, Riford, Sabin, Shuey, Sim, Stewart, Stringer, Sullivan of P. & V., Trusler, Upson, Welch, Woodruff, Wright, Woods, Zeigler, Mr. Speaker - 55.

NAYS - Messrs. Abbett. Bird, Boyd, Brown, Burton, Burwell, Buskirk, Coffroth, Croan, Dunham, Glazebrook, Gregg, Harrison, Howard Humrphreys, Hunt, Lasselle, Lee, Lemon, Lopp, Milroy, Osborn, Patterson, Perigo, Richards, Richardson, Roach, Schoaff of Allen, Shoaff Of Jay, Stuckey, Sullivan of Scott, Thatcher, Veatch, Weikel, White - 35.

div.head: COUNTY SEATS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. DUNHAM, Mr. McVey's bill [H. R. 125] to amend sections 1 and 2 of the act providing for the relocation of county seats, etc., approved March 2, 1855 [containing additional provisions in regard to testimony as to the question of legal votes,] were taken up.

Mr. D. stated that under the old law which was made for the accommodation of Perry county, it was almost impossible to verify the voters. This bill takes the number of the votes cast at the last annual election, with a small per cent, added - two-thirds of these shall be sufficient with the other conditions, to order the relocation - and the person circulating the petition shall have power to administer an oath as to whether the person is entitled to vote. This petition so verified by two witnesses, shall be prima facie evidence that it is signed by legal voters.
Mr. BROWN. If it was a fair bill he would not object to it; but to determine this he would move that it be referred to the Judiciary Committee.
The SPEAKER. The motion could not be entertained without instructions.
After further debate by Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, and Mr. LOCKHART -
Mr. FOULKE moved ineffectually to recommit the bill, with instructions to strike out "two" acres to be donated, and insert "one" in lieu.
Mr. BROWN moved ineffectually to strike out "two" and insert "three" in lieu.
Mr. HIGGINS demanded the previous question, and under its operation the bill was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 79, nays 6.
Mr. NEWCOMB asked and obtained leave to return from the Judiciary Committee Mr. Pettit's Forfeited Recognizance bill [H. R. 294] recommending its passage.
Mr. PETTIT (Mr. Hehricks in the Chair) asked the favor of the House to suspend the rules and put the bill now on its passage.
Mr. DUNHAM objected - there were features in the bill which he desired to have time to look into.
The bill was then (by consent) passed the second reading.
On motion of Mr. RICE, Mr. Roach obtained leave of absence on account of illness in his family.
Mr. GRIFFITH obtained leave to submit a report from the Committee on the State Prisons, returning his Northern Prison bill [H. R. 282] recommending its passage. And then -
On motion of Mr. BURWELL, the House (at 5:10 P.M.) adjourned till Friday morning nine o'clock.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem., called to order at 9 o'clock A. M.
On motion by Mr. OYLER the reading of Wednesday's journal was dispensed with.

Mr. BEESON presented a lengthy memorial from holders of nearly half a million 2 1/2 per cent. State bonds, praying that provision be made for their payment next month, &c., which was referred to the Special Committee on the State debt.

div.head: THE THIRTEENTH ARTICLE.
div.p: The Senate proceeded to the consideration of the special order for this hour, viz.: The joint resolution H. R. No. 1, for an amendment to the State constitution, by striking out the XIIith Article; thereof - the question being shall it pass to the third reading?
The Senate refused to pass it to the third reading by yeas 22; nays, 22 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs Allison, Beeson, Bennett, Brown of Hamilton, Cason, Chapman, Cullen, Davis, Dykes Hyatt, Milligan, Niles, Noyes, Oyler, Reagan, Richmond, Terry, Thompson, Ward, Woods, Wright, and Mr. President - 22.

NAYS - Messrs. Barker, Bowman, Bradley, Brown of Wells, Cobb, Corbin, Douglas, Downey, English, Finch, Fuller, Gifford, Hamma, Hord, Jinkens, Marshall, McClurg, Mason, Moore, Staggs, Vawter, and Williams - 22
Messrs. WARD and CASON presented petitions praying for the repeal of the soldiers' family relief law, which were referred to the appropriate committee.
On motion of Mr. COBB, it was -
Resolved, That no Senator shall hereafter be granted leave of absence during the present session, except on account of sickness of himself or some member of his family.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. CHAPMAN, from the Committee on Finance, returned Mr. Wright's bill, S. No. 273, legalizing the action of Boards of Equalization; recommending its passage.

Mr. CULLEN, from the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements, returned Mr, Wright's bill, S. No. 107, authorizing the construction of a canal from the Calumet river to Lake Michigan; recommending its passage.
Mr. BEESON, from the Committee on Finance, returned the bill, H. R. 212, to legalize appraisement of real estate made under the appraisement act of December 21, 1858; recommending its passage.
Mr. WOOD, from the Committee on Temperance, returned the bill, H. R. 33, amending section 8 of the liquor law of March 5, 1859; recommending its passage.
Mr. WRIGHT, from the Committee on Roads, returned Mr. Cullen's gravel and other roads bill, S. No. 247; recommending its passage.
Mr. BEESON, from the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements, returned the bill, H. R. 75, to empower railroads to construct branches to neighboring coal mines' recommending its passage.
Mr. REAGAN, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill, H. R. 82, creating corporations for the purpose of maintaining high schools, etc.; recommending its passage.
These bills were passed to the third reading.

div.head: INSURANCE COMPANIES.
div.p: Mr. WOOD, from the Committee on Corporations, returned Mr. Thompson's bill, S. 212, to amend section 23 of An Act to incorporate Insurance Companies, approved June 17,1852; recommending its passage.

Mr. THOMPSON urged the passage of his bill, it having already been read three times. Foreign Insurance Companies are now taking from the State a large revenue, which should be retained here, and would be if our home Companies were put on the same footing with those of other States.

Mr. CORBIN did not oppose the bill merely for the purpose of opposition; but would remind the Senate again of the points made against the bill when it was up before. The bill leaves no protection for the insuring public, and is an unsafe measure. It is the duty of the General Assembly to legislate for the people, and not for capitalists and moneyed monopolists.

Mr. ALLISON thought the Senator was attempting to drive all home Companies out of existence. The present law requires Insurance Companies to keep on deposit, at the State Auditor's office, $25,000, and that is sufficient; - it is hardly probable that any one loss would amount to more than that; - while foreign Companies are not required to deposit a dollar. Beside, our Companies are required to pay ten per cent, damage for unnecessary delay in paying losses justly due. He insisted there is nothing wrong about this bill, and hoped it would pass.
Mr. CULLEN demanded the previous question.
Twenty-nine senators seconded the demand, and under its operation the bill finally passed the Senate by yeas 29, nays 15.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES - CONTINUED.
div.p: Mr. HYATT, from the Committee on Corporations, returned Mr. Vawter's town attorney bill, S. No. 283; recommending its passage.
Mr. DOWNEY made art ineffectual motion to amend the bill by providing that the attorney shall attend to any other business of the corporation.
Mr. REAGAN, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill, H. R. 88, authorizing high schools, etc., to change their names; recording its passage.
Mr. WARD, from the same committee, returned the bill, H. R. 106, authorizing the construction of tobacco warehouses; recording its passage.
He also returned the bill, H. R. 149, to enable directors of turnpike companies to change the time of holding their elections; recommending its passage.
These bills were passed to the third reading.
On motion by Mr. MASON, the bill H. R. 177, to amend sec. 143 of the Act to provide for the publication of delinquent taxes, [raising the price from 30 to 60 cents], was read the third time.
Messrs. MASON, BROWN of Hamilton, and CULLEN spoke in favor of the passage of the hill.
The bill failed to pass the Senate by yeas 24, nays 19.

div.head: GRAND JURIESMISDEMEANORS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. DOWNEY his bill (previously read three times) S. No. 156, extending the jurisdiction of grand jurors to cases of misdemeanors, was taken from the table.
Mr. DOWNEY urged considerations in favor of his bill.
The bill finally passed the Senate by yeas 36, nays 6.

Mr. DOWNEY, at the time he introduced this bill, last session, also presented another, S. No. 155, perfecting this arrangement of our laws, but as it has been misplaced he begged leave to introduce a similar one now to enable the Circuit Court to try these cases.
Leave being granted -
Mr. DOWNEY introduced a bill [S. No. 300] for An Act to amend sec. 5 of An Act for the organization of Circuit Courts, etc., approved June 1, 1852; which was read the first time.
On motion by Mr. OYLER, the constitutional restriction was dispensed with - yeas 36, nays 3 - the bill was read the second time and passed to the third reading.

div.head: TOBACCO WAREHOUSES.
div.p: On motion by Mr. NOTES, the bill, H. R. 106, authorizing the construction of ware-houses for the inspection, storage and sale of tobacco, was read the third time.

The PRESIDENT stated that in the absence of the Senator from Vanderburg and Posey, [Mr. Finch] he had been requested by the Representative from those counties to give attention to this bill. He had examined it closely, and saw no monopoly in it which amounts to anything.
The bill was then passed by yeas 43, nays 0.

div.head: WAR LOAN BONDS.
div.p: On motion,by Mr. YAWTER it was -
Resolved, That the Governor and Auditor of State be and they are hereby requested to inform the Senate -

list.item: How many war loan bonds have been issued.
Who are the holders of said bonds.
What conditions, if any, are contained in said bonds.
Fourth. At what rate said bonds were sold.

Whether the Federal government at any time assumed the indebtedness incurred by the State of Indiana in providing supplies and men to aid said Government inputting down the present rebellion; and if so, whether the "money so paid, or securities so given in such assumption," did "esure to the benefit of holders of bonds issued under the provisions of "An Act making additional provisions for the payment of the loan of two millions of dollars authorized by the act of the General Assembly, approved May 13, 1861,' " and if not, why she provisions of the third section of said act was not complied with.

div.head: THE SCHOOL FUNDS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. COBB, the bill H. R. 47, to increase the powers of the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, and to authorize said Board to loan any moneys belonging to said funds in Indiana State bonds or stocks and providing for the cancelling of such bonds or stocks, and the re-issuing of new non-negotiable bonds or stocks, payable to said funds; was taken from the hands of the Judiciary Committee - they not being able to agree upon a report thereon.

On motion of Mr. CULLEN the pending amendment [Mr. Bradley's,] proposing to strike from the bill all that gives authority to the Sinking Fund Commissioners to loan the funds belonging to the State; was laid on the table by yeas 26, nays 21, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Barker, Bennett, Brown of Wells,
Cobb, Corbin, Cullen, Culver, Douglas, Downey, English, Finch, Gifford, Hanna, Hord, Jinkens, Marshall, McClurg, Mason, Moore, Newlin, Oyler, Richmond, Staggs, Vawter, Wright, and Mr. President - 26.
NAYS - Messrs. Allison, Beeson, Bowman, Bradley, Brown of Hamilon, Cason, Davis, Dykes, Hyatt, Milligan, Niles, Noyes, Reagan, Terry, Thompson, Ward, Williams, and Woods - 21.

Mr. NILES remarked that he was not entirely satisfied with the provisions of the bill, and It will be remembered that he made efforts to have it amended. But he had so strong a desire to see the Sinking Fund, and all our other trust funds invested in our public debt, that he had concluded, as a choice of evils, to vote for the bill as it is, rather than to incur the risk of delay and the danger of having the fund distributed to the counties. He had confidence in the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, and he believed they would honorably invest the funds in our State bonds. Their acts can not be done in a corner, but will be patent to all the people of the State. If they act corruptly, they will deserve to have "thief" branded on their foreheads, and their names will go down to their children like those of condemned felons. With such sanctions he was prepared to take the risks of the bill.

Mr. THOMPSON had his hopes and his heart set upon the idea that in a few short months the State of Indiana would be owing only about $3,300,000. Our State debt is upwards of $6,036,000. The amount of the State debt sinking fund is about $1,000,000. In the hands of the Sinking Fund Commissioners, is $600,000. There is also due this fund $900,000, secured by mortgages, which can be made available to the State by the issuing of six per cent, bonds, made payable when the mortgages are collected. Putting all these sums together, and applying it on the public debt, and it would have about $3,300,000. If we could have these funds invested in the State bonds, and the State debt reduced to this sum, it would be the best advertisement we could send to the World's Fair. And it is the act of the Republican party if this is not done, and you will have to answer to the people. The Republican party have the power, from the fact that we stand here 25, and enough of the opposite party are with us to secure this object. We are the party in power, and this reflection is upon ourselves, and not upon the Democratic party.

If these funds shall be squandered, the expectation of the Governor and the hopes of the people will be defeated in this war for money makingand the Republican party are responsible for it. This bill was conceived, brought forth and nourished in the House, and it takes from our children their education money, covenanted to them by our fathers.
Without reading the bill, a vote was taken on its passage resulting: - yeas 28, nays 16.
The Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The Senate met at 2 o'clock P. M.

Mr. BENNETT offered a Joint Resolution [S. No. 22] declaring in what manner the Acts of the present session of the General Assembly shall be published and circulated in the several counties of this State, and when they are to take effect; [on the filing of a stitched copy in the office of the clerks of the several courts;] which was read the first time.

div.head: THE COMMON SCHOOL FUNDS.
div.p: Mr. COBB understood that the bill H. R. 47 has never been read the third time, although a vote was taken on its passage just before the recess for dinner.
On his motion the bill was read the third time, and another vote taken on its final passage, resulting - yeas 31, nays 15 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Bennett, Brown of Wells, Chapman Cobb. Corbin, Cullen, Cuiver, Douglas, Downey, English, Finch, Fuller, Gifford, Hanna, Hord, Jinkens, Marshall, McClurg, Mason, Milligan, Moore, Newlin, Niles, Oyler, Reagan, Richmond, Staggs, Vawter, Ward, Wright, and Mr. President - 31.
NAYS - Messrs. Allison, Barker, Beeson, Bowman Bradley, Brown of Hamilton,Cason,Davis, Dykes, Hyatt, Noyes, Terry, Thompson, Williams, and Woods - 15.
Mr. CHAPMAN, in explanation of his vote said: As I understand it the bill is, now as I now want it. I therefore vote " aye."

Messrs. MILLIGAN, REAGAN and WEIGHT explained, that haying endeavored in vain to place more efficient safeguards around the bill; while favoring its main features, they felt called upon to vote "aye" on its final passage.
And so the bill passed.

div.p: Mr. CORBIN [at 3 o'clock] moved that the Senate take a recess of one hour; - stating as a reason for this motion, that Senators were not in their seats, and it was useless to attempt to do business while they were running to the windows to witness the reception of a regiment.
The motion was agreed to.

div.head: AFTER THE RECESS.
div.p: The Senate resumed its sitting at 4 o'clock.
The PRESIDENT pro tem, announced the consideration of the special order for 3 o'clock, being Mr. Vawter's Morgan and other rebel raids bill, S. No. 15.

div.head: RAILROAD TAXATION.
div.p: The bill H. R. 158, pending at the time of the recess to witness the regiment reception, was read.
Mr. NILES stood opposed to the motion to strike out; and spoke generally in favor of the bill.

Mr. VAWTER gave the reasons which induced him to offer the amendment, reciting the course of this bill through the last session. The appraisement which would be made under the first section of this bill would not give a fair appraisement of the railroad property of Indiana. Under this bill Indiana would have no railroad taxation, and would collect no taxes from railroads whatever. No railroad appraisement ever yet made in Indiana has been permitted to stand by any railroad as an entirety. One of the objects of this bill is to legalize the appraisement made by a board of equalization which did what they had no right to do; and this is one of the reasons for his opposition to the bill. He entered into a detailed history of railroad assessments made in this State, extending his remarks beyond the usual hour of adjournment, and before he had concluded, gave way for -
Mr. WILLIAMS, on whose motion the Senate adjourned till nine o'clock to-morrow.

div.p: Mr. BRANHAM introduced a bill [H. div.head: INDIANAPOLIS CRIMINAL COURT.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB called up the special order, namely, his Indianapolis Criminal Court bills, Nos. 277 to 280, and 300, and moved that they be made the special order immediately after the State Debt bill shall be disposed of.
It was so ordered.

div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: The special order, namely, the consideration of the Joint Committees State Debt Sinking Fund bill [H. R. 285], was taken up - the question being on the final passage thereof.

Mr. COFFROTH, being entitled to the floor, reviewed Mr. Pettit's construction of the acts of Congrees exempting stocks from taxation. He regretted that Mr. P. was not in his place. He first submitted the objection to the bill in section 4, where it is provided that after paying the interest on all the debts including the war debt, of the remainder, 70 per cent, goes towards liquidation of the 5 per cents., and 30 per cent, towards the 2 1/2 per cents. Now the 2 1/2's rate at about 80 cents on the dollar. The 5's are about par. It was probable that these both would go down to half par. But we don't buy them at the market value, but buy their face. If they they should run down to 50 cents it was plain that the loss to the State would be just half the debt.
Mr. BRANHAM. Would't we make more money by repudiating the whole debt?
Mr. COFFROTH could not see the point of the suggestion. All States buy up their bonds at their market value.
Mr. MILLER. Suppose we make such legislation as will reduce them to ten cents on the hundred dollars?

Mr. COFFROTH did not understand that their value could be controlled by legislation. He then proceeded to show, that whether the debt be due or not, the bill is wrong. If the debt be due, the bill does not provide adequately for its payment; and if it be hot due, the people are not in a condition to be taxed for its payment. Never was there a worse time for taxation. The Federal and State and local taxes were enormous. Especially was it not the time to tax for this purpose, when one-fifth or one-sixth of the entire amount of the taxable property of the State is exempt from taxation.

He argued that if the words "at the pleasure of the State" were to be taken as meaning that the debt is not due, it might never be due. The current history of our legislation went to show that the debt is now due in point of time. But these conclusions were useless; because, whether due or not, the bill is wrong.

He came then to consider whether we should tax now to pay the State debt. He complained that the majority had determined, in caucus, to support this bill before it was considered in the House - before the considerations were presented for the information of our judgment. It was really not at all a party question. The minority had voted as a unit against because it was manifestly wrong.
Mr. CHURCH knew of no caucus on the subject: but it was sufficient to command his vote, that the Democrats were against it.
