Mr. COFFROTH was not controlled by any such consideration. The gentleman was not at the caucus: he may have been at the Theater. But if the bill passes here, we will take the question to a forum where there can be no predetermination - the forum of the people.

He submitted whether it was right that the whole of this State Debt burden be taken from the capitalists and placed on the shoulders of the labor of the State. He then replied in detail to the argument of Mr. Speaker Pettit, submitting statements in figures which can not be justty sketched, and would exceed our space. He summed up the capital of the seventy national banks in the State. In this, the Sixth Congressional District, these banks had a capital of about three millions, - which he thought would embrace about one-fifth of the National Banking capital in the State, and that would give the grand total in the State of about fifteen millions.

He got his estimates from one of our most intelligent National Bank Presidents. He had made his estimate of this total at $14,000,000, and the Government deposits with these banks at $1,000,000, including, also, the U. S. securities held by the Free Banks. Then, $35,000,000 of Government stocks were held by the people. Then, the circulation - Treasury notes and National currency - in the loyal States he estimated in round numbers at $1,000,000,000. This would give to Indiana for her share, say 150,000,000 - Indiana being an average State. So his estimate of $100,000,000 exempt from taxation was exceeded by the sum of estimates just recited.
Mr. HIGGINS. The gentleman counts it twice - the bonds and the currency. The circulation emanates from the capital.
Mr. COFFROTH. Not at allor if so, it was proper; because the bonds were held by the banks - the currency by the people. The capital was taxed against - the banks, the circulation against the people.

He then referred to the allegation of Mr. Speaker Pettit, that the stocks of these banks are subject to taxation. But not a dollar of it was on the duplicate; not a stockholder pays a dollar of tax on his stock, so far as he knew. The gentleman says deposits are taxed in the hands of depositors. But a deposit was a special loan. In the case of individuals, the
holder of the deposit and the holder of the note therefor were both taxed. It was not so in the case of these national banks holding deposits of the people; because (as he showed) the deposits were greenbacks. He referred to the decision in the case of Widtney against the city of Madison - November term of the Supreme Court, 1864 - p. 331, to the effect, that bank stock and stock of the United States held as bank capital, are not taxable.
Mr. COWGILL asserted that this decision was under an act of Congress passed prior to that read by Mr. Pettit.

Mr. COFFROTH replied that Mr. Pettit read from the act of June 3, 1864, and this decision was in November of the same year. The Court places it upon constitutional grounds - then taxation is prohibited by the constitution, and not by virtue of any act of Congress. The Supreme Court had made this decision, and, rteht or wrong, it was a rule unto us.
Mr. NEWCOMB. The act of Congress provides that the shares may be taxed.

Mr. COFFROTH. The statute simply says, page 112 of the statutes at large of 1863-64, that they may be taxed if the State or municipal authorities have the authority so to do simply throwing the question back upon the constitution. So he answered Mr. Pettit as to this. He then replied to Mr. P.' s allegation, that greenbacks are taxable as money. He showed from the act of Congress that reenbacks were treasury notes; and that "all bonds, treasury notes, and other securities of the United States" shall be exempt from taxation. He read further from the act to the same effect, that all currency including coupons and stamps, shall be exempt.
Mr. MILLER. Would it have made any difference if this provision of the act had not been passed.

Mr. COFFROTH. Perhaps not so far as bonds are concerned. It was a decision by Judge Marshall, who was constantly disposed to favor the central power. The only appeal from this hardship was to the people. So far as the national currency was concerned, there would be a clear right to tax that, were it not for this act of Congress; and notwithstanding that act, he still regarded it as an open question, that national currency could be taxed by State or municipal authority. The act of 1865 did not militate against the act of 1864. If a more injurious and infernal way of defrauding the people were desirable, or which would be more fruitful of revenue to the privileged class, it could not have been devised better than this system, the creature of that political charletan, Salmon P. Chase. Capitalists make from 35 and 40 to 50 per cent, annually on their investments in these national banks. No national bank was making less than 35 per cent, per annum.

In reply to the hopefulness of Mr. P. that the people will still endure taxation, because they had endured a tax of 300 cents on the hundred dollars, he said, it was like the practice of Dr. Sangrador - warm water and bleed, and bleeding and warm water till the patient dies.

The County Commissioners were not restricted from levying the whole amount of the local county tax in one year, as the gentleman from Wabash had said. With reference to the gentleman's allegation, that we would have had no troubles and no debt if the party of the minority here had been true to the flag, he would say nothing, but admit that the gentleman himself did take military service as Colonel of the 75th regiment; and when the regimen marched to the field the gentleman marched home.
Mr. COWGILL denied that Mr. P., his colleague, ever accepted a Colonel's commission.

Mr. COFFROTH. The gentleman from Wabash was commandant of the post, but he insisted upon nothing about that, only he thought it an ungenerous fling at the party, and that it came with a bad grace from the gentleman, in the face of those of the minority on this floor, [Mr. Milroy and others,] who had served in the Held as well.
The House then took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: On motion by Mr. SHUEY, Mr. Veach obtained leave of absence on account of his wife's sickness.

div.head: LOCOMOTIVE ENGINEERS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BROWN, his Locomotive Engineer bill [H. R. 301,] was taken up and made the special order for to-morrow, 10 o'clock.

div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: Mr. BROWN" (being entitled to the floor,) addressed the House at length against the bill. [The speech is reserved for correction.]

Mr. MILLER. As he understood the question raised but the objectors to the bill, it was this: Should the payment of the public debt be provided for at this time, when $100,000,000 of Government bonds are in the hands of a portion of the people not subject to taxation? There was a vast difference in the estimates of the gentleman from Huntington and the gentleman from Wabash, as to the amount of these bonds exempted. Whether the one or the other was right, it made no difference with respect to the main question here; in either case, it was still right to adjust the State debt. He justified this exemption of bonds from taxation. It obtained money at par to carry on the war.
Mr. COFFROTH. What was the difference between the right to draft for money, and to draft for blood?

Mr. MILLER. The Government got both men and money when they wanted them - got money and secured the draft. The same cry of opposition would have gone up against the draft for money as was heard in certain quarters against the draft for men. He showed that it was absolutely necessary to exempt the bonds from taxation, in order to get the money. Otherwise the city of New York would have reduced the Government bonds twenty per cent. Then, if they were not protected, unfriendly legislation would tax these bodds so as to drive them out of existence.
Mr. COFFROTH. But assessments for taxation must be uniform.

Mr. MILLER. Taxation could not be uniform - the rate could not be uniform either in the cities of the State, or in the different States of the Union. To tax these bonds was a little like taxing money in the pocket. The General Government, a sovereign, should not be taxed by the municipality - nor should the General
Government be overrode by the States. It was the old secession heresy of State Rights. This States Rights taxation would place the General Government in the power of unfriendly States. It was not necessary to say that at the time those bonds were offered, the Ship of State was well nigh foundered, the hissing cry came up from the Sons of Liberty: "Not a dollar, not a man to carry on this unholy war." They said these bonds were not worth the paper; and gentlemen to-day were trying lo make that declaration good. How were these bonds distributed? They were divided among the people without respect to any favored class. This appealing to the prejudice of laborers against capitalists would not avail. Governor Willard - that best of Democratic tacticians - said, this was the reason why the Democracy always succeeded: they appealed not to the prejudices, but only to the patriotism of the people. The right to tax these bonds was founded in principle as deep as the foundations of the Government itself. This tenacity of sovereignty was the foundation stone of the Government.
Mr. BUSKIRK. Was the gentleman in favor of the General Government taxing their bonds?

Mr. MILLER. He was for the General Government doing just what they are doing with them. Gentlemen held as much wild land as they pleased without taxation by the General Government. Without these bonds, the national debt could not be funded at less than 8 per cent. It would not take as large a per cent. of the property in the country to pay off the entire national debt, as it would to fund these bonds. When he had concluded -
Mr. DUNMAM took the floor and spoke an hour in opposition to the bill. [His speech is reserved for authentication. It will be printed hereafter.]

Mr. SHUEY said it might surprise his friend from Floyd if he were to announce that the question before us was the adjustment of our State debt. He was disappointed at seeing gentlemen indulge in these diversions in this debate. The gentleman from Huntington rejects this bill, but fails to propose any adjustment of the debt in its place. He gave way for -
Mr. NEWCOMB, who moved for a night session at 7 o'clock - affirmative 34, negative 30 - no quorum voting. The motion was then withdrawn.

Mr. SHUEY proceeded. He replied to Mr. Coffroth's allegation, that the State would lose $600,000 by paying the public debt, as the bill proposes, at par value. Would not the gentleman be making a pretty figure for the State, buying up its own bonds at a shave. Such a thing would be dishonorable in an individual, much more in a great State. The gentleman would have the State's creditors wait till the Democratic party shall get power again. He trusted that day would never come. Would the gentleman repudiate the debt of the nation? There was no Taney nor Perkins to sustain him in such a course. He remembered in that day of trial when the Government offered these bonds, some of the stump speeches of Democrats alleging that greenbacks were worthless and the Government stocks would turn out as valueless as the old Continental currency. And in this way it was by these speeches on every Democratic lip and tonguethat the Government was compelled to resort to exemption of the bonds from taxation. It was a child of their own begetting.

To a genuine Union man the burden of taxation was not onerous. He complains not, because he regards what has been procured by these national obligations. He was not at all alarmed at the gentleman's determination to take this issue before the people - to cry aloud and spare not: and he thought he appreciated the influence he and his party might command. He recited what the bill proposes. It was but a return to the original contract and engagement of the State in 1846. But, if he could have had his way, he would have put the bill in such a shape as to pay, first the 2 1/2 per cents then he would have paid the five per cents.; and then the sixes - the war bonds. But still he thought the bill was the best bill for this adjustment that was likely to come before the General Assembly this session, and therefore he should support it with his vote.
On motion by Mr. GRIFFITH, the House (at 5 P. M.) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem, commanded order at 9 o'clock A. M.
On motion by Mr. OYLER, the reading of yesterday's journal was dispensed with.
On motion bv Mr. CHAPMAN the regular order of business was suspended and his State Debt bill No. 292, was read by title only and referred to the Special Committee on that subject.

div.head: CIRCUIT COURTS - MISDEMEANORS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. OYLER, Mr. Dpwney's Circuit Court Misdemeanor-Jurisdiction bill, S. No. 300, to amend section 5 of An Act for the organization of Circuit Courts; approved June 1, 1852; was read the third time. The bill passed the Senate by yeas 40, nays 5,.

div.head: EXECUTION OF OFFICIAL BONDS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. CASON, the Judiciary Committee bill, S. No. 289, to provide for the acknowledgment of the execution of official bonds, and to declare the effect and obligation of such bonds as between the obligors and the State; was read the third time.
The bill passed the Senate by yeas 44, nays 0

div.head: THE MORGAN AND OTHER REBEL RAIDS.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem, announced the consideration of the special order for this hour, viz: Mr. Vawter's Morgan and other rebel raids bill, S. No. 15 - the question being on concurrence in the amendments of the House of Representatives.
The House amendment striking out the word "one" in section 1 and inserting in lieu the word "three," as the number of Commissioners; being read -
The Senate refused to concur therein by yeas 20, nays 23 - as follows:
YEAS - Messrs. Allison, Bowman, Cason, Cobb, Cullen, Culver, Downey, English, Gifford, Hanna, Hayatt, Jinkins, Marshall, Mason, Staggs, Thompson, Vawter, Ward, Wright, and Mr. President, 20.

NAYS - Messrs. Barker, Beeson, Bonham, Brown, of Hamilton, Brown, of Wells, Chapman, Corbin, Davis, Douglas, Dykes, Finch, Fuller, Hord, Milligan, Moore, Newlin, Niles, Noyes, Oyler, Reagan, Richmond, Terry, and Woods, 23.
Mr. WILLIAMS, when his name was called, announced that he had paired off on this question with, Mr. Bradley.

The House amendment providing that the Commissioner shall investigate and examine claims, take full and complete testimony of witnesses, reduce it to writing, and report the game for the action of the next legislature, or of the General Government; being read -
The Senate refused to concur therein.

The House amendment to the effect that it shall not be allowed to any person to receive any thing under this Act, till he or his Attorney shall have first filed with the Auditor of State his affidavit, which shall be dated not more than ten days before the issuing of the warrant, that he is the original claimant, and since the passage of this act, he has not gold or transferred the same to any person vvliatever, or agreed or stipulated for the same; and any such transfer shall vitiate the allowance; and it may be recovered back, &c.; being read -
The Senate concurred therein by yeas 39, Navs 2.

The amendment striking out the clause making it the duty of the Attorney to discharge the offices of a clerk, and inserting in lieu a provision authorizing the Governor to appoint a clerk, who shall keep a full and accurate account of the proceedings of the Commission, with a salary of $5 per day; being read -
The Senate refused to concur therein by yeas 17, nays 20.
The House amendment, dividing the claims into classes, as to injury done respectively by troops under the order of State officers, Federal officers and rebels; being read -
The Senate refused to concur therein by yeas 23, nays 18, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Allison, Bonham, Bowman, Cobb, Culen, Culver, Downey, Dykes, English, Fuller, Gifford, Hanna, Hyatt, Jinkens, Marshal, Mason, Oyler, Staggs, Thompson, Vawter, Ward, Wright and Mr. President - 23.
NAYS - Messrs. Barker, Beeson, Brown of Hamilton, Brown of Wells,Chapman, Corbin,Davis, Douglas, Finch, Milligan, Moore, Newlin, Niles, Noyes, Reagan, Richmond, Terry and Woods - 18.
The House amendment making the pay of the Commissioner six dollars a day instead of eight dollars as in the Senate bill, being read -
The Senate concurred therein by yeas 27, nays 13 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Barker, Beeson, Bonham, Bowman, Brown of Hamilton. Brown of Wells, Cobb, Cullen, English, Finch, Fuller Gifford, Hanna, Hyatt Jinkens, Marshall, Moore, Newlin, Noyes, Reagan Richmond, Staggs, Terry, Vawter, Ward, Words and Wright - 27
NAYS - Messrs. Allison, Chapman, Corbin. Culver, Davis, Douglas, Downey, Dykes, Mason, Milligan, Niles, Thompson and Mr President - 13.

The House amendment providing, in effect, that if the payments to be made by the State under the provisions of this Act, shall leave a deficit in the Treasury, it shall be the duty of the Governor, Auditor and Treasurer, or of a majority of them, to borrow so much money as may be necessary to make such payments, for which they shall give the obligation of the State, payable not later than the 10th of March, 1867, with interest at six per cent.; being read -
The Senate refused to concur therein.
The other House amendments, chiefly clerical, were not concurred in.

div.head: RAILROAD TAXATION.
div.p: Mr. COBB moved to make the bill, H. R.158, providing for the valuation and assessment of Railroad property, the special order for Monday, 2 o'clock P. M., and that 200 copies thereof be printed.
Mr. NILES was gratified with the motion to print the bill for, in his judgment, it embraces as fair provisions as the wit of man can make.
Mr. CHAPMAN desired all the bills on this subject printed; and raised a point of order as to the present condition of these Railroad bills.

A long discussion ensued in which the history of these bills were recited and their course traced through the last and the present session: - Messrs. VAWTER, NILES, COBB, CORBIN, WILLIAMS and the PRESIDENT pro tem, taking part. After which -
The motion [Mr. Cobb's] was agreed to.

div.head: TAXATION OF TREASURY NOTES.
div.p: Mr. BROWN, of Wells, by leave, offered the following:
WHEREAS, We believe that a truly republican government is only rightly administered when its burthens are imposed equally and without distinction as to citizens, power and official position; and

WHEREAS, We believe the fos ering of privileged elates, whether such classes be based upon wealth, official position, or any like distinction whatsoever, is inimical to the spirit and genius of our Government; and
WHEREAS, We do especially deem the creation of a moneyed aristocracy as a sure stride toward a centralized and despotic form of government; and

WHEREAS, We believe the legislation of Congress in exempting the bonds, coupons, national currency, United States notes, checks for money of authorized officers of the United States certificates of deposit, stamps and other representations of value of whatever denomination, which have been or may be issued under any act of Congress, tends to create and impose upon our country the evils above deprecated; therefore

Resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, That we hereby infract our Senators and request our Representatives in Congress to labor for the immediate repeal of all laws or parts of laws granting the exemption aforesaid.

Resolved, That a copy of the above preamble and resolution, over the signatures of the President of the Senate, the Speaker of the House, the Principal Secretary of the Senate, and the Principal Clerk of the House, be communicated to our said Senators and Representatives.
It was referred to the special committee on the subject of taxing bonds.

div.head: ANNUAL SESSIONS.
div.p: Leave being; granted -

Mr. BROWN of Wells, introduced a joint resolution [S. No. 23] for amendment of sec. 9 Art. IV. of the State Constitution, so as to provide for annual sessions of the Legislature; which was read the first time and passed to the second reading.

div.head: SESSION HOURS.
div.p: Mr. VAWTER moved that when the Senate adjourns it shall stand adjourned till Monday at 2 o'clock P. M.
The motion was agreed to by yeas 19, nays 18.

div.head: CENSUS EVERY SIX YEARS.
div.p:
Mr. CULLEN. from the special committee thereon, returned his bill S. No. 293, to provide for the periodical enumeration of the white male inhabitants of this State over the age of
twenty-one years; to prescribe the duties and fix the compensation of officers in relation thereto, and also to prescribe the penalties for the violation of official duties in connection with said enumerations, as well as the manner in which, and the Courts by which, said penalties shall be enforced; [in 1866 and 1871, and every six years thereafter, Township Trustees shall make the enumeration before January 1, and July 1;] - recommending its passage.
The bill was read the second time and passed to the third reading.

div.head: CUSTODY OF COUNTY BUILDINGS.
div.p: Mr. RICHMOND, from the Committee on County and Township Business, to which was referred Mr. Downey's resolution of inquiry as to what legislation is necessary with reference to the safe keeping of public buildings of counties; reported a bill [S. No. 301] for An Act with reference to public buildings of counties, and the grounds belonging thereto, and prescribing the duties of County Boards and Sheriffs' with reference to the same. [The County Sheriff shall be custodian.]
The bill was read the first time and passed to the second reading.

div.head: AN EX-SHERIFF'S CLAIM.
div.p: Mr. RICHMOND presented a claim of a late sheriff of Marion county against the State, which was referred to the Committee on Claims, without reading.

div.head: GRANT COUNTY COMMON PLEAS.
div.p: Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on Organization of Courts, returned the bill, H. R. 210, to fix the time of holding the Common Pleas Court in Grant County; recommending its passage.
The bill was read the second time and passed to the third reading.

div.head: OFFICERS OF THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: Mr. VAWTER, from a Select Committee, returned the bill, H. R. 270, fixing the per diem of members of the General Assembly, clerks and officers thereof; recommending its passage with amendments, adding to section 4 a provision to the effect that there shall be but one Clerk and one Doorkeeper for each House. The Secretary of the Senate to receive for a regular session $2,500, for an extra session $2,000; the Doorkeeper for a regular session $1,200, for an extra session $1,000. The Clerk of the House to receive for a regular session $3,000, for an extra session $2.200; the Doorkeeper for a regular session $1,800, for an extra session $1,300.
Mr. ALLISON moved that the bill be laid on the table. It is a bill of considerable importance, and there should be a full Senate when it is considered.
The motion was agreed to.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES
div.p: Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on organization of Courts, returned Mr. Bonham's bill S. No. 276, to amend section 26 of An Act providing for the election and qualification of Justices of the Peace, etc.; recommending its passage.
Mr. COBB, from the Committee on the State Library, returned Mr. Oyler's bill, S. No. 281, increasing the salary of the State Librarian from $800 to $1200 per year; recommending its passage.
These bills were read the second time, and passed to the third reading.

div.head: INSURANCE COMPANIES.
div.p: Mr. COBB, on leave, introduced a bill [S. No. 302] for An Act to amend sections 39, 42, 45 and 54 of An Act entitled An Act for the Incorporation of Insurance Companies, defining their powers and prescribing their duties, approved June 17, 1852; which was read the first time and passed to the second reading.

div.head: WHITLEY COMMON PLEAS.
div.p: Mr. DOUGLAS, by leave, introduced a bill [S. No. 303] for An Act to legalize and declare valid and effectual all the orders, judgments, etc., made and had before the Judge of the Common Pleas Court of Whitley County, in the month of March in the year 1865, then and there before the regular Judge of said Court; which was read the first time and passed to the second reading.

div.head: JAMES G. BRYANT.
div.p: Mr. DOUGLAS offered the following:

Resolved, That James G. Bryant be and he is hereby allowed the sum of $6 50 for a copy of Cushing's Parliamentary law, furnished the presiding officer of the Senate at the regular session for the year 1865; to be paid out of the fund appropriated for legislative expenses.
It was referred to the Committee on Claims.

div.head: INDIANAPOLIS GAS COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. NILES. I desire to submit a claim handed to me, I hardly know why, in favor of the Gas Light Company of this city, for gas furnished to the Governor's house during last session; - perhaps a reason is that I was on a committee, with others, which occupied that house. The bill is for $65 70, and I think there is no doubt, from what I hear, that it is correct. I move it be referred to the Committee on Claims.
The motion was agreed to.
And then the Senate adjourned (under the order made above) till Monday, 2 o'clock, P.M.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The SPEAKER, at 9 o'clock A. M., directed the Clerk to call the roll to determine a quorum; and a quorum having been determined -
On motion by Mr. HAMRICK, the journal of yesterday was authenticated without reading.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. HAMRICK, from the Committee on Corporations, returned his road bill, H. R. 302; recommending its passage.
He also returned Mr. Kilgore's voluntary association bill, H. R. No. 312, with an amendment inserting after the 10th clause "To erect and maintain public ferries."

Mr. HUMPHREYS, from a majority of the Committee on Fees and Salaries, returned Mr. Stringer's delinquent tax bill, H. R. 315, with an amendment striking out ten per cent., and inserting five per cent, in lieu; and so recommending its passage.
Mr. BONNER, from the select committee thereon, returned a Common Pleas bill, S. No. 66; a majority recommending its passage without amendment.

Mr. WHITE, from the same select committee, on behalf of the minority, submitted a report dissenting from the views of the majority - believing it unnecessary to make two districts out of one, which is but an average district; and recommending that the bill be indefinitely postponed.
Mr. BROWN stated that he was informed by the Senator from Rush, that the bill is desirable.
Mr. SHUEY said he was informed that the arrangement was in accordance with the imperative demands,of the business in that district.

Mr. STEWART said that district was composed of the counties of Decatur, Rush, Hancock, Henry and Madison. Rush and Decatur lie south of the National Road. It was a long; narrow district. The two counties below the National Road, (Rush and Decatur,) wish to be formed into a District by themselves.
Mr. FERRIS had information from the Judge, that he is entirely unable to discharge his duties in that large district.
Mr. CHAMBERS said this division was not a thing demanded by the people, so far as he knew. He thought it was for no other purpose than to accommodate somebody that wants to be Judge.
The SPEAKER. The Chair does not understand that the bill is before the House.

Mr. WHITE, from the Select Committee thereon, returned the bill, S. No. 205, fixing the times of holding courts in the Seventh Judicial Circuit; with an amendment striking out "two" and inserting "three" in lieu.
Mr. KILGORE, from the Select Committee thereon, returned Mr. Coffroth's new judicial circuit bill, H. R. No. 305, recommending its passage.
Mr. CHAMBERS, from a majority of the Select Committee on the State Agricultural College, reported a bill locating said college at Bloomington, Monroe County, Ind.
Mr. BUSKIRK said there would be a minority report. He desired that the bill should be made a special order for Monday.
The SPEAKER. That could not be done without unanimous consent. The bill has not been read.
After further conversation by Messrs. BOYD, BUSKIRK, CHAMBERS and MILLER,
Mr. CHAMBERS had leave to withdraw the report.

Mr. LOCKHART, from the Committee on Railroads, obtained unanimous consent to return Mr. Cox's bill, H. R. No. 217, to compel Railroad Companies to transport all freight, of whatever nature, and declaring that one class of freight shall not have precedence over another class; recommending that it be indefinitely postponed.

Mr. WOODS trusted that the House would not sustain the recommendation. He knew than local freight was neglected for through freight. It was not particularly the design of the bill to compel the roads to take perishable freight, but to protect the rights of the people of the State against the power of a growing monopoly.

Mr. LOCKHART said the bill was reported to elicit information. Such a law as this bill provides would seem to be correct; but it was found on maturely reflecting, that it would work hardships and injustice to some of the roads. The fact that up to the commencement; of the war, but few, if any, of the railroads in the State paid the actual expenses of operating them, was sufficient to account for the meagre supply of rolling stock on the various roads.

With the increase of business on the different roads came a corresponding increase in the price of everything pertaining to their operation. Locomotives costing, before the war, from $8,000 to $9,000, cannot now be had for less than $18,000 to $20,000; and freight cars cost in the same proportion. Many of the roads have been deterred from purchasing, on account of the excessively high prices, and have been waiting in hope of a reduction. He was informed by the managers of several of the most important roads in the State, that they are taking steps to thoroughly equip their roads with a sufficient amount of rolling stock to enable them to pieet the growing wants of the country on their lines.

We cannot, if we would, ignore the fact, that during the rebellion, the railroads of Indiana have done a work, the value of which cannot be computed in dollars and cents - not only for our own State, but other States and the General Government.

It is the opinion of the Committee, derived from the numerous petititions, resolutions, etc., coming into their hands from various parts of the State, that there are many cases where the people have just cause of complaint on account of the almost total neglect of the local freight, and the preference given to through freight. This, in the opinion of the Committee, is all wrong. Local interests should be looked after first, in order to the more speedy development of the resources of the State; and in case such measures are not adopted by the different roads, legislation will become a necessity. Your Committee would, therefore, respectfully suggest to the managers of the different roads within this State, or that operate lines running through the State, that they give this matter their immediate attention, so that no citizen may have cause of complaint; and as there, are still portions of our State without railroad facilities, that the people along the proposed lines may be encouraged to assist in the upbuilding of such roads, which so materially aid in the development of the resources of this great State.The difficulty was in regard to perishable property offered as freight. He thought the growing interests of the State would demand that the Railroads should carry perishable freight.
Mr. SIM. As the Committee had not a fair opportunity to consider the bill, he moved that it be recommitted.

Mr. WOODS. Notwithstanding the great public benefit of Railroads, in developing the resources of the State, it must be acknowledged that the people along their lines, and the legislation of the State, have conferred great benefits on the Railroads. If they can carry through freight, they can carry local and way freight. He hoped the bill would not be postponed.
Mr. MILROY was opposed both to the postponement and the recommitment. He alleged that the Wabash and Erie Railroad refused just accommodations to the country; and he denounced monopolies.

Mr. LITSON preferred recommitment. He
had received no notice of the meetings of the Committee to consider this bill.

Mr. COFFROTH and Mr. KILGORE alleged that the Chairman of the Railroad Committee (Mr. Lockhart] had ever been fair and courteous in his notices and invitations for Committee meetings - the latter alleging that the opinions of the Chairman could not be taken as the judgment of the Committee. He spoke of the fact of the selfish, injurious management of Railroads passing through this State, and owned in New York. The Committee had consented that this bill should be reported, in order that it might give place to some other bill, such as that introduced by the gentleman from St. Joseph (Mr. Henricks.) If the Legislature should adjourn without action on this Subject, the tariff of freight would be increased on the first of January. He gathered this from the proceedings of a late Railroad meeting.

Mr. COWGILL said complaints were made in till parts of the Sjate against the lack of Railroad accommodations for way-freight: and men were ruined in their business in consequence. He had no information of the Railroads proposing to remedy this grievance.

Mr. SHOAFF, of Jay, rather concurred in the views expressed by the Chairman of the Railroad Committee. He was not willing to support legislation unfriendly to Railroad 'companies. He was willing to take middle ground, that would guard the interests of the people. But under certain circumstances, and in certain seasons it would be impossible for any Railroad to be prepared to carry promptly all descriptions of freight. It would be an unjust requisition.

Mr. GLEASON stated that he had participated in the deliberations of the Committee on Railroads. He also concurred in the remarks by the Chairman (Mr. Lockhart.) We should be cautious in legislation on railroads, which had done more than anything else to develop the agricultural resources of the country. It should not be forgotten that it was strictly the interest of railroad men to transport all the freight offered on their line; and therefore he had consented to the report for the indefinite postponement of the bill. The railroad system itself would in the end suggest the most advantageous arrangements for freight.

Mr. RHOADS said, when railroads trnch on the rights of the people, they ought to be restrained and regulated by legislation. The people had almost entirely abandoned all other modes of transportation. The railroads had monopoly of thisthey were the common carriers of the nation, and they should be restrained from the infliction of injuries, which their position gives them the power to do. They would not now take a cord of wood to market for any man living on their lines. The bill was not to injure the railroads, but to protect the rights of the people in this regard. He moved that it be made a special order.
The SPEAKER said that the bill was not in possession of the House.
Mr. SIM withdrew the motion to recommit.
Mr, HENRICKS would move to lay the report on the table, that the bill may take its place on the Calendar.
The SPEAKER said that would not effect the object.

Mr. COFFROTH, A large number of the railroads - nearly all of the roads passing over the State, were authorized under special charters: and the bill proposed only to affect those operating under the General Railroad Law. Would it not be better to have a bill that would affect all railroads alike? He submitted whether there was power in the Legislature to pass a law affecting either of these classes of roads. Whilsr the Legislature has the power to regulate railroads, it has no power to impair vested rights. He moved to re-commit the bill to the Judiciary Committee, with instructions to consider and report a proper bill.
[On motion by Mr. Meredith, Mr. Cook obtained leave of absence on account of illness in his family].

Mr. WOODS. The best way to test the question whether the people can control the Railroads or not, was to pass the bill; and see whether we have got to be a New Jersey State on this question. He recited cases of hardships in high prices for way freight, and desired to know whether we were to be mude a mere pathway for these channels of trade owned in eastern cities. He confessed the developing power of R. R's.; but still we should hold them in check, and prevent the tendency to monopolies and favoritcisms amongst R. R. men and their favorites. He preferred, if the bill was to be referred, that it go to a special committee.

Mr. LANE demanded the previous question, and under its operation, Mr. Coffroth's motion to commit to the Judiciary Committee with instructions was rejected - yeas 29, nays 43; and the question recurred on indefinite postponement.
[On motion by Mr. BROWN his Locomosivo Engineer bill [H. R. 301] was taken up and made the special order for Tuesday 10 o'clock.]
Mr. GRIFFITH, desiring further information in the premises, hoped that the bill would not be indefinitely postponed.
He demanded the yeas and nays on the question, which resulted - yeas 6, nays 61; so the House refused to postpone, and the bill remains in the calendar.

Mr. CHAMBERS, (by consent) from the select committee thereon, returned Mr. Buskirk's Agricultural College bill [H. R. No. 6], locating said college at Bloomington, with an amendment by way of substitute.
On motion by Mr. BUSKIRK, it was made the special order for Tuesday, 10 o'clock.

div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM called up the special order, viz.: the consideration of the joint committee's State Debt Sinking Fund bill [H. R. 285], the question being on the final passage thereof.

Mr. NEWCOMB took the floor and spoke at length in support of the bill, alleging his surprise at the partisan opposition to this bill initiated by Democratic members, - especially in the speeches of Mr. Coffroth. He complained that that gentleman voted for the fifteen cents levy in the Joint Committee, and alleged his inconsistency and unfairness in that, as well as in his professions of a desire to adjust and pay the public debt, but at the same time insisting that it shall not be done till Government bonds shall be taxed as other property, and admitting that there is no power to tax Government bonds under the decisions of the Supreme Court of this State and of the United
States. Mr. N. showed that taxing these bonds, even if it were legal and possible, would inflict the greatest financial distress upon the whole country. His speech will be printed in the BREVIER APPENDIX. Before he had concluded, he gave way for a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER (Mr. Henricks in the Chair) laid before the House a communication from the Warden of the Northern State Prison, responding to a resolution of the House of November 25, embracing a statement of the average cost of provisioning convicts for the month of October; the average working days of convict in the months of August, September and October, and copies of the contracts upon which convicts are hired out by the Board of Control.
On motton of Mr. GRIFFITH, it was referred to the Committee on the Northern State prison.

The SPEAKER also laid before the House a communication from the Auditor of State, responding to a resolution of the House of the fifth inst., setting forth the current expenses of the Northern State Prison.
It was also referred to the Committee on the Northern Prison.

The SPEAKER also laid before the House the letter of Charles Butler, of New York, in regard to the adjustment of the State debt, on account of internal improvements, in response to a resolution of the House adopted yesterday.
Mr. BROWN moved that the letter be laid on the table and two hundred copies thereof printed for the use of the House.
The motion was rejected.
Mr. BURWELL demanded the yeas and nays on the motion to print the Butler letter - the vote resulting - no quorum voting. After the call of the Roll -
The SPEAKER directed the Doorkeeper to close the doors.
Mr. BROWN, thinking that sending for absentees would not result in doing any business to-day, moved that further proceedings under the call be dispensed with.
The CHAIR could not entertain the motion under the rules.
Mr. BROWN then appealed from the decision of the Chair.
The SPEAKER (Mr. Henricks in the Chair) could not entertain an appeal in the present condition of the House.
Mr. BROWN thon moved an adjournment, but withdrew it upon request.
Mr. DUNHAM asked leave of absence.
The SPEAKER could not entertain any motion.
Mr. SPENCER made an ineffectual motion to adjourn - affirmative 12, negative 30.
Mr. MILLER moved a resolution to thc effect that each member absent without leave be fined in the sum of $5 for each day of their Absence.

Mr. DUNHAM made the point that under the rules, the resolution is not in order, because the penalty shall be determined upon the absentee being brought to the Bar of the House. He desired to lay it on the table

The PRESIDING OFFICER directed the Roll-call again, to ascertain delinquents - the Chair holding that the Rules require all absentees without excuse, to be sent for, unless the member is himself sick.
Mr. BURWELL alleged that it was in the discretion of the House whether they send for any absentee - he referred to Rule 14.
Mr. BROWN. The House, should designate who they will, send for. The House has the same power to revoke an order that it has to make an order.
The Doorkeeper having been despatched for absentees by direction of the Chair -
Mr. BROWN moved an adjournment - affirmative 20, negative 24.
Mr. Griffith considered if it was competent for the House to send for absentees, it was competent for the House to excuse them.

Mr. BUSKIRK stated the discretion of the House, and gave his opinion that absentees now should be dealt with in such a manner as will vindicate the dignity of the House. He asked the Chair to decide upon the excuse of Mr. Abbett. There might be cases in which there would be hardship and inhumanity in sending for a member.

The PRESIDING OFFICER decided, that there being no House to grant a leave of absence, no leave can be granted. He saw no difference in the present case between exusing a man for absence, and refusing to sent for him.
Mr. BOYD made an ineffectual motion to adjourn.

Mr. PETTIT would suggest that the pending call of the House be adjourned over till Monday. There would be a propriety in having those present in the House that cannot be got here to-day; and a useless protraction of the session now might not prove the most creditable either to ourselves of the State. He thought it would be better to adjourn the call, and save ourselves from unavailing efforts to get a quorum; and if gentlemen would permit him, he would make that motion.
Whereupon the House (at 1/2 P.M.) adjourned till Monday morning 9 o'clock.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro. tem, called to order at 2 o'clock, P. M.
On motion by Mr. GIFFORD the reading of Saturday's journal was dispensed with.

The PRESIDENT pro. tem. laid before the Senate a lengthy communication from the Adjutant General in answer to a resolution of inquiry as to the expenses of his office for the current year, and what amount of the appropriations made for his office last session for the year 1866 will be needed. The report says with reference to the last inquiry that there was appropriated $10,000 more than will be necessary for carrying an the business of the office next year.
The communication was referred to the Committee on Finance.

div.head: RAILROAD TAXATION.
div.p:
The PRESIDENT announced the consideration of the bill, H. R. 158, for a just and equitatable of Railroad property - the question being on the pending amendment [Mr.
Vawter's] to strike out the first and sixth sections of the bill.
Mr. VAWTER, in summing up, gave the following reasons why he should oppose the bill under consideration unless his amendments were adopted.

list.item: Because the statement required, of Railroads is not specific enough, and the information required will operate in favor of the Railroads and against a just valuation.

Because the sixth section of the bill is contrary to the spirit of the Constitution, which declares that all taxation shall be equal, and if railroads are forgiven their delinquency it, in fact, destroys that equality.

Because it is a benefit conferred exclusively upon Railroads. No adjustments are made with persons unable to pay their taxes. The poor men of the country must pay their taxes or suffer the consequences. But to Railroad corporations an exclusive immunity is given by the sixth section of this bill.

Because the valuations made which the sixth section proposes to legalize, were maide - not by the appraisers elected by the people - but by the unauthorized act of the County Auditors, upon the demand of the railroad Corporations, coupled with a threat that unless it was made, no taxes would be paid.

Because in the case of the New Albany & Salem Railroad, for whose special benefit this bill is pressed with such pertinacity, the valuation is clearly unjust. Think of a Railroad with its road bed, rolling stock, warehouses, track, etc., etc., being valued at $750 per mile, when the track alone would sell for greatly over that amount.

Sixth. Because if we are to believe the Auditor of State in his official report to the Senate, the counties and State will lose near a millionof dolIars, which will go to corporations that have shown no favors to the people of Indiana.

Because the passage of this bill will lose to the Common School Fund - to the children of the State - fifty thousand or more dollars. And I know no reason in Railroad history in Indiana that entitles them to any such legislation.
Because the passage of this bill will t>e a triumph to Railroad monopolies, relieving them from burdens imposed upon them by, law, and transferring them to an already tax-burdened people.

div.p: Mr. COBB. The friends of this bill want it to go through on its merits; and they are satisfied if members of the Senate understand its provisions there will be no trouble about its passing. The great point made in opposition is with reference to releasing the Lou. N, A. & Chi. R. R. Company from the back tax assessed against it under the law of 1852. There can be no question in the minds of Senators in regard to that provision being just. The tax on the assessment of the year 1852 would amount to $42,900 a year from 1854 to 1858, and in those years that Railroad company fell in debt to its work hands $200,000; and when the present managers of that road took hold of it they found that debt resting upon it. The managers becoming satisfied they could not pay, the taxes under that assessment they became delinquent from 1854 to 1859; but under the law of 1850 they went back and paid their taxes from 1854 to 1858, through an adjustment made and agreed to by the officers of State at that time.

Senators can see the great inequality practiced upon this road when they are told that the law of 1852 imposed upon it more than one-half the burdens of the entire railroad interests of the State. The original bond-holders the men who built that road for the good of the public - have not received one dollar from it; but on the contrary over $l,800,000 is due by way of interest to the persons who entered into that work and constructed it. It is a poor road - they have not got it in good condition yet, but they hope to make it better before long. It cannot even supply the mills in New Albany which buy their wheat in Chicago with grain to keep them running, because it is not able to buy rolling stock necessary for the transportation.

He insisted that this bill would place all railroad companies upon an equal basis. If this bill passes, railroad companies will be compelled to yield an equal and just taxation. We present you here with a bill that is perfect as every attorney will say, and, as the distinguished Senator from Laporte [Mr. Niles.] has already said, it is as perfect a bill as the wit of man can devise.

He referred to a report of the Supreme Court of the State, going to show what it takes to make a valid assessment, and what it takes to enable a judgment to be given in cases of this kind; and he undertook to say that there was not a provision complied with in this assessment. But suppose you were to receive a judgment for these taxes; it would be nothing but a useless litigation that would only tend to line the pockets of attorneys. This Company is too poor to pay. You find that they have nothing but material necessary for the running of the road, and you sell it and you leave it without being able to meet the necessities of the country through which it passes; and then your debt will not be paid. But he put it on another ground. You can not recover - these suits can never be sustained. The best legal talent of the State are unanimous in the opinion that judgment can not be obtained. He submitted whether Senators were not willing to do justice to a great public improvement of so much benefit to the State?
Mr. CHAPMAN inquired what the appraisement was, per mile, under the law of 1859?
Mr. COBB. Seven hundred and fifty dollars per mile.
Mr. CHAPMAN. Was it not $3,500? That is the reduction made by the Auditors of the counties, as he understood it.
Mr. COBB. If was made $750 by local appraisers, and the Board of Equalization confirmed it.
Mr. WRIGHT understood that the Board of Appraisement made it $8,500 per mile, hut by some hocus pocus it was cut down to $750.
Mr. COBB. The Auditor's report shows that the assessment per mile by the district appraisers was $750; and by the State Board it was put at the same price.

Mr. COBB. The first appraisement under the law of 1859, was made at Crawfordsville by a portion only of the county officers, and they put it at the sum named by the Senator from Kosciusko [Mr. Chapman.] But it was not a full Board by any means. The appraisement was not a legal one - and it is a grave
question whether any of them are legal. Another Board was called, when they were all present, as he believed, and they appraised it at $750 per mile; and then the Board of Equalization which met at Indianapolis, confirmed that appraisement.
Mr. BONHAM. Has not the Auditor of gtate already recovered judgment for the amount of these taxes?
Mr. COBB. No sir. There are suits brought but there never will be judgments rendered.
Mr. CHAPMAN. Is the Auditor claiming under the $3,500 assessment?

Mr. COBB. He is claiming under the original assessment, under the law of 1852, $4,600,000. His position, or the position of his lawyers is, that the law of 1859 is unconstitutional, and the company is liable under the law of 1852.

Mr. NILES understood, and supposed it unquestionably true, that the assessment of the four million and a half against this poverty-stricken Railroad, was on account of a ruinous statement made as a basis by the President of this road, who gave in for assessment the cost of the road, which all will agree was palpably unjust.
Mr. BRADLEY. The amount of the mortgage debt of this road is $2,800,000, and the accumulated interest on that debt is $1,080,000.
Mr. CULLEN. It is very poor, indeed. [Laughter.]
Mr. WRIGHT. If we pass this bill as it now stands, will it not let all other roads out of their taxes?

Mr. COBB. No, sir. This bill is particularly guarded with reference to that point. To talk about losing millions of dollars by this bill is all nonsense. It is untrue, as gentlemen will see from the reading of the bill. We ask as a matter of even handed justice that this bill shall be passed, and that this burden upon a railroad 288 miles long, running the entire length of our State, shall be removed.
On motion by Mr. COBB the amendment was laid on the table by yeas 83, nays 10.
The report of the Committee was then concurred in.

Mr. WRIGHT. The first section of the bill provides for an appraisement on the first Monday in April, 1866, and then it provides in the fifth section that the Commissioner of such railroad company can appeal to the State Board of Equalization; which does not meet till 1869. Then if an appeal is taken, it would have to lie over till the meeting of the State Board. This is a question that ought to be looked into.
Mr. COBB. There is a provision in the bill which requires them to pay their delinquent tax before they can appeal.

Mr. NILES apologized for using: so strong an expression as he did in ttie heat of debate on Saturday, when he said that this bill was as perfect as the wit of man could make it; and he proceeded to point out several clerical and typographical errors.
On motion by Mr. COBB the Committee amendinents were considered as engrossed.

Mr. DOWNEY. If it be true, as suggested by the Senator from Jasper, [Mr. Wright,] that railroads can take an appeal, and thereby suspend the appraisement of railroad property until the meeting of the State Board in 1869, that would be a serious objection to the bill. The State would not be authorized to go on and collect upon an appraisement, when there might be an appeal pending. Unless this can be corrected, he could not vote for the bill.

Mr. HORD. If the special school tax, township tax, road tax. and the school tax are not to be considered State taxes, as he understood this bill, they could not be collected under it. It seems in legislation heretofore, there has been a distinction made between State taxes and school taxes, and there ought to be some provision made in this bill to cover this particular class of taxes. He moved to amend by inserting appropriately these words: "All taxes assessed by State, County, or Township; authority;" so that there shall be no question as to the construction.

Mr. CULLEN had prepared an amendment which would obviate the difficulty suggested by the Senators from Jasper [Mr. Wright] and from Ohio [Mr. Downey;] viz: add appropriately in section 5 this: "provided the right of appeal shall not apply to assessments made in the year 1866."

Mr. NILES had written an amendment reading thus: "Provided no such appeal shall lie till the second appraisement under this act shall have been made." There had occurred to him another difficulty. It will be remembered that this bill was prepared be different personsonly the 8th section was written wholly by himselfand this will account perhaps for a want of coherence; and it justifies the apology he made for his strong expression of the other day, in which he really had reference to the basis of the bill. Section 7 provides that cities and incorporated towns shall tax railroads the same rate per mile as the valuation is for city and town taxation. Looking at that in connection with the fact of their being subject to township taxes, school, road and special school taxes, which probably ought to be provided for distinctly; he suggested whether that would not lead to double taxation.
Mr. VAN BUSKIRK moved to recommit the bill and proposed amendments to the same committee.
Mr. BENNETT demanded the previous question.
The demand was seconded by the Senate and, under its operation -
The motion to recommit was rejected upon a division - affirmative 14, negative not counted farther than 16.

Mr. VAWTER had; opposed this bill as strenuously as any one on the floor, but as there appears to be a disposition to pass it, he appealed to Senators objecting to the amendments proposed to withdraw their opposition and let the bill be perfected.

Mr. CASON, though favorable to the bill, opposed this way of bringing in amendments on the third reading of a bill, and would prefer the House shall take the responsibility of adding these necessary provisions.
The bill was then read the third time and passed the Senate by yeas 80, nays 13, with an amendment of title.

div.head: COUNTY SEATS.
div.p: Mr. BROWN, of Wells, moved to take up the re-location of county seats bill, H. R. 125.

Mr. ENGLISH hoped the bill would not be taken up. Perhaps not a Senator on the floor is interested in it but himself. It is called a
general bill but in reality is intended to change the county seat of Clark county. He had written home for instructions with regard to this matter, and was waiting impatiently for directions so that he might know what course to pursue on the subject. He desired that the bill should take its proper course - he did not want the bill forced upon the Senate. It is a local bill entirely and interferes with no Senator's district but his own.

Mr. BROWN replied that other portions of the State were interested in the bill besides the district of the Senator from Scott, [Mr. English.] He simply desired the bill read by title fpr the purpose of referring it to a committee.
Mr. ENGLISH again resisted the motion in a few remarks.
The motion was rejected.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. RICHMOND from the Committee on County and Township Business, returned the bill, H. R. 124, amending section 30 of the act regulating the fees of officers, etc., approved March 2, 1855: recommending its passage.
Mr. VAN BUSKIRK, from the Committee on Education, returned the bill, H. R. 22, to legalize the sale of certain school lands in Lake county; recommending its passage.
These bills were passed to the third reading.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: Mr. CULLEN introduced a bill [S. No. 304] for An Act repealing sections 38 to 55 inclusive, of An Act for the incorporation of Insurance Companies, defining their powers and describing their duties, etc., approved March 17,1852; to provide for the winding up of the business of Mutual Fire Insurance Companies organized under said act, and providing the time within which the same shall be done; which was read the first time.
Subsequently, on motion by Mr. CORBIN, it was read by title and referred to the Committee on Corporations.
Mr. HANNA introduced a bill [S. No. 305] for An Act in relation to the laying out and opening public highways.
Mr. NILES introduced a bill [S. No. 306] for An Act in relation to the vacation of streets in cities.
These bills were read the first time and passed to the second reading.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on the Organization of Courts, returned Mr. Richmond's bill, S. No. 275, extending the terms of Circuit Courts by adjournment; recommending its passage.

Mr. CULLEN, from the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements, returned the bill H. R. 120, amending section 5 of An Act authorizing the construction of levees and drains; recommending its passage.
These bills were passed to the third reading.
On motion by Mr. BROWN, of Hamilton, his gravel road bill, S. 199, was read by title and referred to the Committee on Roads.
On motion by Mr. BONHAM it was -
Resolved, That the Auditor of State be requested at as early a day as possible, to report to the Senate a correct list of the claims allowed at the last session, and remaining unpaid.

div.head: REAL ESTATE APPRAISEMENT.
div.p: On motion by Mr. ALLISON, the bill H. R. 212, to legalize the appraisement of real estate made under the provisions of An Act approved December 21, 1858, and assessments made and thereafter to be made, on such appraisement; was read the third time.
The question being: Shall the bill pass?
A constitutional provision demanding tht yeas and nays, they were ordered, and being taken -
The result was not announced.
Mr. THOMPSON demanded a call of the Senate.
The demand was not seconded - upon a division, affirmative 5, negative 6.
Several favorable reports from the Committee on Claims were submitted.
On motion by Mr. RICHMOND the Committee on County and Township Business' bill, S. No. 301, making Sheriffs the custodians of public buildings; was taken up and read thg second time.
Mr. RICHMOND demanded a call of the Senate.
The demand was seconded, and the Secretary proceeded to call the roll.
Before the roll call was finished -
Mr. CULLEN said: As two Senators have come in which will insure the passage of the bill, I move that further proceedings under the call be dispensed with.
The motion was agreed to.
The result of the vote on the passage of the real estate appraisement bill H. R. 212 was then announced, viz., yeas 35, nays 0.
So the bill passed.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The SPEAKER took the Chair at 9 o'clock A. M., and directed the Clerk to call the Roll to ascertain a quorum.
The Clerk reported to the Chair that there were 52 members present and answered to their names.
Mr. NEWCOMB. Mr. Speaker, I presume we shall not have a quorum before noon, and I move that the House adjourn till two o'clock.
The motion was agreed to, and, accordingly -
The House took a recess till two o'clock P.M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER directed the Clerk to report the journal of Saturday.
On motion by Mr. BURWELL, the journal was authenticated without reading.

div.head: INDIANAPOLIS CRIMINAL COURT.
div.p: On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, his series of bills [H. R. 277, 278, 279, 280 and 300] for a Criminal Court in Indianapolis, etc., was taken up -

The bill No. 277 to amend the second section of the Judicial act of June '52, was amended in the first section by adding this: "Shall have no criminal jurisdiction but only jurisdiction in civil cases," and so it was ordered to the third reading, read the third time and passed the House of Representatives - yeas 70, nays 4.
[The SPEAKER announced the Select Committee on Mr. Buskirk's Court bill, No. 308; viz: Messrs. Buskirk, Abbett, Boyd, Humphreys and Veach.]

The bill, No. 278, treating the 16th Judicial Circuit, etc., was amended by inserting at the end of the section a cl ause to this effect: " The persons convicted of felony in such court, and sentenced to hard labor in the State Prison, shall not be forwarded to the prison until the end of the term wherein they were convicted, unless by order of the Court."
And then, on motion of Mr. NEWCOMB, the bill was considered as engrossed, ordered to the third reading, read the third time and passed the House of Representatives - yeas 70, nays 6.

The bill, No. 279, amending sections 9 and 10 of the act prescribing the powers and duties of Justices of the Peace in State prosecutions, was also passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 72, nays 5.

The bill. No. 280, to amend the 14th section of the act of March 4, 1852, to limit the number of grand jurors, etc., was amended in said 14th section, after the words "Circuit Court," by inserting: "except as otherwise provided by law;" and so the bill was considered as engrossed, and passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 68, nays 6.
The bill No. 300, to amend section 19 of the General Practice Act of June 18, 1852, was taken up.

Mr. NEWCOMB said this being the last of the series, (in regard to notice) and it not having passed the second reading, he would move a suspension of the constitutional restriction, that it might be twice read and put now upon its passage.
The restriction was suspended - yeas 66, nays 7 - and the bill was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 72, nays 5.
Mr. RHOADS made an ineffectual motion to take up the consideration of bills in the calendar on the third reading.

div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: Mr. BROWN called up the special order; viz The consideration of the Joint Committee's State Debt Sinking Fund bill [H. R. No. 285] the question being on the third and last reading thereof,

Mr. NEWCOMB being entitled to the floor, resumed his speech in support of the bill at the point he was interrupted by the adjournment Saturday morning. He continued his reply to the speeches of last week by Mr. Coffroth and Mr. Dunham. He showed by figures, that it would be suicidal for the State of Indiana or the several States, to ask and to be allowed to tax United States bonds - that she would gain little, as compared with the larger stock-owning States; and that in the end the State of Indiana would be the greater loser in taxation to make up the depreciation in United States stocks that would follow upon their taxation for the benefit of the treasuries of the wealthier and larger bond-holding States.
[The speech is reserved for correction. It will be printed hereafter.]

Mr. HARRISON asked the indulgence of the House to state his objections. The bill imposes a tax of 15 cents on each $100 valuation of the taxable property of the State for the year 1866, and every year thereafter until the interest and principal of the war loan bonds and certificates of State stock are fully paid, the amount of revenue thus derived to be applied in the payment of these war loan bonds and certificates of State stock indiscriminately. It has been said that the main object in convening this extra session of the Legislature was to adjust the State debt falling due in January next. I believe, however, the Governor has never publicly announced such to have been the object. We are informed by the Governor's message that the amount of tlie public debt of the State, consisting of 2 1/2 and 5 per cent, registered stocks is $1,418,960 50. Of this amount, the sum of $5,342,500 is 5 per cent., and the sum of $2,076,460 50 is 2 1/2 per cent. stock. Of these stocks, the Board of Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, and the State Debt Sinking Fund, have purchased in all, $1,382,898, leaving outstanding, in the hands of the creditors of the State, the amount of $6,036,080.It is understood in the bonds that they are redeemable at the pleasure of the State, which I suppose means at the convenience of the State. I had hoped that the amendment proposed by the gentleman from Monroe, to strike out of the first section of the bill the war loan bonds, would have been adopted. The war bonds were issued under the act of May 13, 1861, authorizing the Governor to issue two millions of these bonds. The act provides that these bonds shall be made payable to bearer twenty years after date, with interest at the rate of six per cent, per annum, on the first days of November of each year, at the Indiana Agency in the City of New York. There can be no question as to the fact that these bonds are not due for about seventeen years to come, yet the bill proposes to provide for the payment of these bonds at the same time, in the same manner; and in fact, they have a preference, in so far as placing them first in the bill will give their payment preference over the stocks of the State issued twenty years ago.

The burthens of taxation, already oppressive to the people, will be greatly increased by the passage of the bill, and that too, at a time when nearly one-fifth of the taxable capital of the State is invested in Government securities, which are, as every one knows, exempt from taxation. Whether this will ever be sufficient, I shall not Undertake to say, and so far as the payment of the stocks of the State issued twenty years ago is concerned, it is not in my judgment material to inquire. Justice to the holders of these obligations, and good faith on the part of the State, requires that these obligations should be satisfied as soon as the State can conveniently meet them, but the case is, in my judgment, different in regard to the war loan bonds. There can be no pretence that these bonds are due, and why should we increase the burdens of taxation in order to pay them, (even if we could compel the bearers thereof to accept payment before they mature,) at a time when we are unable to discharge a debt incurred twenty years ago. The payment of these war bonds should be deferred until such time as it may suit the convenience of the State, if they are to be satisfied before maturity, and until all classes of our citizens may have the opportunity of being assessed for their payment.

I do not wish to be understood as favoring any scheme of finance that will imply even a suspicion of repudiation. As to the question of the power of Congress to tax the United States bonds, I believe no one contends that
this can be done while the bonds remain in their present form, as there are undoubtedly tested rights in the holders of them. The next question is, has Congress the power to so modify or change the bonds by issuing a new one to the holders (in lieu of the present ones,) that shall be liable to taxation? I am not aware that this question has ever been directly decided by the Supreme Court of the United States. In the case of Weston vs. The City of Charleston, Second Peters' Reports, decided many years since, the city attempted to tax certain United States securities in his [Weston's] hands; the Court held that the State had no power to tax a United States bond, containing no prohibiton, in the hands of the bearer thereof. The point, however, whether Congress had the power to modify or change the bond was not decided. Sir, it has been said that this Is, and should not be a party question, for the reason that it is a question in which the whole people are interested. There is perhaps no question upon which the people are so sensative, or in which they take so deep an interest, as the one of taxation. There are at this time unmistakable signs of discontent among our people in consequence of the present unequal system of taxation. High prices lor all the necessaries of life still continue, notwithstanding the war is over, and why is this? The answer is, taxation. Look at one of the resolutions recently adopted at the Working-men's Convention held in this city, which is as follows:

Resolved, That we enter our solemn protest against that system of Legislation, whether State or National, which tax three-fourth for the benefit of the other fourth and if resulted in, must result in repudiation.
And in this connection I call the attention of the friends of this bill to the following clause in the late message of the Federal Executive, viz:
No favored class should demand freedom from assessment, and the taxes should be so distributed as not to fall unduly on the poor, but rather on the accumulated wealth of the country.

It is a matter of history that this question of levying taxes to provide for the payment of a war debt once caused an insurrection in this country (under circumstances less obnoxious than the present,) known as Shay's Rebellion. The war of the Revolution involved the United States in a debt of $40,000,000. Of this sum $8,000,000 were borrowed from foreign powers. The rules of the Confederation of 1777, empowered Congress to carry on the war; but they had no power to provide for its expenses. They could only recommend to the several States to raise money for that purpose. Accordingly in 1781, Congress passed a resolution, requesting the several States to furnish their proportion respectively of the eight millions of dollars of borrowed money. They also appointed a committee to determine what proportion of the money ought to be paid by each State. It was proposed to the States that a duty of four per cent, on all foreign goods imported into the United States should be paid, and that the revenue arising therefrom should be applied to the payment of the national debt, both foreign and domestic. The latter was principally due to the officers and soldiers of the army. All the States, except Rhode Island and New York, assented to the proposal. But as these two States had a large share of the public trade their refusal to contribute to pay the public debt defeated the whole plan; and the consequence was, that even the interest of the matured debt remained unpaid. Under these embarrassing circumstances, it was perfectly natural for those States which felt desirous of discharging their debts in an honorable man, ner, to make the utmost exertion to do their part. The country was not, however, in a perfectly settled state. There were some men in Massachusetts who, though they had been willing, in 1776, to go to war with Great Britain rather than submit to taxation without representation were willing, in 1786, to go to war with the Government rather than pay their share of the expenses which the contest with Great Britain had occasioned. As to whether these men were bondholders or not I am not advised. In some parts of the country tumultuous assemblies, under the specious names of conventions, were assembled, which obstructed the courts and other bodies. Shay, who had been a Captain in the revolutionary war, was considered as the head of the insurgents, hence the movement took the name of Shay's Insurrection. The insurgents continued to increase until they numbered 1,500, the spirit of opposition to taxation was rife everywhere, and it required a body of 4,000 armed men to sustain the courts and suppress the insurrection.

Now, as the State is not prepared to meet the whole amount of this indebtedness at this time without increasing the burdens of taxation, (already oppressive to the people) as proposed by the bill, it seems to me that justice to the bondholders, and good faith on'the part of the State, requires that the amount of funds on hand of the State debt Sinking Fund, which is said to be about $1,600,000, should be applied in payment on the State stocks issued twenty years ago, with such a tax as may be sufficient for that purpose,only leaving the residue, together with the war levies to be provided for and paid hereafter, and at such time, as shall suit the convenience of the State to do so.

There is no disguising the fact that a large class of our citizens are demanding the taxation of the Government securities held by another class in the State, and the present indications are that they will not be satisfied until it is done, or at least until the experiment of so doing is tested before the proper tribunals of the country.
On the motion of Mr. BRANHAM, the further consideration of the bill was postponed, and it was made the special order for to-morrow morning 10 o'clock.
Mr. WOODS moved an order to take up bills of the House on the third rending.
Mr. GRIFFITH moved to amend, by substituting the consideration of bills of the House on the second read in.
The vote resulted on a division - affirmative 31, negative 32 - no quorum voting.
Whereupon the SPEAKER directed the Clerk to call the roll; and a quorum being determined -
Mr. GRIFFITH withdrew his motion to amend, and Mr. Woods' motion was agreed to.
On the motion of Mr. TRUSLER, Mr. Kilgore and Mr. Rice obtained leave of absence on account of illness.
On motion of Mr. MILLER the House ordered a night session at 7 o'clock, P. M.

div.head: PROTECTION OF FISH.
div.p: Mr Kilgore's Fish Protection bill [H. R. 174] coming np with the Committee amendment, making it unlawful to take fish by seine, net or trap -
Mr. WOODS moved in effectually to exempt the St. Joseph river from the provisions of the bill.
Mr. WOODS then moved to amend the amendment by exempting Cedar Lake and all the frog-ponds in Lake county.
It was agreed to, and then the amendment, as amended, was rejected.
Mr. BURWELL. Between the 15th of June and the month of September was the best fishing season of the year with his people; and this was part of the time in which fishing was prohibited.
Mr. SPENCER. By this bill, fishing was prohibited from December till March, and this was the best time for fishing with his people.

Mr. GLAZEBROOK said the good fishing in his region invited fishers from Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin and Illinois, who would come in with their gill netts and take away the fish to the injury of farmers along their streams of water. He hoped the bill would pass, for he wanted something to protect the home fisheries.

Mr. BROWN said the spirit of the bill was right. But it restricted hook and line fishing when they could be best caught. He moved to reconsider the vote by which the bill was ordered to the engrossment.
Mr. LOCKHART. The best months in the year for his people to fish was February and Marchtaking them through the ice. The bill prohibited taking fish during these months.
Mr. Brown's motion was agreed to, and the vote was reconsidered.
Mr. MILLLER proposed now to amend by way of substitute, making it Unlawful to take fish by seine, net or trap, except in Lake Michigan and the Ohio. Penalty $10 to $100.

Mr. LASSELLE moved to amend the amendment by prohibiting shooting fish. There was more destruction of the fish of the State by shooting the female fish in the spawning season, from the first to the middle of June, than from all other causes.
On motion by Mr. MILLER, the bill with the pending amendments was recommitted to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

div.head: NEW JUDICIAL CIRCUIT.
div.p: Mr BUSKIRK obtained leave to make a report from the special committee on his new Judicial Circuit bill [H. R. 308] returning the tianie with an amendment, making said Circuit to consist of the counties of Bartholomew, Brown, Lawrence, Monroe, Green and Morgan; and re-arranging the courts for the first, second, and sixth circuits.
Mr. BUSKIRK said it was satisfactory to the lawyers of these circuits.
Mr. PRATHER said, whatever the lawyers might wish, the people did not call for this change, so far as his district is concerned.
Mr. BUSKIRK explained the bill.
Mr. OLLEMAN was not aware that thd bill was demanded, so far as his district was concerned.
Mr. HAMRICK hoped the gentleman would not press action on the bill. Let in go on the table.
Mr. BUSKIRK moved ineffectually that the amendment be considered now.
So it goes to the calendar.
On motion by Mr. GOODMAN, the House, (at 5 p. M.) took a recess till 7 P. M.

div.head: NIGHT SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER resumed at 7 o'clock, P. M., and when the calling of the roll had failed to determine a quorum -
Mr. BRATHER moved a call of the House, which proceeded - the Clerk reporting 66 members present and answering -
The SPEAKER directed the doors to be closed, and dispatched the Doorkeeper for members absent without leave of the House.

Mr. HOGATE, being reported present by the Doorkeeper, and having leave to excuse himself, said he had no excuse, except that he was detained by conversation with gentlemen. He complained (humorously) of the manner of his his arrest, etc.
Mr. GLEASON being reported at the bar by the Doorkeeper, said his time was slow, and had deceived him as to the hour.
On motion by Mr. RHOADS, Mr. Gleason was excused.
On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, Mr. Hogate was excused, with admonition.
Mr. HIGGINS moved that further proceedings under this call be dispensed with.
Mr. MILLER and Mr. PRATHER said members had absented themselves since the call was ordered,
The motion to dispense with the call was agreed to - affirmative 89, negative 26 - but, no quorum voting -
The SPEAKER directed the Clerk again to call the roll, which determined seventy members present.
Mr. RHOADS moved ineffectually to take up his school bill No. 245.

div.head: THE CALENDAR.
div.p: Mr. Gregory of Warren's Manufacturing and Mining Corporations bill, No. 248, coming up on the second reading, with a favorable committee recommendation, it was ordered to the engrossment and third reading.
Mr. Lane's joint resolution No. 21, for increase of pensions of privates and non-commissioned officers, coming up, it was ordered to the engrossment and third reading.
