Mr. HENRICKS was satisfied that this question could not be settled in its present shape, because it was a triangular fight. He proposed that the House go into Committee of the Whole and institute an informal vote so as either to agree on a location, or reduce the question to a decision between two points.
Mr. NEWCOMB indicated another plan, to refer the bill to a Commission, to receive propositions for donations for 90 days.
Mr. SIM objected to the latter plan, because the people of Marion county could offer the largest pecuniary considerations.
Mr. BOYD said it was not necessary to recommit, as Bloomington was the only place where we could locate this institution in the prescribed time, and put it into wrorking order.

Mr. FOULKE referred to the proposition for a donation of $100,000 from Wayne county. He complained that the Committee directed to inquire into this matter of a location at the regular session, did not visit Wayne county. He stated that this Wayne county donation was $100,000 in moneynot in property at exorbitant valuations. He summed up the donations from the Battle Ground and from Stockwell in Tippecanoe county - the first was $48,000, and the latter was $33,000, making a total of $81,000. The donation from Bloomington was $50,000, so neither Tippecanoe or Monroe had offered the substantial inducements that had come from Wayne county, which the Committee of Examination last session entirely ignored. The people of Wayne county did not claim pre-eminence in the State, but they did claim that they have offered inducements for this location outweighing all others.

Mr. McVEY considered the reasons urged for the Bloomington location, combatting the allegation that an Agricultural College could not stand disconnected from a literary and classical school. He said: locate this college anywhere else but in connection with the Indiana University, which never had been, and never could be made a success. To say that this institution could not stand alone was to pay a poor compliment to the great minds of the country that conceived these magnificent donations of land for an Agricultural College in every State in the Union.

Mr. WEIGHT stood ready to do what he judged best to advance the educational interests of the State. He was in favor of making the location at Bloomington. He answered objections to placing this college in connection with another institution, and gave considerations in favor of a liberal education to the agriculturalists of the State, defending the school and the teachers at Bloomington. The battle-ground, as regards its historical renown as a battle-field, was played out. There were hundreds of skirmish fields that were its superior in all that makes matter for history.

Mr. HUMPHREYS was never in favor of accepting this grant; but now it is accepted, the question was, what is best to be done with it. His first precaution in this matter was to avoid expense in connection with it, after the manner we have been called upon for appropriations for the Northern Prison. And he thought he could see that the Bloomington location promised the least expense. He gave reasons for his conclusion, that this college could never be a success. The only hope of its success was in its connection with the State University. These considerations decided his mind for Bloomington, - which had no claim but this above any other location that had been named.

Mr. RHOADS gave general views as to the character of the course of instruction that ought to be commended to the people of the State. He objected to limitations as to just how much a man shall know - just what course of instruction he shall taketo make him an accomplished citizen, farmer or mechanic. He would connect the Agricultural College with the State University, where the sons of the State could receive culture without stint, as becomes a free people.
Mr. PETTIT (Mr. Hamrick in the Chair) seing indications of a demand for the previous question, sent up an amendment as a substitute for the amendment of the Select Committee.

It requires the Governor to appoint a Commission,
consisting of five discreet persons from several divisions of the State, well acquainted with agricultural and mechanical industry, who shall be qualified by oath faithfully to discharge their duties as such Commissioners, who shall proceed, upon personal examination of the premises, to fix the location of the Indiana Agricultural College, provided by act of March 6, 1865, subject to the following conditions:
The location, healthy, accessible, etc.
There shall be donated for the purposes of the college a grant of land not less than one hundred acres, of undoubted title, with suitable buildings, or agreements with reference to buildings, thereon, which shall at the time, by a fair valuation, be worth $100.000. This the said Commissioners shall be authorized to receive and hold in the name of the State of Indiana, and make report thereof to the Governor and the Trustees of the Indiana College.

Mr. PETTIT. Hardly a measure that had been presented to this General Assepbly deserved more consideration than this. The details of the bill were likely to be neglected, while we were considering merely the question of location. He was not prepared to decide on the question of location. This question could not be wisely decided without going actually upon the ground for the purpose. Therefore he had proposed that the Governor shall appoint a commission of competent persons to determine this question for us. Mr. Morrill, of Vermont, who prepared the bill for the act of Congress granting these munificent donations of land, purposed the establishment of great independent schools, disconnected entirely from all other istitutions. At the last session here we had acted wisely; we had accepted the grant and established an agricultural college, and he read the names of the trustees in tlie charter. The bill now before the House proposed to modify this charter so as to make this college a part of another institution, against the pledge of the good name of the State, in the act of last session that we would establish a separate institution. The allegations that an Agricultural College could not stand alone might furnish a good reason against receiving the Congressional grant; but now it was accepted, it was no good argument that we should divert this fund from the purpose for vvhich it has been ottered and accepted. He objected to the details of the bill in the matter of the assignment of the land script to the Trustees. The Trustees would have 390,000 acres of land worth, say, $390,000. The taxes upon this land would become a charge upon the State of an annual expense, not less than $7,000 or $8,000. Then there was the expense of locating these lands - the three Commissioners and the Trustees all receiving traveling expenses and $5 a day for the time employed. Then the management of land a land office of twenty years standing could not be got along with, for less than $3,000 a year. Then the lands were not to be sold for less than a dollar an acre - the purchaser to pay six per cent, on the purchase. Then if the purchasers do not pay promptly, these Commissioners are to declare forfeitures. A novelty in law. Did not the gentleman know that the matter of forfeitures would be regulated by the laws of Missouri, or of the State where the lands may be located? Then the bill provides for a College Report to be made annually to the Governor, which the Governor is to cause to be printed, at an expense of probable $3,000 or $4,000 more. Thus he showed up an annual expense involved in the passage of this bill of about $12,000, merely to set up this school and put it in operationmaking us by so much the poorer than we might have been had we never accepted this grant. Upon the question of location, manifestly the best way to get at that was by a commission as he had proposed.
Mr. KILGORE suggested that the power of of location be conferred upon the Trustees incorporated at the last session.
Mr. PETTIT said that would answer his mind about the matter.

Mr. BUSKIRK replied first to Mr. Pettit. The gentleman assumed that the scrip could not be assigned to the Trustees and by them laid upon the lands. He controverted this by reference to the donation Act of Congress, providing that no State shall locate this land with in the borders of another State, for the reason that one sovereignty should not own land within the borders of another sovereignty, but the Act provides that the State's agent may make this location for the State, provided that not more than one million of acres shall be located in any one State. He then read the Acting Governor's recommendation of such assignment, in one of his late special messages. The State of Rhode Island had already made the location of her Agricultural College land, by assignment of her scrip. He then referred to the gentleman's allegation that it was the purpose of the author of the bill (Mr. Morrill) to establish purely an Agricultural College.
Mr. PETTIT stated that it was the purpose Congress to make it distinctly ancl singly an Agricultural College.

Mr. BUSKIRK responded by reading the 4th section of the act. Mr. B. said he did not regard the bill as at all perfect in its details, and when the location shall be made, he would himself move that the bill be recommitted for general revision. But the gentlemen wanted to sell the land script. Mr. B. showed that by the report of the Trustees, this land could not be sold for more that fifty or sixty cents an acre. Now if the land can not be sold, what was the value of the script? Purely Agricultural Colleges were failures in Europe, as well as in this country - there had been failures in New York, Ohio, and Michigan, as he had before stated; and the reason for this had been well represented in the speeches of the gentleman from Floy'd, the gentleman from Dearborn, and the gentleman from Vermillion. Young men go to school for theory, and return to their farms for practical agriculture. With respect to the gentleman's amendment appointing a committee to make this location, he said, if the House was ready to yield themselves to the guardianship of this commission, it might just as well be written to-day as any day hereafter, that this college shall be at Indianapolis. That would be the result of a commission. For his part, he was not prepared to subordinate the judgment of the House in that way. He conconcluded with a defence of some friends of the location at Bloomington who had been seen in these lobbies and referred to by the gentleman from Tippecanoe (Mr. Miller;) and a tribute to the Indiana University at Bloomington
its people, soil, climate. &c. When he had concluded -
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, demanded the previous question.
Mr. MILLER demanded a division of the question. He would have the first question on striking out "Bloomington."Mr. SIM asked and obtained leave to withdraw his amendment.
The SPEAKER (Mr. Henricks in the Chair) held that the previous question cuts off Mr. Pettit's amendment.
Mr. BUSKIRK stated that there was a minority report locating the College in Tippecanoe county.
The SPEAKER, The first question then was on adopting the report of the minority of the special Committee.

It was rejected - yeas 37, nays 47; and the question recurred on the adoption of the substitute for Mr. Buskirk's bill, No. 6, reported by the majority of the special Committee, and fixing the location at Bloomington.

Mr. GREGORY of Warren moved to reconsider the vote by which his demand for the previous question was seconded and the main question was ordered. He desired to give an opportunity for Mr. Pettit to offer his amendment.
On motion of Mr. BROWN, the motion to reconsider was laid on the table.
The question again recurred on the adoption of the substitute - the yeas and nays thereon resulting - yeas 48, nays 43, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Abbett, Bird, Boyd, Brown, Burnes, Burwell, Buskirk, Chambers, Coffroth, Crook, Dunham, Goodman, Gregg, Groves, Hargrove, Harrison, Hogate, Howard, Humphreys, Hunt, Lasselle, Lee, Lemon, Litson, Lopp, Newcomb, O'Brien, Osborn, Patterson, Ferigo, Pinney, Reese Rice, Richards, Richardson, Roach, Shoaff of Jay, Spencer ,Stenger, Stuckey, Sullivan ot Scott, Thacher, Veatch, Weikel, Welch, White, Woodruff and Wright - 48.

NAYS - Messrs. Atkinson, Bonner, Branham, Caldwell, Church, Cowgill, Cox, Croan, Davidson, Ferris, Foulke, Glazebrook, Gleason, Gregory of Montgomery, Gregory of Warren, Griffith, Hamrick, Henricks, Hershey, Higgins, Hoover, James, Kilgore, Lane, Lockhart, Major, Miller, Milroy, Montgomery, McVey, Prather, Rhoads, Riford, Sabin, Shoaff of Allen, Shuey, Sim, Stuart, Sullivan of P. & V., Upson, Woods, Zeigler and Mr. Speaker - 43.
So the substitute was adopted.
Mr. PETTIT then proposed his amendment by way of substitute for the first section of the bill.
On motion of Mr. KILGORE, the House (at 5:30 P. M.,) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem. called the Senate to order at 9 o'clock A. M.
On motion by Mr. GIFFORD, the reading of yesterday's journal was dispensed with.

Mr. DYKES presented a remonstrance from the officers of a Mutual Insnranee Company, of Goshen, against the passage of the bill proposing to repeal the law incorporating such companies; which was referred to the Committee on Corporations.

Mr. MILLIGAN, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned the bill, H. R. 149, to amend section 6 of An Act regarding estrays and articles adrift; recommending that it lie on the table, as further legislation is deemed unnecessary.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: RE-LOCATION OF COUNTY SEATS.
div.p: The Senate returned to the consideration of the bill, H. R. 125, amending sections 1 and 2 of the re-location of county seats Act, (interrupted by the special order yesterday afternoon,) the question being on the amendment [Mr. Noyes'] then pending.
Mr. CULLEN was of opinion that this amendment, if adopted, would kill the bill; while at the same time it would do no good, in fact or in law.

Mr. HORD could see no objection to incorporating this amendment in the bill, and insisted that it should be agreed to. The bill gives all the advantages to those petitioning for removal, and unless this amendment is adopted he should vote against the entire measure.
Mr. WEIGHT'S opinion, as a constitutional lawyer, (laughter) sided with the Senator from Bartholomew [Mr. Hord.]
Mr. COBB thought the amendment would amount to nothing, and that the proposition of the Senator from Bartholomew wras untenable. He therefore opposed the amendment.

Mr. NILES was not able, from hearing the bill read, to give an intelligent vote upon it, and to better satisfy his own mind, and probably the minds of others, he moved to refer the bill with the pending amendment to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. CULLEN objected, whereupon -
Mr. NILES withdrew his motion.
Mr. DOWNEY should vote against the amendment with a view to offering one which he had drawn up since last evening., and which he read. [It is printed below.]
Mr. NOYES renewed the motion to refer the bill and pending amendments to the Judiciary Committee.
On motion of Mr. CULLEN, the motion to refer was laid on the table by yeas 84, nays 11.
The amendment was then rejected by yeas 10, nays 35.
Mr. DOWNEY moved to further amend the bill by adding to section 2 the following:

Provided further. That any person opposed to such re-location may appeal and defend against the application, and may controvert the facts which the applicants are bound to prove, and for that purpose may show that any of the petitioners are not voters, or did not sign the petition, or afterward signed a remonstrance against the same, and the fact of such signing of such remonstrance may be shown, prima facie, by the affidavit of any person who is a competent witness in other cases.It was adopted, by consent.
On motion of Mr. BROWN of Wells, the amendments were considered engrossed, and the bill was read the third time.
It was finally passed by yeas 41, nays 6.
On motion by Mr. VAN BUSKIRK the House concurrent resolution (adopted by that body yesterday) concerning the present plan of guarding the capitol building, was taken up and concurred in.

div.head: THE STATE DEBT.
div.p: Mr. CULLEN, from a majority of the Special Committee on the subject of the State debt, returned the State Debt bill H. R. 285, with an amendment striking out from the enacting clause and inserting new matter - [Mr. Bradley's bill S. No. 279]
On motion by Mr. C. (the minority report not being ready) it was
Ordered, That the matter be postponed and mad the special order for this evening at 7 o'clock; and that when the Senate adjourns this afternoon it will stand adjourned till that hour.

div.head: STATE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE.
div.p: The Senate proceeded to the consideration of the special order for this morning, viz: Mr. Dunning's bill, S. No. 40, establishing an Agricultural College at Bloomington. A division of the question on Mr. Culver's amendment having been demanded yesterday, the first question will be on striking out.

Mr. OYLER spoke some time in response to the address of the Senator from Vigo [Mr. Hanna] delivered yesterday afternoon; and then referred to the matter before the Senate. He did not think our selection of a location for the Agricultural College should be confined to the three places which have already set up bids there, for while he was not prepared to say at which point it would be better for the college to be located, he did say it was a matter of very great importance and should be well considered by Senators before casting their votes. His present feelings were in favor of locating it where the largest donation can be obtained all other things being equal.
On motion by Mr. NILES the further consideration of the subject was postponed till two o'clock this afternoon.

div.head: VACATION OF STREETS, LOTS, ETC.
div.p: On motion by Mr. ALLISON, the Committee on Corporation's bill, S. No. 164, touching the disposition of lots, streets, alleys, public squares and grounds within the corporate limits of any incorporated city heretofore vacated or hereafter vacated; was taken from the table.

Mr. A. explained. The bill provides that where streets or alleys are vacated the property shall belong to the owners on either side; where lots are vacated tiiey revert to the original owners, and where public blocks are vacated they go back to the county or town.

Mr. NILES said the bill was gotten up by a committee at the suggestion of a resolution offered by himself, and which will be found printed on page 165 of the BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS of last session.
The bill passed the Senate by yeas 36, nays 4.

div.head: REGISTRY OF VOTERS.
div.p: Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on Elections, returned Mr. Thompson's bill, S. No. 64, providing for a registry of voters; recommending that it lie on the table, as the bill is unconstitutional in that it restricts the right of suffrage.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: PLANK AND GRAVEL ROADS.
div.p: Mr. CULLEN'S bill, S. No. 247, authorizing plank, McAdamized and gravel road companies to enter upon adjacent lands, and appropriate earth, stone, timber, gravel, sand etc., was read the third time.
It was passed the Senate by yeas 38, nays 2.

div.head: THE DOG LAW.
div.p: Mr. McClurg's bill, S. No. 253, to relieve officers in certain cases for the year 1865, for violation of the provisions of An Act concerning sheep-killing dogs, etc., being read the third time -
Messrs. OYLER and ALLISON spoke in opposition to the bill, and Messrs. McCLURG and HORD urged its passage.
The bill failed to pass, for want of a constitutional majority - yeas 25, nays 12.
The Senate adjourned till two o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem. laid before the Senate a communication from the Auditor of State, in reply to a resolution of the Senate, embracing a partial list of claims allowed last session.
A select committee's bill, S. No. 307, regulating railroad fare, was read the second time.
Mr. MOORE moved to fill the blank in the bill with the word "four" cents per mile.
The amendment was rejected affirmative 12, negative 18.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN, the blank was filled with "three."
Mr. OYLER thought the Legislature had an much right to fix the price of board as to fix the rates of fare on railroads.
The bill was passed to the third reading.

Mr. Wright's bill, 3. No. 308, for the relief of persons who have made entry of bonds where they can not get a good title from the State, was read by title only, and referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.
Mr. McClurg's drainage bill, S. No. 310, was read by title only, and referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.
Mr. Wright's bill, S. No. 311, legalizig sales by Deputy Sheriffs, was read by title only, and referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. CORBIN, from the Committee on Benevolent Institutions, returned Mr. Thompson's bill S. No. 159, for the erection and maintenance of a house of refuge; recommending its passage.
The bill was read the second time.
Mr. NILES moved to amend so that a city and county may co-operate in this matter.
The amendment was agreed to.
The bill was passed to the third reading.

div.head: STATE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE.
div.p: The Senate then resumed the consideration of the Agricultural College bill S. No. 40.
Mr. NILES submitted a substitute for the bill before the Senate, (which was read lor information) proposing the appointment of seven commissioners, with power to locate the said college, etc.
Mr. N. explained the advantages of this idea, and gave notice that at the proper time he would offer it as an amendment by way of substitute.
Mr. ALLISON offered the following:

Resolved, That the bill and substitute be recommitted to the committee on the Agricultural College, with instructions to report a bill dividing the fund donated by Congress equally between Hanover College, Wabash College, Asbury University, Franklin College, the Indiana University at Bloomington, and the Northwestern Christian University at Indianapolis; and providing for the establishrnent of an Agricultural chair in each of said colleges.

Mr. A. addressed the Senate in favor of his resolution, pointing out the advantages that would result from pursuing the course indicated therein, and insisting that it would be the
most perfect plan yet proposed to carry out the evident designs of Congress in making the grant of lands to the several States and Territories.
Mr. VAWTER made an ineffectual motion - yeas 20; nays 20 - to lay the resolution on the table.
Some eight or nine Senators then proposed amendments, adding as many diiferent colleges to those named in the resolution; which were humorously adopted by consent.
Mr. HORD spoke in opposition to any and every proposition looking to a diversion of this fund.

Mr. COBB had a preference for the location of this college but did not deem it necessary to express it at this time. He thought this fund ought not to be distributed, and hoped an early vote would be taken on the question.
On motion of Mr. HORD, the resolution as amended, was laid on the table by yeas 44, nays 3.

Mr. THOMPSON said that Marion County had not yet appeared as a bidder for the location of this Agricultural College, not because of any indisposition to take an active part in the matter, but because, having many of the public building already fixed within her limits, she feared it would create prejudice in the minds of those from a distance; and it might be thought Marion County wished to monopolize the State institutions. But he would say she was prepared, and could and would give as much as any other County in the State to secure the location.

Mr. DUNNING then presented additional considerations in favor of the location of this college at Bloomington; and earnestly announced his conviction that the connecting of such an institution with the State University would be conducive to the public interests of the entire commonwealth. He opposed the proposition for a commission to receive bids for the location; and compared it to the manner in which the Northern Peniteniiary was located some years ago. The people of Indiana are surprised that we have been so derelect of our duty as not to have made the location before this time. He also opposed the idea of dividing this agricultural college fund and thereby defeating the object of Congress in making this munificent grant. When he had concluded -

Mr. VAN BUSKIRK gave reasons why we should not be in haste in making this location; and spoke in favor of the appointment of a Commission which could take advantage of the competition already commenced. The Congressional donation will come to the State in the shape of land scrip, and that must be sold, and we must wait for accrued interest on money so realized before we can commence to operate the institution. Then why be in such haste to select a location?
On motion by Mr. BROWN of Wells, the further consideration of this subject was postponed till 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon.
On motion of Mr. VAWTER, the Senate proceeded to the consideration of

div.head: SENATE BILLS ON THE THIRD READING.
div.p: Mr. Cason's, S. No. 270, to amend sections 3 and 10 of An Act regulating the fees of officers, and repealing former acts in relation thereto, approved March 2, 1855; [increasing the fees of the County Auditors and Commissioners;] was read the third time.

Mr. C. explained that, though his bill raised the fees of County Auditors, it confines them to the face of the duplicate, and does not pay them for the figures made on scraps of paper, as now is done in many counties under the present law; and because of this provision, it will reduce the Auditor's fees in more counties than it raises it.
The bill passed the Senate by yeas 29, nays 13.

Mr. Douglas' bill, S. No. 271, amending section 1 of An Act authorizing Justices of the Peace, Notaries Public, etc., to administer oaths generally, approved March 9, 1861; [including County Auditors;] - was read the third time.
It was passed the Senate by yeas 39, nays 3.
Mr. Wright's bill, S. No, 273, legalizing the action of the State Board of Equalization at their sessions of 1864, was read the third time.
It was passed the Senate by yeas 38, nays 3.
Mr. Richmond's bill, S. No. 275, providing for extending the terms of Circuit Courts by adjournment when the pending business shall be unfinished, etc., was read the third time.
It was passed the Senate by yeas 40, nays 2.
Mr. Niles' bill, S. No. 306, in relation to the vacation of streets in cities; was read the third time.
It was passed, the Senate by yeas 38, nays 2.
The Senate adjourned till seven o'clock, under an order adopted this forenoon.

div.head: NIGHT SESSION.
div.p: On motion by Mr. VAWTER a call of the Senate was ordered; and being taken 27 Senators answered to their names.
On his further motion the Doorkeeper was sent for the absentees.
When 36 Senators had answered -
Further proceedings under the call were dispensed with.

div.head: THE STATE DEBT.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem. announced the lonsideration of the special order, viz: the State Debt bills H. R. No. 285 and S. No. 279.

Mr. CHAPMAN, from a minority of the Special Committee on the subject of the State Debt, submitted a report dissenting from the majority report presented this morning; recommending passage of the bill H. R. 285 and that the bill S. No. 279 be laid on the table.

Mr. BRANDEY spoke in favor of the conclusions made in the majority report. He urged Senators to stand by the financial integrity of the State under any and all circumstances; and insisted that the bill S. No. 279 would preserve the credit of the State both at home and abroad.

Mr. CORBIN occupied the attention of the Senate, speaking for the bill section No. 279. He could come to no other conclusion than that there can be no more honorable manner of adjusting our debt than the plan proposed in this bill.

Mr. CULLEN contended that the bill originating in the Senate is the one that ought to pass. In his humble judgment the House bill would not adjust the debt at all; it was objectionable from beginning to end while the Senate bill would save to the State over a half a million of dollars.
Mr. VAWTER stood against the majority report, for he would support no proposition which does not provide for the accumulation of a fund to discharge the State debt.
Mr. OYLER obtained the floor, but gave way for -
Mr. HORD, on whose motion, the further consideration of the question was postponed till 10 o'clock to-morrow morning.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: A quorum having been determined by calling the roll -
On motion by Mr. CALDWELL, the reading of the journal of yesterday was dispensed with.

div.head: PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
div.p: Mr. BURNES presented the petition of sundry citizens of Hendricks county for the repeal of the Black Laws.
It was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
The SPEAKER laid before the House the petition of J. W. Wharton and others of Franklin, Indiana, for a change in the Liquor Law, so as to require a majority of petitioners to procure license.
It was referred to the Committee on Temperance.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM, from the Committee on Ways and Means, returned his railroad appraisement bill, No. 159, recommending its passage.

Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the petition of E. G. Dickey and others, lawyers of Miami county, for the removal of Indian disabilities, with the expression of opinion that beyond the action of the House already had on that subject, further legislation is unnecessary. The committee asked and obtained discharge, &c.

Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the joint resolution [H. R. No. 28] for amendment of the 11th section of the 4th article of the State Constitution, so that a majority of each House of the General Assembly shall constitute a quorum to do business,with a recommendation that the same ought to pass; together with an argument therfor, in writing.

Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, from the Committee on Education, returned memorials and petitions by C. P. Newkirk and others, asking for a lowering of the standard of qualifications for teachers of common schools, referring to Mr. Goodman's bill as embracing the matter sought by these memorialists.

Mr. BURNES, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned the Justices' Court misdemeanor bill, [S. No. 27,] recommending its passage.Mr. BURNES, from the same Committee, returned Mr. Major's bill, No. 287, to amend the 43d section of the Decedents' Estates act, of June 15, 1852, recommending that its consideration be indefinitely postponed.
Mr. CHURCH, from the select committee to which had been referred the matter of apportionment of the State for Representative purposes, reported a bill, and moved that it be read the first time now.
Mr. BUSKIRK and Mr. BROWN objected.

Mr. REESE, from a majority of the Select Committee on Constitutional Amendments, returned Mr.Lasselle's joint resolution [H. R. No. 22] for amendment of the fifth section of article 11 of the State Constitution, so as to extend the right of suffrage to females, reported an opinion in writing, with this conclusion: That the enjoyment of the right of suffrage by females would ennoble the sex and promote the general welfare - signed, Reese, Lasselle and Miller.

Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Select Committee to which was referred the special message of the Acting Governor, transmitting the communication of the Surgeon General of the United States Army, together with the transfer of the Jeffersonville Hospital to the State of Indiana, reported two concurrent resolutions in relation to the transfer of the United States Hospital at Jeffersonville to the State of Indiana.

Mr. N. explained that the first resolution authorizes the Lieutenant Governor to accept the hospital. The second provides, that until the State shall assume the care of disabled soldiers and seamen there, the Acting Governor may authorize any private association to take charge of it.

Mr. HIGGINS. This matter was of considerable importance. Unless a Soldiers' Home were established, he was opposed to the acceptance. The committee should have made their report upon the other matters which were referred to them.

Mr. BUSKIRK. The officers of the Government leased this farm near Jelfersonville at $2,975 a year, which expires the 13th of June, this year. He objected not to receiving these buildings; but how were we to get possession? If we had possession, we could not hold longer than the 13th ot June. If we got this farm (117 acres and a half,) must we not pay the rent, lacking but $25 of the $3,000 a year?
Mr. PRATHER. Is the Government required to remove the buildings?
Mr. BUSKIRK. The Government have the right of removing them at the expiration of the lease. He would bring up a copy of the lease this afternoon.

Mr. NEWCOMB explained again. We had here in this city an hospital transferred to an association, caring for many disabled soldiers. The city charges them no rent. This same association could take this hospital of the State, and occupy it for the care of the disabled. The United States Government give these buildings to the State.

Mr. DUNHAM was in favor of accepting the property and turning it over for the benefit of soldiers'. But he was opposed to Soldiers' Homes, as he was to Agricultural Manual Labor Colleges. The man that has been a good soldier wants the amenities of social life = has all the generous and noble feelings of human nature, and dislikes confinement and the restraints of a hospital
.Mr. NEWCOMB. In France there was no more popular institution than the Hotel des Invalides.
Mr. DUNHAM said there was a difference between society in Europe and here.

Mr. NEWCOMB, Mr. COFFROTH and Mr. MILLER gave instances of the benevolence extended to invalid and suffering soldiers by
the proprietors of the Soldiers' Home near this city, - the Sanitary Commission.

Mr. PRATHER. We ought to accept this grant of the Government. If the buildings were not removed, they would follow the realty; but the State might dispose of these buildings for the benefit of invalid soldiers. The acceptance should be made at once.

Mr. COWGILL. It was the State's duty to provide for disabled soldiers. But we should always know the responsibilities we take upon ourselves. This might be an arrangement by which we would lose more than we would gain.
Mr. GREGORY of Warren demanded the previous question, which was seconded, and the main question was ordered.
The concurrent resolution was then adopted.
After some general conversation across the House, the vote was reconsidered.
On motion by Mr. BUBWELL, the subject was laid on the table.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB introduced a bill [H. R. No. 321] for an act to establish a Soldiers' and Seaman's Home, and for the benefit of their widows and orphans. It nominates Trustees, (to serve without compensation, except expenses) one from each congressional district the Governor to appoint three morethe Home to be located at Jeffersonville; and if the Trustees deem the premises suitable, they may condemn the land on which the hospital stands, etc.]

On motion by Mr. SHUEY, the constitutional restrictions being suspended for the purpose - yeas 60, nays 25; the bill was read twice, passed to the engrossment, and referred to the special Committee on the Soldier's Home.

Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, introduced a bill [H. R. No. 322,] for an act proclaiming the duty of persons who maybe keepers or owners of gaming-tables or roulettes, shuffle-boards, nine-pin or ten-pin, alleys, or billiard-tables, for purposes of gaming or otherwise; prescribing penalty for the same, and for the protection of minors.
It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. CHAMBERS introduced a concurrent resolution instructing our Senators and requesting our Representatives in Congress to use their influence to procure an amendment to the act of Congress of July 2,1862, donating lands to the States and Territories of the United States, which shall provide Colleges for the benefit of agriculture and the mechanic arts, as will enable such States to withhold these lands from sale for six years, and to extend the time two years in which said States may establish said Colleges without becoming subject to the forfeiture of their grant.

Mr. BROWN said the resolution contemplated that the State of Indiana may go into another State and levy and hold lands. It was preposterous. The matter desired in the resolution could be accomplished under the existing act.
Mr. NEWCOMB said the State of Indiana held land in Georgia for a number of years.

Mr. WOODS moved to amend by striking out "six" and inserting "three" years' time for selling the land. He knew something of the hardships endured in a new country by large tracts of land being taken up and held by non-residents.
No quorum voting on this amendment - the roll-call determined a quorum,and then the amendment was rejected - affirmative 8, negative 75.
The concurrent resolution was then adopted.

Mr. BROWN introduced a bill [H. R. No. 323] for an act to amend the third section of the act to allow County Commissioners to authorize turnpike road companies, where three-fourths of the persons owning real estate along the line of the proposed road shall petition for the same, and to levy a tax for its construction, and provide that the same shall be free.

The SPEAKER laid before the House a message from the Acting Governor, transmitting a copy of the report of Joseph E. McDonald, Commissioner to investigate the Stover frauds on the 2 1/2 and 5 per cent. bonds of the State, recommending that the matter suggested by the Commissioner be referred to the appropriate committee, and that the Commissioner be heard before the committee.
On motion of Mr. BUSKIRK, the communication was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, with instructions to incorporate into the specific appropriation bill the amount of the account stated.
Mr. KILGORE (being requested so to do, introduced a bill [H. R. No. 324] for an act to authorize changes of venue from the Common Pleas to the Circuit Court, and declaring an emergency.
It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. GLEASON introduced a bill [H. R. No. 325] for an act to amend sections 16 and 17 of the act authorizing the construction of levees and.drains, approved June 12, 1852, and subjecting towns and incorporated cities to assessments; and declaring an emergency.
It was referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.
Mr. BRANHAM gave notice of an amendment of rule 54, so as to terminate the morning hour at 10 o'clock, instead of 11 o'clock.

Mr. CHAMBERS called up his special committee bill, (reported this morning,) H. R. No. 326, for an act to apportion Senators and Representatives for the State of Indiana, and it was passed to the second reading.

div.head: THE CALENDAR.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB moved for the consideration of bills of the House on the second reading, and it was so ordered.
Mr. Buskirk's Agricultural College bill, No.6, coming up -
On motion by Mr. Buskirk, it was postponed, and made the special order for 2 o'clock P. M.
Mr. Branham's bill, No. 95, to enable railroads to alter their lines in certain cases, coming up with an amendment of the Committee on Corporations, subjecting them to the payment of damages, etc. -

Mr. HIGGINS proposed to amend the amendment by a provision, that railroads proposing to change their route for one mile or more shall, previous to such change, pay the owners'of real estate from which said track is proposed to be taken all damages that may be sustained thereby.
Mr. BRANHAM would acquiese in the amendment if he understood it.
Mr. HAMRICK thought the bill, as it is, secured the rights contemplated. If it did not he would vote for the amendment.
Mr. HIGGINS said his people would be largely injured if their road (though not the best in the State) were taken away from them. They had paid dearly for it.
Mr. LOCKHART said, the substance of Mr. Higgins' amendment was embraced in the Committee's amendent.
Mr. HIGGINS said his amendment required damages to be paid previous to the re-moval.
Mr. BUSKIRK proposed to attach Mr. Higgins' amendment by the words "and provided."

It was agreed to, and then Mr. Higgins' amendment was adopted; and the amendment as amended was adopted. The bill failed on the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 50, nays 35 for want of a constitutional majority of 51.
Mr. James' bill [H. R. No. 41] legalizing sales by guardians under orders defective in not prescribing notice, was passsed the final reading - yeas 64, nays 16.
Mr. Humphrey's bill [H. R. 87] amending section one of the Practice Act of June 18, 1852, approved February 2, 1855, coming up -
Mr. HUMPHREYS explained that it simply fixes the fees of the printer.
Mr. DUNHAM suggested that it left out the provision of law which requires an advertisement in the newspaper nearest the land to be sold.
The bill was rejected - yeas 28, nays 51.
Mr. McVey's bill [H. R. No. 117] to amend sections 39, 42, 45 and 54 of the act for the incorporation of insurance companies, etc., approved June 17, 1852, coming up -
Mr. HIGGINS submitted the following:
Resolved, That the State Librarian be authorized to purchase for the use of members of this House $200 worth of postage stamps.
Mr. HIGGINS, Mr. CHURCH and others explained that this appropriation would make no difference as to the expense to the State. It would be charged to the stationery account of members.
Mr. SHUEY said the resolution did not reach the case.
Mr. SHOAFF, of Allen, proposed to substitute the following:

That the State Librarian be authorized to draw on the State Treasurer for the further sum of $100, to be paid out of the appropriation for legislative expenses to purchase stamps to the furnished to members on stationery account.
After some conversation across the House, the substitute was adopted, modified so as to read "$ 200" instead of "$100."
On motion by Mr. BUSKIRK, it was ordered that Mr. Olleman's Railroad Forfeiture bill No. 123, be taken from the table and placed on the files of the House.
On motion by Mr. MILROY, the House then took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM moved to suspend the order of business, and take up his bill, No. 312, for abolishing the Board Sinking Fund Commissioners, and transferring their business to the Auditor and Treasurer of State; and defining their duties in relation thereto, etc.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill was taken up, and read through by the Clerk.

Mr. BRANHAM proposed to amend the bill, by adding two sections, the object of which is to call in the school money now in the County Treasuries not loaned out, and that the same be invested in the securities of the State; and on his motion the further consideration of the bill was postponed and made the special order for to-morrow morning 10 o'clock.
Mr. COFFROTH moved to take up, out of order, his bill, No. 254, to amend the charter of the town of Huntington.
Mr. GOODMAN moved to amend by including his school teachers' bill. No. 237.
The amendment and the motion, as amended, were agreed to.

Mr. Coftroth's bill, No. 254, to amend the 5th, 14th and 17th sections of the charter of the town of Huntington, having been read through by the Clerkif was passed to the final reading in the House - yeas 78, nays 0.

Mr. Goodman's bill [H. R. No 237] to amend section 35 of the common school act of March 6, 1865, [by which school meetings may direct that a greater or less number of branches may be taught,] coming up -

Mr. BURWELL was anxious for this provision to be incorporated into the act of last session at the time of its consideration, but his amendments were rejected. His mind was now changed, and he would support the provision of law which requires physiology and history as qualifications for a common school teacher.

Mr. GROVES. As the law stands, a large number of districts have to go without teachers. There were some teachers claiming to be competent in physiology, who were wholly without qualification for keeping school in other respects.
Mr. WOODS. The bill did not strike out physiology or any other ology as a teachers' qualification, but merely gave a discretion to the districts as to teachers.
Mr. COLLINS would prefer to suspend the law for a time than to make this modification.
Mr. BUSKIRK demanded the previous question, and under its operation the bill was passed the final reading yeas 67, nays 27.

On motion of Mr. FERRIS, the bill [S. 66,] organizing a new Common Pleas of the counties of Decatur and Rush, was taken up, and on his motion it was referred to a select committee, with an amendment including the county of Decatur.

div.head: INDIANA AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE.
div.p: Mr. BUSKIRK demanded the special order; viz: the Agricultural College bill, H. R. No. 6, the pending question being on the substitute amendment of Mr. Speaker Pettit.

Mr. PETTIT( Mr. Henricks in the Chair) desired to amend his substitute for the bill submitted yesterday afternoon, by inserting at the close of the second condition of location to this effect: "But such location shall not be finally fixed by such commissioners until such grant, donation or agreement shall have been first made complete by conveyance or delivery, nor shall any agreement in regard to buildings or property be accepted by them without adequate freehold security."

This proposition was to make this location better than we can do it, - which requires local knowledge and comparison. A Commission could determine a location upon actual examination and comparison, much better than we. We ought to be well satisfied that everything donated should be well warranted before the State is bound in the case. If the particular locations, whose Mends were clamoring for patronage here, could not stand the scrutiny which this amendment proposes, they did not deserve the location. His proposition was a continuation of the legislation taken last winter on this subject.

Mr. BOYD opposed the amendment. He saw here a proposition for a commission, to act as guardian of the General Assembly, which would not result more creditably than the Commission to locate the Northern Prison, He repeated that we had not time for the circumlocation involved in this amendment

Mr. BRANHAM demanded the previous question, and under its force - (after a call of the House suggested by Mr. PETTIT) - the yeas and nays on the adoption of the amendment - substitute being demanded by Mr. BUSKIRK and Mr. PETTIT, and the same being ordered and taken, resulted - yeas 46, nays 49 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Atkinson, Bonner, Branham, Burnes, Caldwell, Church, Collins, Cowgill, Cox, Davidson,Ferris, Foulke, Glazebrook, Gleason, Gregory of Montgomery, Gregory of Warren, Henricks, Hershey, Higgins, Hoover, James, Kilgore, Lane, Lockbart, Major, Miller, Milroy, Montgomery, McVey, Newcomb, Prather, Reese, Rice, Riford, Sabin, Shoaff of Allen, Shuey, Sim, Stewart, Stivers, Sullivan of P. &c V., Trusler, Upson, Woods, Zeigler, Mr. Speaker - 46.

NAYS - Messrs. Abbett, Bird, Boyd, Brown, Burton, Burwell, Buskirk, Chambers, Coffroth, Croan, Crook, Dunham, Goodman, Gregg, Griffith, Groves, Hargrove, Harrison, Hogate, Howard, Humphreys, Hunt, Laselle, Lee, Lemon, Litson, Lopp, O'Brien, Ollerman, Osborn, Patterson, Perigo, Pinney, Rhoads, Richards, Richardson, Roach, Shoaff of Jay, Spencer, Stenger, Stringer, Stuckey, Sullivan of Scott, Thatcher, Veach, Weikel, Welch, White, Wright - 49:
So the substitute was rejected.
Mr. BUSKIRK moved an order to refer the bill to a select committee of five.
Mr. SIM moved to instruct said committee to amend the bill by striking out "Bloomington," and inserting "Richmond" in lieu.
Mr. GRIFFITH moved to strike out "Bloomington" and insert "Battleground."
The vote by yeas and nays on the latter proposition resulted - yeas 44, nays 49.
The yeas and nays on Mr. Sim's motion resulted - yeas 35, nays 59.
The bill was then referred to a special committee of five.
On motion by Mr. RICE, Mr. Woodruff and Mr. Meredith had indefinite leave of absence on account of illness.

div.head: MUTUAL INSURANCE.
div.p: On motion by Mr. OLLEMAN, the House took up bills on the third reading.
Mr. McVey's bill [H. R. No. 117] to amend sections 39, 42, 45 and 54, of the act for the incorporation of Insurance Companies, &c., approved June 17, 1852, coming up -

Mr. NEWCOMB explained that it was a law to amend the present statutes in regard to Mutual Insurance Companies. It requires $50,000 in premium notes before the Company can go into operation. This will give solvency to every new Company. Secondly: The party may pay cash instead of a premium note. Thirdly. Instead of distribution every five years, the earnings shall be added to the stock.
Mr. BUSKIRK said, the provision doing away with premium notes would command his vote; so that when a man takes a policy he knows precisely what he has to pay.
Mr. CHURCH. He would vote for a bill declaring that every traveling insurance agent shall get out of the State. He thought he saw an opportunity here for deception of the people. He gave examples.
Mr. COFFROTH said the purpose of this bill was to provide against the defects of the existing lawto place these companies on a more permanent basis.

Mr. SHUEY. If there was wild-cat anywhere, it was to be found in this bill. Every stock Holder holds his own premium note, and a $50,000 pile of these notes contributes all the security which these mutual insurance companies propose to losers. Then by a provision of the bill, these mutual insurance companies may, by a trick of legerdemain, change their character into that of stock companies, without making the deposits, as required by existing law.
Mr. BURWELL denounced Mutual Insurance Companies as systematized swindling. This bill might by amending the system give it character. He was opposed to giving the system any shadow of respectability.

Mr. WOODS thought this bill was worse than the old law. It gave to the Mutual Insurance agents power to twist themselves into a position where they can play the double part of mutual and stock companies: and gave their agents power to run away with all the money the poor man has, instead of taking only five per cent.

Mr. NEWCOMB defended the provisions of the bill. It would make the people ten times more secure than they now are against these companies. The provision that the stockholder may pay money instead of his premium note, was a common feature in all insurance companies. Then it provides that the cash accumulations shall be added to its capital till it amounts to $100,000, to pay losses. The 2d section would secure the State against the organization of a single bogus company.
Mr. GROVES demanded the previous question, and, under its force, the bill was passed the House - yeas 59, nays 28.
On motion of Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, it was ordered that when the House adjourns it shall be till 7 o'clock to-night.
On motion by Mr. SPENCER, the House took a recess till 7 o'clock, P. M.

div.head: NIGHT SESSION.
div.p: Mr. SIM, (by unanimous consent) submitted an order, which was adopted, tendering the use of this Hall next Thursday evening to Major-General Gross for a public address on current political questions.
Mr. THACHER (by consent) submitted the following:
Resolved, That there be added to the Special Committee on Senate bill No. 66, [dividing a Common Pleas district] the members from Henry, Hancock and Madison counties.
It was adopted.
Subsequently the SPEAKER nominated Messrs. Thacher, White, Chambers and Croan.

On motion by Mr. COWGILL, his deputies legalizing bill, H. R. No. 299 [legalizing the acts of deputies of county officers in the United States service] was taken up out of order, and passed the final reading in the House - yeas 74, nays 4.

div.head: NEGRO SCHOOL BILL.
div.p: Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, now called up the special order, viz: the consideration of his negro school bill [H. R. No. 208] the question being on adopting the substitute as reported by the special committee, entitled as follows: "An act to amend an act entitled an act to provide a general system of common schools, etc., approved May 6, .1865, and also an act supplemental thereto, providing for the separate enumeration of colored children, prescribing tbe duties of Township Trustees in relation thereto, and declaring an emergency.

Mr. BUSKIRK proposed to amend the amendment by striking out the words "expend their proportion of the school fund." and insert this: "shall appropriate for the support and benefit of such schools all the tax derived from colored persons." This would make our legislation conform to the act of Congress for the regulation of colored schools in the District of Columbia.
Mr. B. said he did not think we should go further than Congress on this question.

Mr. NEWCOMB read the first section of article 8 of the Constitution closing with these words: "where tuition shall be without charge and equally open to all." The Constitution made no distinction; and there was another provision of the Constitution prohibiting special class legislation, and that all taxes shall be uniform. What did this mean"all?" "all men?" all taxes? Was it not classifying to provide that the blacks shall recover no more school money than they pay into the fund? We were, perhaps insensibly, applying the policy of the slavery legislation of tha South to the free blacks of the North.
Mr. BUSKIRK. Upon what principle then, docs the gentleman shut the doors of the schools against colored children?
Mr. NEWCOMB, We satisfy the constitutional provision, if we provide common schools for them?

Mr. HARRISON reasoned from the language of the 23d section of the bill of rights, that the word "all," here in the constitution, referred to "all citizens." The gentleman's construction was not in accordance with the bill of rights. Negroes are not citizens.
Mr. NEWCOMB replied.
Mr. BOYD expected to vote against this bill. He placed his justification upon the constitutional provision excluding negroes from the State.
Ms. LASSELLE would oppose it for the rea-ason that the bill was proposing to tax negroes, whilst they remained without representation.
Mr. NEWCOMB. We tax them now. [Laughter.]
Mr. BROWN. They have representation plenty here. [Laughter.]
Mr. LASSELLE. One violation of the Constiution can not justify another. It was a breach of the great American doctrine: No taxation without represention.

Mr. DUNHAM said there had been an effort in many places in this country to set apart the school funds of the German population, and to the Catholics. He thought the white man - the Catholic - just as good as the negro, if he behaved himself. Why now do for the negro what the General Assembly had over and over again denied to white people? Gentlemen should carry this thing out squarely, as well to whites as blacks. He should not so much object to the equality of the negro, as to establishing an aristocracy of negro blood - or wool. [Laughter.]

Take the bull by the horns - put them into the schools at once - and let's have, the issue here, and take it to the people. The constitutional argument of the gentleman from Marion admitted of no half way house. But, sir, you could no more educate the negro beside the white race, than you could raise the blade and the ear of corn to its full maturity under tht shade of the oak. There must be perfect equality in all respects, and consequent amalgamation, or the weaker race will decline and dip out. The man that does not know this had read history to very little purpose.
When he had concluded -
Mr. BUSKIRK demanded the previous question on his amendment, and under its operation his amendment was adopted - yeas 45, nays 35.
And then the amendment, by the committee, as thus amended, was rejected, without a division.
Mr. RHOADS moved to lay the subject on the table; but understanding that the question recurred on the original bill, he withdrew the motion.
Mr. OLLEMAN moved to indefinitely postpone the whole subject, and thereupon demanded the previous question.
The House refused to second the demand.
Pending the question to postpone indefinitely -
Mr. BURTON took the floor in a generally prepared speech agcinst the bill, which will be printed hereafter. He spoke, by indulgence of the House, beyond the 25 minutes limitation.

Mr. WOODS next took the floor, in support of the bill, pleading the considerations of humanity and the Christian Institution. He also delivered a prepared speech, which will appear in the APPENDIX to these Reports.
Mr. WEIGHT interrogated Mr. Burton in questions implicating that gentleman and his party in charging the cause of tbe war upon the people of the Northern States.
Mr. RHOADS submitted the following, which was read for information:

Resolved, by the House of Representatives of the General Assembly of the State of Indiana, the Senate conrurring therein, that this General Assembly shall adjourn without day on Monday, December 18,1865.
Mr. HOOVER and others objected.
Mr. DUNHAM replied to Mr. Woods.
Mr. HAMRICK moved to postpone the further consideration of the bill, and that it be made the special order for to-morrow night.
The motion was agreed to.
And then (at 10.16 P. M.) the House adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem. called the Senate to order at 9 o'clock A. M.
On motion by Mr. GIFFORD, the reading of yesterday's journal was dispensed with.
Mr. WARD, from the Committee on Corporations, returned Mr. Allison's city gas works bill, S. No. 296, with amendments.
Mr. TERRY, from the Committee on Swamp Lands, returned Mr. Wrightfs bill, S. No. 308, for the relief of persons who have made entry of lands where the State cannot make a good title; with amendments.
He also returned Mr. McClurg's bill, S. No. 310, amending sections 1 and 2 of the wet lands and drainage Act of March 7, 1863; recommending its passage.
These bills were passed to the third reading.

div.head: NEGRO TESTIMONY.
div.p: The Senate proceeded to the consideration of the special order for this hour, viz.: Mr. Ward's bill, S. No. 219, defining who shall be competent witnesses in any court of this State - [all persons, without distinction of color] - the question beeng on concurring in the committee amendment, inserting appropriately the words "or blood."

Mr. McCLURG was not in favor of this bill, but did not think it made one particle of difference, as to the force the bill will have, whether this amendment be adopted or not. The idea, in proposing the amendment was simply to make the bill more positive in its terms - merely explanatory. He expected to make opposition to the bill upon principle. It seemed like fighting a man of straw to oppose this amendment.

Mr. VAN BUSKIRK could see a good deal in the amendment. It amounted to something more than redundancy. He could find persons in Indianapolis said to have negro blood in them, as white as he; and such persons would be excluded from testifying on account of color unless this amendment was made.
Mr. OYLER thought it was part of our duty to make the laws plain - so that they could not be misunderstood.
The Committee amendment was then agreed to by yeas 26, nays 21 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Allison, Beeson, Bennett, Bonham, Brown of Hamilton, Cason, Chapman, Cullen, Culver, Davis, Dykes, Hyatt, McClurg, Milligan, Niles, Noyes, Oyler, Reagan, Richmond, Terry, Thompson, Van Buskirk, Ward, Woods, Wright, and Mr President - 26
NAYS - Messrs Barker, Bowman, Bradley, Brown of Warren, Carson, Cobb, Corbin, Douglas, Downey, English, Finch, Fuller, Gifford, Hord, Jinkens, Marshall, Mason, Moore, Newlin, Stages, and Vawter - 21
Mr. DOWNEY then offered his amendment, proposed last Tuesday forenoon.
Mr. ALLISON moved to amend the amendment by adding this; "except such persons as shall have borne arms in the late war for the suppression of the rebellion."
This amendment was agreed to.
The amendment as amended was rejected by yeas 48, nays 0.
On motion of Mr. OYLER, the vote adopting the amendment to the amendment was reconsidered by yeas 26, nays 22.
Mr, YAWTER raised the point of order that this proceeding was unparliamentary.
The PRESIDENT decided the point of order not well taken.
Mr. ALLISON withdrew his amendment.
On motion of Mr. OYLER the vote rejecting the amendment [Mr. Downey's] was reconsidered by yeas 24, nays 22.
The question recurring on the adoption of the amendment -

Mr. DOWNEY said the object of his amendment was to do that which a provision in the 13th Art. of the State Constitution requires the General Assembly to do. Instead of holding out inducements by offering privileges to this class, he held it to be a duty required of this General Assembly so to legislate as to discourage them from coming into the State. He was in favor of allowing those colored persons who were in the State at the time of the adoption of the Constitution, the right of testifying in Courts of Justice; but he was opposed to extending that right to any colored persons who were not here at that time, or who may hereafter come here in violation of the 13th Art. of the Constitution of the State.
The amendment [Mr. Downey's] was agreed to by yeas 26,nays 22 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs Allison, Beeson, Bennett, Bonham, Brown, of Hamilton, Cason, Chapman, Cullen, Culver, Davis, Downey, Dykes, Hyatt, Milligan, Niles, Noyes, Oyler, Reagan, Richmond, Terry, Thompson, Van Buskirk, Ward, Woods, Wright, and Mr. President - 26.

NAYS - Messrs. Barber, Bowman, Brad'ey, Brown of Wells, Carson, Cobb, Corbin, Doug'as, English, Finch, Fuller, Gifford, Hanna, Hord, Ji kens, Marshall, McCurg, Mason, Moore, Newlin, Staggs, and Vawter - 22.
Pending the call -

Mr. CASON, in explanation of his vote, said: I am opposed to the amendment of the Senator of Ohio, excepting and not allowing negroes to testify, who have come into the State in violation of the thirteenth article of the Constitution. I do not mean that I would violate any provision of the Constitution, but I understand that the amendment to the Constitution of the United States has been adopted by a requisite number of States, and it is now the fundamental law of the land. The amendment of the Constitution makes negroes citizens of the State, and annuls and abrogates all laws, whether constitutional or legislative, restoring the liberty of this class of people, Under its provisions we have no more right to prohibit a negro from coming into this State than we have an Englishman. The question then arises whether we will obey the Constitution of the United States, abrogating the thirteenth article of our State Constitution, or obey a provision already null and void. But it is evident that we can pass no law without the amendment of the Senator of Ohio, and as it is better to have the law with this amendment than no law, for the reason that it goes a part of the way toward doing justice to this race of people, I shall vote for the amendment. I vote "aye."
Mr. CULLEN said: My speech has been made by the Senator from Boone [Mr. Cason.] With that understanding I vote "aye."
Mr. OYLER said: Endorsing the remarks of the Senator from Boone, and for the same reasons, I vote "aye."

Mr. THOMPSON in casting this vote did not wish to be considered as being in favor of any Government or Constitution that abridges in any way the natural rights of man; but under the circumstances, as we must have, some
protection, not only for ourselves, but for the colored people, he should vote "aye."

Mr. VAN BUSKIRK said the amendment did not cover all he wanted, but he had confidence in the onward march of civilization, and believed this thirteenth article would be wiped out at no distant day; and when that is done this very law itself will give to all negro persons in Indiana the right to testify. He voted " aye."

Mr. DUNNING (Mr. Beeson in the Chair) was in favor of the thirteenth article at the time of its adoption, and had been for it ever since, until he had become satisfied that the effects of this great rebellion which we have just suppressed would abolish slavery, and now, although he expected to follow the dictates of his judgment as to all questions which may come lip in the future, he was disposed to take it in broken doses. He was not prepared to go the length of other gentlemen. He voted "aye."
The result of the vote was then announced as above recorded.
So the amendment was adopted.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT - yeas 26, nays 23 - the bill was considered as engrossed, and read the third time.
It was passed the Senate by yeas 28, nays 21 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Allison, Beeson, Bennett, Bonham, Brown of Hamilton, Cason, Chapman, Cullen, Culver, Davis, Downey, Dykes, Hyatt, Milligan, Niles, Noyes, Oyler,Reagan, Richmond, Terry, Thompson, Van Buskirk, Ward, Woods, Wright, and Mr. President - 28.
NAYS - Messrs. Barker, Bonham, Bradley, Brown of Wells, Carson, Cobb, Corbin, Douglas, English, Finch, Fuller, Hanna, Hord, Jinkens, Marshall, McClurg, Mason, Moore, Newlin, Staggs, ard Vawter - 21.

div.head: THE STATE DEBT.
div.p: The Senate proceeded to the consideration of the state debt bills H. R. No. 285, and S. No. 279 - the special order for this hour - the question being on concurrence'in the majority report.

Mr. CULLEN, although he considered the provision, in effect, already in the bill S. No. 279, in order to make it more plain, moved to amend by inserting in line eight, section eight, after the word "State" the following: "As fast as moneys from year to year accumulate in said State debt sinking fund, which said fund is irrevokably pledged for the redemption of said stocks and bonds."
Mr. OYLER being entitled to the floor gave way for -

Mr. BROWN, of Wells, who, without any intention to cut off debate, moved the previous question. He was convinced further debate would do no good; this legislative session as drawing rapidly to a close; we have a great deal of unfinished business before us, and if we consume the time in useless discussion, important legislation will be defeated.
The demand for the previous question was seconded by the Senate, and under its operation -
The amendment [Mr. Cullen's] was agreed to.

The question recurring on concurrence in the majority report of the special committee, recommending that the bill H. R. 285 be amended by striking out from the enacting clause and inserting the bill S. No. 279 in lieu.
It was read, and the committee substitute by yeas 31, nays 16.
The Committee amendment striking out the title of the bill, H. R. 285, and inserting in lieu the title of the bill S. 279, was agreed to.
Mr. BENNETT moved that the bill be engrossed and read the third time now.
Mr. CHAPMAN raised a point of order that the bill had not yet been read the second time.
After a conversational debate -
The PRESIDENT pro tem. decided the point of order not well taken.
The motion was agreed to and -
The bill was read the third time.
It was passed the Senate, by yeas 30, nays 18, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Allison, Bennett, Bonham, Bowman Bradley, Brown of Wells, Carson, Cobb, Corbin, Cullen, Davis, Douglas, Downey, Dykes, Finch, Gifford, Hanna, Hyatt, Jinkens, McClurg, Mason, Milligan, Newlin Niles, Oyler, Richmond, Staggs, Van Buskirk, Vawter and Mr, President - 30.
NAYS - Messrs Barker, Beeson, Brown of Hamilton, Cason, Chapman, Culver, English, Fuller, Hord, Marshall, Moore, Noyes, Reagan, Terry, Thompson, Ward, Woods, and Wright - 13.
Pending the roll call -

Mr. ALLISON, in explanation of his vote, said he regarded a defeat of this bill as much as to say that we shall not have a bill for the adjustment of the State debt during the session. There are many features in the bill he did not like, but rather than go home without a bill for the purpose indicated he would vote "aye."
Mr. CHAPMAN said he voted against this bill because he believed we had no right to repeal the law creating a State Agency in New York until all these bonds are fully paid.

Mr. HORD said he had desired to give reasons at length for opposing this measure - he had numerous facts and figures to present against its passage - but he could not recite them now in the limited time In which he supposed the Senate would require him to present the reasons for his vote. He deprecated the course pursued by the friends of the bill in thrusting it upon the Senate under the operations of the previous, question; and trusted it would be defeated in the House.

Mr. VAWTER, in explanation of his vote, said: I came here determined to vote for some adjustment of our State debt. I believe the debt will be due on the 19th of January, 1866; I feel that the honor of Indiana requires an adjustment. I voted in favor of the Branham bill on the motion to strike it out from the enacting clause. I regret that that bill could not have'been amended and passed. The Bradley bill, now on its passage, was this morning, on my suggestion, amended so as to create a fund that will in eight years discharge the debt. The bill under consideration having been amended in this particular is no longer liable to the objection made by me last evening. The bill, now on its passage, is not entirely satisfactory to me. But it is the only bill before the Senate providing for the payment of the State debt. A vote against that bill will place me in .the position of repudiating any and all arrangement for the paying of the debt. I do not want to occupy that position, and I shall vote, under all the circumstances, for the bill, as not the best but as the only plan for the payment of the debt. I love Indiana too well to stand opposed to the payment of her debts. If I believed that the debt was not due I should vote against any bill whatever. But entertaing the other
view, and earnestly desiring so see this incumbus removed, I vote "aye."
The result was then announced as above recorded, and so the bill passed the Senate.
Mr. FINCH introduced a bill [S. No. 313] for An Act to amend sections 1 and 4 of An Act to reorganize the Evansville Insurance Company, which was passed to the second reading.
And then the Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The Senate proceeded to the consideration of the special order for this hour, viz: Mr. Dunning's bill, S. No. 40, establishing an Agricultural College at Bloomington. A division of the question on Mr. Culver's amendment having been demanded, the first question will be on striking out.
Mr. DUNNING withdrew his demand for a division of the question.

Mr. BEESON moved to amend the amendment by striking out all after the word "Act" and insert this: "locate the Agricultural College in the county of Wayne by the citizens depositing $100,000 in the Citizens Bank of Richmond, subject to the order of the Board of Trustees of said college for the use of said college."

Mr. B. gave reasons for the location as proposed in the amendment, which he considered paramount. The great principles involved in this question have been ably discussed, and the simple point remaining is, where shall the College be located? The citizens of Wayne county would feel proud to have it located there; and having no college buildings sufficient, they have proposed to give $100,000 in money. He referred to the enterprise and energy of her people; the richness of her soil; the extent of her manufactories; and declared that "old Wayne" stood pre-eminent in many things, and second to no county in the State in every thing which pertains to the happiness and enioyment of man.
Mr. VAWTER made an ineffectual motion - yeas 22, nays 25 - to lay the amendment to the amendment on the table.

Mr. VAN BUSKIRK moved to recommit the bill to the Special Committee, with instructions to report a substitute leaving the Trustees of the Indiana Agricultural College free to locate the same where a donation may be given not less than $100,000, &c.
On motion of Mr. CULLEN the motion to refer was laid on the table by yeas 34, nays 15.

Mr. BENNETT moved that the Senate resolve itself into a Committee of the Whole for the consideration of this subject. His object was to obtain the sense of the Senate by a kind of ballot in the Committee - no record of which would appear on the Senate journals.
Mr. DUNNING (Mr. Williams in the Chair) opposed this motion. He desired a square vote on each locality.
Mr. WRIGHT regarded this whole college matter as a consummate humbug, and believed that it would prove a leach upon the treasury.
Mr. CASON offered the following:

Resolved, That the Senate proceed to vote viva voce, for a place to locate the Agricultural College, and the place receiving a majority of the votes shall be the place where said college shall be located, and the bill now under considorat on shall be recommitted with instructions to amend the bill by inserting the same.

Mr. NILES opposed the resolution, regarding it as preposterous to limit the vote of Senators, in finally fixing the location of this college, to one of the three points named in the several propositions before the Senate.

He spoke decidedly in favor of Indianapolis as the most central and accessible point, and argued to the Senate that to locate such an institution at a point inconvenient of access, would defeat the chief object of the grant and tend to make the institution like our other colleges, a mere schooe for boys, and it would be as unwise as to have located the French Polytechnic Institute elsewhere than at Paris.

Mr. COBB declared in favor of locating the college at Bloomington. Let this endowment go hand in hand with the Institution already placed thereby a donation from Congress many years ago. He regarded that as the only situation that would give satisfaction to the people of the State at large.
The resolution was adopted.
Mr. THOMPSON submitted the following, that Marion county might be considered as before the Senate:

Resolved, That if the citizens of Marion county, or any part of them, shall, within the next five days, or before the 17th inst, shaIl offer, for the use and location of the Agricultural College, two hundred acres of land situated within three miles of Indianapolis, and suitable for the location of said College, and shall offer one hundred thousand dollars to be expended in the erection of suitable buildings, on said location, then the said Agricultural College should be located on said laud, and in Marion County, Indiana.
The Senate then proceeded to choose a location by ballot.
The first ballot resulted: for Bloomington, 18; for Tippecanoe Battle Ground, 12; for Indianapolis, 11; for Richmond, 5; for Winnemac, 1; for blank, 1.
The second ballot resulted: for Bloomington, 20; for Tippecanoe Battle Ground, 15; for Indianapolis, 8; for Richmond, 2; for Huntington, 1; for blank, 1.
The third ballot resulted: For Bloomington, 18; for Tippecanoe Battle Ground, 17; for Indianapolis, 12; blank, 1.
The fourth ballot resulted: For Bloomington, 22; for Tippecanoe Battle Ground, 15; for Indianopolis, 11; blank, 1.
The fifth ballot resulted: For Bloomington, 24; for Tippecanoe Battle Ground, 20; for Indianapolis, 3; blank, 1.
Pending the ballot, Mr. THOMPSON again urged upon Senators the superior advantages of Indianapolis as a location for this College.
The sixth ballot resulted: For Bloomington, 29; for Tippecanoe Battle Ground, 18; for Indianapolis, 1; blank, 1, as follows:
Those who voted for Bloomington were:

Messrs Barker, Bonham, Bowman, Bradley, Browm of Hamilton, Brown of Wells, Cobb, Corbin, Cullen, Douglas, Downey, Dykes, English, Finch, Fuller, Gifford, Hord, Hyatt, Jinkens, Marshall, Mason, Moore, Richmond, Staffers, VanBuskirk, Vawter, Ward, Williams, and Mr. President - 29.
Those who voted for Tippecanoe Battle Ground were:
Messrs. Allison, Beeson, Bennett, Carson, Cason, Chapman, Culver, Davis, Hanna, McClurg, Milligan, Newlin, Noyes, Oyler, Reagan, Terry, and Woods - 17.
Mr. Niles and Mr. Thompson voted for Indianapolis.
Mr. Wright voted for "blank."

Bloomington having received a majority of votes cast the bill was recommitted in accordance
with the provisions of the resolution authorizing the balloting.

div.head: ENUMERATION OF INHABITANTS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. CULLEN, his Census bill S. No. 298, (described on page 147 of the BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS) was read the third time.
Mr. WRIGHT contended that the assessor could take the census without adding to his labors: it would be much more simple, and could oe done at no cost.
Mr. BENNETT said that was the plan as it stood for years under the old law, and it did not work well.
The bill was passed by yeas 39, nays 2.
On motion by Mr. FINCH, his Evansville Insurance Company Charter bill S. No. 318, (introduced this morning) was read by title only, and referred to the Committee on Corporations.
On motion by Mr. BONHAM the bill, H. R. No. 270, concerning the per diem of members and officers of the General Assembly, was read the second time.
On motion of Mr. BENNETT the Senate amendment relating to paying clerks and doorkeepers a salary in future, was stricken from the bill by yeas 32, nays 10.
On motion by Mr. VAWTER the bill was amended so that its provisions shall apply only to this session.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT the bill was further amended by striking therefrom "$4" wherever it occurs,"and inserting "5" in lieu.
The bill passed to the third reading.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The roll-call having determined a quorum -
On motion of Mr. HOOVER, the reading ot the journal of yesterday was dispensed with.

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: Mr. HOGATE presented memorials for claims by the proprietors of the Daily Journal, Daily Herald, Daily Telegraph, etc., for newspapers furnished, which were referred to the Committee on Claims.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. TRUSSLER, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned Mr. McVey's bill, H. R. No. 216, to amend the 5th section of the act touching the marriage relation, and empowering married women whose husbands are of unsound mind to convey real estate without joining the husband, with the opinion that legislation thereon unnecessary, and recommending its indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. KILGORE, from the Committee on Elections, returned Mr. Higgins' election bill, H. R. No. 37, with an amendment striking out "Sentinel" and inserting "HERALD" in lieu; and so recommending its passage.
Mr. NEWCOMB, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned the felony bill, S. No. 93, recommending its passage.
Mr. BROWN, from the same Committee, returned Mr. Kilgore's Innkeepers' bill, H. R. No. 292, recommending its passage.

Mr. BURNS, from a majority of the Common Rights and Privileges, upon the memorial of citizens of Hendricks county, for repeal of the Black laws, recommended that the prayar of the memorial be granted.

Mr. HOWARD, from the Committee on the State Prison South, reported on the financial condition of said prison, recommending an appropriation of $20,000 to pay the indebtedness thereof, including $2,000 for contingencies.
Mr. STRINGER moved to strike out $2,000 for contingents recommended in the report.
The SPEAKER held that it was not competent for the House to amend the text of the report.

Mr. HOWARD moved to refer the report to the Committee on Ways and Means, with instructions to incorporate the amount recommended in the Specific bill. He moved to strike out "$20,000" and insert $18,000 in lieu, as the recommendation to the Committee on Ways and Means.
