Mr. HAMRICK caused the statement of the Auditor to be read, confirming this fact.
The amendment was agreed to - affirmative 42, negative 31.
Mr. NEWCOMB proposed to amend further by adding balance of assessment against the State of Indiana for the National Cemetery at Gettysburg, $3,469 83.It was agreed to.
Mr. WOODS stated that the claim of Mr. Hart, of Lake county, and proposed to insert his claim, ($50,) and that the same be paid out of the Swamp Land Fund.
It was adopted.Mr. RHOADS proposed to amend by adding an allowance of $350 to the Superintendent of public Instruction.
It was laid on the table.
And then the several amendments reported by the Committee on Ways and Means, were adopted.
The bill as amended was then read through by the Clerk.
On motion of Mr. BRANHAM, the bill was referred again to the Committee on Ways and Means with instructions to examine whether there is not a repetition.

On motion of Mr. HARRISON, (the rules being suspended for the purpose,) Mr. Newcomb's
general Life Insurance bill H. R. No. 255, was ordered to be taken up. But the bill could not be found.

On motion by Mr. GREGORY of Warren, (under a dispensation,) the House took up the Senate's non-concurrence in two of the House amendments to the bill S. No. 198, repealing the soldier's relief law of 1865, etc.
The first amendment in which the Senate refuses to concur - the seven per cent, of the tax of 1865 to be paid into the State Treasury - was adhered to by the House.
The second amendment - Mr. Pettit's - in which the Senate refuses to concur, coming up -
On motion by Mr. GRIFFITH, the House receded -
The Senate amendment to the bill H. R. No. 79, to amend the Supervisor's act, was taken up and concurred in.
On motion by Mr. WOODS, it was ordered, that when the House adjourns, it shall be till seven o'clock to-night.
The bill S. No. 142, defining the crime of drunkenness, and prescribing a penalty therefor, coming up on the second reading, it was read and ordered to the third reading.
The bill S. No. 185, for the incorporation of Hotel Companies, ceming up, it was read the second time.
On motion by Mr. MILROY, it was indefinitely postponed.
The bill S. No. 175 to authorize the formation of companies for the apprehension of horse-thieves, &c., coming up -
It was passed to the third reading.
The bill S. No. 227, for the relief of Isaac T. Armstrong, late Treasurer of Clinton county, coming up -
Mr. BOYD moved its indefinite postponement. There were a number of claims of the same character.

Mr. CALDWELL stated the case. The county safe was broken open, and the State money stolen - about $1,500. Mr. A. had spent time and money after the thief - had caught him - lodged him in jail - but could not recover the money.
Mr. BROWN did not think the State could recover this lost money of Mr. Armstrong, whether this bill passed or not.
Mr. SHUEY alleged that a sense of justice demanded the passage of this bill. He stated the case.
Mr. BOYD withdrew the motion to save time.
Mr. RICHARDS proposed to amend by adding a section relieving Alfred Williams, Treasurer of Brown county, from the loss of $1,279 81 of the State's money, from the treasury of Brown county.
Mr. BROWN made the point, that it was not germain to the bill.
The SPEAKER (Mr. Henricks in the Chair) sustained the point of order.
The bill passed to the third reading.
Mr. BRANHAM, from the Committee on the Ways and Means, now returned the specific appropriation bill, without further amendment, and on his motion, it was put upon its passage.
The bill passed the House - yeas 72, nays 3 with an amendment of title, including 1859, 1861, 1863, 1865 and 1866.
On motion of Mr. THACHER, his life insurance bill, H. R. No. 255, was put again on its passage, the vote resulting - yeas 58, nays 18 so the bill passed the House of Representatives.
Mr. GREGORY, of Warren, moved a suspension to take up Mr. Stringer's swinging gate bill; but.
On motion of Mr. Coffroth, the House took up bills of the House on the third reading.
Mr. Gregory of Warren's bill, H. R. No. 248, restricting the amount of the capital stock of Manufacturing and Mining Companies, coming up -
On motion of Mr. COFFROTH, it was passed over.
Mr. Coffroth's foreign insurance bill, H. R, No. 207, [It revives the law of 1852 declared void for lack of title,] coming up, it was read through by the Clerk.

Mr. COFFROTH stated that it required foreign Insurance Companies to make semi-annual sworn statements of their condition, and to have $100,000 on deposit to secure policies. It is for the protection of the people of the State against foreign Insurance Companies.
The bill passed the House - yeas 60, nays 12.

Mr. Stringer's swinging gate bill, H. R. 286, [on application of twelve petitioners, it allows the County Commissioners to authorize any man to hang a swinging gate on any county or township roads, with restrictions.]
Mr. GLAZEBROOK opposed the bill by practical considerations of public convenience.
Mr. BRANHAM. The Yankees have a gate now that you can open and shut without getting out of your buggy.
Mr. GLAZEBROOK. Yes; but we don't want to introduce Yankeeisms into the Legislature of the State of Indiana.
The Clerk reporting to the Chair that there was no quorum voting on this bill -
The House took a recess till 7 o'clock.

div.head: NIGHT SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER announced the order of the consideration of bills from the Senate on the second reading.
The bill, S. No. 231, to legalize the acts of the Common Pleas Court in the month of November, 1865, in Clinton county, was ordered to the third reading.
The bill, S. No. 233, enabling adopted children to inherit, was passed to the third reading.
The bill, S. No. 265, fixing the terms of the Wells Circuit Court, was passed to the third reading.
The bill, S. No. 206, to amend the act confirming the sale of railroads, and to construct branch roads, was read, considered and passed to the third reading.

div.head: THE SINKING FUND.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BRANHAM, (the rules being suspended for the purpose,) it was ordered that the Omnibus Committee report back the bill from the Senate, No. 314, (authorizing the investment of the sinking fund in stocks of the State,) for the action of the House; whereupon
Mr. HENDRICKS, from the select Omnibus Committee, reported said bill [S. No. 314,] to the House without amendment.
The bill was read by the Clerk - the question being, Shall the bill pass?
Mr. DUNHAM, believing that the proceedings in connection with this bill were violative of the Constitution, he could not vote for it, and would not.
Mr.HENRICKS moved a call of the House, which proceeded, till the Clerk reported 71 members present and answering.

Mr. DUNHAM had resolved in his mind not to vote for any bill from that Commissioners. He desired the reporters to take it down, that he would regard his vote for any of those bills, under the circumstances, as violation of the Constitution, and of his oath to support it.
Mr. BROWN desired the gentleman from Jefferson to inform the House whether, these Commissioners are compelled to turn the bonds in their hands over to the State at the same price they paid for them?
Mr. BUSKIRK could not vote for the bill in its present shape. The new bonds may be issued, not for the amount paid for them, but for the price of the bonds purchased.
Mr. BRANHAM said he was assured by the chairman of the Finance Committee of the Senate, that the bill is right. It comes with the endorsement of members of the Senate of both political parties.

Mr. COFFROTH. The bill directs that the officers of the sinking fund shall invest the sinking fund in the 2 1/2 per cent, and 5 per cent, bonds of the State, or in bonds of the United States. He was informed that at least a portion of the officers of the sinking fund have been making money out of themone of them even boasting that he had made $10,000 in that way. They had thus proved themselves unworthy of public confidence. Now, suppose these Commissioners to have already bought these bonds of the State at a discount. Then pass this bill, and they would make a nice thing of it. They can buy up such as they control at a high figure with their trust funds! He would move to strike out that portion of the bill by which they have permission to invest these trust funds in State stocks, and leave them no discretion but to invest them in bonds or stocks of the United States. He then proceeded, in reply to Mr. Dunham, to defend the constitutionality of the proceedings of yesterday, which created the Omnibus Committee, and made the reference of Senate bills to that committee.

Mr. DUNHAM said, there had been $600,000 of this fund placed the hands of favorites instead of loaning them as the law required. Here was an outrage; but it was nothing, to Ms mind, in comparison with a disregard by the Legislature of constitutional requirements. It was laying down all the rights of the people at the feet of a temporary majority. He argued the constitutional question till the ten minutes expired. As he understood this bill he approved it, but regarding the sanctity of the Constitution above every other consideration, he could not vote for it.

Mr. NEWCOMB knowing the conscientiousness of the gentleman from Floyd, he replied to the objections of Mr. Coffroth. The desire of the Legislature had been indicated at the last session, that these trust funds should be invested in State stocks. By the law the Commissioners were required to keep enough on hand to meet the back bonds as they become due. They had for this purpose a large amount on hand at the beginning of the last session.
Mr. COFFROTH. How much of those bank bonds were now on hand?

Mr. NEWCOMB. Some $20,000. He was not himself entirely satisfied with tne proceedings of the Commissioners. They deposited $160,000 in a banking house in New York, which had failed; and that left a suspended debt, which would probably yet be paid. This bill proposed that they shall not hold these trust funds any longer: but shall invest them where they can not be speculated upon - can not be sold - Can not be stolen. We had but just one day more to legislate in. Should we pass this bill, or leave this fund for another year in the hands of these Commissioners?
Mr. MILLER. Thinking we have had enough debate on this question, and more than enough of lecture on the Constitution, and morality and conscience, he demanded the previous question.
Mr. DUNHAM. He understood that the house in New Nork was ready at any time to make settlement for the new York deposit of this fund.

Mr. MILLER insisted on his demand, and there was a second, and the main question was ordered, viz: Shall the bill be recommitted to the select committee, with instructions to report a provision, that non-assignable bonds be made for the actual amount surrendered or paid for them?
The House refused to recommit - yeas 31, nays 48.
Mr. COFFROTH moved to recommit to the Committee on Ways and Means, with instructions to strike out all that relates to the purchase of State stocks.
Mr. MILLER demanded the previous question on the passage of the bill, and there was a second.
Mr. BROWN demanded the yeas and nays, and the House ordered the main question - yeas 51, nays 27.
The biil then passed the House of Representatives - yeas 53, nays 26 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Atkinson, Bonner, Boyd, Branham, Barnes, Caldwell, Church, Cook, Cowgill, Cox, Crook, Davidson, Ferris, Foulke, Gleason, Gregory of Montgomery Gregory of Warren, Griffith, Hamrick, Henricks, Hershey, Higgins, Hoover, Lane, Litson, Lockhart, Major, Meredith, Miller, Montgomery, McVey, Newcomb, Olleman, Prather, Reese, Rhoads, Rice, Riford, Sabin, Shuey, Sim, Stewart, Stringer, Sullivan, of P. and V., Trusler, Upson, Welch, Woodruff, Wright, Woods, Zeigler, and Mr. Speaker - 53.

NAYS - Messrs. Abbett, Bird, Brown, Buskirk, Coffroth, Dunham, Glazebrook, Gregg, Harrison, Humphreys, Hunt, Lemon, Lopp, Milroy,Osborn, Patterson, Pinney, Richardson, Roach, Shoaff of Allen, Stuckey, Sullivan of Scott, Thatcher, Weikel,and White - 26.

Mr. LASSELLE, when his name was called, said: The fifth section of the bill provides that the two and a half and five per cent, bonds of the State shall be bought up by the Sinking Fund Commissionorg with this fund, or they shall invest the funds in United States stocks. On the first day of May in every year, the Governor, Auditor and Treasurer shall issue a new bond covering the amount of the fund paid out, the new bond payable to the Sinking Fund, signed by the Governor, Auditor and Treasurer. This conflicts with the sixth article
of the Constitution, which says that no debt shall be contracted on the part of the State except for a specified purpose. This is for no specified purpose.
Mr. NEWCOMB (in seat.) Can't we give one obligation for another?
Mr. LASSELLE. No, sir, it is on these new bonds we are to pay six per cent, instead of five per cent.
So the bill passed the House.
Mr. COFFROTH moved to amend the title, by striking out the words: "for the benefit of the school fund."
Mr. DUNHAM proposed to amend the amendment by inserting this: "for the benefit of the money-shavers."
Mr. COFFROTH accepted the modification.
Mr. HENRICKS moved to lay the amendment on the table.
Mr. COFFROTH demanded the yeas and nays.
The amendment was laid on the table - yeas 56, nays 20.
And then under the pressure of the previous question demanded by Mr. MILLER, the title was adopted without amendment.

div.head: SOLDIERS' HOME.
div.p: Mr. HAMRICK moved for a dispensation to take up Mr. Kilgore's bill H. R. No. 312 amending the general law, so that the association for a Soldier's Home may organize as a corporation, and receive donations in that capacity.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill was taken up.

Mr. Brown proposed to amend by adding this: "Provided, that the provisions of this act shall not go into operation so far as building a Soldiers' Home is concerned, unless Chaplain Lozier has charge of it," &c.
It was rejected.
The bill was then ordered to the engrossment and third reading.
The bill S. No. 34 coming up -
On motion of Mr. COFFROTH, it was laid on the table.
Mr. BUSKIRK moved a dispensation to take up his Agricultural College bill H. R. No. 5, and make it the sgecial order for to-morrow affirmative 38, negative 20 -
No quorum.
Mr. BROWN made an ineffectual motion to adjourn - affirmative 16, negative 44.
The roll call discovered 63 members present.
The House [at 9:25 P. M.] adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tem. called the Senate to order a 9 o'clock: A. M.

On motion by Mr. VAN BUSKIRK, the reading of the journal was dispensed with, except that portion referring to the suspension of the rules last night for the reading of all House bills the first and second time.
Mr. HORD submitted the following:

The undersigned, members of the Senate, respectfully protest against the action of the Republican party of the Senate on Monday the 19th of December, in the absence of all the Democratic members of the body, and while there was no quorum in the Senate to do business, in reconsidering the motion adopting Mr. Baker's resolution, which read as follows, to wit:

Be it Resolved, That the Senate is opposed to taxing white men's property for the benefit of negro children. And the referring of the same to the Committee on Education. And also earnetly protest against against the action of the Republican party on this floor, at the same time, when all the Democratic members were absent, and there was no quorum on this floor, by adopting the following resolution, offered by the Senator from Howard, to wit:
"Resolved, That, in the opinion of the Senate, the children of negroes of this State should be educated as children of Democrats are."

The undersigned are opposed to the sentiment of said resolution, and protest against its adoption by the Republican members of the Senate, under the circumstances which the same was adopted; and request that this protest be spread upon the records.
div.signed: H. Corbin, Tbos. Gifford, James P. Vawter, J. D.Williams, Francis T. Hord, E. G. English, Aug. Bradley A. Stsggs, J. D. Marshall, H. Jinkens, J. A. Bowman, Wm. W. Carson, Thos. B. Cobb, Geo. S. Brown, Of Wells, James Barker, A. C. Downey, A. G. Douglas, L. McClurg, James L. Mason, John B. Moore, G. W. Finch, Bayless W. Hanna, J. W. Newlin, B. S Fuller.

div.p: Mr. THOMPSON presensed a petition from citizens of Indianapolis praying the Senate to reconsider the vote rejecting the bill, H. R, -- authorizing builders to lay liens on property and sell without relation or appraisement; which was laid on the table.

The PRESIDENT pro tem. laid before the Senate a communication from the Doorkeeper, stating that his search for the sofas formerly in the ladies' lobby has been fruitless. After stating that Mr. Brown informed him that they were in their proper places when Mr. B. visited his office, the communication read: From Mr. Stevenson I learn that he has no positive knowledge of the property, but .that he infers from the indecent and unruly character of the soldiery during the war in and about these premises, that it is more than probable that they were removed and made way with by them.
Mr. VAWTER moved that this communication shall not be spread upon the journal.
After remarks by Messrs. Champan, Corbin, Cullen and Williams, the communication was laid on the table.
The motion [Mr. Vawter's] was agreed to by yeas 33, nays 5.
Mr. CULLEN offered the following:

Resolved, That Rev. David Stevenson be requested to publish the inuendo against the soldiers of Indiana, contained in his statement to Dr. Thompson concerning the sofas belonging to the Senate Chamber, upon the fly-leaf of his book entitled The Roll of Honor, as a recommendation of said book to the soldiers.
On motion by Mr. CORBIN, the resolution was laid on the table by yeas 21, nays 20.
Leave of absence was obtained for the Finance Committee to consider the appropriation bills.
The PRESIDENT pro tem., announced the special order for this hour to be the resolution on the hanging of Jeff. Davis.
On motion by Mr. BROWN, of Wells, it was postponed and made the special order for 2 o'clock P. M. to-morrow.
Mr. HYATT, from the Committee on Corporations, reported favorably on the bill, H. R. 263, to prevent conductors from obstructing highways or streets with cars.
Mr. NILES did not believe the public interest would be promoted by requiring the breaking up of railroad trains as proposed in this bill.

Mr. TERRY was sorry to hear objections to this bill coming from the Senator from Laporte. In the rear or the town of Peru, in one of the
counties he represents, is a marsh or morass across which is but one public highway, and at that crossing the trains of the Wabash Valley Railroad and the Peru and Indianapolis Railroad have been in the habit for years of standing - frequently occupying the road for one or two hours at'a time, and sometimes longer than two hours. Farmers wishing to go to market, or men going that way with their families are compelled to stand in the cold for sometimes two hours; and he thought it but a matter of justice and right that this bill should pass. He had not occupied much of the time of the Senate and had asked few or no favors this session, but he now very much desired the passage of the bill.

Mr. NILES would regret to see the railroad interest so embarrassed as is proposed by this bill. A bill could be proposed to meet the case of the Senator with out having the effect to injure other railroads, and for such a measure he would cheerfully vote.

Mr. OYLER claimed to be a friend of railroads, but could not consider how anybody could object to this bill. If an individual obstructs a highway, he is liable under the law; and why should a railroad do the same thing longer than ten minutes at a time, anyhow?
Mr. WRIGHT understood in the case cited by the Senator from Miami, the stopping was made at that point by conductors, because of its convenience to groceries.
Mr. CULLEN could speak of cases similar to those referred to by the Senator from Miami. He hoped the bill would pass.
The bill was read and passed by yeas 36, nays 3.
Mr. BONHAM, from the Committee on Banks, reported favorably on the bill, H. R. 189, amending section 52 of the general banking laws.
On motion of Mr. ALLISON the bill was read and passed the Senate by yeas 37, nays 2.
Mr. WILLIAMS offered a resolution, which was adopted, allowing the Principal Secretary $3 a day for extra services.
On motion by Mr. HORD, the railroad bill, H. R. 123, was made the special order for 2 o'clock this afternoon.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT, the House amendments to the Senate amendments to the bill H. R. 270. for pay of members and officers of the General Assembly were concurred in.
Mr. OYLER, from the Committee on Organization of Courts, reported favorably on the bill, H. R. 253, amending section eight of the Common Pleas Set.
Mr. OYLER stated that this bill simply changed the time for holding courts in his Common Pleas District.
It was read and passed by yeas 35, nays 0.
On motion by Mr. BROWN of Wells, the bill, H. R. 254, amending the city charter of Huntington was read.
Mr. BROWN, of Wells, explained its provisions.
It was passed the Senate by yeas 42, nays 0.
Mr. CULLEN, from the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements, reported favorable on the bill, H. R. 250, for the incorporation of hydraulic companies.
Mr. CULLEN explained the bill.
It was read and passed by yeas 39, nays 4.
On motion by Mr. CORBIN, his bill, No. 288, requiring Clerks, of Circuit and Common Pleas Courts to make general indexes of records in their offices; was read.
It was passed the Senate by yeas 35, nays 6.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT, the House message on his repeal of the Soldiers' Family Relief bill, No. 128, insisting on the 7 per cent. amendment thereto, was taken up.

Mr. B. would be opposed to this amendment, as an original proposition, and would yet get out of it if there was any way to do it. He opposed sending about $100,000 up here in this loose kind of way, to be disposed of in the manner proposed, but rather than lose the bill he would vote for the Senate to recede.
Mr. CULLEN held to his convictions expressed the other day, and hoped the Senate would not recede from its former action.
Mr. OYLER understood the House would insist on this amendment with a great deal of earnestness, and unless we recede there is a probability of the bill being lost.
Mr. CULLEN simply asked for a Committee of Conference, and if they could not agree he would vote to recede rather than that the bill should fail.
Mr. HANNA and Mr. GIFFORD were willing that there shall be such a per cent, levied on that tax as shall enable the Governor to meet his obligations.
The Senate refused to recede from its action by yeas 15. nays 28.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN a Committee of Conference was authorized; which the Chair made to consist of Messrs. Cullen, Corbin and Oyler on the part of the Senate.
Mr. CULLEN, from the Committee on County and Township Business, reported favorably on the bill, H. R. 240, to relieve the county officers for 1865 from penalties of the dog law.
Mr. OYLER hoped the bill,would fail to receive a sufficient number of votes to pass it, as it is similar to a Senate bill to which he had heretofore expressed opposition and which was rejected.
The bill was read and, rejected by yeas 20, nays 20.
Mr. CULLEN, from the same Committee, reported favorably on the bill, H. R. 276, authorizing fee bills for costs incurred in suits before County Commissioners.
The bill was read and passed by yeas 32, nays 3.
He also returned the bill H. R. 234 to repeal An Act in relation to the reports of certain officers, approved June 3,1861; recommending its indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.
On motion by Mr. BRADLEY the Senate refused to recede from its amendments to the bill, H. R. 285,: and a Committee of Conference was appointed, viz: Messrs. Bradley and Cason.
Mr. REAGAN, from the Committee on Corporations, reported favorably on the bill, H.R. 255, supplemental to An Act for the Incorporation of Insurance Companies, approved March 17, 1852.
It was read and, passed by yeas 20, nays 8.

On motion by Mr. THOMPSON and Mr. DOWNEY the bills H. R. 277, 278, 279 and 280 for the establishment of a Criminal Court in the city of Indianapolis, were taken up, and severally read and passed by an average vote of yeas 41, nays 0.

Mr. CARSON, from the Committee on Finance, returned Mr, Gifford's bill, S.No. 317,
legalizing bonds issued by Boards of County Commissioners to pay for drafted men; with amendments.
Mr. BENNETT opposed the passage of this bill. The tax raised by the bill we passed last winter is heavy enough.

Mr. NILES also stood opposed to this bill, as he did to the action of last session on this subject. He could see no propriety in taxing returned soldiers to pay bounties to drafted men who procured substitutes. It is making an extraordinary exception in favor of a few.

Mr. GIFFORD. I desire to say. that I introduced this bill for the purpose of getting legalized $17,000 00 worth of bonds issued by the Board of Commissioners of my county, to drafted men who entered or procured substitutes to enter the military service of the United States, to aid the Government in suppressing the late rebellion. Our County Board acted in good faith, and strictly in accordance with the will of the people on this subject. We are only asking this General Assembly to do for us as much as it has done for other counties, in legalizing the action of Boards of Commissioners, in issuing bonds to persons enlisting into the military service, not only to aid the Government in putting down the rebellion, but to prevent a draft.
This bill only legalizes a class of bonds which we supposed was legalized by an act of this General Assembly, approved March 3, 1865, on this subject.

Mr. CULLEN hoped the bill would not pass. It seems unjust to pass a law legalizing bonds issued to keep drafted men out of the service, when the pockets of soldiers who have served faithfully during the war, have to be taxed to pay them off.
Mr. OYLER opposed class legislation. This question has been settled by the Judiciary, and he opposed the passage of laws to change the decisions of our Supreme Courts.
Mr. COBB regarded it as just to the County Commissioners, they having made the appropriation because it was insisted upon by the people; though admitting it was done in violation of law.
Without taking action on the bill -
On motion of Mr. VAWTER, it was -

Resolved, That this Senate regards as unjust, unmerited and improper the imputations made against the soldiers of Indiana by David Stevenson, as stated in the report of the Doorkeeper to this body; and that it regards our soldiers as alike honorable and brave.
The Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. BENNET, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported favorably on the bill, H. R. 68, authorizing County Boards to receive subscriptions and make donations for the erection of monuments to soidiers.
On his motion the rules were suspended yeas 36, nays 3.
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Richmond in the Chair) announced the consideration of Mr. Dunning's Agricultural College bill S. No. 40.

Mr. DUNNING said the bill had been read three times, but he had amendments, embracing the proposition made by Monroe county; and concerning Trustees for the College, etc., which he hoped would be agreed to by unanimous consent.
The amendments were agreed to by consent, and the bill was passed to the Senate by yeas 29, nays 18, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Barker, Bonbam, Bowman, Bradley, Brown of Hamilton, Brewn of Wells, Cobb, Corbin, Cullen, Downey, English, Finch, Fuller, Gifford, Hord, Hyatt, Jinkens, Marshall, Mason, Moore, Oyler, Richmond, Staggs, Terry, Thompson, Vawter, Ward, Williams, and Mr. President - 29.
YEAS - Messrs. Allison, Beeson, Bennett, Carson, Chapman, Cullen, Culver, Davis, Dykes, Hanna, McClurg, Milligan, Newlin, Niles, Noyes, Reagan, Van Buskirk, Woods, and Wright - 18.

Mr. WRIGHT, in explanation of his vote, said he did not like the details of the bill, and he thought the institution was going to be an expensive one to the State, he could not vote for it. He voted "no."
The roll call being finished -

Mr. THOMPSON said he opposed the location of this college at Bloomington because he believed his constituents were opposed to it; and because he thought it was not a central location. The question of location, however, came before the Senate and was fairly won by the accomplished President of the Senate; and he voted "aye" on this bill out of pure compliment to that gentlemen, for whom he entertained the highest regard.The vote was then amended. So the bill passed.

The bill, H. R. 123, declaring forfeited the right of way of certain railroad companies to branch roads, no part of which have been completed, and upon which no work has been done for ten years, etc,; was read.
Mr. OYLER explained its provisions and favored its passage.

Mr. COBB had no idea if the cases to which this bill applied were known to the House it would have passed that body. That body would not have knowingly done the injustice contemplated by this bill to an already overburdened and almost broken down corporation. The bill proposes to take the property of one company, amounting to about $100,000, and put it into the hands of another; and at this very time the company owning the property is negotiating for its sale. He based his opposition to the bill upon the simple question of justice.

Mr. CULLEN sympathized with the condition of the road referred to by the Senator from Lawrence, [Mr. Cobb,] but he regarded this as a case of railroad companies vs. the State of Indiana, and as between the two, he always unhesitatingly took sides with the people. His people were overridden by a monopoly, which this bill would remove, and he earnestly advocated its passage.
Mr. BENNETT demanded the previous question; and under its operation -
The bill was passed by yeas 28, nays 15.

Mr. BRADLEY, from the Committee of Conference on the disagreements betweeii the two Houses on the State Debt bill, H. R. 285; reported ra substitute therefor, embracing a blending of the provisions of the bills H. R. 285 and S. 279.

Mr. B. said the main provisions of the bill are: It provides for the abolishment of the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners on the 26th of July, 1867, and that their duties shall devolve upon the Auditor and Treasurer of State. The funds in the hands of the State Treasurer belonging to the State Debt Sinking
Fund, as well as the funds in the hands of the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, shall be applied to the extinguishment of the 2 1/2 per cent, bonds first. The 10 per cent, levied for a State Dobt Sinking Fund, as it comes in, is to be applied upon the 5 per cent, bonds. But the five cent tax levied and dedicated to pay oft the War loan bonds, when that comes in the officers shall notify the holders of those bonds that the money is ready, and if they do not accept it. it is to be applied toward the liquidation of the registered debt. And the State Agency in the city of New York is to be abolished as soon as the registered debt is paid.
Mr. HORD raised a point of order as to whether amendments can be offered here to a bill that is in the other branch of the General Assembly.
Mr. WILLIAMS questioned whether a committee of conference have the right to strike out from the enacting clause and insert other matter.
After remarks on these points of order by Messrs. Bennett, Niles, Carson, Vawter -
The PRESIDENT pro tem., with doubts as to its correctness, decided in favor of the report, to accommodate Senators and because of the great interests at stake.
Mr. HORD appealed from the decision of the chair.
On motion of Mr. BENNETT the appeal was laid on the table by yeas 38, nays 67.
Mr. BENNETT demanded the previous question.
The demand was seconded by yeas 34, nays 12.
The report of the Conference Committee was then concurred in by yeas 38, nays 0.
Pending the vote -

Mr. HORD, when his name was called, said he considered this measure of vast importance, and he desired to discuss it, and give reasons why it should not be adopted. He was gagged and chocked off by the previous question, on the passage of the original bill; and thus measures of the highest importance and interest to the people are pushed through here without consideration and without time for reflection. As this amendment had but an hour ago been reported to the Senate, and as we have not been able to understand its provisions, he opposed the previous question being sprung by the Senate upon measures of such moment. He merely proposed now to express his unqualified condemnation of this process of legislation upon questions of such great public interest, and, as in this case, of as high importance as any that has been brought before the General Assembly since the first adjustment of the public debt. He voted " no."
The vote was then announced.

A message was received from the Governor announcing his approval of the bill, H. R. 119, to create a State Normal School, and his appointment, in pursuance of the said section, thereof, subject to the approval of the Senate, the following Trustees of said school: - Barnabas C. Hobbs, of Parke county, William C. Hanna, of Laporte county, Isaac Kinley, of Wayne county, and John Ingle, jr., of Vanderburg county.
On motion by Mr. NILES the Senate concurred in these appointments.

Mr. OYLER, from the Committee of Conference on the disagreements between the two Houses on the soldiers' relief bill, S. 198, reported an amendment striking out the word "never" and inserting in lieu the word "five."
The report was concurred in.
Mr. ALLISON presented a report from the Committee of Conference on the Morgan Raid bill, S. No. 15, (similar to the one presented in the House yesterday.)
On motion by Mr. BENNETT it was laid on the table.
On motion by Mr. GIFFORD, the vote was now ordered on the passage of his bill, S. No. 317, to legalize bonds issued by County Boards to drafted men; pending at the time of the recess for dinner.
The bill was rejected by yeas 19, nays 22.
On motion by Mr. WRIGHT, it was ordered that when the Senate adjourns it will stand adjourned till 7 o'clock.
Mr. WOOD, from the Committee on Corporations, returned the bill, H. R. 207, regulating foreign Insurance Companies doing business in this State, with an amendment adding an emergency clause.
The bill was read and passed by yeas 34, nays 7.
Mr. CHAPMAN, from the Committee on Finance, returned the General Appropriation bill, H. R. 329, with amendments.
It was read and informally passed over till the night session.
On motion by Mr. WILLIAMS, the bill, H. R. 95, to enable railroads to alter their lines in certain cases, was read.
Mr. WILLIAMS said it only proposes to authorize alterations where there are dangerous curves, etc.
The bill was passed the Senate by yeas 41, nays 0.
Mr. WRIGHT, from the Committee on Roads, returned the bill, H. R. 164, to provide for working highways contiguous to county lines, recommending that it lie on the table.
The report was rejected.

Mr. STAGGS. This bill, as I understand, is a bill that is mainly designed, when roads run on county lines, to bring each company under obligations to do their part in keeping it up, and I hope the Senate will pass it.
Mr. MILLIGAN cited a case in his immediate neighborhood where this bill would work a great hardship. He hoped the bill would be rejected.
Mr. STAGGS. I will say to the Senator from Montgomery [Mr. Milligan] that his is an entirely local matter, but the bill will apply to any road on the line between any counties in the State.
The bill having been read -

Mr. STAGGS said: In connection with the remarks I have made, by the hearing of the bill read Senators can discover that it is a fair one. It is upon the fair principle that each county shall bear its portion of the burden. That is about the sum and substance of it.
The bill finally passed by yeas 35, nays 6.
The Senate took a recess till 7 o'clock.

div.head: NIGHT SESSION.
div.p: Mr. COBB, from a majority of the Judiciary Committee, reported; favorably on the bill, H. R. 211, to enable common carriers to dispose of unclaimed freight or baggage.

The bill was read, and failed to pass for
want of a constitutional majoritysubsequently (after 11 o'clock,) on motion by Mr. NILES, another vote was taken; and -
The bill was passed by yeas 30, nays 9.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT, the House amendments to "Mr. Oyler's bill, S. No. 281, increasing the salary of State Librarian, were concurred in.

Mr. CASON, from the Judiciary Committee, returned Mr. Corbin's concurrent resolution concerning the Terre Haute & Richmond Railroad (see page 73 of the BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS) with amendments requiring the Committee to report the first day of next session, etc.
The resolution as amended was adopted by yeas 39, nays 3.
Mr. TERRY, from the Committee on Roads, reported favorably on the bill, H. R. 206, for the erection and repair of bridges, etc.
Mr. DOWNEY hoped the bill would not pass. The law as it now stands is preferable to this proposed amendment.
Mr. NILES could see no danger in the provisions of this bill, though he had not particularly examined its details.
Mr. WRIGHT explained the bill. It affected two counties which he represents; and he showed the great advantages it would give to that locality.
Mr. CULLEN was satisfied the bill ought not to pass.
The bill was rejected by yeas 19, nays 21.

On motion by Mr. CHAPMAN the bill H. R. 299. to legalize the acts of officers and their deputies while their principals were performing military service in the army of the United States, was read the third time.
It was passed by yeas 32, nays 9.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN, the bill, H. R. 237, amending section 35 of the Common School Law approved March 6, 1865, was taken from the table and read.
Mr. BENNETT regarded the bill as lowering the standard of teachers, and hoped it would not pass.
Mr. VAN BUSKIRK hoped the bill would not pass.
Mr. CULLEN thought this an eminently proper bill. It leaves the matter in the hands of the people interested, and that is right. On his motion the words "and her" were inserted after the word "him."
Mr. ALLISON stated that the bill as it now stands would exclude females, and if there was no other reason he would oppose the bill for that.
Mr. OYLER also opposed the bill.

Mr. VAN BUSKIRK moved to recommit the bill with instructions to so amend that the law of last session requiring the additional qualifications for teachers of a knowledge of Physiology and History of the United States shall be inoperative till next September.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN this motion to recommit wasr laid on the table by yeas 28, nays 14.
On his further motion he had leave to withdraw his amendment after the vote adopting it was reconsidered.
The bill was passed by yeas 30, nays 13.
Mr. CHAPMAN from the Committee on Finance, returned the specific appropriation bill H. R. 328; with amendments.
The bill was read the third time.
Mr. VAWTER moved to amend by appropriating $1,278 80 State money stolen from Alfred William S. While, Treasurer of Brown county.
After remarks by Messrs Dunning, Cullen, Chapman, Bennett, Oyler and Beeson -
The amendment was rejected.
Mr. DUNNING (Mr. Richmond in the Chair) moved to amend by allowing the pages three dollars a day.
Objection being made -
Mr. DUNNING modified his amendment so as to read two dollars and a half a day.
The amendment was adopted by consent.
The bill was finally passed by yeas 37, nays 6.

On motion of Mr. CHAPMAN, the Senate proceeded to the consideration of the general appropriation bill, read a third time just before the recess for supper, with the understanding that amendments could be offered at the night session.
Mr. CORBIN moved to amend by repealing sections 61 to 68 of the old bill of last session, so as to wipe out this Military Auditing Committee.
Mr. BENNETT believed such a Committee was necessary then, (as a general thing they are useless,) but as the emergency has passed, he should vote for the amendment.
The amendment was adopted.
Mr. COBB moved to amend by striking out from the bill all that relates to the appropriation for the Northern State Prison.
This amendment was resisted by Messrs. Chapman and Niles.
Mr. CASON moved to amend the amendment by striking out the appropriation for the Southern Prison.
Mr. ALLISON favored both amendments.
Mr. CULLEN demanded the previohs question, and under its operation -
Mr. BENNETT demanded a division of the question.
The Senate refused to strike out the appropriation for Ihe Northern Prison, by yeas 19, nays 24. The amendment to the amendment was also rejected, by yeas 19, nays 23.
The bill was finally passed by yeas 29, nays 13.
On motion by Mr. BONHAM the Houas amendments to the bill, S. 205, and Mr. Herd's felony bill, S. 93, were concurred in.

On motion by Mr. CARSON the Swinging Bridge bill, H. R. 320, was read the first time - its second reading was dispensed with by yeas 37, nays 0 - and under a father suspension - yeas 38, nays 0 - it was read the third time.
It was finally passed by yeas 39, nays 0.
On motion by Mr. CHAPMAN the bill, H. R. 187, authorizing the Sinking Fund Commissioner to make certain settlements, &c., was taken up. It having heretofore been read the third time -
It was rejected by yeas 18, nays 17.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN the vote was reconsidered.
The bill was read again and passed by yeas 28, nays 18.
The bill, H. R. 186, authorizing payment of the semi-annual instalment of interest on the public debt, coming up -
On motion by Mr. COBB it was laid on the table.

A message was received announcing that the House of Representatives refued to concur in the Senate amendment to the Specific Appropriation bill, H. R. 268, giving extra pay to the principal Clerk and to the pages; and also adding new amendments to the bill.
On motion by Mr. CULLEN the Senate receded from its amendments, and concurred in the House amendments.
On motion by Mr. THOMPSON, the mechanic's lien bill H. R. 135, was taken up. It having heretofore been read the third time -
It failed to pass for want of a constitutional majority, by yeas 20. nays 15.
On motion by Mr. BEKNETT another vote was had on the passage of the bill.
It was then passed by yeas 29, nays 9.
A message from the House announced further amendments to the general appropriation bill H. R. 329.
Mr. BENNETT moved that the Senate concur therein, with an amendment authorizing the Military Auditing Committee to continue their business till the first of April.
On motion by Mr. CHAPMAN this amendment was laid on the table.
The Senate then concurred in the House amendments by yeas 30, nays 4.
On motion by Mr. BENNETT, a resolution of thanks to the State Librarian was adopted.
The House amendments to Mr. Cason's bill, S. No. 270, increasing fees of County Auditors and Commissioners were agreed to.
And then (at 12:55 o'clock) the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The roll-call having determined a quorum 81 members present -
On the motion of Mr. THACHER, the reading of the journal of yesterday was dispensed with.
Mr. GROVES said he was reported in the newspapers this morning as not voting in the affirmative on the passage of the Sinking Fund Bill. He was present and did vote in the affirmative.

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: Mr. SULLIVAN, of Scott, presented a Temperance Memorial, which was referred without reading.

The SPEAKER laid before the House the memorial of T. L. Hubbard and others, loyal citizens of the State of Indiana, protesting against the pardon of Jefferson Davis and other rebel leaders by the President of the United States.
It was referred to the Committee on Federal Relations.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM, from the Committee on Ways and Means, returned the Commissioners' State Debt Sinking Fund bill [H. R. 288] with the engrossed amendment of the Senate thereto, recommending that the House do not concur in the Senate amendments.

Mr. BUSKIRK, from the Special Omnibus Committee, returned most of the several bills from the Senate referred to them under the Special Rule adopted last Monday, distinguishing from amongst them and recommending and suggesting to the House that bills of the following numbers are of general importance, and in the opinion of the Committee demand the prompt and earnest attention of the House, viz: 293, 254, 315, 143, 300, 273, 210, 284, 275, 281, 289, 249, 270, 241, 269, 215, 216. He stated, also, that within the next half hour, the Committee would be able to report on all the balance of the bills from the Senate which was referred to them.

div.head: PRISON SYSTEM.
div.p: Mr. STRINGER submitted the following:

be it Resolved by the House of representatives Of the State of Indiana (the Senate concurring therein), that the Governor be authorized to appoint a committee consisting of three competent business men, whose duty it shall be to visit the State Prisons North and South, and thoroughly investigate the books and accounts of the same; to compare the workings of the present prison system since its inauguration with the workings of the late system during the past ten years, making such investigations, and presenting such facts and figures as shall enable tbe nexi General Assembly of the State to legislate intelligently in relation to prison affairs; and that in be their duty to report at the next regular session of the General Assembly of the State of Indiana.
Mr. NEWCOMB moved that the concurrent resolution be postponed, and made the special order for Thursday morning at 11 o'clock.
Mr. STRINGER hoped that would not be done. [VOICES: "It can be just as well passed then."]
The motion was agreed to.

div.head: SINKING FUND.
div.p: Mr. COWGILL submitted the following:

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, (the Senate concurrng) That the Attorney General for the State be instructed to inquire what amount of profits have been derived to the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners or any member thereof, in consequence of any mis-application or unauthorized use of any moneys belonging to said Sinking Fund: and if he finds that such profits have enured to the benefit of said Sinking Fund Commissioners, or any member thereof, to bring suit in the name of the State for the same.
On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, it was postponed and made the special order for to-morrow 11 1/2 o'clock.

div.head: THOMAS F. HOWELL.
div.p: Mr. FOULKE submitted a preamble and resolution, reciting that Thomas F. Howell was commissioned as a recruiting officer, and recruited nineteen men who were accepted into the service, for which he has received no compensation; and resolving that $114 be allowed to the said Howell for such service, etc.

Mr. FOULKE had presented a report of this case and it had been referred to the Committee on Claims. He had seen the Adjutant General and this claim would have been paid, but the money set apart for that purpose had been exhausted.
Mr. BUSKIRK suggested that it could be submitted as an amendment to the specific bill.
Mr. FOULKE then withdrew the resolution.
Mr. BUSKIRK moved lor a dispensation to take up his Agricultural School bill H. R. No. and make it the special order for 10 1/2 o'clock.

Mr. MILLER thought it would be for the advantage of the Senate and the Agricultural College itself not to locate the institution this session. He moved to lay the motion on the table, but withdrew it for -
Mr. NEWCOMB, who, though opposed to the bill, moved to amend by making the special order at 11 o'clock A. M.
Mr. SIM stated that Wayne county had not yet been heard on the consideration of this subject.

Mr. BOYD said: There was an understanding that when, by a majority, we should agree upon a location, that we would act together for the advancement of the best interests of the Agricultural College. Now, if we did not set this college in operation this session, we could not convene in time to do it, and the grant would be forfeited.
Mr. BRANHAM demanded the regular order of business - the hour of 10 o'clock having arrived.

Mr. BUSKIRK contended that, since the previous question had been demanded, and the original motion was to suspend the order of business, the demand for the order could not take precedence of his motion.
The SPEAKER held, that, under the rule, whatever motion is pending, it gives way for the regular order at 10 o'clock.

Mr. BUSKIRK appealed from the decision of the Chair thus: "The Chair having decided that a motion made by Mr. Buskirk to suspend the order of business to take up House bill No. 6, is superseded by the call for the regular order. From this decision we respectfully appeal to the judgment of the House. Signed, S. H. Buskirk, Jason B. Brown." He argued the point of order, coming to this conclusion, that if this decision was to be adhered to, it would confine us to the order of bills in the calendar, whether they are of public importance or not. He complained of the ruling against him, and said that upon a bill of such public importance as this we ought to be entitled to a vote.
Mr. LASSELLE sustained the decision of the Chair, by reference to general parliamentary law and the 27th rule of the House of Representatives.
The Clerk was directed to read the Senate's amendments - the Bradley bill - and the same having been read -
The House refused to concur.
The Senate's disagrement of the House amendments to the Habeas Corpus bill [S. No. 196.] coming up -
On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, the House receded.
Mr. GRIFFITH moved a dispensation to take up his Northern Prison bill, H. R. No. 282, and put it upon its passage.
Mr. HIGGINS moved that the motion be laid on the table, but immediately withdrew it.
Mr. Griffith's motion was lost - affirmative 30, negative 41.
Mr. BUSKIRK said his was not an ordinary resolution, but a motion to suspend the order of business.
Mr. LASSELLE. Then his authority did apply.

The SPEAKER felt it was of greater importance to decide this case now than at any other period of the session; especially since the gentleman has just reported some 70 or 80 bills, of which a large number are distinguished as bills of public importance, if the Chair consents to overstep the rules, and allow a matter, not of supreme importance, to get in the way of public business, it would be doing a public wrong. He submitted to the House that this question was decided at the last session. [He read the 53d rule.] Under this rule, till the hour of 10 o'clock, these things can be done viz:
Introdnction of bills.
Reports from Committees.
Resolutions, joint resolutions and bills. The Chair has steadily held that motions were but unwritten resolutions. If the Chair is correct in this, the gentleman's motion simply proposed a resolution of the House that the rules shall be suspended for a particular object. But when the hour of 10 o'clock arrived, nothing was left in order but for the House to proceed to the regular order of business, under the 54th Rule, which he read. The Chair rehearsed and defended its former rulings in similar cases, and justified the same at some length; and he submitted his especial justification in the pendency of bills to adjust the public debt, to provide for the public revenue and for the purposes of education,which ought not to lose their places for the consideration of bills of subordinate importance.

Mr. HENRICKS moved for a dispensation to take up the consideration of the bill [S. No. 293] to prpvicie for the periodical-enumeration of the white male inhabitants of this State over 21 years of age, and prescribing penalty.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill was read through by the Clerk. [It provides for enumerations for the years 1866 and 1871.]The bill was passed the House - yeas 82, nays 0.

On motion by Mr. COWGILL, (under a dispensation of the rules,) the House took up the consideration of the official bond bill [S. No, 289] to provide for the acknowledgment and execution of official bonds, and declaring the effect and obligation of such bonds as between the obligators and the State.
It was passed the final reading - yeas 76, nays 2.
On motion by Mr. BROWN, the House took up the Senate's adherence to its disagreement to the House amendment to the bill No. 198.
On motion by Mr. BROWN, it was ordered that the Speaker appoint a Committee of Conference to consist of three members. The Speaker subsequently nominated Messrs. Newcomb, Brown and Henricks.

On motion of Mr. BURNES, the Witness bill S. No. 241, amending the third section of the Witness act and repealing all inconsistentant acts [to correct a mistake] was taken, up and passed the final reading in the House - yeas 73, nays 6.

On motion of Mr. MILLER, the House took up the Senate's adherence to their amendments to Mr. Branham's State Debt Sinking Fund bill H. R. No. 285; and it was ordered that the Speaker appoint conferees.
The SPEAKER subsequently nominated Messrs. Branham, Brown and Henricks.
Mr. BUSKIRK desired the chair to say at what hour it would be in order for him to make his motion.
The SPEAKER. In the time of the call for orders, and the time for motions and resolutions.
Mr. BOYD stated the reasons why he should be obliged to vote against the decision of the chair.
The Speaker replied, and put the question: Shall the opinion of the Chair stand as the judgment of the House?
It was decided in the affirmative - yeas 53, nays 35.

div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM moved to take up the consideration of the Senate amendments to his committee bill H. R. 288, to provide a state debt sinking fund, etc., with the recommendation of the Committee on Ways and Means, that the House rejoice to concur in the amendments from the Senate.

On motion by Mr. NEWCOMB, the bill S. No. 156 to give the grand jury jurisdiction of misdemeanors, and the bill S. No. 300 to give the Court jurisdiction - [amending the 14th section of the act, and amending the grand juror's oath] were taken up -
The first bill S. No. 156 having been read -
Mr. COLLINS was opposed to the bill, because it would increase the fines. It was a suspicious circumstance, that lawyers were in favor of it.
Mr. RICE said, it was to do away with immunity for crimes. Four-fifths of the small offenses - in the State went "unwhipt of justice."
The bill passed the House - yeas 67, nays 13.
The bill S. No. 300, amending the 5th section of the Circuit Court act, being readIt was passed the House - yeas 71, nays 8.
On motion by Mr. COFFROTH, the incurable insane bill [S. No. 201] to provide for the care of such persons at the State's Asylum, was taken up.

On his further motion, (the Constitutional restriction being dispensed with for the purpose,) the bill was read the second time by title. [It appropriates $36,000 for the erection of such department of the Asylum.]
It was then read the third time and passed the House - yeas 73, nays 2.
On motion by Mr. GROVES, the House took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The roll-call having determined a quorum -

div.head: CRIMINAL COURTS.
div.p: Mr. NEWCOMB asked and obtained unanimous consent for the purpose, and on his motion the House took up the Senate amendments to his series of bills, Nos. 277, 278, 279 and 280, for criminal and civil circuit courts, viz: Amending the bill No. 177, by inserting appropriately these words: "Jurisdiction of complaints in cases of misdemeanor, except in those cases where the fine does not exceed three dollars."
Some difficulty occurring as to the application of the amendment to the text of the bill, it was passed over.
[The amendments were subsequently concurred in.]
The Senate amendments to the bills H. R. Nos. 278 and 280 were agreed to.

div.head: EMBEZZLEMENT.
div.p: The embezzlement bill, S. No. 93, coming up -
On motion by Mr. KILGORE, (there being a dispensation for the purpose,) the bill was read the second time by title, and put upon its final passage.

Mr. KILGORE proposed to amend by way of substitute, which was read. He stated that the substitute embraces several classes of officers and employees not included in the Senate bill. [The penalty not less than $100, nor more than $500, and imprisonment not less than two nor more than twenty years.
It was agreed to.

The bill was then passed the final reading in the House - yeas 84, nays 1 - with an amendment of title by Mr. KILGORE, viz: "An act defining the crime of embezzlement, and prescribing punishment therefor."

div.head: APPEALS.
div.p: The bill [S. No. 216] to repeal sections 43 and 44 of the act prescribing who may make a will, [to abolish the right of appeal from the Common Pleas to the Circuit Courtin probate cases - making the appeal directly to the Supreme Court] coming up -
It was passed the House - yeas 76, nays 8.

div.head: STATE DEBT SINKING FUND.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM from the Committee of Conference on the disagreeing vote, between the two Houses, as to Senate amendments to the House Committees bill, No. 285, to provide a State debt sinking fund, etc., reported an amendment of the same by way of substitute.

Mr. BRANHAM. This measure embodies both bills - that reported from the joint committee, and that from the Senate: and he believed that it meets the views of both parties to a great extent. We found that to come to any result, we have to yield something. The war loan is provided for in this bill by setting apart five per cent, of the twenty-five cents levy, and they will all be redeemed by the first of May, 1867, if the holders of the securities shall present them for payment. This bill provides that the two and a-half per cent, stocks of the funded debt shall be taken up first, and the five per cent, and the unpresented war bonds afterwards. It provides that a tax of ten cents out of the 25 cents shall be a State debt sinking fund, to pay the principal. It also provides that the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners shall be abolished the 26th of January, 1867; and also that the office of State Agent in New York shall be abolished as soon as the registered debt shall be paid. The whole matter being well understood by the House, in order to save time, he would move the previous question.

Mr. COFFROTH objected strenously to the demand for the previous question. Let the bill be made the special order for to-night at 7 o'clock. He was averse to taking a measure' of this importance upon trust of any single member, however worthy of consideration he may be.

Mr. BRANHAM stated further that there was no provision for the issuance of new bonds. Members could not be better informed of the matter of the bill without printing; he therefore adhered to the demand for the previous question.
Mr. BURWELL and Mr. COFFROTH hoped the House would not second the demand.
Mr. BRANHAM adhered to his demand; and there was a second - affirmative 56, negative 23.
Mr. BURWELL and Mr. BROWN demanded the yeas and nays on ordering the main question, and it was decided in the affirmative yeas 59, nays 26.
The yeas and nays were demanded and ordered on the main question, viz: Shall the bill pass?
Mr. BURWELL asked to be excused from voting, simply because he could not understand the proposition.
Mr. HENRICKS made the point, that a motion to be excused from voting was not in order after the main question has been ordered.
The SPEAKER stated that, though it was not in his own opinion correct, yet under the precedent set by the House at the last session, he would now rule the motion out of order.
Mr. COFFROTH then moved that the House adjourn, and demanded the yeas and nays, and there was a second to the motion. [Ten members can second a motion to adjourn.]
The House refused to adjourn - yeas 9, nays 79.

Mr. COFFROTH stated that his opposition was not factious, nor was such opposition contemplated, so far as he understood the feeling of the minority. What he wanted was, simply the beggarly privilege of looking into the bill to see what it is.
Mr. SHUEY saw that this filibustering would be continued if permitted by the majority, and it was the duty of the House to act if the public welfare demands the passage of this bill.
Mr. BRANHAM. If gentlemen wish to make inquiry into the provisions of the bill. He hoped that discussion would be permitted to that extent, notwithstanding the stress of the previous question.
After further conversation - resulting in the understanding that a quorum shall not be broken on this bill
On motion by Mr. BRANHAM, the subject was postponed and made the special order for to-night at 7 o'clock.

div.head: MARRIED WOMEN.
div.p: On motion of Mr. MILROY, the bill, S. No. 223, authorizing married women under 21 years of age to join the husband in conveying real estate, was taken up and passed the House of Representatives - yeas 59, nays 20.

div.head: STATE LIBRARIAN.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BOYD, the Librarian bill, S. No. 281, was taken up.
The pending committee amendments were agreed to, and the bill passed the House - yeas 58, nays 26 - with an amendment of title, "increasing the power of the State Librarian."

Mr. BUSKIRK, from the special Omnibus Committee, returned, without recommendation, the remainder of the bills from the Senate to them referred last Monday.Mr. BROWN moved an order for a night session at 7 o'clock P. M., which was agreed to.

div.head: ADOPTED CHILDREN.
div.p: On motion by Mr. PATTERSON, the bill, S. No. 233, to enable any child adopted under the laws of any State of the United States to take and hold real estate in this State, was taken up and passed the final reading - yeas 82, nays 0.

div.head: PROTECTION OF LABOR.
div.p: On motion by Mr. HIGGINS, the bill [S. No. 117] to amend section 38 of the act to provide for the incorporation of Railroad Companies [Stockholders shall be individually liable for debts incurred on account of labor,] was taken up, and passed the final reading in the House - yeas 81, nays 0.

div.head: INDIANAPOLIS INSURANCE COMPANY.
div.p: Also the bill, S. No. 199, to amend the charter of the Indianapolis Insurance Company, (authorizing an increase of the capital stock to half a million of dollars, and they may add Life Insurance to their business) was taken up.
Messrs. NEWCOMB, BUSKIRK and COFFROTH explained and supported the provisions of the bill.
The bill passed the House - yeas 80, nays 1.

div.head: SWINGING BRIDGES.
div.p: On motion by Mr. SHOAFF of Allen (under a dispensation,) his bill H. R. No. 320, to regulate swinging bridges across rivers, canals and feeder dams, and prescribing penalty for injuring the same, was taken up, and the constitutional restriction being suspended, yeas 68, nays 5, it was read the second time by title; considered as engrossed, ordered to the third reading, read the third time and passed the House yeas 71, nays 5.

div.head: MANUFACTURING COMPANIES.
div.p: Mr. RIFORD moved for a dispensation to take up the bill S. No. 249, authorizing companies to construct and keep up canals for hydraulic power.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill was taken up.
Mr. COWGILL resisted the bill, as an infringement on the right of the writ of ad quad damnum - for assessment of damages.

Mr. SHUEY explained that the bill originated in his county, in the desire of the right of way for a canal to carry the Elkhart river over a fall of twenty feet for manufacturing purposes. The privileges and powers proposed to be conferred were only such as were given to every railroad company in the State.
Mr. BUSKIRK showed that the bill was right.
The bill passed the House - yeas 72, nays 0.
The House concurred in the Senate amendment to the House bill, No. 207 - adding an emergency clause.

Mr. COFFROTH moved for a dispensation to take up up the Whitley County Court legalizing bill, S. No. 303, and the same was read the third time and passed the House of Representatives - yeas 80, nays 0.

div.head: EVANSVILLE INSURANCE COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. COOKE, (under a dispensation,) moved to take up the bill [S. No. 313] to amend the charters of the Evansville Insurance Company, etc., [with increase of capital to one million dollars.]
The motion was agreed to, and the bill passed the final reading in the House - yeas 69, nays 10.

Mr. CALDWELL obtained a dispensation, and tbe House took up the bill, S. No. 227, for the relief of Isaac T. Armstrong - discharging him from liability on account of loss of $1,502 stolen from the county safe.
The bill was read the third time and passed the final reading - yeas 51, nays 25.

On the motion of Mr. STRINGER, (under a dispensation,) the House took up the bill, S. No. 205, to fix the times of court in Hamilton county, (the 7th Judicial circuit,) the question being on the second reading thereof.

On his further motion, the constitutional restriction was suspended - yeas 71, nays 5 - and
the bill was read the second time by title, ordered to the third reading, read the third time and passed the House of Representatives - yeas 68, nays 1.

div.head: COMMON PLEAS.
div.p: Mr. FERRIS moved a dispensation to take up the bills S. No. 66 and 215, for a new Common Pleas district. The new district was absolutely necessary to do the business.
The motion was. agreed to, and the bill S. No. 66 was taken up[to amend the Practice act so as to make it competent for a Common Pleas Judge to try criminal causes.]
Mr. BURTON said he should oppose this bill, because he understood that they had already elected the judge of the new district Judge Ferns. This would be an ex post facto law.
Mr. STEWART. Judge Ferris is not even a candidate.
Mr. BUSKIRK and Mr. BROWN stated that this legislation was unnecessary the latter making an ineffectual motion to lay it on the table.
Mr. MILLER said the bill ought to pass - because there was no law making it competent for a Common Pleas Judge to hold court in the trial of criminal causes.
The bill was passed the House - yeas 64, nays 8.
The bill S. No. 215, to organize a new Common Pleas district, was then taken up, with a minority report to lay it on the table.
Mr. CHAMBERS said the people did not desire this district. He moved that it be laid on the table.
The House divided - affirmative 52, negative 26.
So the bill was laid on the table.

div.head: NEGRO TESTIMONY.
div.p: The witness bill S. No. 219 [defining who shall be competent witnesses - removing negro disabilities in this respect,] coming up, it was read the third time.
Mr. COFFROTH gave his opinion that the bill allowing one class of persons to testify and saying nothing about others, would hardly stand the test of the courts.
Mr. NEWCOMB desired to reply -
But the yeas and nays having been ordered and the first name called, it was held that debate is not in order.
The bill was passed the House - yeas 53, nays 27.

div.head: COUNTY AUDITOR'S FEES.
div.p: On motion by Mr. ZEIGLER, (under a dispensation,) the bill S. No. 270, amending sections 8 and 10 of the act regulating the fees of officers, and repealing former acts, was taken up - [It allows the County Auditor 15 cents per hundred words for the original of the tax duplicate, and 10 cents per hundred words for the copies. There is also an amendment making the compensation of County Commissioners $4 a day instead of $5 as in the Senate bill.]
Mr. NEWCOMB, Mr. WHITE and others explained the bill - the latter heartily recommending its passage as the best thing that can now be done to do away with abuses on the part of County Auditors.
Mr. COWGILL said, it would be found that this bill, instead of remedying the evil, really gave the Auditors more than they now receive.
Mr. BURTON. Will it increase or diminish the compensation of the Auditor?
Mr. THACHER(in seat.) It will equalize compensation.
Mr. BURTON desired the compensation of Auditors to be increased.
Mr. HOGATE spoke in favor of the bill. It gave a uniform method of taxing fees.
Mr. RICE demanded the previous question.
Mr. COFFROTH indicated an amendment: Strike out fifteen cents and insert twelve and a half cents.
There was a second to the demand for the previous question, and the main question was ordered.
The first question being on the amendments reported from the Committee -
Mr. STIVERS indicated an amendment, inserting "as computed by the County Commissioners, whose duty it shall be to count the same."
The amendment of the Committee, striking out "five," and inserting "four" in lieu, was agreed to.
The bill was then read the third time.
The bill was lost - yeas 43, nays 30 - for want of a constitutional majority.

div.head: SPECIFIC BILL.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BRANHAM, the House took up the consideration of the Senate amendments to the Specific Appropriation bill.
The Senate amendments having been read -

Mr. BUSKIRK proposed further to amend, by adding a clause relieving Mr. Williams, the Treasurer of the county of Brown, by adding an appropriation of $1,279 81 to repay him for moneys of the State stolen from the county safe.
Mr. RICE demand the previous question.
Mr. NEWCOMB proposed an amendment allowing the principal clerks of the House the advance above $5 a day which the Senate propose for the principal secretary of that body.
Mr. BRANHAM said there was no provision in the bill for the pay of the clerks of this House.
Mr. RICE withdrew the demand for the previous question.
Mr. FOULKE proposed to add a claase appropriating $114 to Thos. F. Howell, for recruiting nineteen men, for which he has received no compensation.
Mr. MILLER moved to lay Mr. Buskirk's amendment on the table.
Mr. BROWN demanded the yeas and nays.
The amendment was laid on the table - yeas 52, nays 24.
On motion of Mr. LOCKHART, Mr. Foulke's amendment was laid ou the table.
Mr. BRANHAM proposed to amend further by adding an allowance of $491 72 to J. R. Campbell, for books purchased for the Northern Prison, purchased by order of the Governor, under law.
It was adopted.
He also proposed an allowance for the fireman below; which was agreed to.
Mr. BRANHAM proposed to amend further, by adding a clause to the effect, that the employees of both Houses be paid upon certificate of the Speaker of the House and President of the Senate.
It was agreed to.

The several amendments by the Senate were then concurred in, separately and severally - excepting the extra allowance of $120 to O. M. Wilson, Principal Secretary, and $20 to each of the pages of the Senate - which were not concurred in.

div.head: CITY OF MADISON.
div.p: On motion by Mr. LITSON, the bill, S. No. 187, to amend section 53 of the act to amend and reduce into one, the several acts affecting the charter of the city of Madison, was taken up. [It regulates elections in said city.]
It was read and passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 70, nays 6.

div.head: SOLDIERS' RELIEF TAX.
div.p: Mr. HENRICKS, from the Conference Committee as to the disagreeing votes between the two Houses on the House amendments to the bill, S. No. 198, reported that the Committee had agreed to strike out " seven" and insert "five" in lieu, as the per cent of the tax collected under the Soldiers' Relief law for 1865, to be put into the State Treasury to be applied to the repayment of the money ($50,000) advanced to the Sanitary Commission.
Mr. NEWCOMB said, injustice to himself, he would have the House to know that he did not concur in the report.
The report was concurred in.
On motion by Mr. OLLEMAN, the railroad bill [S. No. 206] was taken up.
Messrs. MAJOR and BRANHAM explained its provisions and necessity.
It was passed the final reading - yeas 74, nays 0.

div.head: UNAUTHORIZED PUBLIC PRINTING.
div.p: On motion by Mr. MONTGOMERY, the bill S. No. 284, providing against unauthorized public printing, was taken up, and passed the final reading - yeas 77, nays 0.
Mr. BURWELL moved for a dispensation to take up the bill, S. No. 140, to establish the eastern boundary of the county of Blackford.
Mr. SHOAFF, of Jay, had been warned to resist the passage of this bill. The House refused to suspend the rules - affirmative 36, negative not counted.
Mr. BURWELL still holding the floor, gave way for -

Mr. BURTON. He wished to make a motion, which might seem to come rather late in the session; but he did it out of respect to numerous petitioners. It would be recollected that the laboring men of the State had petitioned the Legislature on the subject of adopting the eight hour system. A petition in this matter, which he had presented, was referred to the Committee on Agriculture, and he had waited patiently to hear the report thereon from that committee, and seeing that this subject is being agitated in both branches of Congress, out of respect to the laboring portion of the people of Indiana, he would move that the petition for this object, which he had presented, be taken from the Committee on Agriculture, and referred to a special committee of one from each Congressional District.

Mr. HOGATE said the Committee on Agriculture had had this matter under discussion, and agreed upon a report; and he had prepared a report, which had, somehow, been misplaced and destroyed, but he would renew and submit that report to-morrow.
Mr. BURTON. If that is the understanding, I withdraw the motion.
Mr. BUSKIRK moved for a dispensation to take up his Agricultural College bill, H. R. No. 6, that it might be made a special order for 7 o'clock P. M.
The SPEAKER. The Chair understands that the gentleman from Blackford and Wells (Mr. Burwell) has the floor. The Chair can not entertain two motions to suspend the rules at the same time.
On motion by Mr. COLLINS, the House then took a recess till 7 o'clock P. M.

div.head: NIGHT SESSION.
div.p: Mr. BRANHAM called up the special order the consideration of the report of the Committee of Conference on the disagreeing votes between the two Houses as to the Senate's amendments to the Committee's bill H. R. 285, to provide a State debt sinking fund, etc.

Mr. COFFROTH stated that he had been misrepresented in his remarks on the sinking fund bill last evening. He had been represented, as though he had reflected on the conduct of the President of the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners. He made no allusion to that estimable and honorable gentleman. He did refer to one member of the Board, Mr. John Harrison, who had boasted that he had made $10,000 out of the trust funds, which fact could be abundantly proved.
Mr. NEWCOMB said, Mr. Harrison did not put $100,000 in a rebel bank in New York, which blew up.

Mr. COFFROTH said he was not careful to make further charges in this matter. With respect to the substitute, he understood that it levies five cents on the $100 for the liquidation of the war debt; and takes 10 cents of the 25 cents to pay the principle of the landed debt,the interest to be paid out o the general fund, and that it provides also that the 2% per cents, be paid first, if the war debt does not come in responding to advertisement. He desired merely to indicate his opposition for reasons which he had heretofore urged upon this floor.
The previous question still urging the vote - it was taken and resulted - yeas 65, nays 27 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Atkinson, Bonner, Boyd, Branham, Brown, Burnes, Caldwell, Chambers, Church, Cook, Cowgill, Cox, Crook, Davidson Dunham, Ferris, Foulke, Glazebrook, Gleason, Goodman, Gregory of Montgomery, Gregoryof Warren, Griffith, Groves, Henricks Hershey, Higgins, Hogate, Hoover, Kilgore, Lane, Lemon, Litson, Lockhart, Lopp, Major, Meredith, Miller, Montgomery, McVey, Newcomb, Olleman, Osborn, Pinney, Prather, Reese, Rhoads, Rice, Richardson, Riford, Sabin, Shuey, Sim, Stuart, Stivers, Stuckey, Trusler, Upson, Veach, Welch, Woodruff, Wright, Woods, Zeigler and Mr. Speaker - 55.

NAYS - Mesrss. Abbett, Bird, Burton, Burwell, Buskirk, Coffroth, Collins, Croan, Greggs, Hargrove, Harrison, Howard, Humphreys, Hunt, Milroy, O'Brien, Perigo, Roach, Shoaff of Allen, Shoaff of Jay, Speacer, Stringer, Sullivan of Scott, Thacher, Weikel, and White - 27.

So the substitute was adopted, and the bill passed the House with an amendment of title, viz: "An act to provide for a State Debt Sinking Fund for the payment of the principal and interest of the five and two and a half per cent, stocks of the State therein named; and
giving priority of payment to the bondholders of the two and a half per cent. stocks of the State of Indiana; prescribing the duties of the Auditor, Treasurer and Agent of State in relation thereto; providing for a Clerk of said State Debt Sinking Fund and fixing his salary; and providing a penalty for the violation of its provisions; abolishing the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, and all officers connected therewith; the office of the Agent of State in the city of New York. To invest the moneys belonging to the Sinking Fund in the stocks of the State. Transferring the business of said Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners to the Auditor and Treasursr of State; providing that the tax thereon levied shall betiken and converted as part of the tax levied under an act entitled An act to raise revenue for State purposes for the year 1865 and 1866, approved March 2,1865, and declaring an emergency for the immediate taking effect of this act."

div.head: BLACKFORD COUNTY LINES.
div.p: On Motion by Mr. BURWELL, (under a dispensation,) the bill, S. No. 140, to establish the eastern boundary oi the county of Blackford of the was taken up - amending the 8th section of the County Boundaries act.
On his further motion, the constitutional restriction was suspended - yeas 72, nays 6 and the bill was read the second time by title, ordered to the third reading, and read the third time.

Mr. SHOAFF, of Jay, resisted the passage of the bill. The arguments for this bill had failed to convince his mind that the management to change this county line was entirely fair, Then his county, (Jay) from which the bill proposed to strike off six square miles of territory, contained less than 400 square miles; and the only pretext for the friends of the bill was to show a mistake in the act affixing county lines. His people looked to him now to defeat this bill. The people of those six sections had been paying taxes in Jay county for sixteen or eighteen years.

Mr. BURWELL said, all they wanted was to fix the boundaries of Blackford county just as the law fixed it in 1839. The taxes of those six sections were paid in Blackford till 1849. when, by a mistake in legislation, those six six sections were set into the county of Jay. We ask for the correction of that mistake. Blackford county contained but four townships. Jay was twice as large.
Mr. ABBETT. The controversy being between two Democrats, and as a Democrat was never known to lie, he was hardly prepared to vote on this question.
Mr. MILROY was opposed to disturbing county lines, and he thought the House better let it drop.
The bill was rejected - yeas 34, nays 57.
Mr. RIFORD addressed the Chair.
Mr. ZEIGLER also desired a dispensation to take up a bill from the Senate.
The SPEAKER (Mr. Henricks in the chair.) The Chair has recognized the gentleman from Elkhart - (Mr. Riford.)
Mr. STRINGER rose to a point of order. The gentleman from Noble [Mr. Zeigler] was not on the list of members on the Speaker's table, having priority of right to the floor. [Laughter.]

div.head: HORSE-THIEVES.
div.p: Mr. GLEASON (under a dispensation,) called up the bill, S. No. 175, to authorize companies for the detection of horse-thieves and other felons, and for mutual protection, &c., and it was passed the first reading in the House yeas 70, nays 5.

div.head: MORGAN RAID BILL.
